title: A Suspect Pleads Guilty As Accessory in Slaying Of Two in Westchester
description: WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 30One of three men accused of shooting two women last March in rural town of Lewisboro pleaded guilty yesterday in Westchester County Court to charges of felony murder, burglary and robbery.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: Sound
description: OUR USUAL CONCERNS with audio more often focus on products than principles, and it is therefore all too easy to lose sight of the first requirement of high fidelitysomething to be faithful to. Sound, after all, is not just the end product of audio, but the raw material as well. It is, as it were, the substance of music, and even the practical side of audio is better understood with some grasp of its acoustic underpinnings.

title: Wilkens Named Sonics
description: Lenny Wilkens, who was one of the finest backcourt players in the National Basketball Association, is back coaching the Seattle SuperSonics. Wilkens, who spent 15 seasons piling up a total of 17,770 points, replaced Bob Hopkins as the Sonic coach. Hopkins was dismissed yesterday from a team that had a 517 wonlost record. Only the Nets have a worse record in the 22team league. Wilkens had been the Sonics director of player personnel.

title: A Fare Deal for the Airlines
description: The International Air Transport Association (I.A.T.A.), which sets ticket prices for international travel, may be about to crash. Its members, a mixture of governmentowned airlines like Air France and private carriers like Pan American, are badly split over fare policy. The split, reflecting differing commitments to tourism and to various marketing strategies for increasing revenues, is now focused on the traditionally profitable North Atlantic routes.

title: TV: Stars Parade; Vietnam Capsule
description: TONIGHT the television schedule leaps, not very nimbly, frcm celebrities on display to the social and psychic debris of the Vietnam War. CBS has An AllStar Tribute to Elizabeth Taylor at 9, and ABC News examines The Class That Went to War at 10.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The General Dynamic Corporation announced yesterday that contrary to some reports its first Trident submarine and all other Tridents under contract will be completed on a profitable basis.

title: ADAMSLewis Greenleaf. November 29, 1977. Devoted husband of Emeline K. and father of Lois A. Goldstone and Richard G. Adams. Also survived by eight grandchildren and five greatgrandchildren. Services private.
description: ALTENBURGHarrietta on November 29, 1977. Loving sister of Marium B. and Elizabeth J. Phillips. Reposing at Walter B. Cooke Funeral Home, 117 W 72 St. Mass of Christian Burial at St John the Martyr Church, E 72 St, Thursday 10AM. Interment St Raymond's Cemetery.

title: Bridge:
description: The greatest single contributor to bridge nomenclature was certainly Ely Culbertson, in books written in the early days of the game.

title: Home Beat
description: Great Dane

title: Red Smith
description: This makes me want to quit my job and go back in the saloon business, Sam Klein said. Sam works for Paul Screvane at the Offtrack Betting Corp., now, but when Toots Shor was alive and running the most famous saloon in the world, Sam was his maitre d'hotel. Now Sam stood on the wet sidewalk outside the IrvingTrust Company at 51 West 51st Street, site of the original Toots Shoes, the brick house that was the mother lodge where everybody who was anybdoy in sprats gatherde to drink with sports fans like Harry Truman and Bob Hannegan, who was Postmaster General, and Earl Warren, who was Chief Justice of the United States Supreme Court. A blue and white bus at the curb bore the painted legend: New York Bus Service Honors Toots Shor. Eight kids in uniforms of the Bluejackets Guard, a Brooklyn youth group, made up a drum-and-glockenspiel corps (six drums, two glockenspiels.) They played Anchors Aweigh, Swanee River and Let's Fall in Love", with thunderous enthusiasm. On the sidewalk, flags of the United States and New York City were flanked by a color guard of uniformed moppets.

title: Market Place
description: There is growing cynicism in legal and Wall Street circles over the process by which major companies find themselves on the auction block despite their intense desire for independence and their best efforts to to remain so.

title: Koch for Proposal That Teachers Live In New York City
description: A proposal to require future New York City schoolteachers to live within city limits was welcomed yesterday by Mayorelect Edward I. Koch and labeled stupid by Albert Spanker, the head of the teacher's union.

title: Dow to Della Femina: $7 Million in Billings
description: Della Femina, Travisano & Partners was assigned approximately $7 million in new billings yesterday by the Dow Chemical Corporation a client.

title: Bill Proposes Rise in Port Authority's Fees to 2 States
description: HACKENSACK, Nov. 30The tax-exempt Port Authority of New York and New Jersey pays about $120 million less than the annual potential tax worth of its $1.7 billion in property in the two states, it was disclosed today at a New Jersey Senate committee hearing at the Bergen County Administration Building.

title: Meadowlands
Collective Bargaining Institute Gives an Award to A. H. Raskin
description: A. H. H Raskin, who is retiring from The New York Times after 43 years as a labor reporter and columnist and a member of the paper's editorial board, has been awarded a medal for distinguished service to collective bargaining by the Institute of Collective Bargaining and Group Relations.

title: PORT AUTHORITY FEES TO 2 STATES DEBATED
description: HACKENSACK, NJ., Nov. 30The tax exempt Port Authority of New York and New Jersey pays about $120 million less than the annual potential tax worth of its $1.7 billion in property in the two states, it was disclosed today at a New Jersey senate committee hearing at the Bergen County Administration Building.

title: Blumenthal Links New York City Aid To Balanced Budget
description: Secretary of the Treasury W. Michael Blumenthal warned New York City last night that it could expect no further Federal loans unless it was prepared to bring its budget into balance and, within three years, stop including operating expenses in its capital budget.

title: Donald J. Thorman, 52
description: Donald J. Thorman; publisher of The National Catholic Reporter, a weekly newspaper published in Kansas City, Mo., And a principal spur to reform of the Roman Catholic Church in this country after the Ecumenical Council Vatican died of hepatitis yesterday at St. Luke's Hospital in Kansas City. He was 52 years old.

title: Topics
description: When Louise Day Hicks sought reelection to Boston's City Council she ran on the slogan, You know where I stand"a not very subtle code for her opposition to school integration. She lost. Bostonians, in addition to telling Mrs. Hicks where she could not sit, also delivered another message: One of the new members of the city's School Committee, which Mrs. Hicks once dominated, is John D. O'Bryant, the first black on that body in 75 years and the second to be elected to any Boston public office in this century.

title: Gamble-Skogmo Offers to Purchase $19 Million of Leath's Shares
description: Leath & Co., a home furnishings chain, announced it has received a merger proposal from GambleSkogmo Inc., to buy each of Leath's 1.1 million outstanding common shares at $19 each.

title: N.L.R.B. Plans to Seek Injunction Against J. P.  Stevens in Union Fight
description: ATLANTA, Nov. 30The National Labor Relations Board disclosed in Washington today that it had authorized its legal staff to seek a nationwide injunction against J. P. Stevens & Company to stop unlawful conduct in its fight to keep unions out of its plants.

title: Nat'l Basketball Ass'n
For Chile's Women, Crafts vs. Adversity
description: SANTIAGO, CHILE

title: State Department Comment
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30A spokesman for the State Department said today that negotiations on the return of Mr. Park were progressing." but the spokesman declined to predict when those discus= sions would be completed.

title: In Praise of the New York Woman
description: SITTING by the window in a coffee shop on 62d and Lexington I admire the women. Now that I live in Connecticut, I come to New York as one goes to an art gallery, to look at the women.

title: EXTRA FUNDS APPROVED FOR AMTRAK BY HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (UPI)The House voted today, 256 to 141, to give Amtrak $18 million extra, apparently halting discontinuance of ChicagoFlorida passenger train service and freezing all other routes at least through March 1.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Fortune Society, founded in 1967, was referred to in The Times of Nov. 14 as the grandfather of organizations engaged in rehabilitative work Involving offenders, former offenders and their families. The Correctional Association of New York, engaged in similar work, was founded in 1844,

title: Sunday Racing Set at Big A, Belmont in 78
description: New York horseplayers will get chance to spend a lot of Sundays at the racetrack next year as a result of a radically new format approved yesterday by the State Racing and Wagering Board.

title: Two Travel Agents Are Convicted of Grand Larceny
description: Two travel agents were convicted yesterday on 16 counts of grand larceny for selling roundtrip charterplane tickets for trips to Israel in 1972, but failing to provide the planes.

title: Long Hours And No Glory
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Nov. 30On lonely Tuesday nights, John Idzik rolls out a cot in the assistant coach's cubicle and falls asleep dreaming of the Perfect play that will lift the Jets to victory.

title: 7 Charged in Kenya News Strike
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Nov. 30 (UPI)The head of the Kenya Union of Journalists and six other union leaders, arrested in connection with a strike against The Nation, Kenya's largest newspaper, appeared in court today on charges of inciting an illegal strike.

title: Washington &
description: WASHINGTONAlmost a year into the Carter Administration, President Carter has appointed 500 men and women to Federal jobs outside his immediate White House staff. The President has named approximately 30 Federal judges, 50 United States attorneys and 60 ambassadors.

title: The Program
description: ALVIN AILEY AMERICAN DANCE THEATER, at City Center.

title: Transcript of the President's News Conference on Foreign and Domestic Matters
description: I have two brief statements to make. One concerns Senator John McClellan from Arkansas, whose funeral is being held today. He served in the Congress for 39 years and exemplified a deep commitment to his own major committee assignments. He has recently been the chairman of the Appropriations Committer. He was always a strong fighter for an adequate national defense and he was a man of supreme integrity.

title: U.S. Charges I.R.S. Auditor Signed Tax Excuse for Gulf Oil Slush Fund
description: PITTSBURGH, Nov. 30 (AP)An Internal Revenue Service review excusing the Gulf Oil Corporation from tax liability on its $10.3 million political slush fund actually was written by a Gulf attorney and signed by an I.R.S. auditor, according to a Federal prosecutor.

title: Open Interest
description: Wednesday, Nov. 30, 1977

title: U.S. Labor Deputy Charged in Fraud
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (UPI)The Securities and Exchange Commission today charged that a top Labor Department official operated a fraudulent financial scheme in cooperation with Cortes Randell, former head of the National Student Marketing Corporation, who was a Federal prisoner working from jail during the period involved.

title: F.C.C. Bids Comsat Add to Escrow Fund
description: The Federal Communications Commission yesterday ordered the CommuIiications Satellite Corporation to make additional payments to the escrow fund maintained pursuant to an F.C.C. accounting order pending the outcome of a judicial review of Comsat's rates.

title: Lobbyist Ends Battle for Minds
description: DETROIT, Nov. 30One of the nation's most influential business lobbyists retired today after more than 20 years as a skilifull, backstairs operator in an increasinelv hostile Washington environment.

title: Television
Obstinate And Ubiquitous
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30Any editor or reporter who thinks the press is a beloved institution should have been in the Supreme Court chamber the other day. A press claim being argued under the First Amendment drew from the bench extraordinarily open expressions of scorn and hostility.

title: Associated Press
description: JOHANNESBURG, Thursday, Dec. 1South Africa's governing National Party rode a mood of defiance among the country's white minority to an overwhelming victory in yesterday's general election, gaining a computerprojected 70 percent of the popular vote among the approximately 1.2 million voters.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Nov. 30 (AP)Mike White, the University of California football coach whose 1977 team finished 74, was discharged today by Athletic Director Dave Maggard, who said he felt the action was best for the future of Cal football.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: U. S., Seoul Resume Talks on Questioning Of Indicted Korean
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 30South Korea and the United States have resumed their protracted negotiations over the questioning of. Tongsun Park, and there are indications of progress.

title: Two Lawsuits Centering Around the Tangled Affairs of Fugitive Vesco
description: In a spreading legal tangle involving the affairs of Robert L. Vesco, the American financier now living in Costa Rica, the company he once headed has sued its former law firm while the law firm is attempting to save its reputation by seeking to expunge from the record a highly critical document prepared by a courtappointed investigator.

title: OCTOBER INDICATORS OF ECONOMIC TRENDS IN 4T11 STRAIGHT RISE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP)The Government index designed to predict future economic trends rose in October for the fourth straight month, indicating a gradually improving economy, the Commerce Department said today.

title: The New York Times/Jack Mannino FROM THE OTHER GEORGIA: Members of the Soviet Georgian Dancers rehearsing yesterday morning. The troupe80 dancers, singers and musicianswill perform at Carnegie Hall through Sunday.
Mrs. Mondale to Go to Finland
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP)  Vice President Mondale's wife, Joan, will represent President Carter at celebrations marking Finland's 60th anniversary of independence, the White House Press,Secretary, Jody Powell, announced today. The celebration will be held in Helsinki on Dec. 5 and 6,

title: Syrie Maughani Style: The 20's Come Ghosting Back
description: YOU CAN almost hear the ice cubes tinkling in the martini shakers, the backgammon chips clacking and Noel Coward making witty remarks as you pass Stuart Greet's new shop at 783 Madison Avenue near 68th Street.

title: Dayan Would Sign an Egypt Pact
description: BONN, Nov. 30  Foreign Minister Moshe Dayan, ending a fourday visit to West Germany, declared today that Israel would sign a separate peace treaty with Egypt any time, any time, and would do so either in advance of a reconvened Geneva conference or outside such framework.

title: 5 Moslem Extremists Condemned For Murdering Egyptian Scholar
description: CAIRO, Nov. 30An Egyptian military tribunal sentenced five members of an extremist Moslem society to death today after they were found guilty of having murdered a kidnapped former Cabinet minister in July and plotted subversion against the Government.

title: Daniel Warren Schwartz
description: Psychiatrist Whose Testimony Led to Acquittal

title: Soviet, Backing Geneva, Fears an EgyptIsrael Deal
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 30The Soviet Union said today that it still supported a Middle East peace conference in Geneva and had turned down Egypt's invitation to a preparatory meeting in Cairo because it was a cover for a separate deal between Egypt and Israel.

title: Aqueduct Racing
description: ENTRIES

title: Manhattan Theater Club To Offer 3 Beckett Plays
description: Three oneact plays by Samuel Beckett, two of which will be having their New York premieres, will play from Dec. 14 through Jan. 15 at the Manhattan Theatre Club, 321 East 73d Street, under the collective title Play and Other Plays. The evening is under the direction of Alan Schneider and will have Suzanne Costallos, Donald Davis and Sloane Shelton as its actors,

title: 3 Arrested in Raid on Alleged Male Prostitution Ring
description: A major call boy operation in New York City has been smashed and the files containing the names of hundreds of male prostitutes and prospective customers have been seized, vice squad detectives said yesterday.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: VENICE OBSERVED New Yorkers can see encouraging evidence that the Adriatic art center, menaced by floods and other natural disasters, is holding its own, treasurewise, in a new display from tomorrow through Dec. 18 at the Banco di Napoli, 277 Park Avenue (near 47th Street). This is a panoramic show, with photographs, illustrating the restoration progress of recent years by various international committees and the Italians themselves.

title: CARTER URGES ARABS TO FOLLOW EGYPTIANS AND TALK TO ISRAELIS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30  President Carter said today that the development of direct EgyptianIsraeli contacts was a historic breakthrough toward a Middle East peace, and he urged Arab countries to follow Egypt's lead and hold facetoface talks with Israel.

title: Hearing Set For Ringer Case Pair
description: Attorneys for Dr. Mark J. Gerard and Jack B. Morgan, the veterinarian and the trainer accused of complicity in the Lebon  Cinzano horse  switching case, agreed yesterday to an immediate hearing in State Supreme Court on the merits of the evidence against the two men.

title: Koch's Choice for Head of Police Is Said to Be Prosecutor Keenan
description: John F. Keenan, the special t..tate prosecutor for corruption in the criminal-justice system, will he offered the job of New York City Police Commissioner, according to sources close to Mayorelect Edward I. Koch.

title: Giants
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 30The National Football League weekly statistics sheet, taped to the blackboard in the Giants locker room today, had an arrow that seemed to be pointing in Jimmy Robinson's direction.

title: DIPLOMATIC PASSPORT IS RETAINED BY LANCE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30The White House persuaded the State Department to allow Bert Lance to keep his diplomatic passport, an international status symbol, despite his resignation from Government service and continuing Federal investigations into his business background.

title: TALKS ON FUND TO AID DEVELOPING NATIONS AGAIN FAIL IN GENEVA
description: GENEVA, Nov. 30Key negotiations between the third world and industrialized nations on the restructuring of their economic relations collapsed again here today.

title: World News Briefs
description: UPPSALA, Sweden, Nov. 30 (AP)The Soviet Union carried out one of its biggest underground nuclear tests of the decade `:..day at its regular proving ground in the Semipalatinsk area of eastern Kazakhstan, the head of the Seismological Institute here reported.

title: In Art, It's Sold in Hong Kong
description: HONG KONG, Nov. 30Hong Kong's emergence as one of the world's premier markets for Chinese art was confirmed today with a $2.23 million aucti of Chinese porcelain here by Sotheby Parke Bernet.

title: Gifts to Village Nursing Home Bring. Reprieve
description: We Made It! read the sign in the lobby of the Village Nursing Home, at Hudson and West 12th Streets. The Nov. 30 deadline for raising $100,000 to avoid closing the _home had been met, with the total suddenly, pushed to $101,632 by yesterday's morning mail.

title: House Panel Leader Says Seoul Tried to Prevent a Witness From Testifying on Korean Lobbying Efforts
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30Representative Donald M. Fraser, chairman of a subcommittee investigating alleged South Korean attempts to influence American policy, asserted today that the Seoul Government had illegally tried to prevent a witness from testifying before the subcommittee.

title: Cousins Expects Loss
description: Cousins Mortgage and Equity Investments said it expects to report an operating loss of $4.19 million for the year ending Aug. 31 compared with $20.42 million a year before. The company said that after an extraordinary credit of $2.82 million the final net logs will be $1.36 million. In 1976, after an extraordinary credit of $7.29 million, the final net loss was $13.13 million.

title: Concerns Need OffJersey Drilling Permits
description: Spokesmen for six of the 10 major oil companies that plan to drill exploratory wells off the New Jersey coast said yesterday that they still needed drilling permits from the Department of the Interior's Geologic Survey as well as approval from the Army Corps of Engineers to place the drill rigs in navigable waters.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: PATRICIA KIRK, OPERATOR OF A CASTING SERVICE
description: Patricia Kelly Kirk, who operated a casting service for television commercials, died yesterday at St. Clare's Hospital after a brief illness. She was 54 years old and lived at 5400 Fieldston Avenue in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

title: WALDHEIM PROPOSAL REJECTED BY ISRAEL
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 30Israel rejected today a proposal by Secretary General Kurt Waldheim that preparatory talks for Geneva be held on the neutral ground of the United Nations.

title: Koch Will Expand Washington Office And Pick New Chief
description: WASHINGTON, Nov, 30Representative Edward I. Koch, Mayorelect of New York, said here today that he would "beef up the city's office in Washington iwpd name as director someone who has a reputation that Congress and the executive branch will respond to, someone who Will not be a bureaucrat.

description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: KELLEY AGREES TO REMAIN IN F.B.I. POST TILL FEB. 15
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (UPI)At the request of Attorney General Griffin B. Bell, the Federal Bureau of Investigation director, Clarence M. Kelley agreed today to stay on the job until Feb. 15, when a new director is expected to take over.

title: Koch Said to Select Prosecutor Keenap For Head of Police
description: John F. Keenan, the special state prosecutor for corruption in the criminal justice system will be offered the job of, New York City Police Commissioner, according to sources close to Mayorelect Edward I. Koch.

title: Film: 'Goodbye Girl' Full of Wisecracks
description: IF ONE COULD ENTER the mind of Neil Simon, I have the feeling it would be like attending a convention of standup comedianseveryone busy topping everyone else, not really listening to anything that's being said except to identify the key word that will be the springboard into the next snappy retort, then the next and the next. Exhuasting without being much fun.Which is more or less the way I feel about Mr. Simon's newest work, the original screenplay for "The Goodbye Girl," a movie that has the form of a romantic comedy but which is so relentlessly wisecracked that it finally has the very curious effect of seeming to be rude to its own characters.The people in "The Goodbye Girl" are very nice indeed, at least when we first meet them. They are a desperately cheerful young woman named Paula (Marsha Mason), a former Broadway hoofer who has a precocious 10-year-old daughter named Lucy (Quinn Cummings) and terrible luck with men, and Elliot Garfield (Richard Dreyfuss), a maniacally egocentric young Chicago actor who's come to New York to star in an Off Off Broadway production of "Richard III."Paula and Elliot loathe each other at first sight, for good reason. Paula's former lover has just sneaked off to Italy after having sublet to Elliot the apartment in which Paula and Lucy are living. Paula and Lucy refuse to give up the premises and Elliot refuses to acknowledge the right of their occupancy. After thus meeting cute, they compromise, deciding to share the flat while keeping their respective distances."The Goodbye Girl," which opened yesterday at Loews Tower East Theater, may be the perfect American comedy for an age in which opportunism is not only an acceptable way of getting ahead in the world, but also a fashionable style of conversation, patterned largely, I suspect, on the manners of television talk-show guests who trample one another for the camera's attention. It's as if Zsa Zsa Gabor had become our Euphues.The courtship of Paula and Elliot is conducted mostly in terms of outrage, insult and misunderstanding. They don't talk to each otherthey compete for the last word. A lot of this, especially early in the film, is quite funny, but eventually it overtakes the characters and the situations so that, to keep the comedy moving, Mr. Simon himself appears to take over, making the characters say and do uncharacteristic things to get the laugh.Thus Paula, who has done her share of sleeping around must behave as if she were both jealous and morally outraged when Elliot brings home an actress-friend to rehearse one evening. We also are asked to believe that Elliot, who is essentially sane though ambitious, would go along with a ridiculously silly production of "Richard III" in which the title character is conceived as a Billy DeWolfe drag-queen.The thing that always confuses my reactions to Mr. Simon's more outrageous inventionssuch as the nutty "Richard III" production hereis that many of them are funny by themselves, but they don't fit easily together. Mr. Simon doesn't hesitate to sentimentalize little Lucy, played with eerie self-assurance by Miss Cummings, while stuffing her mouth with lines that would do justice to Groucho Marx.In certain situations, Mr. Simon's insults and wisecracks work naturally, as in "The Sunshine Boys," about the two old vaudevillians who hate each other while being mutually dependent. It was also very comic in "The Odd Couple," whose two heroes were really early sketches for the Sunshine Boys. His gift for parody was marvelously apparent in "Murder by Death." However, something essential seems to be missing when he attempts to write with feeling about men and women. As he views the war between the sexes, it's a contest of unisex gag writers.Herbert Ross, this year's "hot" director (what with "The Turning Point" already out and Mr. Simon's new play, "Chapter Two," about to open), who is a man of wit and humane concerns, appears to have put his talent so totally in the service of the Simon script that I have no idea what his contributions to the movie may be. Miss Mason and Mr. Dreyfuss are enthusiastic farceurs who manage to keep their wits about them even when they are doing absurd things. Miss Mason's Paula is especially funny in her early scenes with her daughter when she creates a genuinely comic portrait of a woman who has prepared herself for every possible treachery except the one that turns up."The Goodbye Girl," which has been rated PG Parental Guidance Suggested"), contains some mildly vulgar language but is otherwise no more or less offensive than a singing commercial that is insidious because it is more clever than most.

title: Terence Rattigan, 66, Dead; 5Prolific English Playwright
description: Sir Terence Rattigan, the playwright, died yesterday of bone marrow cancer in. Hamilton, Bermuda, where he had been confined to his home for the last itwo years. His age was 66.

title: LEWIS GREENLEAF ADAMS, HEADED ARCHITECTS GROUP
description: Lewis Greenleaf Adams, president of the Architectural League of New York in 1954 and 1955, died Tuesday in New York Hospital after a brief illness. He was 80 years old and lived at 544 East 86th Street here.

INDICTMENT DROPPED IN EXTORTION CASE
description: A New York State Supreme Court justice in Manhattan yesterday dismissed an indictment charging that a lawyer extorted money from a client he had been assigned to represent under a plan for indigent defendants whose legal costs are paid by public funds.

title: Nagle FirstRound Leader
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Nov. 30. (AP)Kel Nagle of Australia, the defending champion, fired a six-under-par 66 today to take the firstround lead: in the Otago Charity Golf Classic. Second was New Zealand's Bob Charles, who carded a 67 on the St. Clair golf course.

title: Dance: Ailey Presents Night Creature
description: Ailey and Ellington could start any party off at a high level and with Night Creature they opened the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater season last night in a shower of good feelings. The City Center 551.11 Street Theater had a festive .atmosphere that permeated the whole program. There were lots of things to celebrate and the company showed its best performing manners.

title: Dance: Georgians Create Aficionados
description: They do much more than eat yogurt in Soviet Georgia. Judging from last night's opening at Carnegie Hall by the Soviet Georgian Dancers and Tbilisi Polyphonic Choir, the national pasttimes take in spinning on knees, dancing on toes and singing in many parts with the lucidity of so many stereo sets going at once.

title: Notes on People
description: Lows O. COXE, Pierce Professor of English at Bowdoin College in Maine, has been named the 36th Fellow of the Academy of American Poets. The fellowship, carrying a $10,000 stipend, is presented annually for distinguished poetic achievement. Past reclotents have included Robert Frost, Ezra Pound ana w imam Carlos Williams. Processor Coxe was cited for a long, powerful, quiet accomplishment, largely unrecognized, in lyric poetry. It was the poet's second major honor this year. In Octoberhe was awarded a creative writing fellowship by the National Endowment for the Arts.

title: Calendar of Events For the Home
description: Christmas at the Ballantine House,

title: Dollar and Stocks Climb in Tokyo As Japanese Seek a Plan on Trade
description: TOKYO, Nov. 30A new Cabinet task sorce, working to meet a sevenday deadline, began to draw up an extensive plan today to reduce Japan's huge trade surplus as the dollar continued to climb against the yen and the stock market here rose again in heavy trading.

title: Hers
description: ANEW feminist heroine has arisen in the person of Francine Hughes, a 30-year-old woman who put an end to her husband's brutal beatings by pouring gasoline around his bed and setting him aflame while he slept. A jury of 10 women and two men in Lansing, Mich., recently found Mrs. Hughes not guilty of murder by reason of temporary insanity.

title: Q&A
description: Q. I am about to close up my house  in the Poconos and am receiving conflicting advice about draining the water lines to prevent damage from freezing. Is it a myth encouraged by local plumbers that it is necessary to have steam blown through the pipes to remove all wateror can one simply drain the water from the lines by opening a drain at the lowest level? G.Y.P., Manhattan

title: Nader Calls On ExColleague to Resign Safety Post
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30Ralph Nader today called on Joan Claybrook, his former colleague in the consumer movement, to resign as head of the Federal auto safety program and to acknowledge that she had been, as he asserted, ineffective in that post.

title: The U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Music: Austerity and Whimsy Mark New Works
TREASURY NOTES SOLD AT A 7.31% AVERAGE
description: The Treasury sold $2.75 billion of notes at competitive bidding yesterday at an average rate of 7.31 percent, or slightly higher than bond dealers expected earlier in the week. At the same time, it sold an additional $685 million of the notes to foreign purchasers, continuing the recent heavy volume of such sales.

title: Engine Failures Halt 2 Concordes, One Here
description: Two supersonic Concorde jetliners had engine trouble yesterday, forcing cne to make an emergency landing in Shannon, Ireland, and the other to abort a takeoff at New York's Kennedy Airport.

title: `Born Again
description: DARIEN, Conn.Bob Ash, a burly, mustachioed 50yearold salesman, stood recently with the congregation of St. Paul's Episcopal church here, his palms upraised and extended, quietly joining in singing alleluia, alleluia.

title: 2 Die in Crash of Air Force Plane
description: NELLIS.AIR FORCE BASE, Nev., Nov. 39 (UP1)The pilot and navigator of an F111 fighterbomber were killed today when the aircraft crashed during a training exercise 107 miles northwest of here: The victims were identified as Capt. Arthur L. Stowe, 29, of Baton Rouge, La,; the pilot; and Maj. Loreley 0. Wagner, 41, of Akron, Ohio,. navigator. The cause of the crash was not immediately determined.

title: Music: Guarneri 4 Remember Elgar
description: AN UTTERLY absorbing program was played by the Guarneri String Quartet and assisting artists last night in Tully Hall. It was absorbing because all of the music was of top quality, and yet the three scores that were played are rather neelected. In the case of Edward Elgar's Piano Quintet in A minor, a real novelty was presented. The Elgar has been recorded, and presumably it has had a few performances hereabouts, but it was the first time that this listener had ever run across it in the concert hall.

title: OFFICER IN SAM
description: Unhappy over being assigned to a uniformed post in the Bronx a few months before he was scheduled to go on terminal leave, Deputy Chief Timothy J. Down, I the veteran detective who headed the I search for the Son of Sam killer, has filed for immediate retirement from the New York City Police Department.

title: Rhodesian Talks. Open Tomorrow
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Thursday, Dec. 1 (Reuters)Prime Minister Ian D. Smith was quoted today as having said that he will start talks tomorrow with black leaders living in Rhodesia to seek an internal settlement based on majority rule with safeeuards for the white minority.

title: Rock: Punk Influences Jethro Tull
description: IN ROCK, as in most popular arts, the ideas and energy of a new generation of artists often make their most telling impact indirectlyltather than change things through their own work, the new artists affect more established artists, who stabilize some random aspects of the newness and popularize it with the masses.

title: Red Ball, Ryan in Dear
description: The Telecom Corporation said its trucking unit, Red Ball Motor Freight Inc., received approval from the Interstate Commerce Commission to buy all the interstate operating authority of Ryan Freight Lines Inc. Red Ball has been operating those interstate rights under Itemporary authority granted by the I.C.C. in October 1976. The purchase price was not disclosed.

description: Putting the Mower in Mothballs

title: New York's PropertyTax Patchwork
description: A major piece of unfinished and unpleasant business awaits New York City's new mayor: comprehensive reform of the real property tax rolls. Everyone knows that there are significant differences in the values set by the city's assessors for different properties over the years. A similar situation exists generally throughout the state and nation. People have learned to live with these inequities, and city officials did not volunteer to undertake a reform that would require years and cost millions. But in recent decisions, the New York State courts have ruled that every city, village and town must provide the equali. ty promised to all taxpayers in the State Constitution. The State Legislature has tried to smooth the way to systematic revaluation. And now New York City must move on this matter whether it wants to or not. The objective must be to construct a sound tax base, not to increase taxes.

description: Although Westminster College in New Wilmington, Pa., is rarely mentioned when people  speak of the powers in intercollegiate football, the little school (1,550 students) northwest of Pittsburgh has the longest winning

title: House Retreats on Ending Ceiling For Earnings of Retired Persons
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30The House declined today to insist on eliminating the ceiling on outside earnings for Social Security recipients, making it almost certain that the current $3,000 limit will be raised substantially but not abolished.

title: People and Business
description: Robert Carswell, Deputy Secretary of the Treasury, told the Securities Industry Association yesterday that the Treasury Department is prepared to seriously consider proposing special tax treatment for stock offerings of nqw companies. He spoke at a meeting of the association in Boca Raton, Fla.

description: SAN DIEGO, Nov. 30 (UPI)Twentytwo lending institutions that sued the auditing firm of Touche Ross & Company were awarded $30 million in damages by a Superior Court jury yesterday.

description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30A diverse coalition of environmentalists, politicians, union leaders, scientists, consumerists and minority representatives announced plans today for a nationwide Sun Day next year to lead the United States into the solar era.

title: Books of The Times
description: FORTY YEARS AGO, Morrow Mayo wrote: Los Angeles, should be understood, is not mere city. On the contrary, is, and has been since 1888, a commodity; something to be advertised and sold to the people of the United States like automobiles, cigarettes and mouth washes.

title: Gold Futures Prices Close Lower in Comex and the Chicago Exchange
description: Gold futures closed lower again yesterday in active trading on both the New York Commodity Exchange and the International Monetary Market of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.

title: ABC Gives `Bums
description: ABCTV yesterday canceled The San Pedro Beach Bums, and reduced The Redd Foxx Show from a weekly series to a number of specials. Along with the midseason changes that are expected to be announced by ABC today, the network will add to its schedule How the West Was Won with James Arness and Fantasy Island with Ricardo Montalban.

title: N.L.R.B. Plans to Seek Injunction Against J. P. Stevens in Union Fight
description: ATLANTA, Nov. 30The National Labor Relations Board disclosed in Washington today that it had authorized its legal staff to seek a nationwide injunction against J. P. Stevens & Company to stop unlawful conduct in its fight to keep unions out of its plants.

title: The New York TImesnank Manning ST. PETER'S CHURCH was opened to view yesterday, and the modem, stylistic design was evident in the main altar. The new home for the Lutheran church in the Citicorp Center, at Lexington and 54th Street, cludes a chapel designed by Louise Nevelson, the sculptor.
Times Declares Dividends
description: Directors of The New York Times Company declared yesterday a regular quarterly dividend of 17 cents a share on the 11,416,949 outstanding shares of class A and class B common stock. The dividend will be paid to some 7,700 shareholders of record on Dec. 26 to holders of record Dec. 8. A regular quarterly dividend of $1.375 a share on the 5 percent cumulative prior preference stock was also declared, payable Jan. 3 to shareowners of record Dec. 8.

title: London Gold Price Is Sent Up or Down By Complex Forces
description: LONDON, Nov. 30The twicedaily gold fixings here are taking far longer than the usual five or 10 minutes. And no wonder.

title: `Born Again
description: DARIEN, Conn.Bob Ash, a burly, mustachioed 50year-old salesman, stood recently with the congregation of St. Paul's Episcopal church here, his palms upraised and extended, quietly joining in singing. alleluia. alleluia.

title: Dow Up by 2.43 for 829.70 Close; Glamour Issues Lead the Advance
description: Stock prices gradually edged into higher ground yesterday under the influence of several favorable factors, with glamour issues leading the way.

title: Unemployment of Newark's Blacks Was Double That of Whites in 1976
description: NEWARK, Nov. 30The unemployment rate among blacks in the greater Newark area in 1976 was twice that of whites, and more than three-and-one-half times as many adult black men than adult white men were out of work, the United States Department of Labor reported today.

title: U.S. Announces Recall of Yeast
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP)The 7exl and Drug Administration announced today the recall of some Health Rite Brewer's Yeast said to be contaminated with salmonella. The agency said the contaminated yeast, made by Devlin Pharmaceuticals of El Segundo, Calif., was not likely to cause serious illness.

title: Quake Rattles California Coast; PASO ROBLES, Calif., Nov. 30 (AP)An earthquake rattled a 50mile stretch of the California coast but apparently caused no injuries or damage, the authorities said. The United States Geological Survey in Menlo Park said yesterday that the earthquake had a preliminary reading of 4.0 on the Richter scale. While the epicenter had not been determined, a spokesman said that it lay along the San Andreas Fault. Reports of the 8:40 A.M. tremor were received from southern Monterey County as far south as Atascadero.
Big Board Releases Its Reports Of Changes in Stock by Insiders
description: The New York Stock Exchange issued yesterday its latest reports of changes in stock of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchange.

title: Home Improvement
description: DESIGNED particularly for easy do-it-yourself installation, the new Omni Water Filter is sold as a complete kit. It includes all the fittings needed to enable any home handyman or handywoman to install the unit without buying extra valves, adapters or other parts. The head or top of the unit has its own shutoff valve to permit turning the water off when cartridges are being changed. In addition, a builtin bypass is also part of the unit. Switching to bypass enables the owner to switch to unfiltered water when large amounts of water are needed that don't require filtering. The bypass is also handy when changing cartridges, or when the old one is clogged and a new cartridge is not readily available. In both cases, switching to bypass will permit an uninterrupted flow of water, though it will not be filtered for that time.

title: Hyland Says He Will Quit Jan. 17; `Family Obligations
description: TRENTON, Nov. 30Attorney General William F. Hyland, citing family obligations and a need to devote myself to whatever new venture should materialize, announced today that he would leive his $43,000-a-year post on Jan. 17 when his term expired.

title: A Policeman and a Retired Officer Accused of Importing Thai Narcotics
description: A New York City police officer and a retired officer were arrested with four other persons yesterday on charges of importing and selling narcotics from Thailand.

title: Events Today
While Burns Roams
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 304I don't believe anybody is indispensable, President Carter told his press conference. ... if I should decide to replace Dr. [Arthur] Burns as chairman of the Federal Reserve, then it would be incumbent on me to get someone who is competent and who would arouse the confidence of the American people, including the business community.

title: U.S. AIRLINES WILL BEGIN CHARTE SERVICE ??URA
description: HAVANA, Nov. 30 (Reuters)Cuban officials announced today plans for two weekly United States charter flights to Cuba, one starting next month. The flights,specifically for tourists, will provide the first passenger service to Havana for Americans in 16 years.

title: East German Leader Off to Asia
description: EAST BERLIN, Nov. 30 (Reuters)Erich Honecke?, the East German leader, left today on a tour of the Far East, including the Philippines. He will be the first East German leader to visit the Philippines, a Westernaligned country.

title: Capital's Latest Game Is Match the Dossier
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30The Federal Bureau of Investigation's files on Representative Robert F. Drinan, a Roman Catholic priest, contained summaries of several of his sermons. The dossier on Eldridge Cleaver, a former leader of the Black Panthers, recorded the name of a person who took fried chicken to a political conference. Gabriel Kaimowitz, a lawyer in Michigan, found a picture of the family St. Bernard in his state police records.

description: PARIS, Nov. 30The United States, Western Europe and Japan agreed today to work together in attempts to reform their troubled steel industries, burdened by inefficient plant and excess capacity, in order to preserve freeworld trade steel.

He already calls himself that and says friends call him One Zero for short..

title: PENTAGON REVIEWING STRATEGIC POSTURE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov, 30The Defense Department, worried about the vulnerability of American landbased missiles because of Soviet missile advances, has begun a major review of the nation's overall strategic posture.

Later, the Administration succeeded in persuading Mr. Sadat to put off the date of the gathering, high Administration officials disclosed today.

description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Nov. 30Syrian leaders view President Anwar elSadat's moves to establish normal relations with Israel not only as a serious blow to the Palestinian cause but also as an open door to Israeli economic expansion in the Middle East.

description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (Reuters)The State Department denied a report today that Turkey had threatened to expel the 7,000 American troops there if early progress was not made on a joint defense agreement.

title: No Fun Being a Cop
description: As a kid I used to put on the policeman's cap I was given as a birthday present and daydream about catching a thief. I was preserving law and order against the onslaught of criminal offenders: John Dillinger stick em up, ya under arrest. I never really outgrew these fantasies, although cops became the enemy as I was passing through a postadolescent Marxist phase in my life. But that was very temporarya little like believing I would be President of the United  States.

description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP)Prices farmers get for raw products rose 1 percent between Oct. 15 and Nov. 15, the second consecutive monthly increase, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Pop: Al Caiola Makes Club Debut
description: AS MUSICIANS who once worked steadily in recording and television studios have found their calls diminishing in recent years, more and more of them have begun playing in public, some for the first time in a deacde or more. The latest studio musician to go public is Al Caiola, the guitarist, a veteran of more than 20 years in the studios. He is making his New York nightclub debut leading a trio at Hopper's this week and next.

title: All U.S. Olympic Trials To Be Televised,by NBC
description: NBC announced yesterday it would guarantee the United States Olympic Committee $7.5 million for exclusive rights to televise all United States trials for the 1980 Winter and Summer Olympic Games.

title: Italian Reds Seek EuropeWide Alliance of Leftist Parties
description: ROMEThe Italian Communist Party, going beyond its usual Communist allies, has begun sounding out the important socialist parties of Europe on a plan for a big meeting in Italy to set up joint study groups and establish regular relations. It is a major move by the Italian Communists that could have longterm significance for European politics on many levels.

title: Investigating tne Investigators in Trenton
description: TRENTON, Nov. 30The State Commission of Investigation, created by the Logislature in 1968 to look into reports of widespread organized crime activity in New Jersey, is fighting for its existence and Governor Byrne, who is largely re- sponsible for its predicament, has not yet come to its defense.

title: Cosmos Promote Official

description: MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 30Assemblyman Irwin J. Landes admitted through spokesman today that he had never been certified as a lawyer in New York State.

title: BUILDING UNIONS PLAN ORGANIZING CAMPAIGN
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 30 A national surge in nonunion construction is pushing the building trades unions into an organizing campaign, an unusual step because they are generally known for restricting their ranks.

title: 10 Coast Women Believed Slain by Same Strangler
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 30  Twelve women and girls have been strangled in the Los Angeles area in the last six weeks, and the police said today that they believed at least 10 of them were victims of the same killer or killers.

description: Mayor Beame pressed plans for a convention center on 34th Street yesterday amid conflicting reports on whether the site is favored by the man who will have the final sayMayorelect Edward I. Koch.

title: MESSAGE ON INJURY TO BIKO IS DISCLOSED
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Nov. 30The police officer in charge of the interrogation of Stephen Biko sent a telex message to his superiors after Mr.Biko's death in forming them that an injury had been inflicted on the black leader Curing his custody, according to ev'clence presented today at the inouest into the death.

title: Anthony E. Insolia Is Appointed. The Executive Editor of Newsday
description: GARDEN CITY, L. L, Nov. 30 (AP)Anthony E. Insolia, managing editor for operations of Newsday singe 1970, has been named executive editor, effective Jan. 1, according to David Laventhol, editor of the Long Island daily.

title: CLEVELAND OFFICIALS VOW TO KEEP CITY SCHOOLS OPEN
description: CLEVELAND, Nov. 30 (AP)City officials vowed today to keep Cleveland's schools open despite a threat by many of the system's 5,500 teachers to stay out tomorrow because their paychecks are a week overdue.

description: The dollar edged up against most major currencies in Europe and in foreign-exchange trading yesterday, but fell in New York against most currencies and closed unchanged against the yen, The Associated Press reported.

description: The Brownsville Poets wrote a poem about the slaying of Randolph Evans that they were to read last night at a memorial service on the first anniversary of his funeral. The poets never got to read.

title: Dispute Erupts in Spain Over. Move to Separate Church and State
description: MADRID, Nov. 30A national debate over relations between church and state has begun, with the Spanish Roman Catholic Church openly criticizing the first draft of a new Constitution that is being written by a committee of Parliament.

title: Canadian Court Allows Deletion Of U S. TV Ads
description: OTTAWA, Nov. 30  The Supreme Court of Canada ruled today that it was legal for Canadian cabletelevision operators to delete commercials from American programs that are taken oft the air free and transmitted into Canadian homes for a monthly fee.

title: Veterans Increase Awaits Action
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP)A bill that would give 2.5 million veterans, widows and orphans a 6.5 percent increase in their Veterans Administration pensions is awaiting President Carter's signature. The last legislative step for the measure came yesterday when the House approved by voice vote a resolution making technical corrections. Mr. Carter's expected signature would make the increase effective Jan. 1. The paynients for veterans, widows and widowers vary according to other income. The bill would raise the maximum pension for a veteran from $185 to $197 a month. The minimum pension would remain at 1 $5.

title: jews in the Ukraine Charge That the AgeOld AntiSemitism Persists
description: KIEV, U.S.S.R.A monument finally stands over Babi Yar, where for 34 years the Soviet Government did little to honor the memory of the 100,000 people, most of them Jews, whom the Nazis rounded up and massacred outside this Ukrainian city in 1941.

title: WALDHEIM PROPOSAL REJECTED BY ISRAEL
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 30Israel rejected today a proposal by Secretary General Kurt Waldheim that preparatory talks for Geneva be held on the neutral ground of the United Nations.

title: THE HOMELESS: Vietnamese refugees are cast adrift in the Gulf of Siam by a Thai marine police boat. The refugees, about 50 in number, had fled from Vietnam
description: ASSOCiatee Press and landed in Khlong Yai, Thailand, seeking refuge. They were refused entry in keeping with the recent decision by Thailand to discourage boat people.

title: Backgammon:
description: Often in backgammon a relatively experienced player will look ahead several moves, foresee danger and take measures to counteract it. However, backgammon is a deceptive game, and sometimes these apparent measures prove ineffective.

title: Recital: Patricia Brooks Sings
description: PATRICIA BROOKS'S 15-year-association with the New York City Opera has made her an admired and popular interpreter ???? roles, and until relatively recently her clear, agile soprano seemed one of the more secure voices in the company. It appears now, however, that something has changed. Her recital at Alice Tully Hall on Tuesday night was one in which the best of intentions and brave showmanship could not conceal vocal limitations.

title: Fed Sold Marks To Help Dollar
description: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York, attempting to support a skidding dollar, intervened heavily in the foreign-exchange markets from August to October by selling the equivalent of $236.8 million in West German marks, Fed officials said yesterday.

title: William T. Fanning Is Dead at 42; Partner in Stock Brokerage Firm
description: William T. Fanning, a partner In the stock brokerage firm of Manley, Bennett & McDonald, died suddenly Monday of a heart attack. He was 42 years old and Jived at 155 South Maple Avenue, Ridgewood. N.J.

title: Waldheim Says Israeli Rejection Of U.N. Talks May Not Be Final
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. Nov. 30Secretary General Kurt Waldheim said today that he did not accept as final Israel's refusal to attend Middle East talks here following the Cairo conference called by President Anwar elSadat.

title: Paul Sills Improvises at Stage Cabaret
description: THE NEW YORK Shakespeare Festival's new venture into theater cabaret is winding up a kind of trial run, and the results are pleasant but tentative.

title: Philip Glass to Write Gandhi Opera for Rotterdam
description: Philip Glass, the experimental American composer, has been commissioned by the city of Rotterdam, the Netherlands, to provide an opera that will open the 198081 season of the Netherlands Opera. The work will be entitled Satyagraha, and will concern the early years of the Indian leader Mohandas K. Gandhi. The lyrics, adopted by Mr. Glass and Constance de Jong, will be drawn primarily from the BhagavadGita and will be in the Sanskrit language, with mythic incidents from the epic paralleling key moments in Gandhi's life.

title: Officer Torsney Acquitted as Jury Rules Him Insane in Killing of Boy
description: Police Officer Robert H. Torsney was found not guilty by reason of insanity yesterday in the shooting death of 15yearold Randolph Evans in Brooklyn on Thanksgiving Day last year.

title: Islanders Tied by Rockies With 54 Seconds Left, 33

title: STUDY URGES RESTRAINTS ON IRAN ARMS CONTRACTORS
description: WASHINGTON Nov. 30 (AP)A Pentagonsponsored study said today that a law enforcement void was encouraging defense contractors to make improper payments to obtain deals in the $19 billion program of American arms sales to Iran.

title: Wife of Man Accused of Stealing $3 Million From Trunk Is Indicted
description: Lorraine Hart, the wife of one of two men arrested in connection with the alleged theft of between $3 million and $4 million from a trunk abandoned at the Morgan Manhattan Storage Company was arrested yesterday on an indictment charging her with 11 counts of criminal contempt before a grand jury investigating the case.
