Rhodes of Arizona, the House Republican leader, suggested today that abortion foes in the House might be willing to end a fivemonth deadlock and accept a Senate compromise on federally financed abortions if Democratic leaders agreed to expedite consideration of a constitutional amendment that would prohibit abortions.

title: Personal Beauty
description: IT'S the season to be jolly. And to be tense and bone weary. Plowing through crowded, overheated stores looking for just the right thing for a dowager aunt, a teenage niece and perhaps the family dog is a prospect that is exhausting to even think about.

title: News Summary
description: THURSDAY, DECEMBER 1, 1977

title: Leath Gets Merger Bid From GambleSkogmo
description: Leath & Co., a home furnishings chain, announced it has received a merger proposal from GambleSkogmo Inc. to buy each of Leath's 1.1 million outstanding common shares at $19 each.

title: MOTHER CALLED DEAD, BUT FETUS IS ALIVE
description: A Brooklyn hospital is trying to save a 4monthold fetus whose mother technically died one week ago but whose body functions are being maintained by lifesupport apparatus.

title: Ballet: Escape To Nutcrackerland
description: FANS of the sevenheaded mouse king will be delighted to hear he is back. Th3 New York City Ballet opened its annual monthlong run of The Nutcracker last night at the New York State Theater.

title: Thomas E. Mullaney
description: The Economic Scene

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, Dec. 1The Senate Judiciary Committee today deferred until next week a decison on whether the cite the chairman of the State Commission of Investigation with contempt for his refusal to honor a subpoena to turn over transcripts of a politically sensitive inquiry.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: SAN SICARIO, Italy, Dec. 1 (UPI)Perrine Pelen and Fabienne Serrat of France placed one, two today in a World Series women's giant slalom that was partly boycotted by the Austrian and Swiss teams. Only two of the eight Austrian skiers completed both runs and not one of Swiss completed the event, after officials had ignored their complaints that the track was dangerous.

title: October Factory Orders lip 3.4%; Construction Shows 1.1Billion Rise
description: WASHINGTON. DEC. 1 (AP)New factory orders rose 3.4 percent and new construction in . The United States increased by $1.1 billion to $176 billion in October. the Commerce Department reported today.

title: For Oil and Gas Compromises
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.Consumers of oil and gas are receiving a subsidy of $30 billion yeatlythe result of the United States Government's setting the prices of United Statesproduced oil and gas below world market prices.

title: STOCKS OF DISTILLATE OIL SET HIGH FOR A WEEK
H.E.W. to Issue New Regulations To Prevent Forced Sterilizations
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1Joseph A. Califano Jr.. the Secret y of Health. Education and Welfare, announced today that.his department was taking new steps to make sure that women, particularly the poor, were not coerced into being sterilized.

title: Polish Party Chief, Received by Pope, Gets Offer of Help
description: ROME, Dec. 1  Poland's Communist leader visited Pope Paul VI today and received an offer of a positive contribution to Polish society. The Pope asked in return that the church have the right to carry out its religious mission unim- peded.

title: West German Urges Placing Neutron Weapons in Europe
description: The deployment of United States neutron weapons in Western Europe has been urged by a West German defense expert who argues that, under present conditions, the conventional forces of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization could not halt an attack by Warsaw Pact forces.

title: Delegate of .U.S. To Cairo Parley Alfred Leroy Atherton Jr.
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1  President Carter's decision to have the United States participate in the Cairo meeting this month required a diplomat deeply versed in the details of the Middle Eastern negotiations and trusted by both Egyptians and Israelis, the only parties besides the United Nations that will be there. The selection of Alfred L Atherton Jr., a 56vearold native of Pitts burgh with 30 years in the Foreign Service, seemed, to make the most sense.

title: Events and Openings
description: METROPOLITAN OPERA, Lincoln Center, Pucclni's madama Bultertly, B.

title: Market Place
description: The smokedetector business, though only five years old, may be facing overcapacity, some industry followers contend.

title: KARL G. STROEHER, AT 87; A NOTED ART COLLECTOR
description: DARMSTADT, West Germany, Dec. 1 (AP)Karl G. Stroeher, an art. collector and owner of one of the world's large Collections of American avantgarde art,

title: Hussein Says Sadat Has Damaged Mideast Peace Effort by Policies
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Dec. 1 (UPI)King Hussein said today that President Anwar elSadat's trip to Israel had set back efforts to negotiate a Middle East peace, and he said he would not go to Israel. But the King promised that Jordan would not take sides in a resulting interArab quarrel.

title: COAL TALKS DISPUTE FOCUSES ON LEADERS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1Efforts by Federal mediators to revive the deadlocked coallabor talks here focused tonight on whether the controversial United Mine Workers chief, Arnold R. Miller, and his industry counterpart wolud par- ticipate in mediation sessions.

title: Decade After First Heart Transplant: Fanfare Dead But at Leat 8,5 Live
description: Ten years after Dr. Christiaan N. Barnard performed the first successful transplant of a human heatt at Groote Sauur Hospital in Cape Town, South Africa, several dozen men and women are living with hearts that once beat in others.

title: Retail Chains
description: Consumer buying in November reflected the firm pace that began early in 1977 as a dozen of the country's largest retail chains yesterday reported sales gains over 1976, most of them in the double digit range.

title: Business Records
Carter Plans 2 Speeches Abroad
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1  President Carter plans at least two major speeches during his weeklong foreign trip later this month; Administration officials said today after releasing a preliminary schedule for the sixnation tour.

title: F.B.I.Is Upheld On Search Warrant For Church Offices
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1A Federal appeals court today upheld the validity of a warrant used by the Federal Bureau of Investigation to seize materials at the headquarters of the Founding Church of Scientology here in July.

title: The Problems of Insanity as a Defense
description: The acquittal of Police Officer Robert H. Torsney by reason of insanity in the shooting death of a Brooklyn youth was in many ways highly unusual.

title: CODD RESIGNING POST, EFFECTIVE ON DEC, 31
description: Police Commissioner Michael J. Codd yesterday formally submitted his resignation, effective Dec. 31, clearing the way for Mayorelect Edward I. Koch, vgio takes office on Jan. 1, to name a new Commissioner.

title: An Art Gallery Throws a Circus
description: A la of parties end up as circuses, so it's kind of a relief to walk into one that's a circus right from the start. Bydesign.

title: Federated Stores Expects Sales to Double
description: Ralph Lazarus. chairman of Federated Department Stores, told the New York Society of Security Analysts that his company's annual sales will nearly double to $8 billion by 1982. The nation's largest department store chain had sales of $4.4 billion last year.

title: Maddox loins Mets
description: The New York Mets unveiled Elliott Maddox as their first major investment in the freeagent market yesterday, and i.ariPger Joe Torre said that the former Yankee center fielder would probably !ay right field in Shea Stadium next season.

title: Soviet Workers Tell of Hazards Of Complaining
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 1What happens when a Soviet worker asks for a raise, or complains about safety violations on the job, or uncovers corruption among his employers?

title: ENERGY CONFEREES COMPLETE ACTION ON UTILITY REFORM
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1  Scuttling lifeline eleCtric rates for the elderly, the House-Senate energy conference completed action today on utility rate reform and prepared to face the big remaining issues: taxes and natural gas prices.

title: Obituary 6 -- No Title
description: Lord Rowallan Dies; Headed British Scouts

title: GOLDIN BLOCKSMAYOR ON PATRONAGE MOVE
description: Comptroller Harrison J..Goldin last night defeated an effort by Mayor Beame to reward one of his closest political allies with a lucrative Federal jobtralning contract in the waning days of his administration.

title: Danish Premier to Visit U.S.
description: COPENHAGEN, Dec. 1 (Reuters)Prime Minister Anker Jorgensen of Denmark and Foreign Minister K.B. Anderson will pay an official visit to Washington early next year at the invitation of President Carter, Mr. Andersen said today.

title: HIGHER PHONE RATES APPROVED BY P.S.C.; COIN CALLS STILL 10C
description: New York State's Public Service Commission yesterday set new rates for the New York Telephone Company that give a caller three minutes instead of five for his first 10 cents in a payphone call and that reduce longdistance rates within the state by 5 percent.

title: Grazing Program Set by Bergland
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 1 (AP)Agriculture Secretary Bob Bergland said today that he has decided to allow farmers to graze livestock on wheat land set aside from produotion in 1978 to help reduce grain output. Mr. Bergland disclosed the grazing program at the annual meeting of Farmland Industries, a large Midwest farm cooperative.

title: 2d Greenwich Recount: Mrs. Sims
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 1Greenwich completed its third count of the ballots fcr First Selectman in last month's municipal elections today and feund the results reversed again. with a woman Democrat the apparent winner by one votemaybe.

title: The Pop Life
description: JUST a few years ago, the Joy of Cooking was the feminists pride. Not that the two leaders of the band, Toni Brown and Terry Garthwaite, had much competition in the macho world of rock-androll. And not that the Joy of Cooking was an allwoman band. But it was fronted by two women, and the very rarity of other bands that featured women prominently in roles other than chick singer made the Joy of Cooking stand out.

title: Mayor's Panel Calls for Rate Cuts By Con Ed When Service Is Bad
description: A special mayoral commission, charging that the July 13 blackout in New York City and Westchester County was caused by the Consolidated Edison Company's poor management, recommended yesterday that the company's rates be cut when it gave inadequate service and that three publicinterest trustees be appointed to the company's board of directors.

title: Radio
description: 9 A.M., WNYCAM. Symphony in D, W.F. Bach; Sinfonia Concertante in E flat (K. 297b), Mozart; Symphony No. 7, Beethoven.

title: Missouri Group Accused of Bias
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 1 (UPI)  A Boy Scout leader says a publicly financed community group asked him to assemble a lilywhite honor guard for its Christmas program.

title: TV WEEKEND
description: SUNDAY appears to have a stranglehold on specials. A new version of Kipling's Captains Courageous is slated for 7 P.M. on ABC. At a NBC has The Annie Christmas, featuring the cast from the Broadway musical. And back at ABC, Edward Asner and Maureen Stapleton star at 9 in The Gathering.

title: Friedman Says Leftist Protesters Harass Him on Chilean Economy
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 1  Milton Friedman believes that the spirit of Joseph R. McCarthy survives and flourishes in the United States but that its target has moved from the political left to the right.

title: A Young Master of the Piano Demonstrates a Mature Hand
description: Though some contend that international piano competitions breed pistonfingered specialists in Tchaikovsky, Prokofiev and Rachmaninoff, any number of relatively recent winnersGarrick Ohlsson, Murray Perahia and Emanuel Ax are three that spring to mindare best known as refined, not flashy, players. And there seems every reason to believe that Gerhard Oppitz, the 24yearold German who placed first in Israel's Arthur Rubinstein Competition six months ago, is an unusually serious, even sober, artist.

title: Snag Over Funds Is Said to Hurt 2 Federal Agencies
description: WASHINGTON. Dec. 1For the third time in three months, two major Federal departments found themselves technically without funds today, and officials said that this sort of fiscal brinkmanship was hurting efficiency and morale.

title: Screen: His Brother's Epic
description: "IF I SAY CINEMA what comes to mind? asks an interviewer on the set of Bernardo Bertolucci's 1900. Cold, answers the actress Stefania Sandrelli, who has been waiting around to complete an outdoor shot too long, Actor? the interviewer parries. Cold, she again replies. Director? Hot. Money? Cold. Woman? I don't know.

title: Times Plans a New Sports Section on Mondays
description: The New York Times will publish, beginning Jan. 9, a new Monday section devoted to sports, A. M. Rosenthal, executive editor, announced yesterday. Called Sports Monday, it will cover both spectator and participant sports and will include a variety of new columns and features centered mainly on news events.

title: The. High Cost of Repression
description: Those three brave Chilean women who have refused to sign a statement renouncing political activity have done more than give upat least temporarily  their homeland. They have demonstrated once again the duplicity and callousness of the Pinochet regime in Chile (not that they were ever in question, except by the gullible).

title: Obituary 4 -- No Title
From Bust to Best With the Broncos
description: Suddenly the coach was bleeding from a cut over his left eye. Red Miller had been demonstrating a blocking technique to Claudie Minor, the Denver Broncos offensive tackle. Without bothering to put on a helmet, the coach had lined up against Claudie Minor so that the 6foot4-inch, 280pound lineman would better understand the blocking technique. But when Claudie Minor charged, the coach began bleeding. Coach, said the big tackle, stepping back, you're bleeding, Coach, hey I'm sorry, Coach, you need the trainer. But the coach, ignoring the bloaa teat was now trickling across his face, demonstrated the blocking technique again. And all around him, the players on the Denver Broncos were staring at Red Miller and appreciating his involvement in practice. In volvementthat's what. Red Miller has supplied to the Denver Broncos as their new head coach this season. And his involvement, perhaps more than any other factor, is why the Denver Broncos now are atop the National Footalt League with a 101 wonlost record.

title: F.B.I.RECORDS TRACE OSWALD AND BULLETS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP)Newly disclosed Federal Bureau of Investigation documents on the assassination of John F. Kennedy raise, but do not answer, questions about Lee Harvey Oswald's movements in the days before Dallas and about the source of the bullets that killed the President.

title: Freeholders at Eagleton Forum Decide It Works to Think County
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, Dec. 1What do a farmer. a newspaper executive, a schoolteacher, a builder, a chemical engineer and two salesmen have in common? They are all newly elected members of Boards of Chosen Freeholders who gathered at the. Eagleton Institute of Politics here today for a forum sponsored by the New Jersey Association of Counties.

title: Use of Press and Clergy Barred In Proposed Espionage Charter
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1  The Senate Select Committee on Intelligence will propose legislation forbidding the Central Intelligence Agency to use reporters or members of the clergy in its espionage activities, the committee chairman, Dan- iel K. Inouye, said today.

title: Wednesday's Fights
Chancellor Calls Shift His Idea
description: John Chancellor will be replaced as anchorman on NBC Nightly News sometime in the future, but he said the decision to leave the post was his own. When the network has decided upon his successor, Mr. Chancellor will become the television equivalent of a newspoper columnist, contributing commentaries and news analysis to the NBC Nightly News three or four times a week.

title: Sunday's Football Fare on TV: Giants and Jets
description: The pro football games to be televised here on Sunday are the Giants at home against the St. Louis Cardinals (Channel 2, 1 P.M.), and the Jets in New Orleans against the Saints (Channel 4, 4 P.M.). The game that will not be televised here, but almost everywhere else by NBC, is Oakland at Los Angeles. The Monday night match is a key game between Baltimore and Miami, with first place in the American Conference Eastern Division at stake (Channel 7, 9 P.M.).

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: At its annual holiday gala concert tonight, the Somers Chorale in Westchester will celebrate two big events of the monthHanukkah and Christmas. The 8 P.M. program in the Somers High School Auditorium will include highlights from Handel's Messiah and Christmas carols, as well as traditional Hartukkah songs. The threeyearold community chorus, which will be joined by several professional singers, has 50 members who sound like 200, according to Frank Karian, the director, who has sung with the Robert Shaw Chorale and other wellknown groups. Admission is $3.50 (S1.50 for students). From New York take the Hutchinson River Parkway to Route 684; continue to Route 35 and turn right on Route 100. At Route 139, turn left and continue to the high school. Information: (914) 2487778 or (914) 2325375.

title: Mr. Vorster's Mandate
description: The nonevent of the year, was how a leading black newspaper in South Africa characterized Wednesday's election in which the ruling National Party increased its popular majority from 55 to more than 70 percent and its parliamentary majority from 70 to 80 percent. Yet even for blacks, who cast no votes and are unrepresented in Pretoria, that description may be overdrawn. For they, too, will be acutely affected by what Prime Minister Vorster chooses to do with his new mandate. He can use it to lead his white flock deeper into the fortified lauger a siege that would require everincreasing repressionor forward to a genuine sharing of power with the country's black majority.

title: At the Movies
description: "IVE been lying about my age for years, Dorothy Loudon conceded. I can never remember how old I've said I am; but I really ion't care any more. After all, there's just so much Max Factor you can put on your face. On the other hand, I don't feel 44.

title: Jazz: Jimmy Knepper Quartet
description: IN THE 1950's, when the jazz trombone was hung up between the staccato, Morse code, blips of J. J. Johnson at one extreme and the effulgent braying of Stan Kenton's trombone section on the other, Jimmy Knepper appeared at the end of the decade to reestablish and explore the full range and rich colors of the trombone and to emphasize the almost forgotten fact that the instrument was played with a slide, not with valves. He has been one of the most consistently interesting and provocative trombonists in the jazz world since then, adding his flair and individuality to a long number of New Yorkbased jazz groups from Charles Minp,us's workshop in the late 50's through Gil Evans's Orchestra, the Thad JonesMel Lewis Band, and, most recently, the'Lee Konitz Nonet.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: MunicipalSecurities Bill

title: People in Sports ...
description: Tom Lasorda, who in his first season as a major league manager led the Los Angeles Dodgers to the National League pennant, signed his contract yesterdair for the 1978 season. He predicted that the acouisition of Terry Forster, a tree agent. as a lefthanded rel'ef pitcher would strengthen the team that finished 10 games ahead of the Cincinnati Reds, . . . Rick Venturi, a defensive specialist while Pn assistant coach at Northwestern, Illinois and Purdue, has been named head football .coach at Northwestern. Venturi succeeds John Pont, who resigned after the Wildcats won only one of 11 games lest season. Venturi, who is 32 years

title: Pop Music: Harold Rome's World
description: HAROLD ROME's earliest successes in writing scores for the musical theater were satirical revues"Pins and Needles, Sing Out the News, Call Me Mister. Later, he moved on to book musicals, which required ballads and situation songs as well as some satire"Wish You Were Here, Fanny, Descry Rides Again and I Can Get It. for You Wholesale. This progression provides a convenient hook for a review of Mr. Rome's songs by the Joseph Jefferson Theater Company called Lyrical and Satirical: The Music of Harold Rome, which opened Wednesday evening at the Little Church Around the Corner, 11 East 29th Street. It will continue there Wednesdays through Saturdays for the next three weeks.

title: Teachers
description: CLEVELAND, Dec. 1A walkout by teachers who have not been paid since Nov. 11 crippled the public school system here today but failed to close it.

title: People and Business
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1Robert S. Strauss, Special Trade Representative, warned today that restrictive legislation against Japanese imports was very imminent if the newly reshuffled Tokyo cabinet did not make impor- tant concessions to reduce the trade surplus, now expected to be $8.5 billion this year with the United States.

title: F.D.A. Proposes Warping Label, On Protein Weight-Loss Products
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP)The Food and Drug AdMinistration proposed today to require a warning label on all protein supplements used in weight reduction or Maintenance proirains.

title: S.E.C. Puts. Off Deadline On End to Trading Curbs
description: BOCA RATON, Fla., Dec. 1Harold M. Williams, chairman of th Securities and Exchange Commission, said today that the proposed Jan. 1 deadline for abolition of the remaining exchange restrictions on offboard trading will not be met. Th.e. deferral of the deadline represented a rerieve for Wall Street on a highly controversial issue.

title: Spurs Top Knicks as Gervin Nets 29
description: SAN ANTONIO, Dec. 1The same problem that has plagued the New York Knicks often on the road this season surfaced again tonight in the Convention Center Arena.

title: Curb Is Urged On CB Radio Imports
description: Richard Homer, president of the E. F. Johnson Company, a large CB radio manufacture:, urged swift Government action to curb imports of CB radios from Japan and other countries.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ARRIVING TOMORROW, DEC. 3

title: Art: Special Breed At Folk Art Show
description: UNDER ordinary circumstances, when art critics speak of dogs, it is not the canine variety they have in mind. Exactly how the name of mates best friend. as it pleases us to call this. animal, came to be identified With creative work that is botched or otherwise repulsive, is not the mission of this column today to investigate. Suffice to say that it does seem an unfair aspersion on a class of creatures known to give pleasure to their owners, if not always to others, in far greater measure than most works of art (failed or otherwise) are likely to do.

title: Nat'l Basketball Ass'n
Review of Federal Ruling Could End Foreign Credits Of $100 Million for Banks
description: WASHINGTON, Dec, 1The Treasury is reconsider:no a 1957 ruling that could result in the disallowance of up to $100 million a year in foreign credits taken by 17 major American banks.

title: Police Screening System Disarms  Officers Who May Be Dangerous
description: About 100 New York City police officers were forced this year to work temporarily without their guns on nonpatrol assignments.

title: West German Aide Is Held in Secrets Case
description: BONN, Dec. 1An official in West Germany's secret service was arrested today as part of a 10month inquiry into how a news magazine was able to publish copies of official reports stamped secret.

title: Drug Products: Forced Generic Prescribing Does Pose Risks
description: Much flaMboyant and inaccurate rhetoric prevailtd at the hearings of the Monopoly Subcommittee of the Senate Small Business (Nelson) Committee last week, with witnesses raising the stale canard that large brand name manufacturers charge excessive prices, denigrate small generic houses, and claim that brand name drugs are superior to generic products.

title: Paul Resigns From Yankees, Tallis Roseau to Replace Him
description: Gabe Paul isn't ready to announce that he is returning to Cleveland to try to rescue the ailing Indians. He is not ready to announce it because the reorganization of the Indian ownership has not been completed.

title: Tighter Rules Proposed On Shrinkage Permitted In StoreBought Meats
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1Under new regulations proposed today by the Agriculture Department, packaged poultry and meat products on a grocery counter would have to weigh very close to what the labels on them said they did.

title: Korea Investigators Subpoena Records Of Albert, Passman
description: WASHINGTON (UPI)Personal papers of retired House Speaker Carl Albert and former Representative Otto Passman of Louisiana were subpoenaed for the House e hies comm'ttee investigation of alleged Korean influencebuying in Congress, it was learned today.

title: Leaders of Planned Farm Strike Voice Optimism After Texas Rally
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 1When the movement calling itself American Agriculture and asking a nationwide farm strike emerged a little more than two months ago, it was no bigger than a furrow scratched in a wheat field in the vast expanse of the Middle Western plains.

title: Pro Transactions
QUEBEC LIBERALS SAY POLICE RAIDED OFFICE
description: QUEBEC, Dec. 1 (Reuters)Quebec provincial police raided the headquarters of the opposition Liberal Party in Montreal yesterday and seized party membership lists, Gerard D. Ldvesque, the Liberal leader, charged today.

title: Amy Leads The Tour In Booklet For Kids
description: WASHINGTONThe Carter Administration, like three Administrations before it, has prepared a booklet to send to the many thousands of children who write to the White House for information about the first family.

title: Where To Have An Ice Day
description: THERE's a lot to he said for ice skating. In what other sport, except maybe stickball, has the equipment changed so little in the lifetime of the average adult? No trailing halfway across the state if not the continent; no expensive gear or clothes with the labels sewn on the outside, nothing more required apres than a bracing cup of chocolate. Isn't it wonderful?

title: Management
description: In his years as a management recruiter, Gerard R. Roche, a senior vice president for Heidrick & Struggles Inc., has helped to identify and place many top corporate officials But there have been some failures along the way. Mr. Roche recalls one such episode with amusement and a little sadnessthe case of a leading job candidate who lost out because of a fish.

title: Charter to Merge Two Publications
description: American Home magazine, a fixture on the American publishing scene, will cease to be after its February edition. The Charter Company, which owns it, announced yesterday that American Home would be combined into its successful Redbook magazine.

title: Tributes to Humphrey Pour In From Across the Country
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1A Connecticut man asks forgiveness for his rude and inconsiderate behavior in helping disrupt in 1968 a Boston campaign speech by Hubert H. Humphrey.

title: Figaro
description: The Marriage of Figaro, Mcizart's farcical satire, will be perforated in a modern English translation by the Eastern Opera Theater Company at the American Shakespeare Theater in Stratford, Conn., tonight and tomorrow at 8 P.M. Tickets range from 54.90 to $9.90, with a 30 percent discount Yor students and the elderly. Parking is available, with donations appreciated. Reservations are advised: 9663900 or (203) 3787321.

title: G. Clark Ramsay, at 62, Vice President of MCA And Universal Studio
description: G. Clark Ramsay, vice president of MCA Inc., the parent company of Universal Studios, died Tuesday in Los Angeles after a short illness. He was 62 years old.

title: Ski Operators Watch the Weather
description: Watchful waiting was the attitude. of ski area oporators, yesterday as rain and rising temperatures put a damper on the optimistic plans they had for the weekend.

title: Beanie Gives Friedman and Golar Lifetime Jobs on the Water Board
description: Two $20,000ayear lifetime jobs on the Board of Water Supply were awarded yesterday by Mayor Beame in a surprise political package designed to save the parttime board from abolition.

title: Sports Today
description: Nets vs. Nuggets, at Denver.

title: Letters
description: Frank Snepp's explosive account of the C.I.A.'s bungling operations in Vietnam (the neglect of vital intelli gence, dereliction of duty through corruption, personal greed and dangerous personal preference, major political misjudgment. and wishful thinking, etc.) poses a much larger question of intelligence and policymaking. It clearly demonstrates the everpresent threat to the state and its important policies by nonuse, misuse and abuse of intelligence. For instance, whenever there is a serious gap between the intelligence community as a whole and the decisionmakers who act on its advice, fatal errors could be easily embedded in the national policies to the detriment of genuine national interest.

title: Ruling Due Today on a HighRise Plan for Secaucus
description: LYNDHURST, Dec. 1In a major test of home rule in New Jersey, the Hackensack Meadowlands Development Commission will decide tomorrow whether to allow highrise apartment houses in Secaucus.

title: Auditors in Hard Hats: A New Breed
description: In the chill mist over the East River yesterday morning, Allan Fogel, sporting a jaunty yellow hard hat, climbed 9. catwalk into the steel cobwebs of the Queensboro Bridge and examined blisters of gray paint flaking from a peeling girder.

title: Verdict Is Due Today in the South African Inquest Into Biko's Death
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Dec. 1The lawyer for the family of Stephen Biko appealed to an inquest court here today to act as a brake upon the abuse of power and find members of the security police criminally responsible for the black leader's miserible and lonely death in police custody two months ago.

title: Hanukkah Puts Bluegrass In a New Light
description: The happy Jewish holiday of Hanukkah, the Festival of Lights, starts its annual eightday run Sunday night, and there are some attractive public gatherings for those who want to kindle it in a joyous way.

title: Music: Bernstein Leads Foss Cantata
description: LUKAS FOSS wrote, an Amerscan Cantata in 1976 and then stcrted revising it. The fruits of his work were revealed last night at the New York Philharmonic concert directed by Leonard Bernstein. In a way American cantatas are as old as the Republic. From the beginning we base had musical st7tements about this or that facet of the country, and Mr. Foss's new work is merely the last in the line of a long series.

title: OATHS ON FEES
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (Reuters)The Defense Department said today it did not know what could be done to stop improper payments by American companies selling arms to Iran.

title: How Farm Commodities Have Performed
Assembly Votes to Continue the State Income Tax
description: Continued From Page A1 go along with the Assembly.

title: Union Won't Meet in States Opposed to Rights Proposal
description: DETROIT. Dec. 1 (AP)The United Auto Workers union said today it will not hold national conventions or maior meetings in states that have not ratified the proposed equal rights amendment.

title: 50 Years of Atom Smashers on View in Capital
description: Of all forms of research, none are more mystifying to the uninitiated than efforts to probe theinner workings of the atom.

title: Hanukkah: A Tradition That Lives in Memory and in Practice
description: Before there was ever a Christmas, there was a Hanukkah. But since they fall In the same month in the Western calendar, the holidays have tended, in this consciously ecumenical era, to blur together into Hanukkah/Christmas savings clubs, into a blend of Christmas trees and Hanukkah bushes that blink at each other from house to bouse.

title: World Hockey Ass'n
Auctions
description: OVER the last 10 days, the star tapestry in today's auction at Sotheby Parke Bernet, sparked a tense drama in the offices of the auction house at Madison Avenue at 76th Streeta drama that resulted in its withdrawal from sale yesterday.

title: Barringer Faces Challenge On the Field and in Court
description: Barringer's football team has a date on the field at Giants Stadium in East Rutherford, N. J., tomorrow and a date in court on Tuesday. Each date should hive some effect on the school football picture in New Jersey. The Newark school, unbeaten through 10 games, will play powerful Westfield for the North Jersey Section 2 Gtoup 4 championship at Giants Stadium at 1:30 P.M.

title: Art: A Builder With Grand Designs
description: VARUJAN BOGHOSIAN is a true poet, and a man whose work could not be mistaken for anyone else's. But what kind.of work is it? A difficult question. To answer it, we have to spend some time with his new work, which is on show at the Cordler & Ekstrom Gallery, 980 Madison Avenue at 76th Street through Dec. 10.

title: MacDonaldEddy Festival
description: A retrospective of 16 MGM musicals starring Jeanette MacDonald and Nelson Eddy, together and separately, will begin Sunday at the Regency Theater, Broadway and 67th Street, and run until Dec. 24. Two films will be shown continuously for two to four days, beginning with Naughty Marietta (1935) and Rose Marie (1936) on Sunday. Admission is $3 for adults, $1.50 for children through 11 and S1.50 for the elderly, weekdays until 5 P.M.; a series card for four films is available at S. Information: 7243700.

title: Officer Torsney May File for a Disability Pension
description: Police Officer Robert Torsney, who was acquitted Wednesday of the 1976 killing of 15yearold Randolph Evans for reasons of insanity, may file for a medicaldisability pension from the Police Department, his lawyer, Edward Rappaport, said yesterday.

title: What Moscow Seeks iri the Middle East
description: To the Editor:

title: Jazz in Church From Vespers to Matins
description: When the sanctuary In the new St. Peter's Church at. 54th Street and Lexington Avenue has its official opening Sunday, the day will begin with a service at 11 A.M. for members of the conerecation, followed by a 4 P.M.. service of dedication to the city of New York. Bilt. the big celebration at the Lutheran Church will be All Nile Soul, a marathon 12hour jam session that will begin at 6 P.M. and Which will attract some of the brightest jazz names in the country.

title: Red Tape as Swaddling
description: We were waiting on line for redress of a grievance, reading Red Tape, Its Origins. Uses and Abuses, by Herbert Kaufman, a respected student of government at the Brookings Institution, who wondered why red tape. despite all the satires, laments and denunciations, had never been treated analytically and so set out to determine what can and cannot be done about it.

title: Justice Tyler Gets 5 Years
description: Justice Andrew R. Tyler of State Supreme Court was sentenced yesterday to five years probation after the justice who presided at his perjury trial refused a defense request to set aside the jury's guiltv verdict and a Department of Probetion and prosecution request for imprisonment.

title: Art People
description: SOME new light was thrown the other day by Thomas Hoving, retiring director of the Metropolitan Museum, on the J. Paul Getty Museum's recent purchaseat a once between $3.5 million and $5 millionof a rare Greek bronze found in the sea and thought to date from the fourth century B.C.

title: CARTER DRAWS FIRE FROM LATIN AMERICA ON U.S. SUGAR MOVES
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 Americans are expressing sharp criticism of President Carter for raising tariffs and imposing a fee on sugar imports last month without consulting the other American nations, as he had promised to do.

title: Unilever Takeover of National Starch a-- Chemical Being Discussed
description: A friendly takeover bid by Unilever for the National Starch and Chemical Corporationwhich would involve at least $300 million at present market pricesis under discussion, both companies disclosed yesterday.

title: Trend to Racially Isolated School Districts Grows
description: A recent series in The New York Times reported that the goal of integration has been all but abandoned in the New York City schools, that 78 percent of the white children attended schools that were at least 50 percent white in the 19741975 school year and that 75 percent of minoritygroup children were then enrolled in schools with more than a 75 percent minority registration.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Up 1.2%
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 13.5 billion tonmiles, up 1.2 percent from the yearearlier level. Carloadings in the same week totaled 385,977 cars, up 0.2 percent front last year. The American Trucking Associations Inc., reported intercity truck tonnage rose 1 percent from a year ago.

title: In Hearing On Gerard
description: Nassau County District Attorney Denis Dillon won a postponement yesterday of the hearing in State Supreme Court on the complicity of Dr. Mark J. Gerard and Jack B. Morgan in the LebonCinzano ringer case.

title: Coast Concern Plans Bacteria Use For Brain Hormone and Insulin
description: A California company called Genentech said yesterday that it expects to use bacteria to manufacture a human brain hormone called somatostatin by the middle of next year, and human insulin within a year.

title: Obituary 7 -- No Title
The Heart Has Its Reasons
description: Ten years ago, Dr. Christiaan Barnard created a worldwide sensation when he successfully transplanted a human heart into the chest of a patient whose own heart had virtually given out. For months thereafter, some surgeons seemed engaged in a race to see which of them could transplant the most hearts. It took a while to learn that the actual transplant is the easiest part the job; the hard part is to prevent the patient's rejection of the foreign tissue; most recipients died within a few weeks. Surgical techniques have improved, but transplants are not the answer to heart disease. The problem of rejection is still unsolved, the cost of the operation is high and it is not easy to find healthy hearts for transplanting.

title: ADDITIONAL FUND FAVORED TO AVERT AMTRAK CUTBACK
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP)A HouseSenate conference committee approved today an additional $18 million for Amtrak to avoid cutbacks of national rail pssenger service this winter.

title: Restaurants
description: PEW restaurants have had such an upagain, downagain reputation forfood as La Goulue, the handsome Art Nouveau Parisianstyle bistro that has been on 70th Street just east of Madison Avenue for the last five years. The word was that the food has reached an alltime high in quality, and so it was with eager anticipation that we returned to this stylish setting to check out those cheerful rumors. Fortunately, they proved to be true for the most part, and while the cooking at La Goulue still falls far short of being sensational or even consistently excellent, it does average out to be very good indeed.

title: Theater: Battle of the Ages
description: "THE OFFERING is the classic duel between the aging male and the young one, their strengths clashing in a shifting balance until the very end.

title: On 3d Try, Saltharov Gets Invitation Sent by Meany, But It Is Still to No Avail
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 1 (Reuters)Andrei D. Sakharov, the physicist, today related the bizarre circumstances under which he has been prevented from attending the A.F.L.C.I.O. convention in Los Angeles later this month.

title: Books: Women Against Deadlines
description: UP FROM THE FOOTNOTE: A History of Women Journalists. By Marion Marzoll. 310 pages. Hastings House. $1195.

title: Two Businessmen Are Indicted on Charges of Bilking Jersey City Bank
description: NEWARK. Dec. 1Two outofstate businessmen were indicted today on charges of bilking a Jersey. City bank of more than $1.3 million in fraudulent loans by submitting false financial documents and bribing the bank's vice prestt dent.

title: Braths
description: LEVINESidney, on November 30, 1977. Beloved husband of Celia; loving father of Joseph: cherished grandfather; brother of Harry Bremer. Services today llAM Westchester Riverside, 21 W Broad Si. Fleetwood, Mt. Vernon. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to Dobbs Ferry Hospital, Dobbs Ferry NY

title: Two U.S. Groups In Kiev Confront Separate Worlds
description: KIEV, U.S.S.R.Now that the tourists have fled the cold winter rains, only about a dozen Americans live in this capital of the Soviet Ukraine, half of them members of a future United States consulate and half of them students.

title: Publishing: Humor in Budapest
description: WHEN George Konrad's first novel, The Case Worker, was published in this country a few years ago, the Hungarian sociologist Immediately moved to the front rank of European writers,. East or West. The story of the claustrophobic life of a case worker stuck in the human files of Budapest was compared to Kafka; its linguistic inventiveness reminded some readers of Joyce.

title: Ignoring Foes, Cairo Moves Ahead On Parley to Prepare Geneva Talks
description: CAIRO, Dec. 1Despite the gathering of Arab hardliners in neighboring Libya, Egypt is pressing ahead with its plans to convene a preparatory meeting for new Geneva peace talks, though the meeting is not expected to get under way until midDecember to allow more time to get ready.

title: U.S. OUTLINES TACTICS FOR FUEL SHORTAGES
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP)The Department of Energy spelled out today tactics to cope with any winter shortages of natural gas, oil, coal, propane, or hydroelectric power, including possible allocation of fuels and mandatory thermostat settings.

title: U.N. and Developing Countries, In Deadlock, Recess Fund Talks
description: GENEVA, Dec. 1A United Nations conference on a projected international fund to stabilize the earnings of developing countries from the export of raw materials was recessed in deadlock tonight.

title: Australia Leads in Tennis
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Friday, Dec.2 (AP)Tony Roche defeated Italy's Adriano Panatta, 63, 64, 6.4, today to take the opening singles match of the Davis Cup Challenge Round, putting Australia on the way to a possible 17th Davis Cup victory.

title: WESTINGHOUSE GREED ALLEGED BY GULF OIL
description: PITTSBURGH, Dec. 1Jerry McAfee, chairman of the Gulf Oil Corporation, lashed out today at another giant Pittsburgh company, the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, contending that Westinehouse tried to hide its greed or mana- gerial mistakes in the nuclear power business by raising a uranium cartel smokescreen.

title: 500 Riot in Bermuda in Protest At Death Penalty Ruling by Court
description: HAMILTON, Bermuda, Dec. 1 (AP)Meting erupted on the edge of downtown Hamilton tonight after Bermuda's highest court rejected a final appeal for a stay of execution against two .convicted murderers and ordered them to die by hanging at dawn.

title: Schmidt and Andreotti Confer
description: VALEGGIO SUL MINCIO, Italy, Dec. 1 (Reuters)The West German Chancellor, Helmut Schmidt, and the Italian Prime Minister, Giulio Andreotti, met near here today for talks expected focus on economic issues.

title: World News Briefs
description: PARIS, Dec. IFrance's three major union federations staged a 24hour national strike today to protest Government restrictions on wage rises and the high jobless rate, causing severe disruptions. in the capital.

title: Television
description: TOP WEEKEND FILMS

title: Choirs Will Sing Britten's Praises
description: St. Cecilia has long been known as the patron saint of music, and it pleased Benjamin Britten that he happened to be born on her day, Nov. 22, in 1913. At 29, he composed a work to celebrate their relationship and took as his text W. II, Auden's Anthem for St. Cecilia, which begins:

title: Books of The Times
description: BOOKS are a triviality. Life alone is great, wrote Thomas Carlyle to his journal in 1839. Still, books are easier to gift wrap than life; and since it's gift wrapnins we do at Christmas, you might consider doing it to the following, which are ranked approximately acccrding to their price tags.

title: Art: Drawing With Metal
description: THOUGH they may at times seem indistinguishable from each other, sculpture and painting proceed from very different impulses. One is a somewhat masculine enterprise, akin to architecture, whose primary effect is to arrest spectators by a physical presencean obstacle. The other, being confined to two dimensions, works upon its audience more obliquely, entrapping it by color, texture and illusion in a way that could be called feminine.

title: Ralph H. Atkinson, Who Retired In 1955, as Research Metallurgist
description: Ralph H. Atkinson, who retired in 1955 as research-metallurgist for the International Nickel Company Inc., and other concerns, died Tuesday in Overlook Hospital, Summit, N.J., after a short illness. He was 87 years old and lived at 861 Tice Place, Westfield, N.J.

title: ASSEMBLY IN JERSEY VOTES TO CONTINUE STATE's INCOME TAX; ACTS TO CANCEL EXPIRATION; Senate Is Expected to Follow Suit '20 and Out Pension Bill for Policemen and Firemen Loses
description: TRENTON, Dec. 1The 11yearfight in New Jersey over a state income tax appeared near an end tonight when the Assembly voted to repeal the June 30 expiration date of the tax. The Senate is expected to do the same when it reconvenes Dec. 15.

title: HARDLINE LEADERS GATHERING IN LIBYA
description: TRIPOLI, Libya,Dec. 1 (AP)Leaders of hardline Arab countries assembled here today for a Libyansponsored summit of resistance to thwart President Anwar elSadat's bold peace overtures to Israel.

title: WEEKEND MOVIE CLOCK
description: BRONX

title: A Reader's Guide to Fifth Ave.
description: FIFTH AVENUE is still the city's elegant, ageless matron. Its fashionable stores still glisten. Its sidewalks are crowded with exuberant  Christmas shoppers. But that street of dreams houses more than diamond and silk confections now adays. From the south edge of Central Park to a few blocks short of Washington Square, Fifth Avenue has a decidedly literary look.

title: Opera: Dashing Duke in `Rigoletto
description: THE METROPOLITAN OPERA clearly has high hopes for Neil Shicoff, a 28yearold tenor who made a promising debut last season in Gianni Schicchi. He has already been given his first leading assignment with the company, as the Duke in Rigoletto, and Wednesday night he made his second appearance in the role.

title: Liquefied Gas Era May Be Ending Even as Supply Flood Is Starting
description: Early next year, a tanker riding oddly high in the water will steam 75. miles up Chesapeake Bay to an offshore docking platform one mile from a jut of land known as Cove Point, Md. The ship will tie up along one end of the halfmilelong pier, and five hollow mechanical arms will reach out like some spidery sea mon ster to siphon off the buoyant cargoliquefied natural gas at a temperature of minus 259 degrees Fahrenheit.

title: Miss Moncharsh Becomes Bride of Brian S. Leyden
description: Diane Moncharsh, assistant salespromotion manager of Seagram Overseas Sales Company, and Brian S. Leyden, president of Odyssey Chartering and Brokerage Corporation, a member of the Leyden Group of Companies in New York, were married yesterday. Rabbi Maurice Aranov performed the ceremony, at the home of the briddgroom's father, Bernard Leyden.

title: Landes Charged With Practicing Law in Nassau Without a License
description: MINEOLA. Dec. 1Assemblyman Irwin J. Landes was charged today by the Nassau County District Attorney's Office with practicing law without .a license.

title: Lord Rowallan Dies; Headed British Scouts
description: GLASGOW, Scotland, Dec. 1 (AP)Lord Rowallan, a former leader of the British Boy Scouts, died in a nursing home today. He would have been 82 years old Dec. 19.

title: Bridge: Cappellettis of Alexandria, The Top HusbandWife Team
description: There is little doubt that Michael and Kathie Cappelletti of Alexandria, Va., are the best hubandandwife bridge partnership in the world.

title: Sidor, Venezuela's Steel Concern, In $500 Million Loan Bid Abroad
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 1Venezuela's Governmentowned steelmtker, Siderurgica del Orinoco, is currently trying to borrow $500 million from foreign hanks. it was learned today.

title: Carter's FirstYear Strategy
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1President Carter's close. personal friend, Charles Klrbo of Atlanta, was in the capital the other day commenting on the physical strains of the Presidency. He said he thought the President looked tired and

title: Carter Sets Up Special Commission To Review the Antitrust Laws
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP)President Carter announced today the creation of a special commission to review antitrust laws and procedures. Mr. Carter signed an executive order setting up a 15-member national commission that will go out of business after conducting a sixmonth study.

title: Con Ed's Chief Finds Distortions in Report
description: Arthur Hauspurg the president of Consolidated Edison, charged yester day that the mayoral panel's report on last July's blackout had deliberately distorted a paragraph from a 1967 Public Service Commission report. Page 29 of the March 1967 P.S.C. report to the Governor and Legislature on the 1965 blackout said:

title: Commodity Spot Price Index Up 1.8 To 209.1 From 207.3 Last Week
2 Black Groups Meeting With Smith Today
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Dec. 1Two Governmentsanctioned black nationalist factions said today that they would meet tomorrow with Prime Minister Ian D. Smith for talks that he had suggested on the possibility of eventual black rule.

title: W.B.C. Extends Ali Deadline
description: MADRID, Dec. 1 (UPI)The World Boxing Council backed down today on its repeated threat to strip Muhammad Ali of his heavyweight championship despite strong lobbying by ken Norton and Don King.

title: What New Phone Rates and Rules Mean to Subscribers
description: For 42 long days, a telephone line was held open between Baruch and City College computers. The call, from May 17 to June 26, 1976, cost 8.2 ecnts.

title: Correction
description: Elaine Morgan's article In Defense of Virgins, which appeared on this page Nov. 25, inaccurately attributed a New Yorker drawing to James Thurber, as several readers have pointed out, testily. Actually, Carl Rose drew the little girl who tells her mother, I say its spinach, and I say the hell with it, and E. White wrote the caption. One reader observed: It seems that, even at this late date, Thurber [who often spoke of the drawing before his death, in 1961] is still capable of being at the heart of misinformation.

title: Met Orchestrates a Bazaar
description: It could be the opening scene from an opera: a fanciful bazaar with food, drink and merry men and merry women picking through wares to the flouri:h of trumpets and the songs of madrigal singers

title: Blues Professor
description: Professor Longhair, who is making one of his exceedingly rare New York appearances tonight at 8 o'clock at New York Univerisity's Eisner and Lubin Auditoriums, is a living legend. This is not as romantic as it sounds. Being a living legend can mean hearing your music in the styles of many more successful performers, being discUssed knowledgeably by experts, and not writing very much.

title: J. P. Stevens Quarter Net Up 6.8%, But FiscalYear Figure. Fell 14.4%
description: J. P. Stevens & Company, the nation's second largest textile producer, which has been embroiled in bitter labor problems, yesterday reported a 6.8 percent increase in earnings for the fourth fiscal auarter but a 14.4 percent decline for the fiscal year ended Oct. 29.

title: Obituary 3 -- No Title
Ban on Birth Control Classes Ends
description: LANSING, Michigan, Dec 1 (Reuters)Pichigan has lifted its ban on the teaching of birth control in public schools, (having Louisiana the only state in which such a ban still exists. The Michigan law mandates that local advisory boards be established to review any programs put Into effect and prohibits discussion of abortion as a method of contraception.

title: Metropolitan Baedeker:
description: VERY few persons think of. Greenwich, Conn., as anything other than an exclusive, wellheeled suburban community that has resisted largescale residential developments although acceding in recent years to corporate headquarters and office parks. But Greenwich also is a town filled with interesting and unusual things to doa town that is well worth a weekend visit.

title: Advertising
description: The American Motors Corporation, whose passenger car sales plummeted a disturbing 26.5 percent in fiscal 1977, announced yesterday it was splitting on Jan. 1 with Cunningham & Walsh, its passenger car advertising agency for five and a half years.

title: Bell Puts Off Naming U.S. Attorney Pending an Inquiry Into Payments
description: Attorney General Griffin B. Bell, under pressure from investigators in his own department, said yesterday that he would delay a planned appointment of a United States Attorney in Pittsburgh pending an inquiry into payments to a Congressman.

title: Money Cut Aids Credit Markets
description: In a decline that was somewhat larger than expected, the nation's basic money supply dropped $2.4 billion in the week ended Nov. 23, the Federal Reserve discicised yesterday afternoon. The decrease caused a modest rebound in the credit markets.

title: BRITISH AWAIT BEGIN, ONCE A BITTER FOE
description: LONDON, Dec. 1Three decades ago Menahem Begin was at the top of the wanted lists circulated by the British police in Palestine. He was denounced here as a terrorist and a murderer.

title: The Program *
description: 6 P.M., Billy Taylor, piano; 6:30, Bobby Short, vocalist and piano; 7, David Chesky Band; 8. Vera Auer Quartet; 8:30, Sheila Jordan Trio; 9, Dick Hyman, piano; Howard McGhee, trumpet; Pepper Adams, saxophone; 9:15, Eddie Bonnemere Orchestra and Choir with Evelyn Blakey, vocalist.

title: Broadway
description: PERHAPS there are people who do not like dancing; perhaps there are people who do not like Santa Claus, either. For everyone else, however, there Is something called Dancin', which Bob Fosse will choreograph and direct, and which will be virtually all song and dance, with the spoken word only here and there. Dancin" will go into rehearsal Dec. 27, open at the Colonial in Boston on Feb. 11, come to New York for previews March 9 and then open officially around March 20. It will be produced by the Shubert Organization, Columbia Pictures and Jules Fisher, who will also, of course, do the lighting. Mr. Fisher says Dancin' will have lots of lighting.

title: Notes on People
description: Richard E. Gerstein, the State Attorney it Florida whose investigation of Miami area figures first established a link between the Nixon White House and the Watergate burglary, resigned in Miami yesterday after more than 20 years in office. Mr. Gerstein, 54 years old, was elected six times to the office, generally regarded as the second most powerful in Florida, after the Governor. His current term expires in January 1981, but he is joining the law firm of Murray Sams Jr. in Miami.

title: Dollar Continues To Drop Abroad; Gold Is Unchanged
description: The dollar resumed its yearlong slide against major currencies in Europe, held firm against the yen in Tokyo, and de dined for the most part in New York in foreign exchange trading yesterday The Associated Press reported.

title: About Real Estate
description: The former West Side Towers, a singleroomoccupancy hotel, once described by Attorney General Louis 3. Lefkowitz as an incredible chamber of horrors, is undergoing a conversion to apartments.

title: Summit Conference Set for Bonn
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (Reuters)The next international summit conference on economic problems will be held in Bonn sometime next year, Jody. Powell, the White House Press Secretary, said today. The last such meeting, attended by six Western industrialized countries and Japan, was held in London in May.

title: For Children
description: MUSIC FOR ST. NICHOLAS, the annual St. Nicholas Day oresenlalloo at the Van CortIan& Mansion, tea. turino old Dutch Carols, given by the Bronx Arts Ensemble and Singers. at 11:30, 2 and 3:30 on Saturday and Sunday. In the mansion's herb cellar. Atter the concerts. candlelight tours of the holiday

title: The Standings
Music: National Chorale Surveys The Age of Glory
description: THE NATIONAL Chorale, one of the most firmly established professional choral groups in the country, has planned a series of concerts under the title The Age of Glory, and it got under way Wednesday night in Avery Fisher Hall. The program will survey the choral masterpieces of Western music, and the first one included a Jubilate Deo of Giovanni Gabrieli, Bach's Magnificat, the E flat or Christmas version, Brahms's flank and Mozart's Requiem.

title: Vorster Party's Landslide Victory Raises Possibility of Tougher Stand
description: JOHANNESBURG, Dec. 1 The South African Government's overwhelming victory in yesterday's general election appears to have set it more firmly than ever on a collision course with the country's black majority and with the foreign powers that are uniting in an effort to force the abandonment of its racial policies.

title: SOCIAL SECURITY PLAN BORES PRESIDENT
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP)Seeking to hold down soaring payroll taxes, President Carter told Congressional conferees today that the nation cannot afford increases in Social Security benefits at this time.

title: N.A.M. to Help Employers Bar Labor Unions
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1The National Association of Manufacturers announced today the formation of a national organization intended to help employers keep unions out of their factories, stores and offices.

title: Tax Filing Rules Simplified
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (UPI)The Internal Revenue Service said today that filing requirements for certain government and church employers with employee retirement plans had been simplified. The service said that the change applied to plans maintained by more than one government or church unit when the assets of the plans were pooled into a single fund for investment purposes. The simplified filing rules apply to Forms 5500 and 5500C.

title: Dow Average Off 3.99 to 825.71, But Stock Advances Top Declines
description: The general stock market outperformed the Dow Jones industrial average-its bestknown indicator-by a handsome margin yesterday.

title: MAYOR's PANEL URGES CUT IN CON ED's RATES MIEN SERVICE IS BAD
description: A special mayoral commission, charging that the July 13 blackout in New York City and Westchester County was caused by the Consolidated Edison Company's poor management, recommended yesterday that the company's rates be cut when it gave inadequate service and that three publicinterest trustees be appointed to the company's board of directors.

title: Stage: Deadly OneonOne
description: THE LAKE is foul, the grounds are almost deserted, and menace hangs in the air like thunderclouds. Murders have taken place in these'lonely cabins in the woods. Steve Tesich's new play. Passing Game, which opened last night at the American Place Theater, begins promisingly on a note of mystery and nortent.

title: PateStacy Lead in Golf By 6 Strokes
description: LARGO, Fla., Dec. 1The personal chemistry of a. golf partnership is elusive and mysterious, and its members can seldon define why they play well or badly. About the best they can say is what Hollis Stacy said of her round today with Jerry Pate: We worked awful well together.

title: Some Racing Crowds Don't Add Up Delay Won
description: Padded attendance figures have been playing an unnoticed role in the promotional battle between the Meadowlands track and its New York rivals. The heaviest padding appears to he taking place at Meadowlands, the stateowned tacility across the Hudson River from midtown Manhattan in East Rutherford, N.J. As many as 1,400 or more employees at the new track are counted each night in the official attendance.

title: Bolivian Vote Set for July 9
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, Dec. 1 (Reuters)President Hugo Banzer today set next July 9 as the date for Bolivia's first elections in 12 years. He said he would not run for the presidency and this decision was irrevocable. In a nationwide broadcast General Banzer, who seized power six years ago from previous military governments, said Bolivians would vote for a president, a vice president and members of a constituent assembly.

title: Orders, Construction Up
description: Factory orders increased by 3.4 percent and new construction rose by $1.1 billion in October, the Commerce. Department reported. .Page D3.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. on budgetary matters, followed by the question of Palestine.

title: Teachers Union Asks U.S Court To Upset RaceAssignment Pact
description: The United Federation of Teachers and its president, Albert Shanker, moved in Federal District Court yesterday to overturn as unconstitutional an agreement between the Board of Education and the Federal Office for Civil Rights that has resulted in the assignment of several thousand New York City school teachers on the basis of race.

title: Assembly in New Jersey Votes To Continue the State Income Tax
description: TRENTON, Dec. 1The 11year fight in New Jersey over a state income tax appeared near an end tonight when the Assembly voted to repeal the June 30 expiration date of the tax. The Senate is expected to do likewise when it recon- venes Dec. 15.

title: Israelis Will Submit Draft Peace Accord At Meeting in Cairo
description: TEL AVIV, Dec. 1An Israeli Foreign Ministry official said today that Israel planned to take a draft peace agreement to the projected talks in Cairo for use as a means of defining the areas of agreement and disagreement with

title: New York Welfare Costs Declining
description: ALBANY, Dec. 1In what appears to be a significant reversal, New York States wefare and capital Medicaid costs for the first six months of 1977 showed a substantial decline from the. corresponding period in 1976, according to a report by the Assembly's Ways and Means Committee released here today.

title: Officer Accused of Using Excessive Force on Man With 2 Dogs on S.I. Ferry
description: A police officer was accused yesterday by 15 Staten Island ferryboat passengers of having used unnecessary force in arresting a man who had brought his two young German shepherd dogs aboard.

title: Defense Opens Case With Film of Victims In Coast Kidnapping
description: OAKLAND, Calif.. Dec. 1With film clips and medical testimony, the defense attorneys in the Chowchilla kidnapping case are attacking prosecution allegations that four children and their summer erbrull bus driver suffered bodily injury from their 16hour imprisonment in a buried trailer.

title: FARM FUTURES UP IN MOST CONTRACTS
description: Wheat and oats futures scored sizable gains yesterday, while soybeans futures prices advanced slightly on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Sparing a Future Randy Evans
description: Many of us New Yorkers were jolted by the acquittal of Robert Torsney, a white police officer, on grounds insanity, for killing Randolph Evans, a 15yearold black. The biggest jolt should be felt by the Police Department, for what is truly insane is to send unbalanced officers intn fhe ctrretc with shield and gun. The question of sparing Robert Torsney is not nearly so important how to spare some future Randy Evans.

title: COUNCIL SLATES VOTE ON PAY RAISES TODAY
description: The New York City Council will introduce today its own bill calling for raises up to $10,000 for the city's 51 top elected officials who take office Jan. 1.

title: Phone Company to Ask Increase for Certain Coin Calls
description: The New York Telephone Company said yesterday that it would apply for an increase to 30 cents on socalled twomessage unit paytelephone calls.

title: Queen Quartet Rocks With. Control
description: Queen's show at Madison Square Garden on Thursday evidenced some good and bad aspects of what rock is and where it is going. On the good side, a basic rock quartetdrums, bass, guitar and occasional piano from Freddie Mercury, the lead vocalistwas able to carry a show more than two hours long without resorting fo the smoke bombs, laser lights, stage props and other accoutrements that sometimes seem to be becoming more important than the music. Queen demonstrated exemplary control of its material and solid professionalism in terms of arrangements, pacing and sound.

title: Thailand and Vietnam Plan Full Diplomatic Links
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 2Tha1and and Vietnam announced today that they intended to proceed with plans to establish full diplomatic relations and exchange ambassadors.

title: Barnes Guilty In Drug Case; Could Get Life
description: Leroy (Nicky) Barnes was convicted yesterday of heading a major narcotics organization that sold millions of dollars of heroin and cocaine in Harlem.

title: . . . on the Navy
description: MILWAUKEETo many Navy men, the term Mickey Mouse sometimes means laughterbut not at a cartoon character. Sometimes it isn't a laughing matter.

title: West Virginia Coal Town, Expecting Strike, Displays Concern But No Panic
description: TWILIGHT, W. Va., Dec. 2Every weekday afternoon about o'clock a train of railroad cars rumbles along the west fork of the Little Coal River here in this hamlet of 100 families in the heart of the West Virginia coal fields.

title: Car Crash Injures Carter
description: PHOENIX, Ariz, Dec. 2 (UPI)Duane (Pancho) Carter, 27, of Brownsburg, Ind., was injured critically today when his race car crashed during a test run at Phoenix International Racetvay.

title: Good Samaritan Pursues Gunman Who Kills Him Before Being Seized
description: A 30-ycar-eld rn:=n. responding to a woman' pleas for help. was shot and kiFecl yesterday as he chased a gunman through the crowded streets of Greenwich Village.

title: A SelfEducated Communicator
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 2  Struggling against the economic floodwaters of the Depression, Maurice Bernard Mitchell quit New York University in 1935 when his money ran out and took a job, at $10.50 a week, selling

title: Carter Signals Start Of Nuclear Reactor
description: A major alternative to the highly advanced nuclear breeder reactor planned for Clinch River, Tenn., went into commercial operation yesterday 25 miles northwest of Pittsburgh, Pa. President Carter, who objects to the Clinch River plant because it involves nuclear materials that can be made into bombs, participated in the ceremony from the Oval Office.

title: Aide Says Hughes Paid Politicians
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Dec. 2 (UPI)Noah Dietrich, onetime chief aide to Howard R. Hughes, testified today that the late industrialist processed $400,000 a year through a Canadian outlet of the Hughes Tool Company to pay off politicians.

title: !Mrs. Badillo a Hospital Patient After Suffering Mild Heart Attack
description: Irma Badillo. the wife of Representative Herman Badillo, is a patient at New York Hospital, where she was admitted on Wednesday suffering from what. hospital spokesman described as a mild heart attack.

title: Garden Lineups
Events Today
Problem of Battered Wives Draws Increased Attention
description: ATLANTALike the issue of rape before it, the problem of battered women, those beaten by a boyfriend as well as those beaten by a husband, has become a crusade for women's groups and others across the country.

title: Bernstein Conducts an American Cantata
description: Lukas Foss wrote an American Cantata last year and then started revising it. The fruits of his work were revealed Thursday night, at a New York Philharmonic concert directed by Leonard Bernstein. In a way, American cantatas are as old as the Republic. From the beginning we have had musical statements about this or that facet of the country, and Mr. Foss's new work is merely the last in the line of a long series.

description: Han Suyin has spent most of her bU years making East meet West and flouting frontiers and much of conventional morality. I go right on and do as I please, she says, flashing a smile that transforms her plain, high-cheekboned face into that of a radiant gamin resembling Audrey Hepburn.

title: Washington's Farewell Brings Tears (of Laughter) This Time

description: COXSACKIE, N. Y., Dec. 2About 40 youthful inmates of the State Correctiona! Facility here seized three hostages today but released them unharmed, one of them late this afternoon and two tonight, after being allowed to present a list of 35 arievances to state officials and representatives of the news media.

title: G.M. CHIEF HOLDS FIRM ON 4.4% SALES RISE IN '78
description: DETROIT, Dec. 2Despite uncertainty in some automotive circles, the chairman of the General Motors Corporation, Thomas A. Murphy, reiterated today his belief that newcar sales during 1978 will rise 4.4 percent to 11.75 million units from the 11.25 million projected for this year. When projected truck sales of 3.75 million units are added, he said, the industry would realize a 5 percent gain in overall unit sales next Year.

title: U.N. WORKERS IN GENEVA VOTE TO STRIKE OVER PAY
description: GENEVA, Dec. 2  United Nations workers here voted today to hold a oneday strike to protest Secretary General Kurt Waldheim's decision to freeze present salaries and reduce the pay scales of general service employes by 17 percent on Jan. 1, staff officials announced.

description: ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 2 (UPI)Rightist laborers threw a bomb at a lunchtime crowd of students today, causing a shootout in which at least 20 persons were wounded, the authorities said. The students have been protesting the presence of about 500 laborers, saying the rightist Government planted them to silence protest.

title: Editorial Article 1 -- No Title
description: Although the basic competency tests in reading and arithmetic for New York State's high school students will not be mandatory until June 1979, some of New York City's eighth and ninth graders are already taking them. About threequarters have passed; the rest will be given remedial work to help them pass by their senior year. Unless they do, they will be denied a diploma.

title: About Newyork
description: When Edward Rappaport was a homicide .proseculor in Brooklyn, he won a conviction in a case in which a policeman buying a pack of cigarettes was stopped by a stranger who slashed the policeman's throat from ear to ear with a hunting knife. A crowd chased the man, and the defendant later contended unsuccessfully in court that they had caught the wrong man.

title: Police Still Have No Clues in Killing Of 5 in Bergen Family 2 Years Ago
description: TEANECK, Dec. 2 Two years after Jean Diggs and her four children were murdered with a .22caliber rifle late at night in their threestory home in this Bergen County suburb, the authorities acknowledged today that thousands of investigatory manhours had produced virtually nothing.

title: Getty Mausoleum Approved
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 2 (UPI)The Los Angeles city zoning office yesterday approved the construction of a mausoleum for J. Paul Getty at the late .oil tycoon's Malibu estate. The city Planning Commission and the Coastal Commission must also approve the mausoleum. Mr. Getty's burial request came in a will. He died June 6, 1976.

title: Whitewash in Pretoria
description: Died mysteriously is the phrase we have been using in comments on the death, in police custody nearly three months ago, of Stephen Biko, the young South African black leader. But the only mystery remaining after the lengthy magistrate's inquest, now concluded with whitewash verdict, is which of the security officers who interrogated Mr. Biko actually administered the fatal blows. Their selfprotecting testimony was riddled with contradictions, ably exposed by the Biko family counsel.

title: HARRY DAY
description: VALETTA, Malta, Dec. 2 (Reuters)Harry (Wings) Day, a British Royal Air Force group captain who led the biggest escape from a German prisoner of war camp in World War II, died in a hospital here today after a short illness. He was 79. The captain was one of the few survivors of the socalled Great Escape in 1914 when about SO R.A.F. officers escaped from Stalag Luit III through a tunnel. He was recaptured.

title: Jersey Radio Station Struck
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 2 (UPI) -- A strike forced radio station WUSS off the air for eight hours yesterday. Eleven newscasters, disc jockeys, and salesmen and clerks walked out because their paychecks were late. The station was off the air from 8 A.M. until 4 P.M. when management took over broadcasting operations. The employees said they were angry because their paychecks had been late several times in recent weeks.

title: PateStacy Lead by 3 as Darkness Halts Play

Bolt, now 59 years old and suffering from a touch of what he calls arthuritis, had a few angry moments today, but not enough to spoil his day.

title: Much Heat, Some Light on the Blackout
description: Immediately after the blackout of July 13, Mayor 8eatne had no doubt where to put the blame for the disaster'gross negligence by Consolidated Edison, he called it. The Mayor promptly appointed a special investigation commission, which held hearings, examined documents, and got into frequent tiffs with the utility. The commission has now issued its final reporta twovolume indictment that avoids the phrase gross negligence out. essentially, supports Mr. Beame's dark-of-thenight verdict.

title: Beatingsof Pregnant Woman, Now Comatose, Alleged
description: The Brooklyn District Attorney is investigating allegations that Rosemarie Maniscalco, the 27-year-old pregnant woman who suffered apparent brain death Wednesday night, had frequently been beaten by her husband.

Kasten Jr., a 35-year-old Wisconsin Republican, does not normally have rent control in New York City on his mind, what with representing communities like Whitefish Bay and Waukesha. But yesterday he found himself immersed in the intricacies and conflicts surrounding New York's rent laws.

title: Sieve Forbert, New Folk Singer
description: How tired Bob Dylan must be to hear of young performers compared to him, and how tired young performers must be to encounter that totemic invocation. Nonetheless, Steve Forberta 22-year-old folk singer who will be at Kenny's Castaways, 157 Bleecker Street, through tomorrow and at the Other End Monday nightis the next new Bob Dylan. He is also the next new Elvis Presley and the next new Rod Stewart.

description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2-The United States and Mexico today signed their first commercial agreement since 1942, signaling not only an improvement in relations between the two countries but also an important advance in the latest round of multilateral trade negotiations in Geneva.

title: 2 HANGED IN BERMUDA; BLACK RIOT QUELLED
description: HAMILTON, Bermuda, Dec. 2Two convicted murderers were hanged at dawn here today, the Government announced, after a night of riots by blacks protesting the British colony's first executions in 30 years.

title: Notes on People
description: Lieut. Gov. Lowell Thomas Jr., son of the commentator, apologized to all Alaskans who may have been offended by his recent remark that racial intermarriage was against nature. Mr. Thomas said that the remark, made before the Alaska Black Caucus last week, revealed a shortcoming in my personal attitude which I will endeavor to overcome. The Lieutenant Governor said he found it difficult to explain to himself why he could have uttered such sentiments, since he said he Intervened with prison authorities only last year to enable a black prisoner and his white finance to marry. So why my offhand remark a week ago that intermarriage of blacks and whites bothers me? he asked. I really cannot say, except that it must have represented a prejudice rooted in my childhood that, frankly, I was not even aware of. After Mr. Thomas's original remarks, there were widespread demands that he

title: RETROACTIVE TAX ASKED ON SASKATCHEWAN OIL
description: OTTAWA, Dec. 2A bill to put a retroactive tax on income from oil wells in Saskatchewan, replacing an earlier levy that was ruled unconstitutional by the Supreme Court of Canada last week, was introduced in the provincial Liegislature today. Passage of the measure, which is virtually assured by the Government's majority in the Legislature, will relieve the province of having to repay more than half a billion to drilling comp under the same Supreme Court decision.

title: 2 Slain by Argentine Terrorists
description: BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 2 (UPI)Terroristsfired their submachine guns at a car in which three bodyguards of a Chrysler executive were riding today, killing two of the men and wounding the other. Gunfire and firebomb attacks on Ford, Chrysler and MercedesBenz dealerships were also reported. The precise motive for the attacks could not be determined.

description: QUEBEC, Dec. 2Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau and Premier Rene Levesque met in private for the first time today and agreed to cooperate on economic problems despite their continuing political differences.

title: Professor Longhair: Mythic Music
description: Professor Longhair, the New Orleans pianist and originator of rhumba blues who made one of his infrequent New York appearances at New York University on Friday night, is a figure of truly mythic proportions. It is significant that in an era when myths are manufactured by the yardin the music field, almost anyone with a recording contract can buy onethe Professor does not record for anyone. In fact, only one album of his work has been released in the United States, even though his career has spanned three decades. his imitators are many, and at least one major record company owns the rights to a superb Professor Longhair album that it has not chosen to release.

title: A Gingerly Approach to the Steel Bind

It cannot minimize the political impact of major steel plant closings in such Democratic strongholds as Youngstown, Ohio, and Buffalo. Yet it does not want to come down so heavily on imports as to invite retaliation in major American markets abroad.

The writers were sleeping a sleep five thousand years old.

title: IN BRIEF
description: Wall Street won a reprieve when the Securities and Exchange Commission deferred the abolition of the remaining exchange restrictions on offboard trading. The restrictions, embodied principally in the New York Stock Exchange's Rule 390, forbid member firms to trade listed stocks anywhere but on the exchange floor and to act as broker for both buyer and seller in the same transaction.
