description: SALT LAKE CITY, Dec. 3 (UPI)A crosscountry skier dug his two friends out of an avalanche and the three men were rescued yesterday by a helicopter pilot, the authorities said today. Deputy Sheriff Al Casto said Allen Murphy, 25 years old, dug out Larry Daum, and Joe Holland, bath 26, after the avalanche occurred.

title: Earth Tremors Shake Kamchatka
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 3 (Reuters)Strong earth tremors shook the Kamchatka Peninsula on the Soviet Union's Pacific coast early today the press agency Tess reported. The epicenter of the tremors, measuring 5 points on the 12-point Soviet scale, lay 60 miles offshore in the Pacific Ocean. Tess said.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: Fantasy. This fall, it seems, has been a time when millions of Americans were anxious to get out of the real world. During the past six months they've paid over $120 million to see Star Wars,'!..a movie about faraway times and places, more money for any film in historyand are snatching up 3,671,712 copies of a novelization of it. They're making hardcover best sellers of books about gnomes, pixies, hobbits and other Middleearth creatures. They're grabbing up large quantities of albums by such fantasy illustrators as Frank Frazetta. They're buying 600,000 copies of the 1978 Tolkien Calendar; in the past, half that number would have been considered a great sale. Lester del Rey, who's spent the past 25 years as a writer, editor and publisher of fantasy and its close sister, science fiction, says that there's never been a season like it.

title: Suspect, 25, Held In Stabbing Death Of Boy, 16, on L.I.

description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 3What Fifth Avenue is to New York and the Miracle Mile of North Michigan Avenue is to Chicago the Country Club Plaza is to Kansas City. When it was badly damaged by flood two and a half months ago, many who surveyed the wreckage wondered if it would ever come back.

title: At 70, Sculpture Is a Way of Life For Gina Schimel
description: JERSEY CITY IN HER 90's, she was a seamstress. In her 50's, she was a widow, working to make ends meet. She was remarried before she was 60, and now, as she turns 70, she is making her way in the New York art world.

title: EUROPE
description: N England politics remain in poor taste, they do not invade literary life. If our writers vote at all they do so in silince, and when our politicians publish a book no one mistakes it for literature. In other European countries they are not so coy: Writers make a great show of their party allegiances, and politicians long to be thought cultured rather than effective. That anyway is the tradition, but it could be changing. There are signs now that the mainland is failing into step, that writers there are losing faith or interest in public matters and asserting instead the rights and fascinations of private ones.

He visited Southern Yemen, Saudi Arabia, Egypt, the Sudan and the United Arab Emirates. The tour of Arab countries was his second in three months and the first since Somalia broke relations with the Soviet Union and Cuba.

Chapman of Bloomfield Hills, Mich., to Randolph John Strech, son of Mr. and Mrs. Fritz W. Streoh of Birmingham, Mich. The Rev. Lewis W. Towler performed the ceremony.

title: HIGHLIGHTS
description: The red ink in America's foreign trade accounts deepened in October when the nation recorded its largest monthly trade deficit in history. Although special factors accounted for much of the unusually large shortfall, announced last week by the Commerce Department, it highlighted the continuing imbalances in the international economy that are fueling protectionist pressures.

title: WIFEBEATING DENIED BY MAN IN COMA CASE
description: John Maniscalco yesterday denied allegations that he had frequently beaten his wife, Rosemarie, a 27-year-old pregnant woman who has been in a coma since Nov. 23, but he acknowledged having exchanged blows with her in a fight last July.

The ceremony was, performed by the Rev. Jack Schutte.

title: PEOPLE
description: Historically the watchers of other people's money, accountants have lately been urging their corporate clients to provide more and more information to the public while remaining closemouthed about their own finances. The veil is gradually lifting, however, and last week a new nugget of information came to light.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: NEGOTIATIONS have failed once again, as they do almost every year at this time. The nub of the problem is the heap of withering leaves that are cluttering the little patio. They are soggy today, a dead and lumpy giant wad that gives no clue to the recent past, when they went out in a blaze of beauty and color. But the mourning period has long since passed, and it is time that the leaves were decently interred.

title: Protesters Disrupt Appearance By Australia's Prime Minister
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 3 (AP)About 200 demonstrators booed and hurled eggs, ice and rolledup newspapers ??? Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser at an ejection rally here today. Australia won both opening singles yesterday and leads the three-of-fivematch final by 21.

The new party will start fresh and clean, said John M. Couture, chairman of the executive board cf the National Organization of State Conservative Parties. About 50 persons from 15 states had registered by last night for a threeday convention to organize the new party.

Like the policeman and the doctor, like the soldier and the sailor in moments of national eerily but unlike most of us, he is responsible for the very lives of the members of his community.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: God is Brazilian, the citizens of Rio de Janeiro will say. In Bali, at the other end of the world, such thoughts are expressed somewhat differently. The Balinese are immensely sorry for anyone who has had the misfortune to be born outside of Bali, writes Xenia Zarina, the Western author of a primer on Classic Dances of the Orient.

title: Alone at Montauk: Sand and Solitude
description: The rattle of blowing sand on a Marlboro wrapper. The hiss of gray surf boiling over the beach. The silence of a strange feathered thing halfburied in a dune. Offseason Montauk can be the sound of one hand clapping, a deafening quiet that jars the senses, reawakening an interloper to unremembered music, sea sounds, sand scratchings and the rushing of the wind. It can also be a place of public pleasuresfishing parties, dockside taverns and crowded seafood restaurants.

title: The World
description: The outcome of South Africa's election last week was never in doubt. The only question was how large the ruling Nationalist Party's majority would be. The answer: bigger than ever. For the country's 4.4 million whites, the election was also an exercise in defiance, a way of showing the rest of the world and themselves that they, in Prime Minister John Vorster's words, are willing to fight to the end rather than share power with South Africa's 18.6 million blacks.

title: Pravda Points Up Continuing Soviet Problems in Providing Goods That Are in Demand

title: Snake on Endangered List

The species, the Atlantic salt marsh snake, lives in brackish and salt water habitats on Florida's Atlantic Coast. The main threat to the snake is from the continued destruction of its habitat by development.

title: BRIDGE
description: The idea that duplicate bridge is a game in which luck plays no part is a popular misconception. It is true that the luck of the deal is eliminated, since your partnership or team is matching wits with others with equal opportunities. But luck takes other forms. Most players are oblivious of good luck, considering it their just due, but they are keenly aware of bad luck.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: Add Jacob Druckman to the list of American composers currently in full flight from academic serialism, and quite voluble about it. It aLmost seems de rigueur these days for a composer to issue a manifesto to the effect that he will have nothing to do with the bad old days. Thus when Mr. Druckman's Chiaroscuro was given its premiere by the New York Philharmonic a few weeks ago, he went on record as saying that he wanted to reestablish the element of communication between composer and listener. Whether or not he succeeded in Chiaroscuro is a debatable point. There were those listeners who felt, to invert John Milton's phrase, that new priest was but old presbyter writ large. Mr. Druckman could not entirely break away from his roots of the 1960's. But the very fact that he has disavowed totally organized music and all its offshoots makes him still another of that large band unhappy with the music of the immediate past and very concerned about its future.

title: New Pragmatism Dictates Freer Election in Taiwan

But when the Ambassador began shooting pictures from a traffic overpass near the Nationalist Government headquarters, a policeman grabbed his camera and escorted him to a nearby police station. The police were not impressed with Mr. Unger's credentials, and the Ambassador was only released after the director of the Government Information Office personally intervened.

title: 37 Percent of Canada's People Termed Functional Illiterates

People aged 65 and over were found to be 61 percent functionally illiterate, those 20 to 24 were 14 percent illiterate and those 15 to 19 were 22 percent illiterate.

title: Headliners
description: To be attacked by Ralph Nader can be unpleasant. TO be attacked by Ralph Nader when you once were his chief lobbyist is, some would say, a form of excommunication from the consumer movement. But Joan Claybrook, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administrator, said she was proud of her record and she tossed aside Mr. Nader's demand last week that she resign. Her former close friend accused her of a failure of nerve, supposedly by compromising her beliefs on auto and highway safety since joining the Administration earlier this year. The proper course, he said, was to resign and then to instruct others on how to avoid pitfalls in Government service. Miss Claybrook replied that she intended to honor her pledge to stay on for four years.

title: MUSIC AND DANCE
description: Opera, though ideally a fusion of music and drama, is always struggling to escape from the death grip of one or the other. Since World War II, with the proliferation of opera houses and the resultant scarcity of major voices, it is dramaturgy that has had the hammerlock on this nearly 400-year-old art form. Rudolf Hartmann's luxuriously produced volume testifies to that on every page. Mr. Hartmann, for many years intendant of the Bavarian State Opera in Munich and a director of note, wanted this book to be a comprehensive study of how an opera production comes into being, at least from the staging standpoint. Essays on various aspects of their craft are provided by directors such as Gunther SchneiderSiemssen, JeanPierre Ponnelle and Hans Hartleb. A history of European stage design is given by Heinz Bruno Gallee, and there are brief biographies of 62 currently or recently active regisseurs, with a heavy emphasis on Europeans. as could be expected. An appendix offers vital

title: If You Go
description: to Montauk from midtown Manhattan, take the Long Island Expressway to Exit 70 (Manorville), follow signs south to Sunrise Highway (Route 27) and continue east to Montauk. The Long Island Rail Road goes there, too; Montauk is the end of the line. About 15 of Montauk's approximately 80 inns and motels, including the wellknown Guerney's and the posh Yacht Club and Inn, stay open all year. The Chamber of Commerce offers a list of accommodations, obtainable by writing Box CC Montauk, N.Y. 11954 or phoning 516-668-2428. Even in winter, reservations are advisable. Several leading restaurants, including Bill's Inn, the Blue Marlin and Lakeside Inn, also remain open yearround. Although Montauk in winter is said to be 10 degrees warner than the city, thanks to the moderating Gulf Stream, the wind can be fierce, so take along warm clothes, and take sunglasses, for the sun on  the beach is blinding.

title: AGORAPHOBIA LIFE RULED BY PANIC
description: Agoraphobia? Fifteen years ago the word meant nothing to most people. Certainly it meant nothing to the college girl about to sled down the hill in Vermont. As a cold wind hit the hill, she stood holding her chin, looking back at the house in the distance. Her friends heard her mutter somethingthat she had snow in her boot, or needed the bathroom  some such lie. Then she began to run, looking down at the snow. She couldn't look at the house, it seemed too far away. She started to sweat and her legs went soft. She could not feel her feet, but they were running. Her heart was pounding, her face flushed. She began to pant. She felt as though she were coming apart, as if she had been running forever through the syrupy snow of a nightmare. Six Miltowns rattled against four Valiums in her pocket. The sweat on her body tripped triggers in her brain; the adrenaline signaled the nerves to further panic. What if I die? she thought. Oh, my God, I'm going crazy. Then she was at the house, the safe place. But she had added more fears to an already long list. She was afraid of snow. She was afraid of hills. And, above all, she was afraid of ever again feeling the way she did running hill in Vermont.

title: Noo Yawk. Oh, Man. Noo Yawk.
description: It was close to midnight. The car had broken down and my son and walked about two miles to our home. This was in East Northport, L. I., and most of the walk took place along Larkfield Road, a main drag given over to markets, bars, pizza places and gas stations. During the day, Larkfield Road is about as interesting as a paper towel. At night, it was ominous a street on which we were intensely aware of our own footsteps and prone to view the two or three people we passed with suspicion rather than welcome. About five blocks from home, a patrol car passed and the cop offered us a lift. We accepted; we were glad to see him.

title: CONFESSIONS OF AN AMERICAN GURU

II is a story that up to now has been told merely in part, and then only in smallcirculation movement journals. It's about his being fired from Harvard, in the 60's, for giving hallucinogens to undergraduates and lying to the administration about it, only to rise to a position of nearsainthood as a guru to the New Age Generation. It's about his most recent fall.

title: The Great Berman Controversy And Other Liszt Interpreters
description: Lazar Berman has become a lightning rod, attracting bolts of blinding praise as well as criticism searing enough to take the skin off a brass monkey. We have been urged to believe, IT inflamed publicists, that the 47-year-old Soviet pianist is Horowitz, Rubinstein, Rachmaninoff and the reincarnation of Franz Liszt all wrapped up in one chunky, bearded package. Skeptics argue conversely that he is a soulless clod with five thumbs on each hand. Caught between such remarkably conflicting opinions, what is the poor uncommitted music listener to do? .

title: TV VIEW
description: T elevision's curious and often careless habit blurring the delicate lines between fact and fiction and between classics and adaptations has been sharply illustrated by a number of recent shows. The boundaries of dramatic license were stretched in The Trial of Lee Harvey Oswald. Oswald was not killed by Jack Ruby but instead was brought to trial for the assassination of John F. Kennedy. Selective facts were then presented objectively, but the performances and direction left no doubt that Oswald was guilty and was used as a dupe in a conspiracy involving the C.I.A. or the F.B.I. or Cuban exilesor any combination of the three. This type of interpretive propagandizing is hardly new to television entertainment, but the Kennedy assassination remains an emotionally charged event, and the program triggered widespread questioning from critics and audiences.

title: Bomb Explodes, Injuring 6, In the Old City of Jerusalem

Two West German tourists, three Israeli Jews and one Arab were treated at hospitals.

title: Gypsy Moths Spare State's Trees
description: FOR the first time since the 1940's, Connecticut is finishing a year without any measurable signs of gypsy moth infestation. Despite the fact that the leafeating gypsy moth caterpillars ate well in the Northeast this year, causing nearly twice the damage that they did last year, there were no reports of defoliation of trees in the state, according to a survey by the United States Department of Agriculture.

title: Today's Punks Make the Old Punks Sound Mellow
description: Not so long ago, almost any kid who brandished an electric guitar was a punk. The term had less to do with music than with the attitued behind itan insolence dating back to Presley's sneer. But the emergence over the past couple of years of a distinct genre or pop music labeled punk rock (or new wave) has called everyone's bluff. Bruce Springsteen, for example, has played the role of a swaggering rebel for several years, but his bravado pales beside the insurrection of geniune punk rockers like England's Sex Pistols, whose first single, Anarchy in the U.K., ended with a snarling exhortalion to Destroy, Graham Parker stands pugnaciously at the microphone, grsturing will) Jabs and clenching his body in a boxer's half crouch, but he's a paper tiger compared to the Dead Boys, who have actually brawled with New York audiences. The punk rock of the Ramones is such an assault, so relentlessly loud and breakneck, that it can make the rock-and-rull of a group like Southside Johnny and the Asbury Jukes seem nambypamby.

title: Sandra Zeeman, an Actress, Wed to Stephen Boccieri Jr.

title: What's Doing in the VIRGIN ISLANDS
description: ATMOSPHERE-The United States Virgin Islands are a mixture of tropical suspension of time, spectacular scenery (above water and below), an utterly salubrious climate and occasional bouts with Murphy's Law. It's a place where a sense of humor helps and a slightly hedonistic approach to life never hurt anyone. In short, if you appreciate Provincetown, Greenwich Village, Key West and a bit of Colonial Williamsburg, you might feel at home in these outpostsSt. Thomas, St. Croix and St. Johnnext door to Puerto Rico.

title: ENGLAND
description: HE best illustration of what is happening in English letters at the moment may be found in the chorus of derision that greeted John Fowles's new novel Daniel Martin on its English appearance in October. The book had been hailed in America as little short of a masterpiece. The New York Times Book Review suggested that It must be judged his best piece of work; Saturday Review pronounced that Fowles was the only writer in English who has the power, range, knowledge and wisdom of a Tolstoy or James. Its English reception was not uniformly abusive, but the contrast was sufficiently marked for The Times of Londonone of the few newspapers that had treated the book respectfullyto publish a long second article comparing its reception on the two continents. Various explanations for this phenomenon can be offered. Many novelists suspect a conspiracy among reviewerswhen I wrote novels, I was not immune from such a suspicion myselfbut, having been regular weekly novel reviewer now for seven years, can assure them that no such conspiracy exists. English novel reviewers never meet and seldom even know each other.

description: The Christmas tree in Rockefeller Center stands in its scaffolding, an early signal that the holiday season is at hand. Department store sales of gifts are booming. The children's lists of things desired are in final prepa ration. At a time when so many bask in the warmth of giving and receivingtangible evidence of being loved, remembered, cared forthose who dwell outside good fortune's circle suffer grievously. Their want is made more poignant by loneliness, their pain more sharp by the sense of being forgotten.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: CHICAGOThe postThanksgiving snowfall and drop in temperatures in this and other parts of the Middle West served as a grim reminder of last winter's adversities but failed to dim the fairly optimistic expectations that persist here both for the national economy and the region's business activity next year.

title: IN AMERICA
description: NEW YORK. The Loew's Paradise still stands on the Grand Concourse near Fordham Road, but now that its rococo interior has been carved into three small moviehouses, its glory days as a landmark in the Bronx can be only a memory. it means something to me, however, because I graduated from the place. It was my second commencement in a movie theater. The first had been in the much less distinguished Riviera Theater on Broadway and 97 Street, so the Paradise seemed a definite step up, just as the Bronx High School of Science had seemed a definite step up from Booker T. Washington Junior High. I don't remember specifically but I'm sure we were told on graduation day that life would be like thatone step upward after anotherfor we were constantly reminded that we had been certified and chosen as gifted and special'; that, therefore, our horizons wereand of right ought to beboundless. I'm reasonably sure also that no one that June morning saw fit to comment or even reflect on the astounding racial homogeneity of the class. And yet we were the class of 1954, graduating only a few weeks after the Supreme Court handed down its decision in Brown v. Board of Education.

title: ART VIEW
description: The magazine Artnews, with the two parts of its familiar name now conjoined into a single word, is currently observing the 75th anniversary of its founding, and to mark this event it has just brought out a hefty, 459page anthology of critical essays, reviews, interviews, memoirs, news items and miscellaneous writings drawn from its own pagesThe Art World, edited by Barbaralee Diamonstein, with introductory essays by Harold Rosenberg and Richard F. Shepard (Rizzoli, $29.95 until Dec. 31; $35 thereafter). It has also brought out a special 75thanniversary number of the magazine itself ($2.50). Taken together, these publications offer us quite a lot to read and to think about, and naturally invite some reflection on the ways in which the art world (including the world of art journalism) has and has not changed since the relatively placid day when Hyde's Weekly Art News-the original name of the journal-first appeared.

This collection of picture books about distant places eliminates such pitfalls. The large, handsome volumes are all clean and odorless, speak English and, despite their high prices, you can buy them all for less than it costs to fly from New York to Tegucigalpa. There is no frigate like a book. . . . as the poet says.

title: Food; ...Something Completely Different
description: Classic French cooking is, almost by definition, unchanging. However, though most of the basic procedures of the French kitchen had been laid down for posterity by the time Auguste Escoffier died in 1935, it is still possible to come up with new and innovative ideas simply by experimenting with the old, familiar rules. Some years ago when we added hazelnuts to a basic cheesecake and printed the recipe, our readers responded appreciatively. Lora Brody, who has a catering business in and around Wellesley, Mass., wrote to tell us that when a friend wanted something to equal that cheesecake, but different, she substituted some ginger for the hazelnuts and the

title: Hall and Oates Sing White Soul At Palladium
description: It is likely that the first time black music was heard in North America, a white musician listened and tried to imitate what he heard. As black and white American cultures did their dance of alternating embraces and estrangements over the decades and centuries, there were always white imitators, from the earliest blackface minstrels to the allwhite Original Dixieland Jazz Band to the white bluesmen of the 1920's, and on down to the present.

Many seem designed more to dazzle their occupants than to enrich them spiritually, as if their architects feared that worshipers would lose interest in religion otherwise.

Case's bid for a fifth term in 1978. He figures his campaign will cost $1,600,000 to $1,800,000.

title: Patriots Edge Falcons, Keep Playoff Hopes Alive
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 4The New England Patriots remained alive in their struggle for a position in the National Football League's postseason playoffs today while the Atlanta Falcons chances were dealt a severe setback. New final quarter, a drive that had in it the to an 89yard touchdown drive in the England won a close game, 160, thanks kind of big play that so often decides these tight N.F.L. contests late in the season.

title: Music: Gerhard Oppitz in Debut
description: The New York debut of Gerhard Oppitz Saturday night at Alice Tully Hall brought together a diverse crowd. Mr. Oppitz is a German pianist who won the Arthur Rubinstein Competition in Israel six months ago. His fiveconcert American debut tour began on Nov. 22 in Pasadena, Calif., and ended in New York. It was sponsored by the Ambassador International Cultural Foundation, a lavishly ambitious philanthropic organization based in Pasadena and allied with a fundamentalist Protestant Christian sect.

title: Coal Talks Recess With a Strike At Midnight Apparently Inevitable
description: WASHINGTON. Dec. 4 (AP)Industry and union negotiators bargained for several hours today on a new coal contract but apparently failed to reach agreement on any major issue.

title: 3 Children Die in an Upstate Fire After Apparently Lighting Match
description: Three children were killed in a fire in Phoenix, N.Y., near Syracuse, early yesterday morning. The police said the fire might have started when one of the children lighted a match during a search for hidden Christmas presents.

title: Afghans Juggle Aid Donors in Effort to Join Modern World
description: KABUL, AfghanistanThrough the efforts of a forwardlooking Government and a vigorous though tiny intellectual elite, modern ways are coming to this ancient and primitive country at the gateway to South Asia.

title: Concert Is Tribute To Lazar Weiner
description: There can be little doubt that the deft, deeply felt songs of Lazar Weiner, 14 of which were performed at yesterday afternoon's birthday tribue to the 80yearold composer at the 92d Street Y.M.Y.W.H.A., would be better, known were the texts, not in Yiddish. Atthe same time, it is a pointless hypothesis, for the passionate conviction and resillient irony of the music are obviously anchored in, the sound of the language and the world of experience it evokes. The Russiaribom Mr. Weiner, who for decades served as music director of New York's Central Synagogue, says as much in Mayn Sprach, his 1976 setting .of a poem by I, Papernikov.

title: 4 Killed in Arizona Lodge
description: ELFRIDA, Ariz., Dec. 4 (UPI)Four persons were found shot to death today near this ranching community in southeastern Arizona, the Cochise County sheriff's department reported. Sheriff's deputies said the bodies of three men and a woman were found at the Cochise Lodge and Guest Ranch. They said the victims all lived in the area but their identities were being withheld.

title: Behind Windows, Christmas Fantasies
description: If New York has a season when one can forgive it all its drawbacks, it's Christmas, when the city lights up and glitterslike miles of jewelsthrough the air pollution. The best theater in town comes free, courtesy of the merchants, and the holiday season is not complete without a viewing of the department stores dazzling efforts in display windows.

title: BRISK RISE REPORTED IN DOMESTIC DEMAND BY STEEL PRODUCERS

title: Insko, a Harness Driver, Is Injured at Roosevelt

title: Mobotu Reelected in Zaire
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, Dec. 4 (Reuters)President Mobutu Sese Seko was today officially proclaimed Zaire's head of state for a further term as preSident by the Supreme Court, the official press agency reported. The only candidate in last Friday's elections, President Mobutu won 98.16 per cent of votes cast for leadership of the ruling Popular Movement for the Revolution.

title: 15Month Snarl Checks Sanitation Law Enforcers
description: In the last 15 months, 133 city sanitation workers have been promoted to higherpaying jobs with authority as special patrolmen to issue summonses for parking, health and sanitary violations. But thanks to a bureaucratic mixup, the little army of inspectors has yet to issue a single summons.

title: Sabres 6, Red Wings 1
description: BUFFALO, Dec. 4 (AP)Gil Perreault and Rick Martin each scored twice, pacing the Buffalo Sabres to a 61 victory over the Detroit Red Wings tonight in a National Hockey League game.

title: BRITISH TROOPS LAND IN UNEASY BERMUDA
description: HAMILTON, Bermuda, Dec. 4Battleclad British soldiers landed on this Atlantic resort island tonight, where fresh plywood has been tacked up over pink, blue and yellow storefronts in the wake of three days of racial unrest.

title: DE GUSTIBUS
description: When in the course of enswering a reader inquiry about haggis, conceivably the national dish of Scotland, we diSmissed the dish with a brief paragraph, including a general outline of the ingredients. The response to the coluMn was impressive.

title: GAS POTENTIAL ASSESSED FOR APPALACHIAN SHALE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (AP)As much as 1,000 billion cubic feet of gas a yearabout 5 percent of current national production levelscould be proyided in future years from shale rock in the Appalachians, according to a study released today, by the Congressional Office of Technology Assessment.

title: Qaddafi Takes Hard Line on Israel
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4Col. Muammnar elQaddafi of Libya took an extremely hardline position today on the Palestinian issue, saying in effect that Israel had no right to a separate existence and that Jews should live there only as citizens of Palestine.

title: Fate of Sunken Alexander Hamilton Rests in Raising Funds
description: ATLANTIC HIGHLANDS, N.J.  The Alexander Hamilton, the last of the grand old sidewheel steamboats that plied the Hudson River, is dying a slow death in 16 feet of water at the end of a Navy pier here, the victim of six years of frustrated dreams to restore the boat's original grandeur and of ravaging seas that partly sank her early last month.

title: TV: Violence
description: Moderately wealthy and pleasantly aging into baldness and weight problems, Ira Davidoff lives in Los Angeles and writes scripts for television. One of his world premiere movies has a series of fires in the central plot.

title: Crash Kills Trooper In Way Father Died
description: FRANKLIN, Dec. 4 (UPI)An offduty state trooper was killed in a weekend traffic accident, 16 years after his father, also a state trooper, died in a similar highway accident.

title: Koch Cautiously Praises Proposal For a Restructured Schools Board
description: A plan to let a restructured Board of Education share in picking the person who would run New York City's schools Won cautious praise yesterday from Mayorelect Edward I. Koch.

title: Mrs. Lambert Draws Criticism Over FundRaising Party for Her
description: A month ago, Marie M. Lambert became the first woman elected Surrogate in Manhattan, and three weeks ago she celebrated her 57th birthday. So yesterday some of her friends gave a $250aperson birthday party to help make a dent in reducing the campaign deficit of nearly $175,000.

title: 9 Women to Start Detective Classes For Homicide Squad
description: Nine women investigators will begin training today for their assignment to the New York City Police Department's now allmale elite homicide investigation squads.

title: After Criticism,HarvardActs To Improve Teaching Quality
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 1In response to longstanding complaints by its own students and changing conditions in the academic world, Harvard University has initiated a campaign to improve the quality of its undergraduate teaching.

title: United Way of TriState Expecting 15% 1 Increase in Funds Collected
description: The United Way of TriState, in its first effort as a collecting organization for 1,000 private humancare agencies in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, is doing so well that it will probably end its drive in February with about 15 percent more than the $60 million raised separately by its member agencies in 1976

title: Bokassa Crowns Himself Emperor In Rich Central African Pageant
description: BANGUI, Central African Empire, Dec. 4 (Reuters)JeanBedel Bokassa, once a French colonial soldier, today crowned himself Bokassa I, Emperor of the Central African Empire, in a sports stadium on the edge of the jungle.

title: FIVE WAYS TO SALT AWAY A LITTLE SOMETHING, TAX FREE.
description: You may be aware of the tax benefits of Keogh retirement plans. But are you aware that your money grows faster or slower depending on how you invest it? The Personal Financial Management Division at Citibank can help you create a Keogh retirement plan balanced to fit your investment objectives. Here's how.

title: U.S. Will Back Renovation of 10 Buildings in Harlem
description: Ten partly abandoned buildings on West 135th Street will be renovated and a group of Harlem residents will be given improved living quarters, thanks to a $7.9 million mortgageinsurance commitment from the Department of Housing and Urban Development.

title: Not That Job, Thanks
description: The other day, Joe B. was offered a job pumping gas for $92 a week. He is 30, unskilled, and unemployed. He turned down the job. Similarly, Linda K. turned down a receptionist's job paying $130 a week. She is 25, has a bachelor's degree in history, is unskilled and unemployed.

title: Cleansing the Cosmetic Laws
description: It's enough to make the hair turn gray. A debate over the possibility that some hair dyes may contain a dangerous ingredient has revealed a dangerous loophole Federal law. Even if every expert in the country agreed that the dyes present a major hazard, the Government would be powerless to remove them from the market.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: The Tiniest Ham
description: Go almost anywhere in the suburbs or the country now, even to the edge of a city park if there is a bird feeder nearby, and you will see chickadees.

title: Buffalo Yacht Club Opens Rolls in Face of Bias Suit
description: BUFFALO, Dec. 4The Buffalo Yacht Club has opened its membership to Jews, blacks and women, thus ending a threat that it might be evicted from the cityowned property that it occupies virtually rentfree.

title: Seattle Stadium Suit a Legal Test on Cost Overruns
description: SEATTLEA legal battle between King County and the construction company that built part cf the enclosed Kingdome Stadium here could determine whether local governments will ever be able to control the cost of major construction projects.

title: Agnes de Mille: Encounter With Wisdom
description: It was a matter or catcning wisdom on the wingwisdom and. tartness and hauteur and a sudden blunt intimacy that made your head snap back. I'm speaking of a single evening offered a few weeks ago at City Center, an evening sponsored by the Joftrey Ballet along with Agnes de Mille's American Heritage Theater and an evening devoted to dance in general and Miss de Mille in particular.

title: Advertising
description: You really have to put your ego aside, said Carlo Vittorini, president of Charter Publishing and publisher of Redbook.

title: Fanfares and Opera by the Bagful at Met Bazaar
description: Twas three weeks before Christmas and all through the Metropolitan Opera Housein the orchestra, parterre, grand tier and dresscircle lobbiesthousands of musiclovers shopped their way through a crowd scene as festive as the Act II opening in La Boheme.

title: Servomation Chief Identifies 2 Buyers
description: Shareholders of Servomation Corporation have been approached by Allen & Co., Inc., a securities firm, which is seeking to buy shares in the diversified food and beverage vending machine company with annual sales of $411 million, it was disclosed yesterday.

title: Andre Eglevsky, Dancer, Is Dead; Was Called Greatest Classicist
description: Andre Eglevsky, often acclaimed as the greatest male classical dancer of his generation, died yesterday afternoon of a heart attack. He was in Elmira, N.Y. with his company which was to perform his staging of The Nutcracker.

title: SALE OF LANCE STOCK TIED TO S.E.C. INQUIRY
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4Negotiations for the sale of Bert Lance's 200,767 shares of stock in the National Bank of Georgia hinge on whether the former budget director will be allowed to take an active part in its management, according to sources familiar with the transaction.

title: PateStacy Takes Golf by Shot on LastHole Birdie
description: LARGO, Fla., Dec. 4Ah well, that's show business. One team catches the leaders on the 17th hole, and then the leaders birdie the 18th hole today to win the Mixed Team Championship.

title: Recital: Cellist
description: Barney Lehrer, whose New York recital debut took place Saturday night at Carnegie Recital Hall, is a young cellist whose teachers have included Leonard Rose and Paul Tortelier. He has also studied at the Vienna Academy of Music and taught at the University of Sao Paulo.

title: Job Bias Cases Challenge Plans Favoring Blacks
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4A confrontation over favored employment treatment for minority groups, an issue potentially much broader than the heated dispute over admissions to professional schools, is taking shape in the Federal courts.

title: Carter's Gettysburg Address
description: Exactly two hundred and one years, five months and one day ago, our forefathersand our foremothers, too, as my wife, the First Lady, reminds me our highly competent Founding Persons brought forth on this land mass a new nation, or entity, dreamed up in liberty and dedicated to the comprehensive program of insuring that all of us are created with the same basic human rights.

title: College Teacher Triumphs Over 2,000 in Shore Marathon
description: ASBURY PARK, Dec. 4Under a bright blue sky, Bill Sieben of Rahway ran 26 miles and 385 yards yesterday to win the seventh annual Jersey Shore Marathon in the record time of 2 hours 18 minutes. The victor, an environmental science teacher at Middlesex County College, led a field of more than 2,000.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: STARDUST The New York Opera Club, a thriving membership group of devotees, regularly is host to informal visits by operatic celebrities, with interviews, questionandanswer sessions and mingling over wines or cocktails and food. Door admissions at $6.50 are still available for today's meeting at 28 East 35th Street, in the art gallery of the Community Church.

title: REV. H. KERR TAYLOR
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., Dec. 4 (AP)The Rev. H. Kerr Taylor of Atlanta, an author and missionary, died here today. He was 86 years old.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: Federal Judge Holds a Meeting On Cleyeland's School Dispute
description: CLEVELAND, Dec. 4 (APP)Attorneys for parties involved in the financial tangle that has kept the Cleveland school system from meeting its payroll met privately at a Federal judge's home today to prepare for a hearing this week.

title: Issue and Debate
description: In 1975, a young law student at Georgetown University believed that the Federal Reserve had no right to keep secret its monetary policy directives. He sued the Fed and won.

title: ARAB MEETING FAILS TO FORGE JOINT FRONT AGAINST SADAT MOVES
description: TRIPOLI, Libya, Monday, Dec. 5The summit meeting of hardline Arab countries failed here early today to achieve its principal aim of a strong united front against the peace initiative taken by President Anwar elSadat of Egypt when a key participant, Iraq, walked out.

description: HAMILTON, Bermuda, Dec. 4British soldiers in battle dress landed on this Atlantic resort island tonight, where fresh plywood has been tacked up over pink, blue and yellow storefronts in the wake of three days of racial unrest.

title: Crime in New York city: Specialists Are Looking to New Deputy Mayor fok Solutions
description: People in New York think about crime a lot. They think. about it when they are riding in elevators, when they are walking dOwn the street by themselves, when they'are standing on lonely subway platforms and when they read their newspapers. Legislators and other elected officials attest to the Urban fact that many of their conAffairs stituents want sharp, hard solutions, such as capital punishment or heavy penalties for crimes against the elderly.

title: British Firemen's Strike in 4th Week
description: LONDON, Dec. 4 (UPI)The strike by Britain's 35,000 firefighters entered its fourth week today, and union leaders predicted it would last through the Christmas holidays, a peak fire period. The Government showed no sign of backing down on its antiinflation program to hold pay increases to 10 percent, and the firefighters appeared determined to get a 30 percent raise.

title: Central African FatherChief
description: How does an African leader build a nation from a patchwork of tribal lands, separated by language, custom and animosities but bound together by a colonial power for the convenience of its administrators? The task has been tried by army commanders, despots and wily politicians but nowhere with more panache than in the heart of Africa by the man who yesterday crowned himself Emperor Bokaisa I.

title: News Summary
description: MONDAY, DECEMBER 5, 1977

title: New Hurdles for Vietnam Boat People
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 4At both ends of their perilous journeys across the South China Sea, Vietnamese boat people are finding new obstacles, but still they keep coming.

title: 30 ISRAELI JOURNALISTS WILL COVER EGYPT TALKS
description: TEL AVIV, Dec. 4Egypt announced today that a total of 30 Israeli correspondents, photographers and television and radio technicians would be admitted to the country to cover the political talks scheduled for later this week.

title: Giants Upset Cards, 277; Rams Stun Raiders, Win Division Title
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 4Customarily criticized for being dull while being successful, the Los Angeles Rams used a 43yard touchdown pass with 2 minutes 10 seconds to play to beat the Oakland Raiders today, 2014, and clinch their fifth straight title in the National Conference's Western Division.

title: Regional Bands at Bottom Line
description: The San Francisco and Boston areas both boast strong regional music scenes, and both are suffused with a good deal of selfrighteousness that they represent untrammeled purity as opposed to the commercial cynicism of New York and Los Angeles. Two bands that have worked in both San Francisco and Boston/Cambridge appeared Friday and Saturday at the Bottom Line. Each made smooth, appealing and sometimes even original music. But if your criterion for a good time at a club is lively, spontaneous energy, they seemed a little safe, settled and slick.

title: Town's Voters to Pick Officials Who Don't Run
description: TAYLORSVILLE, Ga., Dec. 4 (AP)The voters will go to the polls Tuesday to elect a mayor and two aldermen. No candidates are on the ballot, but no one seems worried.

title: Ethiopian Labor Leader Slain
description: LONDON, Dec. 4 (Reuters)An Ethiopian trade union official was assassinated in the Ethiopian capital yesterday, Addis Ababa radio reported today. The radio, monitored here, said Kebede Gebre Mikeel, treasurer of the AllEthiopian trade union, was killed by antipopular forces on the way home from his office. The radio did not elaborate.

title: Main Breaks at 42d and Lexington
description: A 20inch water main burst under the intersection of 42d Street and Lexington Avenue Saturday night, buckling the pavement, flooding nearby streets and a few basements and knocking out 14,000 telephone lines in the largely commercial district.

description: BOSTON, Dec. 4The death of Stephen Biko was disclosed on Sept. 13 by South Africa's Minister of Justice, James T. Kruger. He issued an unusually detailed statement, saying in part:

description: MEN'S BASKETBALL

title: For Neil Simon, It's Chapter Two
description: Neil Simon's popularity rests upon his fine control of a very particular kind of painful comedy. It consists of his characters saying and doing funny things in ludicrous contrast to the unhappiness they are feeling.

title: Still In Coma After Surgery
description: ALBANY, Dec. 4 (AP)An unidentified woman remained in critical condition today after a malfunctioning machine cut off the oxygen supply to her brain during surgery nine days ago, a hospital spokesman said.

title: DRINKING BY TEENAGERS IS REPORTED LEVELING OFF
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (UPI)A new report by the National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism says that though drinking among teenagers is still a serious problem, it appears to be levelink off. The institute plans to present the report to Congress soon as a followup to a 1974 study showing that teenage drinking was increasing.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Body Discovered in Virginia
description: RICHMOND, Dec. 4 (AP)The authorities say that a body found in a wooded area near here is believed to be that of a missing New York State man. The body, which had decayed, is believed to be that of Merle B. Wright, 94 years old, a retired rural mail carrier from Dansville, N.Y., the Chesterfield County authorities said. Mr. Wright's automobile was found abandoned June 25 near where the body was found on the shore of a lake, the authorities said.

title: Spirited Cosmopolitan Symphony
description: The Cosmopolitan Symphony Orchestra opened its 14th season Saturday afternoon in Avery Fisher Hall with a concert led by Patrick Flynn, currently a conductor with American Ballet Theater.

title: Frank T. Dixon 3d, a Miler at N.Y.U
description: Frank T. Dixon 3d, one of the country's leading milers and distance runners at New York University in the 1940's, died of cancer on Saturday in Mercy Hospital, Rockville Centre, L. I. Since 1973 he had been assistant principal of Public School 44 in Brooklyn. He was 55 years old and lived at 635 Hempstead Avenue In West Hempstead, L. I.

title: Rangers Tie Stars, 4 to 4, On Late Goal
description: Still bearing the marks of his rookie initiation last weeka raggedly shaved chest and aborted brush cut above his forehead  Lucien DeBlois passed happily through the rites of rookie hero last night by scoring two goals to give the Rangers a 4.4 tie with the Minnesota North Stars at Madison Square Garden.

title: Tito Ends Visit to Rumania
description: RELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec, 4 (Reuters)Presidenl Tito of Yunoslavia returned here today after a 24hour visit to Rumania for rooting consultations with president Nicola. Ceausescu, Earlier today the two leaders held a final round of talks at the Rumanian border town of Turn Severin, the offical Rumanian press agency reported.

title: Topics
description: The Canadians have devised a bargain way of death: A funeral parlor in British Columbia offers to let the deceased lie in what looks like an expensive oak casket during the funeral before being buried in a cheap pine box. Since the oak is a mere shell, easily removed for reuse, the departed can indulge in conspicuous consumption without consuming anything. The saving is substantial; a real oak casket costs about $1,000. the nine box less than $400. We understand the desire of the bereaved to provide the appearance of the finest, but whatever happened to the idea of death as the last inescapable truth? The Romans said, more ultima ratio  death is the final accounting. Little did they know that even at the very end somebody would find a way to juggle the books.

title: ANGOLA DUE TO MOVE TOWARD MARXIST RULE
description: LUANDA, Angola, Dec. 4 (Reuters)Angola's leftist rulers are expected to take major steps this week to move the vast, potentially rich country closer to Marxist rule, brooking no opposition.

title: Congress Questions Advantage and Cost Of U.S. Consultants
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4The Department of Agricillture hired the prestigious management consultants Booz, Allen & 1Hamilton to find out how to cut the cost of meat and poultry inspections. It was told, among other things, that the industry could hire more inspectors itself and that the chickens, which pass Federal inspectors at a rate of 25 a minute, could be speeded up.

title: CARTER IS CONFIDENT ON PROGRAMS FOR '78
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4  President Carter is coming down to the end of 1977 in a philosophic moodsurprised by the endless complexities of foreign and domestic affairs, disappointed by the opposition to many of his national programs, but expressing confidence that he has established a solid foundation for substantial progress at home and abroad in 1978.

title: Energy Department: Dust Is still Settling
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4Since it opened its doors on a rainy Saturday afternoon two months ago the Department of Energy has been caught in a rapid shuffle of people and offices and responsibilities.

description: The United Way of TriState, in its first effort as a collecting organization for 1,000 private humancare agencies in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, is doing so well that it will probably end its drive in February with about 15 percent more than the $60 million raised separately by its member agencies in 1976.

title: Molin Reaches Final
description: ROSLYN, L. I., Dec. 4Dave Oberstein and Jon Molin gained the final of the $1,000 Metropolitan men's tennis championship at the Roslyn Racquet Club today. Oberstein downed Doug Barrow, 76, 46, 64, and Molin beat Hal Main, 16, 75, 63.

title: Louis Balogh, Industrial Engineer Who Created Many New Designs
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4  Louis Balogh, a mechanical engineer with many industrial developments to his credit, died of cancer on Friday in Holmes, N.Y. He was 72 years old.

title: Swiss Voters Turn Down Proposals On Military Exemptions and Taxes
description: GENEVA, Dec. 4The Swiss remained true to their traditions today by decisively rejecting in national referendums proposals to exempt conscientious objectors from military service and to impose some national uniformity in local incometax rates.

title: COAST PAPER DEFENDS STAND ON LAND LAW
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 4  In recent weeks The Los Angeles Times has peatedly denounced in editorials a. Federal order that would enforce a 1902 law limiting to 160 acres the size of larms irrigated by Government water projeCtst If enfoiced, the law threatens to break up thousands of large farms.

description: Morning

title: New Accounts Added By Ally and Manoff
description: For the Richard K. Manoff, Inc., and Carl Ally Inc., advertising agencies, last week ended on a happy note. That is if new accounts can be considered joy provoking.

title: Penguins 4, Capitals 2
description: LANDOVER, Md., Dec. 4 (UPI)Pete Mahovlich, newlyacquired center, scored his fifth goal in four games with Pittsburgh, sparking the Penguins to a 42 victory over the Washington Capitals tonight.

title: Ailey Revives Choral Dances After 6 Years
description: The Alvin Ailey who choreographed Blues Suite and Revelations nearly two decades ago is not the Alvin Ailey who created the 1971 Choral Dances, which his company has just revived at the 55th Street City Center Theater.

title: It's a TwoPenthouse Serenade For QE2 in Drydock at Bayonne
description: BAYONNE, Dec. 4The world's largest active passenger ship, the Queen Elizabeth 2, which regularly makes excursion cruises to ports in such places as Britain, Barbados and Bermuda, called at Bayonne for the second time this year so that two ready  made, split  level penthouses could be hoisted onto her signal deck today.

title: Bomb Injures Oakland Youths
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Dec. 4 (AP)Six youths were injured today, one of them critically, when they stopped to examine a large envelope on a bus stop bench and a device inside exploded. Alejandro Morales, 13 years old, of Oakland, was hospitalized in critical condition. David Vamora, 16, also of Oakland, was being treated for metal fragments in his eyes. Four others were released after emergency treatment.

title: Phil Ford and Butch Lee in Spotlight
description: Phil Ford has been called the magician of North Carolina's fourcorner offense. Pro scouts like to talk about his tremendous quickness, shooting and passing.

title: New York City Discovers Diplomatic Community Is Financial Asset
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 4The 22.000member diplomatic community in New York City ^ontributes $450 million a year to he city's economy, more than offsetting the $20 million that it is estimated to cost the city to host the United Nations, its member delegations and foreign consuates.

description: MILLSKerry. Though he is no tonger here, AT A GEORGIA CAMP MEETING, MEET ME IN ST. LOUIS, LOUIS & RED WING will Iive forever.

title: Some Horse Owners Making Money, as Barn 38 Shows
description: Is it true, the trainer was asked, that Don Newman pays you $630 a day to keep his 18 horses in shave?

title: SIX STRANGLING VICTIMS ARE LINKED TO HOLLYWOOD
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 4 (UPI)At least six of the 10 young women whose nude bodies were found in the Glendale and north Los Angeles area over a sixweek period were linked to Hollywood, the police said today. They also reported that a man being questioned as a suspect was apparently not linked to the series of rapes and stranglings.

title: F. GWYN VAUGHAN
description: F. Gwyn Vaughan, a former vice president and director of marketing for Grolier Inc., publisher of the New Book of Knowledge and the Encyclopedia Americana, died Wednesday in North Palm Beach. Fla. He was 77 years old.

title: Bucks Outlast Nets In Overtime, 134118
description: MILWAUKEE, Dec. 4 (UPI)The Milwaukee Bucks scored 9 straight points at the start of the overtime period6 by Brian Winters who scored a total of 36 pointsand beat the New Jersey Nets, 134118. tonight.

title: World News Briefs
description: MADRID, Dec. 4 (UPI)  More than three million people demonstrated across Spain today for home rule in various provinces: Riot policemen and the paramilitary Civil Guards clashed with protesters in the southern city of Malaga, leaving one person dead and dozens injured.

title: RUMANIAN AMNESTIES STIR FEARS OF CRIME
description: BUCHAREST, Rumania, Dec. 4In the last six months the Rumanian Government, in two separate mass amnesties, has released about 30,000 young criminals and a handful of political prisoners.

title: Rhodesian Policeman Kills 14
description: BULAWAYO, Rhodesia, Dec. 4 (Agence FrancePresse)  Fourteen persons all blacks, including five children and three policemen, were killed here tonight and 16 were wounded when a black police sergeant ran amok with a shotgun. The gunman was killed by Rhodesian security forces. Bulawayo is in southwestern Rhodesia, near the border with Botswana.

title: Aussies Take Davis Cup
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 4 (AP)John Alexander outlasted Adriano Panatta of Italy in a fiveset marathon that took 3 hours 54 minutes to play today and regained the Davis Cup for Australia. In one of the most tense and closely fought matches in recent Davis Cup history, the 26yearold Alexander recovered to win, 64, 46, 26, 86, 119.

title: Planes Search Atlantic for Yawl With Five Marylanders Aboard
description: Planes searched a vast expanse of the Atlantic Ocean yesterday for a 41footyawl carrying five young Marylanders that was reported overdue in Bermuda, The Associated Press reported.

title: Appeal for Neediest Aided By Estates and Trust Funds
description: The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund started its 66th annual appeal yesterday with $442,611.51 already donated by estates, trust funds and 198 contributors.

title: Rose Joan Krause Married To Dr. Douglas G. Treshan
description: Rose Joan Krause, who is with the document services division of the Internal Revenue Service in Holtsville, L.I., was married yesterday to Dr. Douglas Gerald Treshan, a dentist in Wantagh L.I.

title: Around the Nation
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec, 4 (AP)Carter Administration officials defended the focus of a planned national urban policy in remarks today to municipal officials who expressed fears that it would be tilted too much in favor of troubled cities.

title: Japanese Brokers Cultivate an American Image on Wall St.
description: Yoshitoki Chino, deputy president of Daiwa Securities, one of Japan's Big Four brokerage houses, has a superb 17th century gold screen in his Tokyo officeinherited from his samurai ancestors of the Tokugawa era.

title: Developer Calls It a Robot Butler; Scoffers Say Screws Are Loose
description: It resembles a fivefoottwo aerosol can on wheels. It is said to be a highly intelligent being, unlike anything seen before. It can speak 250 words and understand 50. It can vacuum the house, serve dinner, babysit and answer the door. Well, how do you do? it might say.

title: First Family Will Send 60,000 Holiday Cards
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 4 (UPI)The Carter family has a Christmas card list of 60,000. A spokesman for the Kansas Citybased Hallmark Card Company said the specially designed cards were shipped to the First Family over Thanksgiving week.

title: Maddox Opens Souvenir Stand
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 4 (AP)Lester Maddox, the former Governor of Georgia, has opened a souvenir stand at an Atlanta flea market to recoup $300,000 in financial losses from past political campaigns. The souvenirs include Maddox watchet, Confederate flags, plastic chicken bones and ax handles, reminders of his days as a restaurant owner. Mr. Maddox had refused to allow blacks in his restaurant and some that tried to entered were blocked by ax handlewielding whites.

title: Manufacturers Hanover Agrees To Reduce Some Interest Rates
description: The Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company has agreed to reduce interest charges on cash advance balances owed on its Master Charge and Visa accounts and on its overdraft checking services to an annual rate of 12 percent from the current 12.17 percent.

title: Jets Beat Saints, 1613, on Leahy's 3 Field Goals and Todd Scoring Pass
description: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 4Pat Leahy connected on three of four fieldgoal attempts and kicked one extra point to help lift the New York Jets to a 1613 victory over the New Orleans Saints today. It was a football game that should have been declared off limits to people with heart trouble.
