description: Music

title: New York City Air: Cleaner but Still Not Clean Enough
description: New York City's air is significantly cleaner than it was a decade ago, but it is still dangerous to health. The problem is the continuing pollution caused by cars.

title: Washington &
description: WASHINGTONAmid the intensive debate on Capitol Hill over the President's National Energy Plan, a littlenoticed battle over what to do about growing imports of refined petroleum products is slowly gathering strength.

title: About Newyork
description: Here is a great moment on the citys streets: The intended victim, a grayhaired physician pausing for a moment in his car by the curb, looks up to find a hulking teenager by his window saying, Gimme a dollar, while a second stalker holds a lead pipe menacingly at the hood of the car.

title: Sunspot Cycle Seen As Drought Influence
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 7 (UPI)Scientists have reported ne evidence of sunspots influencing droughts, a deduction that, if correct, could mean the drought in the West has one more year to go.

title: COMPROMISE 15 VOTED BY HOUSE AND SENATE IN ABORTION DISPUTE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7The House and Senate compromised today on their dispute over the use of Medicaid funds for abortion, ending a fivemonth impasse that had held up appropriations for two major Government departments.

title: Berkowitz Trial Change of Venue Denied by 4Judge Appeals Panel
description: A fourjudge panel yesterday unaniously rebuffed a request by lawyers for David R. Berkowitz for a change of venue, saying that an impartial jury of 12 could be found among Brooklyn's 2.5 million residents for the trial of the alleged Son of Sam killer.

title: Notes on People
description: A former Prime Minister of Denmark, Poul Hartling, was nominated yesterday by Secretary General Kurt Waldheim to be United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees. The 63yearold Mr. Hartling will succeed Prince Sadruddin. Aga Khan of Iran, High Commissioner for the last 12 years, who asked to be relieved of his assignment as of Dec. 31, a year before the end of his latest fiveyear term. The High Commissioner, who has the rank of a United Nations Under Secretary General, second only to Mr. Waldheim, heads an office, in Geneva that provides legal protection and arranges asylum and resettlement for refugees from war, persecution and other disorders in the world. The position pays $59,250, plus liberal expense allowances.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Edward I. Pfeffer, Deputy Superintendent Of Schools in Newark for the Last 12 Years
description: Dr. Edward I. Pfeffer, deputy superintendent of schools in Newark for the last 12 years, died Tuesday in Beth Israel Hospital in Newark after a short illness. He was 60 years old and lived at 507 Clinton Place, Newark.

title: Schlesinger, in the City, Delivers Emotional Appeal for Energy Plan
description: Warning of severe economic trauma of the sort that we have not witnessed in this country since the Great Depression, Energy Secretary Jaynes R. Schlesinger swooped into New York City yesterday to appeal for support for the Administration's national energy plan before an audience of key businessmen.

title: U.S. Stilt Seeks Geneva Talks
description: WASHINGTON; Dec. 7 (SAP)President Carter is not abandoning his goal of holding Middle East peace talks in Geneva and continues to view a separate EgyptianIsraeli peace settlement unfavorably, his chief spokesman said today.

title: Q&A
description: Q. I have six inches of insulation above my ceilings, and there are several vents in the roof above this insulation. I can understand how these vents would help circulate air in the summer, but do they serve any function in the winter, or can I close them to conserve heat?Dr. P.L.L., Denver, Colo.

title: NBCTV Adds 58 Specials
description: Publication of NBCTV's schedule of special programs for the first three months of next year indicates an increasing tendency to run fewer, but longer programs, and to frequently prempt regular series for specials.

title: Landes Pleads Guilty to Lesser Charge
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 7Assemblyman Irwin J. Landes pleaded guilty today to a charge of attempting to practice law without a license, a misdemeanor, and was fined $150. He could have been fined $500 and sentenced to 90 days in jail.

title: A Christmas Card for the Neediest Extols Virtue of Capacity to Care
description: A Christmas card bearing season's greetings and showing a redbreasted cardinal perched on a wreath of pine boughs, holly berries and mistletoe was received yesterday for the 66th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Israelis Report Talks With Egypt
description: TEL AVIV, Dec. 7Egyptian and Israeli officials started secret meetings few days ago and are discussing substantive matters without waiting for the Cairo conference to open, the Israeli state television reported tonight.

title: Schoolgirl Makes F.B.I. List
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (UPI)A young schoolgirl who wrote to the Federal Bureau of Investigation asking for information about Lee Harvey Oswald for her civics class ended up with no information, but she now has her own F.B.I. file. Diane Fleddermann of St. Louis, in a handwritten letter in December 1963 asked the bureau for the information and got a letter back from J. Edgar Hoover saying he could not help her. But the letter also started an F.B.I. file on Miss Fleddermann, with the notation that she could not be identified anywhere else in the bureau's recads.

title: Decorative Fans: A Different Way to Dress a Tree
description: THE ANNUAL Christmasdecoration olympics are in full swing and it doesn't cost a thing to see most of the competitors. shooin for a gold medal in best tree ornamendation is Henri Bendel for its enchanting white tree trimmed from ceiling to floor with pleated fans and tiny white lights.

title: THOMAS A. YOUNGLOVE
description: ST. LOUIS, Dec. 7 (AP)Thomas A Younglove, who joined the Communist Party as an informer for the Federal Bureau of Investigation, died of cancer at a hospital here yesterday. He was 74 years old.

title: Hussein Meets With Assad in Effort to Halt Arabs Rift With Egypt
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Dec. 7King Hussein of Jordan flew here today for talks with President Hafez alAssad in an attempt to prevent further deterioration of relations between Syria and Egypt.

title: NEW & USEFUL
description: Alessandro, the Italian designer known for his contemporary custom furniture designs, now has decorative accessories on view at his own gallery in Bonwit Teller. A fine example is a handpainted African gourd with copper fittings. Its rounded bottom is supported by a doughnutshaped basket stand. The inside of the shell is hollow, so it can be used as a container as well as a decorative piece. The gourd comes in aubergine (each copper topping is a different shape), stands nine inches tall and costs $40. Other pieces by Alessandro, a master in the art of lacquer, feature tortoise, sand and stone finishes.

title: Justices Relax Rule on Phones In Surveillance
description: WASHINGTON, Dec, 7The Supreme Court concluded today, 5 to 4, that Federal district courts have the authority to order a telephone company to install surveillance equipment as part of a criminal investigation on the basis of evidence no stronger than that needed for a search warrant.

title: SECOND MAN CONVICTED OF A MURDER CONSPIRACY
description: A second man was convicted in Federal Court in Manhattan last night of conspiracy in the murder of Anthony Finn, a Federal narcotics informant, in a bar do the Lower East Side more than three years ago.

title: Mets Get Back Foli to Play Shortstop
description: HONOLULU, Dec. 7  The ever spending New York Yankees added another name and another big salary to their world championship cast tonight when they bought Andy Messersmith from the Atlanta Braves.

title: WOMEN CADETS IN VEST POINT'S PRAISE
description: WEST POINT, Dec. 7A study of the United States Military Academy's first Women cadets indicated today that they had integrated suprisingly well despite the opposition of most male cadets.

title: ENERGY CONFEREES CONDITIONALLY BACK A GAS GUZZLER TAX
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7House and Senate energy tax conferees agreed today to impose a tax on cars that get poor gas mileage, provided that another group of energy conferees agrees to reject an outright ban on manufacturing gas guzzlers.

title: Natl Hockey League
description: AT ATLANTA

title: 2,637 Faithful Nets Fans Suffer a Letdown Again
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J., Dec. 7Why do 2,637 sturdy fans brave chilling winds and 20degree temperature to watch a team that has only won three of 24 games?

title: Four Children Die in Fire
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 7 (AP)Four childr en were killed last night when a space heat: er apparently ignited a mattress on which three of the youngsters slept in their South Side apartment. Dead were Felicia Reed, 4 years old; Ronnie, 7, and Kerry, 9, who had been asleep on the mattress on the livingroom floor near a space heater, and a brother, 9-month-old Robert, who was sleeping in a crib in the dining room.

title: Hers
description: ARUSSIAN friend, an emigr writer who recently arrived in the United States, was telling me of his astonishment at the peculiar American institution of couple friendship. When Americans are married, he observed, you are expected to be friends with both or with neither. You pretend you want to see the two of them when you only want do see one; they pretend they both want to see you when one of them goes to sleep at the very sound of your voice. It's all very strange to me.

title: Parkway Modernizing ProposedIn Westchester, With Toll Rises
description: WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 7The East Hudson Parkway Authority, which controls the Hutchinson River, Taconic State, Saw Mill River, Cross County and Sprain Brook State Parkways in Westchester County, called today for a $320 million moderization program to be financed by increases in tolls and the imposition of new ones.

title: Article 5 -- No Title
description: MIAMI, Dec. 7 (AP)The Coast Guard has boarded a Venezuelan fishing boat and seized some 800 bales of marijuana that the agency says apparently were meant for smugglers alone the Gulf coast.

title: Three Magazines Called Obscene.
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 7 (AP)Hugh Hefner, publisher of Playboy and Oui magazines, and Bob Guccione, publisher of Penthouse, have been charged with distribut ing obscene materials in Fulton County. County Solicitor Hinson McAuliffe also charged them with abetting the sale of the allegedly obscene items, the December issues of the magazines.

title: The Economic Scene
description: Leonard Silk discusses economists who believe the time has come to end the game of precise economic forecasts. Prof. Lester C. Thurow of M.I.T. finds that economists cannot make economic predictions and Prof. James B. Ramsey of New York University asserts that economic forecasts are merely statements about the probability of a future event. Page D3.

title: CURTIS TO STEP DOWN AS DEMOCRATS CHIEF
description: WASHINGTON, Dec, 7  After 10 months of often strained relations between the White House and the Democratic National Committee, the White House confirmed today that Kenneth M. Curtis would resign shortly as Democratic national chairman.

title: Deaths
description: ALLENJohn Brice Ethan, of 726 Taunton Road, Tavistock. Wilmington, Delaware. died of cancer at Wilmington General Hospital, on December 7, in his 17th year. He was a senior research chemist with E.I. du Pont de Nemours. Survived by his wife, the former Mary Ann Hasenbach, formerly of Racine, Wisconsin, two sons, William Ethan (Toby), age 9, and David Brice, age 6, his father, Ethan Allen of Roxbury, Conn. and New York City, and his mother, Jean Brice Allen, of Darien, Conn. Memorial service at Alderspate United Methodist Church, Concord Pike, Fairfax, Wilmington, Delaware, at 10:30 A.M. on Saturday, December 10. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Sierra Foundation, 2410 Beverly Blvd. Los Angeles, Cal.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Bloomingdale's Customer Charges Sex Bias
description: An Englewood, N. J., woman has filed a sex discrimination complaint against Bloomingdale's department store in New York City, alleging that it charges to alter women's clothing, but provides the same service free or men's.

title: Restaurateur Calls Bribe Demands By Health Inspectors Horrendous
description: The owner of a restaurant that was fined $450 this week for alleged health code violations yesterday described the pressure from various city inspectors for bribes as horrendous.

title: Jane's Editor Says B1 Decision May Doom the West
description: LONDON, Dec. 7 (AP)President Cart er's decision to scrap the B1 strategi bomber may help bring about a Westen defeat if a general nuclear war break out, according to the editor of Jane' All the World's Aircraft in a preface to the 197778 edition.

title: Exotic and Erotic Fantasies Fill a London Showroom
description: LONDON AGLITTERING Gothic wonderland, peopled with human skulls wearing moss agate sunglasses, 10foothigh dodos perched atop footballsized ostrich eggs and eightfoothigh ostriches with sterling silver toenails opened here last week at J. Antony Redmile's new Sloane Street showroom.

title: ALAN B.ROTHENBERG, AT 70, WROTE BOOKS AND TAUGHT
description: Alan Baer Rothenberg, author, poet, painter, and former teacher at Prospect Heights High School, Brooklyn, and at Hunter College, died suddenly Monday in his home, 225 Lincoln Place, Brooklyn. He was 70 years old.

title: U. S. MAY POSTPONE NEXT LEASE SALE OF OFFSHORE OIL, GAS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7The Carter Administration may delay its next sale of offshore oil and natural gas leases as a means of pressuring the House to consider pending legislation that would alter management procedures for the outer continental shelf, Secretary of Interior Cecil D. Andrus said today.

title: Pakistan Frees Journalists
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Dec. 7 (Reuters)Thirty journalists and other newspaper workers who had been arrested during a hunger strike over the forced closing of an Urdulanguage paper in October were released from prison tonight. The country's military rulers ordered their release after saying yesterday that the Karachi edition of Musawat could resume publication under its owners, a company headed by the wife of ousted Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto.

title: 2 Rare Salamanders Are Missing in Tokyo
description: TOKYO, Dec. 7 (AP)Detectives are looking for two rare salamanders, valued at more than $40,000, that are missing from two Tokyo zoos. The search is concentrating on pet stores and gourmet shops.

title: Congress Passes Bill To Help Poor in Cold
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7The House has joined the Senate in approving a $200 million plan to protect lowincome families from high utility bills in the event of another severely cold whiter.

title: Sardinians Stage Job Protest
description: CAGLIARI, Sardinia, Dec. 7 (Reuters)Riot policemen firing tear gas and wielding clubs today broke up a demonstration by thousands of workers on strike to protest against rising unemployment on this Mediterranean island, the police said. They said that earlier 25,000 strikers marched to the mayor's office to demand government action against unemployment.

title: Family Money: Women's Rights in Credit
description: WHEN a young writer we'll call Marie Quinlan walked into a New York City bank with her fianc recently in search of a mortgage, she was stunned to hear the desk officer say her income couldn't be counted toward the loan because she was of childbearing age.

title: Bridge:
description: A player holding a long, strong minor suit is almost always willing to settle in three notrump when his partner opens one notrump. But if the suit is a major, a 10trick contract is generally safer.

title: Facets at Ailey: Genius of Jamison
description: THE DYING ART of the dance solo remains surprisingly alive and intermittently well at the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater.

title: CRUDE IMPORTS UP IN WEEK 900,000 BARRELS A DAY
description: Imports of crude oil rose to 6.4 million barrels a day in the week ended Dec. 2 from 5.5 million barrels a day in the preceding week, according to the latest weekly supply figures released by the American Petroleum Institute.

title: Nordic Bloc Puts Off Bid for U.N. Criticism of Uganda
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 7In the face or vigorous opposition from African and other thirdworld countries, five Nordic nations reportedly agreed today to suspend further action on their proposal that the General Assembly express its concern for the first time over violations of human rights in Uganda.

title: Home Beat
description: IF I KNEW YOU was coming I'd have baked a cakeand put out a fresh cake of soap, the song should go. Many American consumers, it seems, put out a brand new cake of soap when company isexpected. This soap is called guest slap, and there is a large market for it (although not large enough to make Ivory nervous).

title: On WatchBorrowing
description: There appears to be no limit to the radical ambitions of the Carter Administration. First, it set out to control the use of Federal limousines. Then came the effort to simplify Federal prose and regulations. Now comes a yet more revolutionary plan: to regulate the Federal use of consultants.

title: KOCH BIDS CITY AIDES REMAIN BEYOND JAN. 1
description: Mayorelect Edward I. Koch urged yesterday that current city department heads stay on the job past Jan. 1 and not leave us in the lurch.

title: Advertising
description: Around the Brown Forman Distillers Corporation and DKG Advertising there is the warm feeling that the new approach to Old Forester Bourbon advertising uncorked in September 1976 is paying off. Sales are up and that's the name of everybody's eame.

title: TV: LowKey Paul Simon
description: THE VICTIM of a miscalculating concept, the already lowkeyed Paul Simon almost disappears from his own show tonignt at 9 on NBC. The diminutive singer and composer, whose easygoing personality suggests the contemporary pop equivalent of Perry Como, is supposed to be worried about appearing on his first television special. That's the running gag, and it is about as funny as a case of fallen arches.

title: Music: Fine Recital By Ileana Cotrubas
description: One glance at the program that Ileana Cotrubas put together, and it was clear that she wanted to be judged as a serious singer. The Rumanian soprano, last night in Carnegie Hall, with the able assistance of Martin Isepp at the piano, avoided fluff. Nor were there any opera arias. She sang lieder by Schubert and Brahms, a group of Faur songs, and five songs by Benjamin Britten. It was a short but concentrated program.

title: Hunter, 13, Is Shot to Death
description: WARETOWN, N.J., Dec. 7 (UPI)A 13yearold deer hunter was found shot to death yesterday. He had been Hunting with several members of the Atlantic Highlands Gun Club. The death of the hunter, Daniel Smith, of Atlantic Highlands, was considered suspicious, and an autopsy and inquest were ordered. Several spent Shotgun shells were found near the boy's body. hunter, Daniel Smith, of Atlantic Highlands, was considered suspicious, and an autopsy and inquest were ordered. Several spent Shotgun shells were found near the boy's body.

title: SITE BOARD APPROVES UPSTATE ATOM PLANT
description: ALBANY, Dec. 7The New York State Board of Electric Generating Siting and the Environment today approved construction of a $1.1 billion nuclear power plant on the shores of Lake Ontarioits first decision since it was created in 1972 as a onestop state agency to balance the public need for power against environmental effects and to expedite generatingplant applications by public utilities.

title: EGYPT ORDERS SOVIET AND ALLIES TO CLOSE ALL CULTURE OFFICES
description: CAIRO, Dec. 7Egypt moved today to broaden its counteroffensive against foreign critics of President Anwar elSadat's peace initiatives by closing cultural centers and some consulates of the Soviet Union and four other East European Communist countries.

title: Mount Etna Erupts
description: CATANIA, Sicily, Dec. 7 (Reuters)Mount Etna, Europe's largest active volcano, erupted early today, spewing jets of molten lava hundreds of feet into the air. Officials from the nearby volcanology institute said there was no immediate threat to people nearby.

title: Mondale to Inspect Air Command
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (AP)Vice President Mondale is to fly tomorrow to the Strategic Air Command base in Omaha aboard an Air Force jumbo jet used as a flying command center, Jody Powell, the White House press secretary, said today. Mr. Powell said that Mr. Mondale would be accompanied by the Deputy Secretary of Defense, Charles Duncan, and Air Force Gen. George Brown, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. Mr. Mondale will be making the trip because President Carter thought his Vice President should be fully briefed on such matters, Mr. Powell added.

title: 11 Accused Smuggling of Hashish With Estimated $1.5 Million Value
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (UPI)Eleven men wtre being held today on charges of smuggling at least 800 pounds of hashish worth an estimated $1.5 million from New Delhi to Dulles Internotional Airport.

title: CORRECTION
description: A chart that appeared in The Times on Nov. 29 incorrectly presented the participation rate and percentage of women in the labor force. The data were for the entire labor force, fill time and part time, not fullcime wokers only, as the chart stated.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, Dec? 7Governor Byrne announced today the formation of an early warning group to bring new industry into the state and keep present businesses in a productvie status.

title: Stage: New Images Full Oedipus Is Presented
description: RICHARD SCHECHNER has urned Ted Hughes's muscular and beautiful adaptation of Seneca's Oedipus into a collection of assorted and slightly broken theatrical images.

title: New York State Plans Strategy In Case Coal Strike Is Long One
description: New York State energy officials yesterday said they were planning what to do if the United Mine Workers strike outlasted coal stockpiles,

title: BILL ON PAYMENTS ABROAD SENT BY HOUSE TO CARTER
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (AP)Legislation that would set fines of up to $1 million for corporations that bribe foreign officials was passed unanimously by the House today and sent to President Carter for signature.

title: JUAN SUANCES IS BURIED; A SPANISH INDUSTRIALIST
description: MADRID, Dec. 7 (Reuters)Juan Antonio Suances y Fernandez, the main architect of Spain's industrialization after the 193639 civil war and founder of one of Europe's largest businesses, was buried here today.

title: U.S. Indictment Accuses ExNew York Realty official of Tax Evasion
description: Harry Stern, a former New York City assistant commissioner of real estate, was indicted yesterday on four counts of incometax evasion and four counts of filing false returns.

title: Judge Criticizes Sentence of Girl in Killing
description: WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 7Justice Isaac Rubin said in State Supreme Court here today that the sentencing of Christina Prate to prison in 1975, when she was 16, for killing a man who allegedly had raped her, had been an error.

title: COMPROMISE IS VOTED BY HOUSE AND SENATE IN ABORTION DISPUTE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7The House and Senate compromised today on their dispute over the use of Medicaid funds for abortion, ending a tivemonth impasse that had held up appropriations for two major Government departments.

title: Toy Alphabet Blocks Recalled
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (UPI)A Consumer Product Safety Commission survey of Christmas toy shelves has resulted in the recall of 8,400 sets of wooden toy alphabet blocks, which may be coated with paint containing more lead that the law allows. The recall is being conducted by the M.W. Kasch Company, of Mequon, Wis. The blocks were packaged in sets of either 15 or 28 and sold for about $1.35 and $3. Thy came in bags with a cardboard label stamped ABC Educational BlocksMade in Taiwan for Skyline International, Milwaukee, Wis., USA.

title: 5 in F.B.I. Inquiry Quit Investigation InlisputeWithBell
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7The five lawyers conducting an investigation of alleged burglaries, illegal wiretapping and mail opening by the Federal Bureau of Investigation have asked to be removed from the case because of a disagreement with the Attorney General over whether new indictments should be sought at this time, the Department of Justice said today.

title: G.&W.Net Down 27.4% in Quarter
description: Gulf & Western Industries Inc. yesterday reported a 27.4 percent drop in earnings for the first fiscal quarter ended Oct. 31, despite a 15.4 percent sales gain.

title: Spassky-Korchnoi Match Delayed
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 7 (AP)The seventh game of the chess match be tween Boris Spassky and Viktor Korchnoi, scheduled for today, was postponed until Friday, officials said. The official physician, said Spassky had a cold and had requested the postponement. It was the second time Mr. Spassky had asked for postponement in the 20game match to select a challenger to the world chess champion, Anatoly Karpov of the Soviet Union, He trails Mr. Korchnoi, 4 to 2.

title: Sound
description: THE ABUNDANCE of performing talent in our colleges and communitysponsored music and theater groups provides occasion for almost anyone with a good tape deck to do some live recording. Yet, surprisingly, audio fans rarely seek opportunities for such activities, which would offer them creative challenge along with appreciation of the artists and actors whose work is documented by their recordings.

title: Lisbon Government Falls
description: LISBON, Thursday, Dec. 8The Socialist Government of Prime Minister Mario Soares was defeated just before dawn this morning on a motion of confidence as two rightist parties and the Communists voted against it.

title: Books: Philosophy With a Game
description: THE AMBITION of The Philosopher's Game is to introduce us in a way that is not merely painless but positively amusing to some of the most interesting people who ever lived. As to whether they are what the title page calls themthe 100 greatest thinkers of all time there is room for debate. Scheherezade (in The Arabian Nights) was a pretty girl who could tell a good story, but no more than Sappho does she rank with Bertrand Russell when it comes to abstract formulations. Yet both she and Sappho are in The Philosopher's Game, while Russell is not.

title: 25,000 Films Taken From Paris Institute
description: PERHAPS AS MANY as half of the 50,000 films collected by the French Cinmathque, one of the world's foremost film institutes, are missing, according to two of its administrators.

title: 52 Intraocular Lenses Recalled After They Are Found Too Strong
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (AP)The Food and Drug Administration announced today the recall of 52 mislabeled intraocular lenses, including 10 implanted in the eyes of cataract patients in Melbourne, Fla.

title: Around the Nation
description: CHARLESTON, W.Va., Dec. 7 (AP) Arnold R. Miller, president of the United Mine Workers, said today that the nation's soft coal producers wanted a onemonth strike to drive up prices and weaken the union. But he added that they might get a strike that would last three or four months.

title: A.T. &T. to Spend $12.5 Billion, A Record, for Construction in 78
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced yesterday it would spend a record $12.5 billion on construction in 1978, more than any American corporation hss ever expended on construction in a single year.

title: What Price Victory Sunday for Jets?
description: HEMPSTEAD, LI., Dec. 7As they began preparing for their final home game against the Bills on Sunday, the Jets discovered today that victory not only would ensure them a fourthplace finish ahead of Buffalo but it would also guarantee them a tougher schedule next year.

title: Scientists Believe Cosmic Rays Generate Electricity That Causes a Stroke of Lightning
description: Cosmic rays from space probably generate the added electric potential that triggers a lightning stroke, according to scientists of at the Applied Physics Laboratory of the Johns Hopkins University in Laurel, Md.

title: ESKIMOS GIVEN QUOTA ON KiLLING OF WHALES
description: TOKYO,. Dec..7. (AP)The International Whaling Commission decided today to limit Alaskan Eskimos to a total catch of 12 bowhead whales for 1978. Eskimo leaders immediately warned that their hungry people would be forced to break a quota that small.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A finance panel headed by Gov. Ella T. Grasso yesterday allocated $1.4 million extra for winter clothing for welfare children after the initial $1 million was used up in two days.

title: Sudan's Leader Backs Sadat
description: KHARTOUM, the Sudan, Dec. 7 (Reuters)President Gaafar alNimeiry of the Sudan rejected today Arab criticism of President Sadat's visit to ISrael and said there was no alternative to peace in the Middle East.

title: General Electric and Hitachi Form Joint TV Venture
description: The General Electric Company and Japan's Hitachi Ltd. announced yesterday the formation of a new joint venture, General Television of America Inc., that will engineer, manufacture and market television products. The new company will produce G.E., Hitachi and privatelabel television sets and will manufacture and sell parts to other producers as well.

title: ARTnews, Now 75, Expanding Sharply
description: ARTnews, the monthly that considers itself the world's most widely read fine arts magazine, is marking its 75th anniversary with the November issue now reaching the newsstands. It carries more than 150 ad pages.

title: RUMANIANS GET CALL FOR MORE AUSTERITY
description: BUCHAREST, Rumania, Dec. 7President Nicolae Ceausescu asked today for eight more years of austerity and sacrifices to raise Rumania to the ranks of the developed countries.

title: A.F.L.C.I.O., Opening Convention, Appears on the Brink of a New Era
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 7The American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, in appearance calm and monolithic as it prepares to open its 12th biennial convention here tomorrow, seems on the brink of a new era.

title: A Key Ingredient in Lacquer And Nail Polish Runs Low
description: In a few weeks, it may become little harder to buy lacquered bookshelves or fingernail polish. A tightening in the supply of nitrocellulose, key ingredient in furniture lacquer, printing inks, smokeless gunpowder and paint, is likely to curtail production of certain consumer products until new supplies can be arranged with foreign countries.

title: Corporation Affairs I.O.S. to Accept $11 Million In Claims Against Vesco Unit
description: I.O.S. Ltd. and the I.O.S. Dollar Funds have agreed to accept $11 million to settle all claims against the International Controls Corporation, International said yesterday. The small conglomerate, based in Thomaston, Conn., once was headed by Robert L. Vesco, a fugitive now living in Costa Rica.

title: About New York
description: Bologna in Italy and the professors would look for more pristine speech from him. I'd shout back at them. I was as old as they were, and being a.cop I knew how to handle myself.

title: Market Place
description: Blockbuster motion pictures such as Jaws, Star Wars and Close Encounters of the Third Kind have brought new life to shares of the companies that made the pictures. However, there is confusion as to what, say, a $100 million gross means to the bottom line.

title: Suffolk Policemen, Highest Paid in U.S., Given Raise of $2,957 a Year
description: HAUPPAUGE, L.I., Dec. 7Suffolk County policemen, already the highest paid in the country, have been awarded a raise of almost $3,000 a year each by a state labor arbitrator.

title: U.S. Publishers Doubt an Early Soviet Pact
description: American publishers made it clear yesterday that Moscow would have to comply with the humanrights provisions Of the Helsinki accords before they signed any trade protocol with the Soviet Union's bookpublishing industry.

title: Armco Will Not File Complaints In Dumping Case
description: C. William Verity, chairman of the Armco Steel Corporation, said yesterday that his company would refrain from filing two extensive dumping complaints with the Treasury Department as a mark of our good faith in the Carter Administration's plan to aid the Steel industry.

title: Award for Brendan Jones of Times
description: The World Trade Writers Association yesterday named Brendan Jones, a reporter for The New York Times, the recipient of its worldtrade writing award for 1977. Mr. Jones, who joined The Times in 1947, was cited for the high standards in covering foreign trade developments for more than 25 years.

title: 5 In F.B.I. Inquiry Resign From Case In Dispute With Bell
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7The five lawyers conducting an investigation of alleged burglaries, illegal wiretapping and mail opening by the Federal Bureau of Investigation have asked to be removed from the case because of a disagreement with the Attorney General over whether new indictments should be sought at this time; the Department of Justice said today.

title: A Retreat From the Frenzy of Seventh Avenue
description: TOM FALLON has created an island of quiet serenity, where he can close out the frenzy of the city and the particular madness that is Seventh Avenue, where he works. It's important for anyone who works in New York to have a private space for himself, he said.

title: Roche, Ailing, Pulls Out Of So. Australian Tennis
description: ADELAIDE, Australia, Dec. 7 (UPI)Topseeded Tony Roche withdrew from the $100,000 South Australian tennis championships today because of stomachmuscle injury.

title: Letters
description: Leather Repair

title: Home Improvement
description: THERE are many occasions when it is useful to be able to cut a sheet of glass to a specific size, or to drill one or more holes through a sheet of glass, a bottle or a mirror.

title: Dave Anderson
description: They must be impostors. That was the only possible explanation for how the Boston Celtics were playing basketball this season. Perhaps the Brinks holdup men had struck again, kidnapping the Celtic players and wearing their uniforms over costumes that resembled John Havlicek and Dave Cowens and Jo Jo White and all those other faces in the green and white underwear. They must be impostors. They could not possibly be the real Celtics, not the Celtics who had won the National Basketball Association championship as recently as the 1976 playoffs, not the Celtics who are talking about moving, along with the hockey Bruins and the tennis Lobsters, out Boston Garden into a proposed suburban playpen. The real Celtics could not lose eight of their first nine games this season. The real Celtics could not lose to the Seattle SuperSonics by 22 points, 11189, in the Boston Garden last Friday night. The real Celtics could not have a 714 wonlost record when they arrived Tuesday night for their first Madison Square Garden appearance this season. They must be impostors.

title: Messersmith Is Sold ToYanks by Braves
description: HONOLULU, Dec. 7I never told this to anybody, Al Campanis of the Los Angeles Dodgers was saying, but last year I was in on the only baseball trade ever swung in Greek.

title: Roosevelt
description: ENTRIES

title: Dollar Still Sagging; Drop Called Threat To World Recovery
description: LONDON, Dec. 7The dollar continued to sag on world currency markets today, approaching its lowest levels since World War II against the mighty West German mark and Swiss franc.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: A Time for Testing
description: What should determine who goes to collegea national policy designed to promote social fairness and equality, or the educational merit of the individual applicant?

title: A Jewish Meeting Applauds Unusual GuestCairo Envoy
description: Ashraf A. Ghorbal, the Egyptian Ambassador to the United States, was given a rousing welcome in New York last night by one of the nation's leading Jewish organizations. It was described as the first time an Arab ambassador had addressed such a group.

title: Ramsey Rape Suspect Consents to Tests on Hair, Blood and Saliva
description: HACKENSACK, N. J., Dec. 7The operator charged with raping a baby sitter and robbing two homes in Bergen County, consented today to a prosecution request that Mr. Ader submit to tests on his hair, blood and saliva.

title: JOAN LITTLE IS SEIZED IN BROOKLYN CHASE Former Friend Tells Police Where to Find Carolina Escapee
description: Joan Little, who drew national attention in 1975 when she was acquitted of murder in the death of a prison guard she said had tried to rape her, was arrested early yesterday after a 70mileanhour automobile chase through Brooklyn.

title: A New Way of Getting to School
description: EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Dec. 7It's about 20 miles from Shirley, a small community on Suffolk County's South Shore, to Suffolk Community College in Selden, and public transnortation is available.

title: House RollCall Vote on Abortion Funds Compromise
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (UPI)Following is the rollcall by which the House agreed to soften its stance and move to a compromise bill with the Senate on federally financed abortions. A yes vote is a vote to soften the House position. Those who did not vote are denoted by xxx.

title: Article 5 -- No Title

Informing on Mister Untouchable Six months ago, The Times Magazine brought to public attention the case of Leroy (Nicky) Barnes, who was identified by authorities as the major drug peddler in Harlem. In tribute to his ability to evade the law, he had won the title of Mister Untouchable. In fact, he was already in the process of being touchedand last week he was found guilty of running a huge narcotics ring. Ten associates were convicted with him.
description: In a city that has suffered greatly from the ravages of the drug trade, there must be satisfaction at the conviction of the elusive Nicky Barnes, who reported on his tax return a miscellaneous income of $250,000 a year. But the satisfaction will be soured for some by the knowledge that his conviction required the testimony of paid informers.

title: FundRaising Group Set Up for Carey
description: In another sign of Governor Carey's intention to seek reelection, Carey allies disclosed yesterday a milliondollar fundraising effort to retire his debt from the last gubernatorial campaign and to start a war chest for next year's election.

title: State of Violence: II
description: BOSTON, Dec. 7You are an American banker or businessman with significant interests in country X. You are made aware that the basic national policy of X is to repress 80 percent of its population: systematically, violently, forever. What do you do about loans to X, or business there?

title: Dollar Still Sagging Abroad
description: LONDON, Dec. 7The dollar continued to sag on world currency markets today, approaching its lowest levels since World War II against the mighty West German mark and Swiss franc.

title: Calendar of Events For the Home
description: Christmas Tree Sale, Convent of the Sacred Heart, 1 East 91st Street

title: MORRELL GOLDBERG, AT 67, LONG HOSPITAL OFFICIAL
description: Morrell Goldberg, executive vice president of Brookdale Hospital Medical Center, a voluntary, nonprofit unit in Brooklyn, died there yesterday after a long illness. He was 67 years old and lived at 55 East Ninth Street in Manhattan.

title: Gift Paper: A WrapUp Of 80 Artists Designs
description: THE NOBE GALLERY, at 250 West 57th Street, invited more than 80 artists this year to create something memorable to wrap memorable Christmas gifts in. Oneofakind gift paper, by artists, will be on display from Monday until Christmas Eve and may be purchased for $5 to $25 a sheet.

title: SmallCity Officials Say Their Needs Are Neglected
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 7  As the Federal Government prepares a strtegy to aid the nation's ailing large cities, small cities are becoming increasingly resentful in the belief that their needs are being neglected.

title: JOAN LITTLE IS SEIZED IN BROOKLYN CHASE
description: Joan Little, who drew national attention in 1975 when she was acquitted of murder in the death of a prison guard she said had tried to rape her, was arrested early yesterday after a 70mileanhour automobile chase through Brooklyn,

title: Common Price Paid at Gold Sale
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (Reuters)The International Monetary Fund said bidders at today's .gold sale for the benefit of the world's poorer nations would pay an average price of $160,03 an ounce for the 524,800 ounces of gold auctioned. The latest auction was held under the common price, or Dutch Auction, system under which every successful bidder pays the lowest acceptable price. For the last six months, successful bidders have paid the actual price bid.

title: 5,500 Zenith Workers Certified By U.S. for Special Federal Aid

title: Sports News Briefs

description: Dr. Peter Carl Goldmark, whose invention of the longplaying phonograph record for CBS revolutionized the recordedmusic industry, was killed yesterday in an automobile accident on the Hutchinson River Parkway in Westchester County. He was 71 years old.

title: Powerful In Celebration

It was originally presented at the Royal Court Theater in 1969, a superlative production that was preserved with its original cast in a Lindsay Anderson film. The play was also offered in 1974 at the Arena Stage in Washington. It is now having its longdelayed New York premiere Off Off Broadway at the Sutton East Theater.

description: AUSTINClarence L. In cherished memory of Clarence L. Austin, December 8, 1975. Oh Lord, let Thy mercy be showed upon is as we do Put our trust In Thee. ALICE.

The plan is aimed at people whose current financial status may make larger monthly payments difficult during the early years of loan.

title: CARE Appeals for More Money To Help Indian Cyclone Victims

title: The Critics Choose Their Personal Favorites
description: So many attractions, so many nice things said about them. But you don't remember which they said were merely great or which they called superb. And now you have time to see them during the holiday season. So 14 critics of The New York Times are here to tell you what they themselves would to see this weekend just for the fun of it. Here are their choices in theater, music, films, dance and art. This is the quality tip of New York's cultural iceberg and there is no better place to start than at the top. Just remember to telephone ahead to be sure if the programs are on as scheduled.

title: Save Our Oil
description: To the Editor: Everyone seems to be recommending we spend (waste?) a lot more money exploring and intensifying our efforts to get more of our oil out of our land to make us less dependent on foreign oil. Why not burn their oil while we can get it and leave our precious oil in the ground for the future?

title: Suit Testing Brings Inquiry For Cup Skiing
description: VAL D'ISERE, France, Dec. 8Hours after she finished second in a World Cup giantslalom race today, Annemarie MoserProell of Austria was threatened with disqualification because her ski suit failed to pass inspection.

title: Metropolitan Baedeker
description: CENTRAL PARK SOUTH, more even than Fifth Avenue, is the quintessential outoftowner's street. Lined with hotels, it is a bridge from the East Side to the West, tying midtown to Lincoln Center and the Coliseum. For its whole length, from Grand Army Plaza at Fifth Avenue to Columbus Circle at Central Park West, the street has the greenery of Central Park at its edge. Its buildings have some of the best views in town, and the street itself has a dignified boulevard width, just right for strolling or for riding in a hansom cab.

title: Drama: Innaurato Falters
description: SHAKESPEARE may have said that all the world was a stagenot one of his better lines, in fact but it seems a mistake for Albert Innaurato to go on from there to say that all the world is a graduate school of drama.

title: Art: A Nevelson Made to fast
description: NOWADAYS scarcely a week passes without some news of Louise Nevelson. It is no secret that she is well along in her eighth decade, yet her sculpture or the unmistakable figure of the sculptor herselfseems to be everywhere. Indoors and outdoors from New York to San Francisco, the whole country seems to be on its way to becoming one big Nevelson sculpture garden. Her photographic image, too, stares at us wherever we turn; it is now as familiar as Picasso's: In truth, there must be more than a few people who are tired of reading about this artist and her sundry exploits.

Mr. Corigliano, son of the late, longtime concertmaster of the New York Philharironic, is quoted as saying: I has been fashionable, of late, for the artist to be saying: It has been fashionable, of late, for th eartist to be misunderstood. I wish to be understood. It is the job of the composer to reach out to his audienees with every means at. his disposal.... Communication should be a primary goal.

title: Concorde May Brush Malaysia, Despite Ban, On Singapore Flight

title: Restaurants
description: SUGGEST a restaurant that is staunchly, strictly vegetarian, without meat, fish or eggs in any fowl, add to that the phrase low cholesterol, and you will probably turn away people by the dozens. Yet the diner sampling the oalateteasine, soulsatisfying contrast of spices, herbs and textures at Madras Woodlands might hardly notice those omissions, and certainly most serious eaters would not miss them. This two-and-a-halfyearold restaurant, on 44th Street between First and Second Avenues, features the hot, spicy and savory vegetarian cooking of South India, and does so with mouthwatering results.

The television coverage begins tomorrow with Pitts burgh at Cincinnati (Channel 4, 1 P.M.) and continues with Washington at St. Louis (Channel 2, 3:30 P.M.). The third game is Miami at New England on Sunday (Channel 4, 1 P.M.), and the fourth, Minnesota at Oakland, will be televised nationally by CBS but not in this area.

It looked exactly like a common wooden cigar box. Mr. Greene then surveyed his assemblage of 42 lookalike, mostly Russianmade boxes, all of which he owns and has consigned to sell next week at Sotheby Parke Bernet, Madison Avenue at 76th Street, and said it represented the largest number of these rare cigarbox simulations to be auctioned at one time in recent years.

The truth is that the African governments are unwilling to display the same outrage over the repression of blacks by blacks as they regularly display over the repression of blacks by whites.

title: Reprise
description: BLACK BAG MYSTERY  Increasingly, it appears that Attorney General Bell, in his ardor to clean up the F.B.I.'s reputation, is stepping on his own. Last April, he authorized the indictment of John J. Kearney, an F.B.I. official, on charges involving black bag jobs, warrantless wiretaps and breakins. It looked like the first in a commendable series of cases demonstrating that the law applies to everyone, including law enforcement officers. But the months have passed, leaving us and others to wonder, what series of cases? And now, in a startling act, the five Justice Department lawyers handling the Kearney case have resigned from it because the Attorney General has refused, in the hiatus, to authorize any more indictments. Mr. Bell's logic grows steadily more mysterious. No one thinks the indicted F.B.I. man dreamed up the illegal activity on his own; so to prosecute only him is perverse justice. Why not indict others, then? Mr. Bell has said he wishes to pursue the standard prosecutive strategy of indicting one defendant and pressing him to implicate others. But that hardly seems a sensible strategy when there is, obviously, considerable evidence about other potential defendantsand when, in any event, Mr. Kearney steadfastly refuses to tattle. So what can Mr. Bell be thinking of? Perhaps he now feels he was too hasty in approving the Kearney indictment in the first place and it is wrong to indict other law enforcement officers for similar conduct. But if that is so, why does Mr. Bell let the solitary Kearney case drag on? The Government should not ask agents to do black bag jobs; still less should it make them scapegoats.

title: Legislatures Inaction Snags Prisoner Exchange Plan
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 8The failure of state legislatures to pass laws embracing the Federal Government's prisoner exchange treaty with Mexico has temporarily trapped in state prisons several hundred Mexican nationals who might otherwise qualify for repatriation, according to Federal prison officials.

description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8The Carter Administration has drafted and will soon send to Congress the most sweeping proposal to overhaul the nation's pharmaceutical laws since adoption of the Food and Drug Act of 1906.

title: Nashville Author Tries Stege
description: Joan Tewkesbury, who wrote Robert Altman's movie Nashville, is one of a new breed of star screenwriters. Now she is about to join another minoritywomen movie directors. Early next year she will make her directing debut with Old Boy Friends. But at the moment, she is involved in a third career as a playwright. Her first play, Cowboy Jack Street, has just opened at the Perry Street Theater in Greenwich Village, where it will run through Dec. 22.

title: Books of The Times
description: ANY list of this year's best book for teenagers has to be headed by Robert Cormier's I Am the Cheese (Pantheon, $6.95.) A few years ago it was Cormier's The Chocolate War that was also the most praisedand most debated for its brutal portrayal of life inside a prep school and the unredemptive quality of human existence. I Am the Cheese makes the earlier book seem like playtime in a sandbox. On a dreary October day, Adam Farmer, 14, is pedal ,g his bike on the way from Massachusetts to Vermont to visit his father. But is he? And is he really Adam Farmer? In alternating chapters we read a taped interrogation probing a boy's past. Gradually the pieces begin to fit together. Adam has two birth certificates, his father receives periodic visits from the gray man, his mother makes a weekly mysterious telephone call. In short, father, mother and son, having changed identities, are paying the price for testimony given to a Senate committee. If the syndicate doesn't get them maybe their own Government will. And so this sophisticated, almost adult thriller moves to a grim, chilling and devastating climax.

title: Two Men Sentenced In StockFraud Case
description: Judge Milton Pollack yesterday im posed prison sentences of 12 years on Arnold Nelson Mahler and eight years on Dean H. Ubben in a stockfraud case in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: Broadway
description: IF ARTHUR CANTOR does not do one thing, then he is certain to do another, and now Mr. Cantor will bring over the Irish actor Donal Donnelly in My Astonishing Self. This is a oneman production in which Mr. Donnelly is George Bernard Shaw, and when it was donne in the Loeb Drama Center at Harvard last September the critics fell all over themselves in delight. It will open here Jan. 18 at the Astor Place Theater near Greenwich Village, where it will stay only three weeks or so, and then go out on tour. My Astonishing Self has been what they call devised by Michael Voysey, which means that it has been put together from the lectures, diaries, letters and miscellaneous utterances of Shaw. Mr. Donnelly was on Broadway in A Day in The Death of Joe Egg, and before that he got a Tony nomination for Philadelphia, Here I Come.

title: Making Peace With Big Steel
description: The President sued for peace with big steel this week, offering the industry some modest protection against the competition from imports plus a package of Government benefits designed to lower domestic production costs. In return, Mr. Carter is asking for a breather on lobbying efforts for protectionist legislation and an end to demands for stricter enforcement of the existing protectionist trade laws. The steel plan is one item in a general strategy for dampening protectionist pressures at minimal economic and diplomatic cost. Its success will depend upon as yet undisclosed details of how much the Administration is willing to give and how much will be needed to satisfy the steelmakers.

title: Bran Bank Reported Acquiring 3% to 4% Of First Wisconsin
description: The Bank Omran, wholly owned by the Shah of Iran's Pahlevi foundation, has reportedly acquired an interest in the first Wisconsin Corporation of Milwaukee, a bank holding company, and may receive a seat on the concern's board.

description: EZE, France, Dec. 8Christian Dolan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick Dolan of New York, was married here today in the private chapel of St. Dominic at her parents home overlooking the Mediterranean to Peter Gordon Shiach of Elgin, Moray, Scotland.

title: Notes on People
description: Peter Mark Andrew Phillips is the name of the first grandchild of Queen Elizabeth II of Britain. The infant's parents, Princess Anne and Capt. Mark Phillips, named him yesterday. Buckingham Palace announced that the child. born 24 days ago, would be christened Dec. 22, at the palace, by the Archbishop of Canterbury. The godparents will be the baby's uncle, Prince Charles, heir to the throne, and four friends of Princess and Captain Phillips. A palace spokesman said that the child's first name is that of Captain Phillips's father, and his third, Andrew, is that of another uncle, Prince Andrew. Because of the wishes of his parents, Peter Mark Andrew Phillips Is the first grandson of a British monarch in centuries to be born without a title.
