title: Geese Are Guards At Shore Nursery
description: BRICK TOWN IN THE fall of 1976, the Dvoraks had had enough. After repeated and expensive incidents of childish vandalism at Brick Town Farms, their plant nursery on Brick Boulevard, the fatherandson team decided they had to find an effective security system.

title: Phyllis Dorothy White Uncovers The Secret Face of P. D. James
description: 'I feared that if I didn't settle down and write a novel, I'd end up an old lady telling my children and grandchildren that I had always wanted to be a writer, said Phyllis Dorothy James White.

title: In the Land Of Sorrow
description: ALAN MOOREHEAD, that marvelous chronicler of the two arms of the Nile, suffered a stroke some years ago and lives in retirement in London now. But if you look him up there, you meet a man still built like a little bull, still as forcefullooking as a rolling bowling ball, so that it's easy to visualize how intently he must have covered the ground when he researched his admirable books. They served as a model for Peter Forbath's estimable account of the discovery, exploration and exploitation of the Congo River by Europeans, Forbath says. I wish I could say that Forbath's prose is as fluid, or possesses an equivalently personal lanit's distant and anonymous, by comparisonbut his learning is comparable, and the matters of which he writes are as rich. Though we may not be rereading him in 15 or 20 years with the pleasure one feels in picking up Moorehead again, his book is encyclopedic, churning with heroism and terror and all manner of action, and very much a book for this year.

title: An Attack Hits Home in Norwalk
description: NORWALK TROUBLE has come to Village Creek. The name makes it sound like cue of those places that Connecticut is famous for, where the pines, ashes and oaks shade cozy homes, where life is tranquil and privatepermanently and pleasantly severed from urban crises.

title: What's Doing in PUERTO RICO
description: TWO CHRISTMASESAs a result of its bicultural heritage, Puerto Rico's children live in a fairyland of two Christmases: Dec. 25, the traditional United States giftgiving day, and the Feast of the Epiphany Jan. 6 celebrated throughout the Hispanic world. The children hang their stockings on Christmas Eve to be filled by Santa Claus and also put out grass on Jan. 5 to feed the camels of the Three Magi, who bring gifts the next day. As a result, the festivities last longer than in the United States. The streets of Old San Juan, the old part of the capital, are illuminated and decorated and in the plazas brass bands play Hispanic carols. The City of San Juan mounts a display of the Nativity on a hill overlooking the ocean near the Capitol, with figures of the Three Magi astride camels.

title: Texas Inventor Hopes His Device Will Help Cut Highway Deaths
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP)  For many years now, a tinkerer and inventor from Austin, Tex., has been trying to sell a gadget that he thinks might save thousands of lives on America's highways.

title: Karen Campbell Kohl And Robert A. Root, Students, Betrothed
description: Karen Campbell Kohl and Robert Allen Root, students at Brigham Young University, will he married this winter at the Mormon Temple in Washington. Their engagement has been announced by the parents of the prospective bride, Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth A. Kohl of Pennington, N.J.

title: Study on TeenAge Auto Accidents Is Termed Tragically Misleading
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP)A driver education spokesman has described as tragically misleading a study that blames high school driver education for increases in fatal traffic crashes.

title: Athletes Transfer
description: LAST SPRING, Dennis Morris and Ken Cooper were living with their families in the slums of New Haven. Both teenagers had completed their second seasons as reserves on the basketball team at Richard C. Lee High School in New Haven.

title: For Aluminum, the Energy Crunch Was a Blessing
description: On the face of it, aluminum production in the United Statesalready 31 percent of worldwide outputis on the launching pad. Demand for the lightweight metal is strong, prices are keeping pace and the profit outlook for the aluminum industry is better than it has been for a decade. The stage is set, in theory, for billions of dollars in new investments and thbusands of new jobs.

title: Philip Monahon Jr. Weds Susannah Seabrook
description: Susannah Hall Seabrook, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. deLacy Hofius Seabrook of Short Hills, N.J., was married there yesterday afternoon to Philip Christopher Monahon Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Monahon of Newton Highlands, Mass.

title: INTERVIEW
description: WHITE PLAINS JOHN RUDDLEY, director of the Westchester Art Workshop, is writing a novel, an art historical novel, he said last week, about the structures that artists have to work around to become successful.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: Dag Hammarskjld once wrote that he'd spent his entire life feeling as though he were present at a dinner party from which the guest of honor had already departed. And I suppose most of us, one way or another, are a bit haunted by absences, by a sense of having missed what was there to be known or to be taken, orworse yetby the secret, furtive certainty that we did not even try to be on time, to knock at the door when the door might have opened, to become what our destinies invited us to become. Curiously, two recent plays have touched on this sensation of standing on the edge of a world that was never quite entered, one much more successfully than the other.

title: Anne Dowling, W. W. Holzman Have Nuptials
description: Anne Therese Dowling and William W. Holzman were married yesterday at the National Arts Club in New York by State Supreme Court Justice Bernard Klieger.

title: CAN SCHOOLS SPEAK THE LANGUAGE OF THE DEAF?
description: A new Federal law requires public schools to educate deaf children, but in states

title: Mondale Motorcade Is Rerouted Around Crash That Killed Woman
description: PORTLAND, Ore. Dec. 10 (UPI)A fiery auto crash in downtown ,Portland last night claimed one life and forced a rerouting of Vice President Mondale's motorcade to his hotel, the police reported. The accident occurred just minutes before the Vice President was to travel through the area.

title: Torrington vs. Conrail: A Town Fights for Its Rails
description: TORRINGTON, Conn.If buildings were able to talk, the squat, rambling redbrick factory that houses the Charter Oak Container Corporation could spin an epic tale about industry in the Northeast.

title: Boston Meeting House Burns
description: BOSTON.Dec. 10(AP)The 140yearold South Meeting House burned to the ground today, leaving four white, fluced columns standing. The Ipswich IiiStorical Society said the meeting house was built in 1837 and was owned by the Friends of Ipswich Youth, which used it as a center for teenagers.

title: $468 Parking Allowance for Year Offered to Employees in Illinois
description: EVANSTON, Ill., Dec. 10 (UPI)On the theory that a company parking space a pay fringe benefit, American Hospital Supply Corporation has announced that it will make a parking allowance of $468 a year to all headquarters employees starting Jan. 1.

title: What They Are Saying
description: Jim Dickey, the new head football coach at Kansas State University, says he will try to recruit his son, Darrell, a senior at Chapel Hill (N.C.) High School: There would have to be some outstanding quarterbacks in this area if I were not to try to recruit him. I consider my son an outstanding prospect, and I get along well with his mother.

title: Consumer Advocate Says N. Y.  Telephone Inflates Its Costs 20%
description: A Long Island consumer aavocate contends that the bills of New York Telephone Company could be inflated as much as 20 percent because of bloated executive salaries, charitable contributions, promotional advertising and excessive advance charges for income taxes.

title: Dean Silver Is Fiance Of Rosemary P. Power
description: Col. Roger C. Power Jr., U.S.M.C. retired, and Mrs. Power of Weston, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Rosemary Patricia Power, to Dean Strauss Silver, son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin S. Silver of Teaneck, A June wedding is planned.

title: Art, Artifacts and Supershoppers
description: THEY don't have the latest in video games, Star Wars memorabilia, gourmet cookware or fashion designer cologne. But what you will find in the gift shops at some of the Island's museums are distinctive items culled from farflung sources that are eminently suitable for the people on your shopping list.

title: Catherine Piccone Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Dante N. Piccone of Larchmont, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Catherine Anne Piccone, to Gregory Leonard Gigantino, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Gigantino of Edison, N. J. Miss Piccone and her fianc plan a May wedding. They are graduates of Wagner College.

title: Fund Backs Controversial Study of Racial Betterment
description: A private trust fund based in New York has for more than 20 years supported highly controversial research by a dozen scientists who believe that blacks are genetically less intelligent than whites.

title: Christmas in the Air
description: PERRY COMO'S OLDE ENGLISHE CHRISTMASThe singer and his friends celebrate with musical Christmas cards in English settings in a special on ABC Wednesday at 10 P.M.

title: Doctors Disown New Hunterdon Pact
description: FLEMINGTON A NEW legal move was under way here this weekend to overturn an outofcourt settlement that allowed hospital specialists on the staff of Hunterdon Medical Center to open private practices outside the hospital.

title: Dances of Albert Reid Enhanced By His Own Quick, Intense Solos
description: Albert Reid's dances are usually inventories of movements that have occupied his creative attention rather than sustained choreographic development of single ideas. Inevitably they are best expressed in his own solos, which are performed with the grave, quick and intent purposefulness that make them coherent. He presented quartet of pieces Friday evening at the American Theater Laboratory; his Sketchbook was the most satisfying. Mr. Reid is lean and serious but permits himself sinuous, slinky gestures that serve as bridges between his careful articulation of walks, marching steps in place and precise turns! There is an inwardness of concentration that disdains the showier aspects of performing to emphasize control and careful placement. He is like a collagist placing and balancing the separate elements in harmonious relationship to one another.

title: GIFTED AND TALENTED GIVEN A CHALLENGE
description: Twice a week, Amy Decker leaves her fifthgrade class in a ShorehamWading River elementary school a few minutes early to go to the district's high school, where, she says, J learn things and then put them into the computer to see if I'm right.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: ICOME from a long line of brown baggers, and, if my children have their way, the tradition will continue for at least one more generation. Our suburban town has a good reputation for the varied menus it provides for the public schools, but my children do not partake.

title: Tractors Carry Farmer Protest To Washington and 30 Capitals
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10Two columns of tractors and trucks rolled into the nation's capital from Maryland and Virginia today to demonstrate their drivers anger over farm conditions that they say are Pushing them into bankruptcy.

title: World News Briefs
description: LISBON. Dec. 10 (Reuters)Prime Minister Mario Soares, defeated in a con???? m??? two days ago, met today with President AntOnio Ramalho Banes but said he had not been asked to form a new government.

title: 5,000 Italian Women Demonstrate For Right of Choice on Abortions
description: ROME, Dec, 10 (Reuters)About 5,000 women demonstrators marched through Rome tonight to demand the right of choice in having abortions in Italy.

title: IN AMERICA
PEOPLE
description: Last October the $200,000ayear chairman of Bonwit Teller was called back from a Paris fashion show and given only a weekend to clear out. Last week the 45yearold Mr. Schumacher filed a $1 million claim under arbitration procedures against Bonwit's parent company, Genesco Inc. of Nashville. The claim is for salary and other renumeratlon due under his remaining contract. He is also seeking damages for mental anguish and for harm to his reputation caused by the manner of his dismissal. Genesco gave no explanation in October for firing Mr. Schumacher; the company would not confirm trade reports that his life stylespecifically, a triplex apartmenthad been a major reason.

title: German Films Are Subsidized
description: With the exception of Volker Schlondorff's The Lost Honor of Katharina Blum and several of Rainer Werner Fassbinder's films, most of the qual ity movies being turned out by Germany's contemporary filmmakers have been greeted with apathy by the German public. It is quite likely, in fact, that the imaginative but demanding works of Werner Herzog and Wim Wenders would not exist at all were it not for the fact that subsidy money has been made available to them. Indeed, as much as 80 percent of the funding of typical German feature is accomplished through a subsidy of one kind or another.

title: Divided Nation, Separate Peace?
description: CAIROPresident Anwar elSadat of Egypt has declared with high emotion that in negotiating with Israel he is serving the cause of the Arab nation, not just the immediate interests of the Egyptian state. All others involved, including Prime Minister Menahem Begin of Israel, have stressed that the goal of EgyptianIsraeli negotiations is an overall Middle East settlement, not a separate peace between the two countries. Even from Washington has come an unaccustomed call for Arab consensus and solidarity.

title: Forum Discusses Sexism in Bible, Some Attributed to Translators
description: Carolyn Hopley said she was stunned the other day when her Sundayschool class could not think of any way in which women approached the image of God except possibly by giving birth.

title: LETTER TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: Once again the residents of the Town of Hempstead have rejected the basic precepts of the democratic electoral process. They have returned to power the oneparty monopoly that has ruled the town for the last 75 years.

title: Culture Outings
description: MOUNT KISCO Apilot program of day trips to cultural sites has been planned for Mount Kisco youngsters by this community's Cultural Arts Coordinator, Connie Spector. For working parents, the bonus of this federally subsidized program of Saturday, Sunday and evening trips is the trial outings scheduled on school holidays.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: MANY people have beautiful old picture frames stowed in their basement or attic, or on the top shelf of closet, that would be perfectly fine except that the corner joints have begun to work loose and mounting a picture safely thus becomes impractical.

title: A Sales Pitch Fot New York
description: It's not exactly a salesman's dream. The product is flawed, the comptition is intense, the customers are waryand the payoff doesn't come until years after the sale. Yet last year,New York City (the product) was host to more conventions (834) and more convention visitors (1,213,960) than at any time since the World's Fair of 196465. And this year is expected to be as good as or better than, last year.

title: At 9, She Has Mastered The ShowHandling Art
description: Jane Forsyth has a double in the show ring these days. Sue Forsyth not only looks like her mother, but at only 9 years of age, (still too young for junior showmanship competition) she also has mastered the art of handling. Sue.,

title: Surprisingly, the Governor Turns Out to Be a Surprise
description: The nominating convention will not be held until July, but powerful forces in the Democratic Party in Connecticut are already at work to unseat their Democratic Governor, Ella Grasso. The dissatisfaction with Mrs. Grasso, elected in 1974 by a majority of 200,000 votes, has developed over the last three years and comes from many sources.

title: NewCar Sales Dip
description: A slump in newcar sales took the auto industry by surprise last week, as the four major producers reported sales of 4.7 percent below the yearearlier level for the last 10 days of November.

title: Federal Safety Inquiries to Focusi On 9 Million Fords and Peugeots
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (UPI)The Department of Transportation has announced new safety investigations focusing on 1968 to 1974 Ford cars and 1972 to 1975 Peugeots.

title: REVEL-ATIONS
description: If the function of an essay in political theory Is to help IS understand the period we live tn. then it follows that the study of the opposation the essay arouses Is rewarding.

title: Deaths
description: ALLENEugene, beloved husband of Irma, devoted father of Joseph, Stuart, cherished son of Rebecca Epstein, loving brother of Herbert Epstein. Services at Jeffers, 188 St & Hillside Ave, today at 12:30 PM.

title: U.S. Cigarettes Serve as Hard Currency in Rumania
description: BUCHAREST, Rumania, Dec. 9Some time last month, no one is quite sure when, the price of having a tooth pulled by a firstclass dentist here in the capital went from one carton of cigarettes to twoand not just any cigarettes but American ones, and only in 100millimeter length, thank you very much.

title: CAMERA
description: The question of what can be legally photographed is one that has gotten photographers into hot waterand kept attorneys busyalmost since the invention of photography many years ago. Many of the questions involved are answered in the latest revised edition of the popular and informative book, Photography and the Law, by George Chernoff and Hershel Sabin (Amphoto, soft cover; $7.95): Both of the authors have long specialized in many aspects of photographic law, and for many years they wrote a column on this subject in Popular Photography magazine.

title: Miss Jordan Bars 4th House Term
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 10 (AP)Barbara Jordan, the Texas Congresswoman whose oratory highlighted the 1976 Democratic National Convention and the impeachment hearings of President Nixon. said today that she will not seek reelection.

title: New President for Chicago U.
description: NEW HAVEN, Dec. 10After the trustees of the University of Chicago voted today to name Hanna Holborn Gray its 10th president, the board chairman, Robert W. Reneker, issued a statement.

title: Tomjanovich Stable After Game Brawl
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 10 (AP)Rudy Tomjanovich, the Houston Rockets forward, was reported to be In stable condition today at Centinela Hospital Medical Center after a brief but violent secondhalf brawl in the Rockets probasketball game with the Los Angeles Lakers last night.

title: Albany a Favorite Target of Environmentalists on L.I.
description: .When the phones start to ring at the State Department of Environmental Contervation headquarters in Albany some Friday afternoon, people there know that :there Is probably trouble somewhere, and it. it's trouble it's probably on Long Island.

title: Events Today
description: Christmas Fair: antioues, clothing, gifts, crafls, food; 10:30 A.M. to 7 P.M.; Flushing Armory at 137th Street and Northern Boulevard, Flushing, Queens. (Admission 50 cents for the benefit of the Working Organization for Retarded Children.)

title: ART
description: GARDEN CITY BOOKS are meant to be seen as well as read. That statement may seem somewhat heretical to readers, but to judge from the book collectors treasures on view at Ade1phi University's Swirlbul Library, the visual aspects of books have played as big a role as the printed word for the last five centuries.

title: Cairo Prepares And So Do Other Arabs
description: Having learned shuttle diplomacy from the peripatetic Henry Kissinger, the Arabs last week were proving apt imitators. In half a dozen capitals, arriving and departing Arab leaders were either seeking reconciliation or retaliation in the wake of Egypt's call for an exploratory conference in Cairo to start this week.

title: A Regulatory Agency Limits the Catch
description: Businessmen smarting under the lash of one regulatory agency or another can find some solace in the plight of Alaska's Eskimo whale hunters.

title: Funky and Functional Craftsmanship
description: A creamy white, elegant handwoven shawl; classic silk mandarin jackets with appliqus inspired by Oriental landscape paintings; whimsically decorated but perfectly functional goblets and platesworks of some of the nation's top craftsmen have been gathered together at The Elements, a new crafts shop at 766 Madison Avenue, just for the holiday season.

title: Deaths
description: HAYESCornelius, native of Kiilaloe, County Care, Ireland. Beloved husband of the late Veronica (nee O'Brien) Hayes, loving father of John Michael Haves, brother of Sarah Hayes, Dublin and Margaret Sheehan, Broadford, County Clare, Ireland. Funeral from James C. Nugent Funeral Home, Ave D and East 28 St, Brooklyn, Tuesday 9:00 AM. Mass of kesurrection Our Lady of Refuge RC Church Tues 9:45AM In lieu of flowers request contributions to Catholic Charities, Diocese of Brooklyn, 191 Joralemon St.

title: Drinking Drivers Go Back to School
description: VALHALLA O N his way home from work in fashionable wine shop in northern Westchester last fall, Jim stopped to drink a few martinis at a local bar, then drove his car into the first tree in his path.

title: Newsday Editor to Be Honored
description: TUCSON, Ariz., Dec. 10 (AP)Robert W. Greene, a senior editor of the Long Island newspaper Newsday, will receive the John Peter Zenger Award for distinguished service in behalf of freedom of the press and people's right to know, tne University of Arizona has announced. Mr. Greene is to receive the prize Jan. 21 in Phoenix for his work as head of a team that investigated the 1976 carbomb death of Don Bolles, an Arizona Republic reporter. Mr. Bolles was last year's recipient of the Zenger award and the first to be honored posthumously.

title: FOOD
description: DURING the Christmas season, the kitchen is in the spotlight. In the spirit of foodfilled holiday festivities, cookware is great to give and to receive.

title: Bernstein Looks At Bernstein
description: Leonard Bernstein's programs with the New York Philharmonic this month include a premiere each week new scores by Lukas Foss, John Corigliano and Leonard Bernstein. His own and his latest, which is to be heard this week, is entitled Songfest. This sixpart work for six singers was premiered last month in Washington to inaugurate Mstislav Rostropovich's first season as music director of the National Symphony. The program on that gala occasion was allBernstein, and also included a new and rowdy overture entitled Slava (recycled from the fallen musical 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue and dedicated to the Russian cellistconductor), three Meditations from Mass reset for cello and orchestra and the suite from On the Waterfront.

title: AllEast College Football Team
description: Quarterbacksleamon Hall, Army; Chuck Fusina, Penn State; Matt Cavanaugh, Pittsburgh; Mike Rieker, Lehigh.

title: Pessimistic Bills Face Optimistic Jets
description: They are the bottom clubs in the American Football Conference Eastern Division, the lightestscoring collection of players in the entire conference except for Kansas City. Only three other clubs in the National Football League have yielded more points.

title: Louise HeadleyWed To B. F. Ferguson 2d
description: Louise Adams Headley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Duval Adams Headley of Lexington, Ky., was married yesterday to Benjamin Franklin Ferguson 2d. son of Mrs. Charles Hall Ferguson of Paris, Ky., and the late Mr. Ferguson. The Rev. Elmer R. Moore performed the ceremony in Holy Spirit Roman Catholic Church in Lexington.

title: First Attachments
description: SELMA FRAIBERG'S new book, Every Child's Birthright, appears at a crucial moment. We Americans have always been worried about our children and about the state of our families. But today these anxieties have reached a new intensity. To be sure, 98 percent of American children are still raised in families. But families are changing fast. Birthrates are aeclining, most mothers of schoolage children now work outside the home, divorce rates are escalating and more and more children live insingle parent families.

title: Safety Tips
description: When you are ready to put the tree up indoors, cut one inch off the stump and put the tree into a stand that provides warm water constantly.

title: Mrs. Carterio Examine Program in Harlem School
description: Rosalynn Carter will visit a public school in Harlem tomorrow to examine a program that brings social services into the classroom, a program she learned about as the First Lady of Georgia.

title: Surrender in a 1963 Coast Killing Came After a Year of Planning
description: ALBANY, Calif., Dec. 10There were probably no outward signs anyone would have noticed, but about a year ago Joseph Otto Egenberger, a handsome $25,000ayear systems analyst, began to make plans to turn himself in to the authorities to be charged for a notorious and unsolved 14yearold murder.

title: Memories I  Faded Dreams
description: PARISAt the end of this month I am being retired by The New York Times, an event which stirs many reflections covering the 44 years since I first began a journalist's career in Pittsburgh at the age of 21.

title: Farm Strike Loomsand With Reason
description: PAROLE, Md.On Delaware's Eastern Shore, William Parker is known as an upandcoming young farmer. He began farming after graduating from the University of Delaware, starting small and expanding until he now has 1,000 acres of corn, soybean, wheat and pasture land. But, Mr. Parker says, counting up a year of losses that he places at over $35,000, both his hopes and hardwon assets are threatened.

title: Wine Sales by Grocers In New York Is Urged
description: ROCHESTER. Dec. 10 (AP)The New York Farm Bureau has voted to campaign for legislation to permit the sale of wines in retail grocery stores in the state.

title: On the Farm, Doctors
description: WANTAGE TOWNSHIP AT 5:30 every morning, Ronald Liss slogs over to his barn to check his cattle and horses, dish out their breakfasts and do other barnyard chores.

title: Horse Show Calendar
description: TodaySunnyfield. Route 172, Bedford; N.Y. Suitable local and children's working hunters; ponies, equitation. 8:30 A.M.

title: Support for a Landmark Action
description: IRONICALLY, but perhaps understandably, it has too often taken the destruction of a landmark to provoke the formation of a landmarks preservation organization. This has been most clearly illustrated in the metropolitan area by the creation of the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission following the demolition of Penn Station in the mid1960's.

title: The Good Life Still Reigns On Paterson's Eastside
description: PATERSON IN Guide to New Jersey, first published in 1939 by the Federal Writers Project of the Works Progress Administration, Paterson's Eastside was described as the city's best residential area. As the guide put it:

title: Pondering the Ethics of Public Life
description: IT was one of those labyrinthine afterdinner discussions that seem to roll in with the cognac and caf filtre, and it had to do with ethics. It was inspired, as are so many. of these. kinds of things, by a recent communication from Princeton University that noted that some of its students werepondering the ethics of public life through a series of posed moral dilemmas.

title: NEW DEVICES MIMIC SOLAR FUSION ACTION
description: A new generation of devices is taking shape in the effort to solve the world's energy problems by mimicking the conditions deep within the sun that bring about hydrogen fusion.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The superintendent of an East Side apartment building was stabbed to death at 10:45 P.M. Friday by an unknown assailant at 78th Street and Third Avenue. He staggered about 50 yards to 205 East 78th Street, where he collapsed.

title: Fraser the Winner
description: CANBERRA, AustraliaWith singleminded appeals to the Australian voters pocketbooks and contemptuous comments about the opposing candidates, Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser and Gough Whitlam, former Prime Minister and leader of the Opposition, crisscrossed this vast country on military V.I.P. jets in the campaign for yesterday's election.

title: Peter M. Wolf, Prosecutor, Atid Sherry Balot Married
description: Sherry M. Belot, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Balot of Howard Beach, Queens, and Peter Michael Wolf, son of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Wolf of Little Neck, L. I., were married yesterday in the East Nassau Temple in Syosset, L. I. Rabbi Morris Appleman performed the ceremony.

title: Freshly Cut Christmas Spirit
description: SHELTON ICY blue dawn. A lingering frost from the night before had dipped the needles of blue spruce and white pine in a shimmering cobweb of icejust on cue, it seemed, for Christmas.

title: Sports Today
description: Brooklyn College at City College, 5 P.M. (RadioWNYCAM, 5 P.M.)

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox: The Athlete Who Helps
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: How to Be a Bird's Best Friend
description: ALTHOUGH winter's mantle of snow has only been a light shawl thus far, nature's wildlings have been ready for some time. Squirrels have nabbed all the nuts they could find for their storehouses, and. the mice have tunneled deeper to keep their seed and berry supplies drv. The groundhogs couldn't be bothered with all this preparation; they choose to sleep through. And the birds? They will have to make do with the foods they can find.

title: Feminist Tone Colors Speech By a Laureate
description: STOCKHOLM, Dec. 10Rosalyn S. Yalow, New York's new Nobel Prize winner, introduced a strong feminist note at the formal dinner that ended the 1977 Nobel Festival here today.

title: London Sunday Times Reporter Is Found Shot Dead in Cairo
description: CAIRO, Dec. 10 (Reuters)David Holden, the chief foreign correspondent of The Sunday Times of London, has been found shot dead in the desert near Cairo Airport, the police said today. Mr. Holden, who was 53 years old, had been shot in the back.

title: Those Honolulu Trade Winds
description: When the Yankee purchased Andy Messersmith last week during the baseball convention in Honolulu, the typical reaction was, They never stop. And they did not stop there. They later signed Rawly Eastwick.

title: Robber Reads Rights In Pornographic Movie
description: NASHVILLE, Dec. 10 (UPI)A man posing as a plainclothes policeman staged a bogus raid on a pornographic theater, read 13 patrons and the manager their constitutional rights, then stole their wallets.

title: Mental Patients Seeking Damages From Doctors
description: BOSTON, Dec. 10A suit brought by seven mental patients, seeking $1.2 million in damages from 15 doctors at Boston State Hospital for allegedly illegal use of solitary confinement and forced medication, began in Federal District Court here this week.

title: LETTER TO THE CONNECTICUT EDITOR
description: A rusty gas cap award should go to the person who dreamed up the drivethrough food market, described in Station Wagon Supermarket [Nov. 13]. Perhaps it is an idea whose time has come, but surely only in a country that moves without regard for which direction is most appropriate.

title: Koch May Delay His Moving Date To Help Beames
description: Edward I. Koch is scheduled to take the oath of office as Mayor on Jan. 1, but he may not move into Gracie Mansion, the Mayor's official residence, until some time after that. The Mansion's current occupants, Mayor Beame and his wife, Mary, have asked Mr. Koch if they can stay awhile longer. It's a typical New York story. Somebody rents an apartment, but he can't move in because the tenants who are supposed to move out have run into a delay with their new place. So it is with the Beames, who have purchased an East Side cooperative apartment that will not be ready for them on Jan. 1.

title: Report of Chris Evert Wed to Connors Denied
description: Rumors flew faster than Jimmy Connors's service yesterday that he and Chris Evert eloped last week. But Miss Evert's sister, Claire, speaking by phone from her home in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., last night, denied that Chris was married.

title: INTERVIEW
description: HARTFORD VERYBODY wants to talk to me about the ordination of women, the new Bishop of the oldest Episcopal diocese outside of the British Isles said with an air of resignation.

title: The Trials of Trying the Mad
description: Forensic psychiatry has been on the front pages in recent weeks, and once again it has provoked controversy and confusion.

title: Regional Troupe Is Alive and Well
description: MAMARONECK THEATER, when it is strong enough and honest enough, is the cheapest form of travel of which I know. It can transport you anywhere. If proof is needed, get yourself over to the Emelin Theater for the WestchesterRockland Regional Theater's production of Jacques Brel Is Alive and Well and Living in Paris.

title: National Press Club Officers
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (UPI)  Frank Aukofer, a Washington correspondent for The Milwaukee Journal, has been elected president of the National Press Club, succeeding Robert Farrell Arthur F Wiese of The Houston Post was electedvice president. Other officers elected Friday were W. J. Coughlin, editor of The Coal Daily, secretary; Casey Crawford, publisher of Healthcare Publications, treasurer and John F. Barton of United Press International, financial secretary.

title: The Comptroller Lands on a Bank
description: Tighter constraints on bank lending to members of banks boards of directors, large stockholders and other insiders were proposed by the Comptroller of the Currency last week, making it illegal for them to receive preferential treatment when applying for loans. It is already illegal for special treatment or interest rates to be extended to bank officers.

title: IN BRIEF
description: The United Mine Workers struck the Bituminous Coal Operators Association, idling 130,000 miners who produce about halt the nation's coal. The union has warned that the longthreatened strike may last three months. But it is not expected to have any immediate economic impact becauie major consumers (such as electric utilities) had built up big stockpiles. The issues: the right to strike individual mines and financial help for the miners health and retirement funds.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: In less than two weeks, children are expected to be nestled all snug in their beds with visions of sugarplums dancing in their heads. Meanwhile, there's some time to kill in the endless, impatient days before The Big Night. And what have publishers done by way of new picture books about the Christmas season to fill in a child's time, to give him newer, deeper visions to replace or supplement those traditional sugarplums?

title: The World
description: Relatively speaking, the only political calm Portugal has known since the dictatorship was overthrown in 1974 has come under the 17month Government of Prime Minister Mario Soares. Last week, the Government fell, raising the danger of new political polarization, administrative paralysis and further economic decline.

title: Bridal on May 27 Set By Sueanne Peacock
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Peacock of Mountain Lakes, N. J., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Sueanne Peacock, to William Cole Gascoigne, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Gascoigne of Boonton Township, N. J.

title: Music: Szeryng
description: Only a handful of violinists could have played the Bach Unaccompanied Sonatas and Partitas the way Henryk Szeryng did at the Metropolitan Museum of Art's Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium on Friday night. Mr. Szeryng has long been admired as one of the world's most accomplished virtuosos, but even the best of them can be intimidated by these touchstones of the instrument's technique and interpretive art.

title: Carter Rejects Need For Autocratic Staff
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10President Carter says that he does not need or want a strong powerful autocratic White House staff and that he relies instead on Vice President Mondale to coordinate staff work.

title: NOBEL PRIZES GIVEN IN SWEDISH CEREMONY
description: STOCKHOLM, Dec. 10The Nobel Prizes were presented today with Americans leading the list of laureates.

title: Engagements
description: Mr. and Mrs. Milford Rankin of Woodmere, N.Y. joyfully announce the engagement of their daughter. Linda, io Mr. Mark Harris, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Harris of Woodmere.

title: Pesticide: Boon and Possible Bane
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10Half the 70,000 chemicals being churned out by American industry are pesticides, many of which are not only a boon to agriculture but also a hazard to those who make and use themand, possibly, everyone else.

title: Eastman Trio Performs In Auspicious Debut
description: The Eastman Trio, which came together late last year, made an auspicious New York debut Sunday night at Alice Tully Hall. Its members, all on the faculty of the Eastman School, are wellknown soloists who evidently share similar. ideas about the performance and interpretation of chamber music. If there was one aspect of their performance that held true for the entire evening, it was the transparency of the playin.

title: Cavanaugh of Pitt Leads AllEast Football Team
description: when Matt Cavanaugh broke his arm in the first quarter of the first game of the 1977 season, Pittsburgh not only lost the game to Notre Dame, but also lost the best quarterback in the East for four weeks. The senior, who is built more like a tight end than some other more delicate quarterbacks, returned to lead the Panthers into the Gator Bowl. Penn State beat Pitt in the season finale, 1513, for the only loss suffered by the Panthers in the last two seasons with Cavanaueh healthy

title: Citizen Unit for Children Praises A Foster Care Ombudsman Panel
description: While foster care for children in New York City is beset with problems, the Citizens Committee for Children said last week that it has produced one new program that is humane and effective and the only one of its kind in the U.S.A.

title: Pet Adoption Service Adds Evening Hours
description: The Humane Society of New York will be open evenings to increase the opportunity for people to adopt pets before Christmas. Starting tomorrow, the society's shelter at 306 East 59th Street will remain open Monday through Thursday evenings from 6 to 8 P.M.

title: Ideas &Trends; In Summary; Drilling Deep Under the Ice Of Antarctica; Which Drivers Use Seat Belts?; Rules Pregnant With Confusion
description: The trouble last year was that the dentists spent too long over coffee. During a break from trying to penetrate the Ross Ice Shelf in Antarctica, ice moving faster than the experts had calculated immobilized their drill. We blew it, an American engineer admitted.

title: Suffolk County Executive Is Critical of the Administration's Urban and Regional Planning Methods
description: The way John V. N. Klein the Suffolk County Executive, tells it, the Carter Administration's current method of planning urban and regional policy is like getting ready for a shot to the :won wil1iout any aerospace engineers.

title: The Courts, Politics And God
description: THE recent resignation, under protest, of United States Attorney Jonathan B. Goldstein, a Republican who is being replaced by a Democrat; the attempt by Governor Byrne to seek Chief Justice Richard J. Hughes's help in naming an Atlantic.

title: Article 3 -- No Title
A Christmas Trip, A Holiday Ritual
description: In the hiatus between the excitement of the first snowfall and lastminute shopping, discontent sets in. Some break is needed, some respite from the overheated crowded shops and lowering gray skies.

title: MUSIC
description: NOT every impresario can pronounce himself happy at the prospect of a $3,000 deficit from his annual fundraising event, but Michael Pollon isn't your average impresario. He's the executive director of the Westchester L.onservatory of Music, and in view of the extraordinary example of community spirit on display last weekend during the performance of Mozart's The Magic Flute, he has every reason to be proud. When I think what an incredible experience the production has been for all of us at the conservatory, Mr. Pollon said in an interview a few days before the performance, the good will that it has been engendering all through the area, and the possibility it will get us enough attention from future donors to offset the extra costs of the opera, I'm not only happy, I'm thrilled.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: In the article The American Corporate Presence in South Africa (Dec. 4) Timothy H. Smith, director of the Interfaith Center on Corporate ReSponsibility, is quoted as saying that I.B.M. still provides computers to that [South African] Government for any purpose, however repressive. That is not true, and Mr. Smith should certainly have known that when he made his statement.

title: Long Island This Week
description: Harold Clurman, critic, speaks in Great Neck

title: Beverly Wolff's Singing Marked by Intensity
description: Although Beverly Wolff has been singing in concerts and operas in New York for many years, the recital she gave at Town Hall on Tuesday night was apparently her first in the city.

title: COST CONSCIOUS CONGRESS CUTS BACK ON DIRECTORY
description: WASHINGTON. Dec. 10 (AP)The Congressional Directory, a compendium of Government information published annually for generations, will not be published in full next year.

title: Burgers or Ballplayers: The Perils of Monopoly
description: Marvin J. Miller (''How Much Is an Athlete Worth? And Who Decides?', &ov. 13) asserts that player salaries are none of the public's business. His arguments are that (1) a player's salary results from a private agreement between the player and the club's ownership and (2) owners do not consider player salaries when setting ticket prices.

title: 2 Children Die in Buffalo Fire
description: BUFFALO, Dec. 10 (AP)Two infants were killed today when a threealarm fire burned their East Side home, investigators said. The victims were identified as 1monthold Letonia Jones and her 2yearold sister, Plutzie Jones. Five other persons were taken to Sheehan Memorial Hospital for treatment for smoke inhalation.

title: GARDENING
description: ALTHOUGH winter's mantle of snow has only been a light shawl thus far, nature's wildlings have been ready for some time. Squirrels have nabbed all the nuts they could find for their storehouses, and the mice have tunneled deeper to keep their seed and berry supplies dry. The groundhogs couldn't be bothered with all this preparation; they choose to sleep through. And the birds? They will have to make do with the foods they can find.

title: State Reforms In WelfareTrouble Ahead
description: TRENTON ON April 2, it will become unlawful for ablebodied welfare recipients in New Jersey to sit on their duffsas Governor Byrne put itand draw relief checks.

title: New York Outlines Projects in Bid For Federal Funds for Needy Cities
description: Railroad yards in the South Bronx would become an industrial park, a surplus Coast Guard station would become marinerepair facility and the electricity costs of plastics manufacturers would be subsidized under a series of New York City proposals described at a hearing last week on a new Federal program for needy cities.

title: Ann Davis Bride of Joseph MacLaughlin 3d
description: Ann Kelso Davis was married yesterday afternoon in Newcastle, Me., to Joseph Shaw MacLaughlin 3d of New Haven, executive director of Art Resources of Connecticut. The Rev. John Ineson performed the ceremony in St. Andrew's Episcopal Church.

title: POINT OF VIEW.
description: Venture capital for startup companies, particularly hightechnology companies that have pioneered dramatic advances in such fruitful areas as microcircuitry and microcomputers, has all but vanished.

title: Words and Pictures
description: Last year Paddington Press inaugurated a continuing series of moderately priced paperbacks, Masterpieces of the Illustrated Book. Five were published then, seven more have just been issued: Public and Private Life of Animals, originally out in 1877, 175 blackandwhite illustrations by J. J. Grandville ($6.95). A New Method of Landscape, a 1785 book with 28 drawings by Alexander Cozens ($4.95). Images From the Old Testament, 1543, illustrated with 94 woodcuts by Hans Holbein ($4.95). Selections From a History of British Birds, a 1797 book written and illustrated with more than 200 wood engravings by Thomas Bewick ($6.95). The Revelation of St. John: Apocalypse, a 16thcentury volume with 23 engravings by Jean Duvet ($4.95). Under the Hill, Aubrey Beardsley's 1904 work with 18 blackandwhite illustrations ($4.95). Faust, by Johann Wolfgang Goethe, illustrated with 18 lithographs, dating from 1828 ($5.95).

title: Sports News Briefs
description: HAVERFORD, Pa., Dec. 10Philadelphia defeated New York, 43, today in the opening of the TriCity squash racquets singles matches at the Merion Cricket Club.

title: Practical Traveler: Charters and Security
description: Sidney Nemirov was amazed. At 2:30 A.M. on Oct. 1, he and his wife, Norma, boarded a charter flight of Capitol International Airways from New York to Rome. They walked directly from lounge at Kennedy International Airport onto the plane, without passing through any sort of check for security.

title: Precautions Are Urged For Happier Holidays
description: Elinor Guggenhelmer, the city's Consumer Affairs Commissioner, issued series of precautions yesterday for the coming holiday season, including the following: Know a stores refund policy before buying gifts.

title: Headliners
description: Two years ago, she was a symbol oC oppression Tor black and women's groups. Last week, she was the object of a midnight police chase through the streets of Brooklyn.

title: Four Novels
description: It is 1932, and Brant Laster has just returned to Milo, Ala. from the University at Tuscaloosa. He finds his hometown. like the rest of America, simmering in the afflictions of hard times and. Prohibition, waiting with mounting impatience for salvation in the form of Franklin D. Roosevelt. Filled with an uneasy mixture of loyalty and estrangement as he returns to the insular backwater that spawned him, Brant nurses a consuming loathing for the sort of Southern gentlemen he.

title: Dig They Must, Hither and Yon
description: MOST courses at the Scarsdale Adult School run for 10 weeks, ending in midDecember. But an archeology course that began in the fall of 1975 has not yet endedit just changed shape and direction.

title: LETTERS TO THE WESTCHESTER EDITOR
description: William Chappell's letter and the magnificent photograph of the railroad bridge at Goldens Bridge Nov. 13 were much appreciated. Your readers might be interested to know that the bridge, as one of three spans, was originally constructed over Rondout Creek, near Kingston, N.Y., about 1883. By its nature easily disassembled, it was moved in 1904 to its present site.

title: East German Civil Defense Force Upgraded to Paramilitary Group
description: BERLIN, Dec. 10 (Reuters)East Germany has upgraded its civil defense force into a fullscale paramilitary organization with ranks up to general and with the right to draft young men into its service.

title: Donations Provide Both Help And Hope
description: When Clare G., 42 years old, lit the oven and heard the gas ignite, she sighed with relief and satisfaction, and said to her homemaking teacher: The most important lesson to learn is never to give up hope. And that's what you taught me.

title: Yulia Lipmanovich Shows Impetuosity on Piano
description: Yulia Lipmanovich, who was born in the Soviet Union and emigrated to Israel in 1971, came to the United States as a scholarship student at the Juilliard School in 1974. Her piano recital Recital.

title: William Hale Fiance Of Suzanne Griffin
description: Mr. and Mrs. George Wortham Griffin Jr. of New Canaan, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Suzanrr., Rivers Griffin, to William Benton Hale, son of Dr. and Mrs. William H. Hale of Appleton, Wis.

title: Income Tax Is Seen As a Happy Event
description: THE state has finally done it. Whether one likes the income tax or not, the Assembly's action to end its automatic repeal next June (with the Senate likely to confirm) is providing the longerterm financial stability that New Jersey desperately needs.

title: Kristina Becker Is Bride Of Gerald S. Armstrong
description: Kristina Becker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George John Becker of Ridgewood, N.J., was married yesterday evening to Gerald Stuart Armstrong. son of Mr. and Mrs. George William Armstrong Jr. of Armonk, N.Y.

title: Rochelle Volin Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Maurice F. Volin of Oceanside, Li., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Rochelle Barbara Volin, to Steven W. Suflas, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Suflas of Haddonfield, N. J. The future bride, specialist with the United States Environmental Protection Agency in Philadelphia, and her fiance, a lawyer with the National Labor Relations Board in Philadelphia, plan to be married next April.

title: Brazilian Labor Federation Brinfis Court Action Against Government
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 10With Brazilian trade unions beginning to demand greater freedoms, one major labor federation has brought court action against the military Government in an unusual dispute over wages involving misleading official data on inflation.

title: Hospitals Await New Rate Plans.
description: TRENTON DR. JOANNE E. FINLEY, the state's Comissioner of Health, is in the process of preparing proposed rates that the 118 licensed general hospitals in New Jersey will be able to charge Blue Cross and Medicaid next year.

title: POLICEMAN AND BROTHER CHARGED WITH BURGLARY
description: A New York City policeman, who is on a disability leave, and his brother were arrested on larceny and burglary charges in Hicksville, L.I., a spokesman for Denis Dillon, the Nassau County District Attorney, said yesterday.

title: Armenians Ask Moscow for Help, Charging Azerbaijan With Bias
description: A territorial and ethnic conflict between Armenians and Azerbaijanis in a mountainous region of the Soviet Caucasus has ledaccording to reports filteracross the Soviet borderto tension, clashes, protest demonstrations at public events and pleas by Armenians to Moscow for help, including a recent letter to Leonid I. Brezhnev.

title: TOUGH LABOR ISSUES FACING KOCH IN 1918
description: Next year will be a light one in labor negotiations nationally, but it will be heavy one in collective bargaining in the public sector in New York City, where all major contracts expire.

title: Opponents of the Shah of Iran Burn Documents in Rome Embassy
description: ROME, Dec. 10 (AP)Twelve Iranian students shouting Down with the Shah! broke into Iran's Embassy here yesterday, and burned documents and smashed furniture and windows. the police renorted.

title: Moving and Desperate
description: ALLEN TATE'S work in poetry, fiction, and criticism touches American life at nearly every point of consequence and continues exert moral pressure even when the causes it serves are already mostly lost. Many of his poems take up arms against his fated enemies: the North; the forces in the Old South that made the New South inevitable; the ideologies of positivism and naturalism, which Tate regards as vandalism. The Collected Poems the definitive manual of these wars.

title: SADAT WARNS PLO. TO ALTER ITS STAND
description: CAIRO, Dec. 10President Anwar elSadat gave the Palestine Liberation Organization what amounted to a warning today to reverse its stand and support his negotiations with Israel.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW
description: The difference between good and bad architecture, or just plain pedestrian architecture., is a quality that might be vastly oversimplified as thoughtfulnessthe degree of sensitive concern. with which the elements of a program are com bined to satisfy both function and art.

title: Golden Driller, Shoe Size 393 Flakes in Tulsa
description: TULSA. Okla., Dec. 10They call it The Oil Capital of the World, this Southwest city of 352.000 people where J. Paul Getty and Harry Sinclair amassed fortunes in Oklahoma black gold.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: MANY people have beautiful old picture frames stowed in their basement or attic, or on the top shelf of a closet, that would be perfectly fine except that the corner joints have begun to work loose and mounting a picture safely thus becomes impractical.

title: ARBITRATION OF CASES URGED IN U.S. COURTS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP)Dan Meador, an Assistant Attorney General, is trying to persuade Federal judges to test his proposal for arbitrating disputes instead of scheduling them for the usual long round of hearings and a trial.

title: Forum Organized To Study Growth In New Hampshire
description: CONCORD, N.H., Dec. 10 (AP)New Hampshire's rampant and haphazard expansion has caused enough alarm among some of its prominent citizens to move them to organize and do something about it.

title: 909 Admitted to Bar In Trenton Ceremony
description: TRENTON, Dec. 9 (AP) Nine hundred nine lawyers were admitted to the bar in swearingin ceremonies here yesterday.

title: New Woman As Artist
description: DOROTHY RICHARDSON (18731957), author of the 13volume modernist novel,Pilgrimage, has always been subject to wild swings of adulation and neglect. John Cowper Powys worshipped her as a Pythian soothsayer; Leslie Fiedler, conceding the importance of her baffling and unorthodox literary technique, nonetheless found the novels permeated by her special dullness. Gloria Fromm's sober and conscientious biography fully establishes the facts of Richardson's hitherto shadowy life, and gives a more persuasive estimate of her achievement than any previous study.

title: Disturbance From Below
description: THIS is a provocative book that should be read by both students and makers of social history. say this even though I have some serious disagreements with what I consider to be the onesidedness of Frances Fox Piven and Richard A. Cloward's examination of four American protest movements. But even though I have significant reservations about the basic theses of Poor People's Movements, it is so superior to the the usual academic interpretation of these movements that I want to recommend it clearly before I state my differences.

title: BRIDGE
description: Some European experts have experimented with mininotrump opening bids on balanced hands with about 10 pointsoften with a vulnerability restriction to reduce the chance of losing 800 points against a nonvulnerable game.

title: Television This Week
description: Elizabeth Cheshire and Cliff DeYoung star in Sunshine Christmas, about a widower and his daughter who return to the family homestead for Christmas, Monday night at 9 on NBC.

title: For the Moment, a Film of the Mind
description: THE idea of somehow making a film of Marcel Proust's novel has no doubt been turned over by many minds in the half century or so since was published in its entirety. But what a daunting notion! Besides being the longest work of fiction we possess, Proust's great book is among the most subtle and complex, as well as being almost empty of action, external and physical events of the kind the screen has always seemed best suited to portray. The film hasn't yet been made and may never be, but Harold Pinter's screenplay for such a project has now been published. A rumor until now, wholly unexpected, a triumph against the odds, The Proust Screenplay is a superb piece of work.

title: As Others See Us
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10A big change has taken place in the way most regions of the world are now talking about the United States. Not so long ago, they were complaining that Washington was trying to dominate them, and now most countries seem to be complaining that Washington is neglecting them and minimizing their problems.

title: Business Is Booming At Christmas Tree Farms
description: HOLMDEL MORE and more now in the two weeks before Christmas, people will be coming here to the little hillside and pine grove of the Hazienda Evergreen Plantation to choose their trees and wreaths. The Hazienda, once the 50acre country retreat of the late Harold A. Zahl, an atomic physicist, is one of about 190 Christmas tree farms in the state.

title: Nature and Naturalists
description: What hiker, bird watcher or nature lover hasn't wished he could know America before it was settled, and experience its wildness as the continent's first naturalists did? In First in the Field: America's Pioneering Naturalists Robert Elman traces the careers of several men who, often compelled more by their own driving curiosity and ambition than by any. one else's encouragement, explorea the wnaerness from the Atlantic coast to the Grand Canyon, trying make order of the bewildering array of new plants, animals and natural features. From these mapping and collecting odysseys came the broad foundations North American botany, ornithology, mammalogy, geology and paleontology that enabled later generations of scientists to move from field to laboratory, ever refining and building upon the work of the often untrained pioneerscientists.

title: Stress and Strain In BudgetMaking
description: WHITE PLAINS PUTTING together an annual budget for Westchester County is a slow and tedious process under what seems to be somewhat unusual rules. The process began Nov. 14, when Alfred B. DelBello, the Democratic County Executive, gave the Republicandominated County Board of Legislators a proposed 1978 budget of $410 million, an increase of nearly $12 million over the current one.

title: Christine Hall Bride of Dr,. Paul Conrad Szal
description: Christine Nickerson Hall, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Durell Hall of Chatham, Mass., was married yesterday to Dr. Paul Conrad Szal, an intern at the DartmouthHitchcock Medical Center in Hanover. N.H.

title: Citizens Group Handbook Urges New Yorkers to Help Themselves
description: A handbook that encourages New Yorkers to help themselves has been issued by the Citizens Committee of New York City.

title: Rock's History On Six Disks
description: In looking over recent popmusic record releases, it occurred to this observer in a possibly misguided moment of whimsy that it might be possible to construct a capsule history of rockandroll in the course of reviewing six new albums. Not that each of the six necessarily represents the best of a type, or that there are six and only six types to consider in the course of rock. Still, each suggests something salient about a particular aspect of the mass music of the last two decades:

title: Hawaiian Amphipod and Spider May Become Endangered Species
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (UPI)An eyeless relative of the shrimp and a blind spider that eats it are being proposed for the nation's endangered and threatened species list, according to officials The Department of Interior.

title: Rutgers Finds A Book in Old New Jersey Postcards
description: NEW BRUNSWICK We are ??? ??? ??? ??? sahr wish you were here to go for hickory nuts with us. With love to all. Goodbye. In 1907, Esther E. Homell scrawled this message on the back of a postcard showing an alreadyquaint blacksmith shop in South Branch and mailed it to friends in Gladstone.

title: Wolf HybridsThe Latest in Pets
description: CHERRY HILL MANY of Cherry Hill's 800,000 inhabitants own animals, including a few horses, and now this sprawling subtir, ban township can boast of a moreunconventional animal. Not far from the ruins of Garden State Park live two animals known to a steadily growing number of fanciers as wolf hybrids.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: The article A Kind of Alchemy Turns Homes in Princeton to Gold, [Nov. 20], about the rising prices of homes in Princeton describes the realization of prophecy by the planning board at least five years ago.

title: Family of 5 Gets Touch Of New Life
description: There are four children in a family on the Lower East Side who are slowly coming into their own. An 18yearold girl has just started college. A 14year old boy, a sliver over 5 feet tall, holds his own in three basketball leagues. A 13yearold girl has begun to look people in the eye when she talks with them. And a 9yearold girl who once hung timidly back when people were around now craves a skateboard to make her the terror of Avenue C.

title: The Big Throwaway
description: THE Island is one of the nation's largest marketing areas, with residents who spend aggressively, supporting large shopping complexes spilling over with nonessentials that we are told we must have.

title: Immigrant Children of West Indies Reported Having School Problems
description: For many West Indian immigrant children and youths, the most severe culture shock, according to a recent conference on issues facing this immigrant community, is experienced in the city's public educational systems.

title: Shirley Logan Bride. Of Marcus Mitchell
description: The marriage of Shirley Cynthia Logan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Powell Logan of Hickory, N. C., to Marcus Goodrich Mitchell took place yesterday in the Corinth United Church of Christ in Hickory. The Rev. Gordon H. Sperry performed the ceremony.

title: The Course Is Jewish Social Studies
description: LAST October, seven teenagers sat quietly in Michael Baran's mainfloor classroom at the I.L. Peretz Jewish School in East Meadow, waiting for the start of the first class of the new Mittleshul High School sponsored by the Workmen's Circle of New York, a fraternal Jewish organization.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: It is Messiah time, and from now to the end of the year Handel's great oratorio will be omnipresentin the concert halls as presented by major musical organizations and lesser ones, and in the churches. There even is an annual Messiah singin. Thus it has been for over two centuries, despite the fact that some scholars continue to point out that Messiah is, properly speaking, more an Easter than a Christmas work.

title: LETTER FROM WASHINGTON
description: NEW JERSEY ranks third among the states in the amount of money spent per pupil in public elementary and secondary schools, but nine other states pay their publicschool teachers more than New Jersey does. And when it comes to higher education (colleges and universities), the state's expenditures per capita rank 46th.

title: At the Sovereign, There's Distress Amid Splendor
description: Alice Baker recently had a friend call and assure her that anytime she was afraid to stay in her apartment she could sleep at the friend's house. A retired execptive who lives in the same building says his daughter asks him, How's your building getting along? Joseph Braswell, an interior designer, says that whenever people find out where he lives they declare, Oh, you live in that building.

title: A TOUCH OF THE TRAGIC
description: lose Quintero suffers, as did Eugene O'Neill. from a sense of ??? about practically everything: sex. the quality of his work the core of his identity. The two never met, but Quintero feels possessed by 0'NeIll's

title: A Harbor of Refuge: Galilee, Rhode Island
description: There come to Rhode Island those halcyon late fall days of crisp blue skies and buffeting winds and cotton clouds that are so full of chilly, zip that nobody wants to stay home and admit that winter is upon us. On such days for 30 years now Rhode Islanders have been saying: Let's go down to George's in Galilee for some chowder and clamcakes.

title: INVESTING
description: Soybeans are falling? Great! Buy me 100 contracts as soon as possible.

title: Mexico's Yaqui Indians Retain Strong Tribal SelfGovernment
description: TORIM, MexicoWith dusty unpaved streets, dogs and chickens running wild and a tiny store selling sodas, the eight villages belonging to the Yaqui Indians seem like thousands of other rundown, communities in rural Mexico.

title: New Mothers Get Car Tips for Babies
description: PERTH AMBOY AUTOMOBILE accidents are among the leading causes of death among children, and the mothers of newborn babies who are patients at Perth Amboy General Hospital are taking part in a program designed to acquaint them with the peril of carrying infants and children in automobiles when the youngsters are not wearing approved restraints or are not in infant car seats.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: MANY people have beautiful old picture frames stowed in their basement or attic, or on the top shelf of closet, that would be perfectly fine except that the corner joints have begun to work loose and mounting a picture safely thus becomes impractical.

title: FISHING
description: FOR those hardy souls who pile on layers of clothes, grab their tackle boxes and rods and head for the partyboats in search of cod, there is some good news and some bad news. While there are only scatterings of cod, substantial quantities of baitfish have moved into waters along the South Shore, and it is hoped that cod will follow in their wake.

title: Two Goalies Tie Mark; Bladon's 8 Points a Record
description: National Hockey League recordchasing was capped last night when Dan Bouchard of the Atlanta Flames and Tony Esposito of the Chicago Black Hawks, goalies, each collected two assists in victories by their teams. They tied a record set three years ago by Gilles Meloche of the Cleveland Barons.

title: Soviet Dissidents Say K.G. B. Ends Confinement of
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 11Soviet dissidents said today that K.G.B. secret police gents had left the apartments of more than 20 activists who had been kept under house arrest all day yesterday.

title: A Consummate Correspondent
description: LONDON, Dec. 11David Holden was considered by his peers in Fleet Street to be one of the outstanding British correspondents of the postwar era.

title: Ethel Roosevelt Derby, a Daughter Of President Theodore Roosevelt
description: Ethel Roosevelt Derby, a daughter of President Theodore Roosevelt, died Saturday at her home in Oyster Bay, L.I. She was 86 years old.

title: Stroem Bowling Victor
description: LONDON, Dec. 11 (AP)Arne Stroem of Norway beat Phillipe DuBois of France, 609 to 606, and won the Bowling World Cup today.

title: Interior Dept. Hires Arbitrators To Settle EnergyEcology Rifts
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (UPI)The Interior Department has hired the American Arbitration Association to study ways of resolving the growing conflicts of environmental protection and energy development, it was annonced today.

title: Betsy J. Rosenfield, TV Aide, Is Bride of Norman H. Samet
description: Betsy. 7. Rosenfield, a production associate in the documentary unit of ABC News, and Norman H. Samet, an associate director with ABC Sports, were married yesterday afternoon in Temple Shaaray Tefila by Rabbi Bennet M. Hermann of East Meadow Oueens.

title: Commodity Futures Trading Up By 26 Percent for November
description: Commodity futures trading volume jumped 26 percent last month from the November 1976 level, the Futures Industry Association reported over the weekend.

title: Cocteau's Charming 'Baron'
description: "The Phantom Baron" is a fairy tale that ends with the words "once upon a time," but that's the least of its eccentricities. Written by Jean Cocteau, and nominally directed by Serge de Poligny (Cocteau is known to have directed parts of the film himself), it combines the structure of an ordinary fable with the nebulous spirit of a sweet dream. Characters who are fully identified remain perplexingly unknowable, and no situation is ever quite what it seems to be. Yet Cocteau's screenplay is drawn with such delicacy that the film's warmth and generosity override its cool fascination with sleight-of-hand.In this 1943 production, now having its New York theatrical premiere at the Bleecker Street Cinema, the baron of the title is played by Cocteau himself. He vanishes mysteriously in his own chateau, leaving behind a very knowing-looking black cat. His family, including a countess and her young daughter and stepdaughter, come to live on the estate, which is photographed in shadow and on a tilt, and which is made to look as haunted as an estate can possibly be. The girls immediately befriend a young servant boy, Herve.Years later, they both begin to fall in love with him. However, they are also a little bit in love with the dashing soldier Alberic, (Claude Samval), whose confident manner makes Herve (Alain Cuny) seem especially withdrawn by comparison. The young women seem somewhat alike at first, but the heiress Elfy (Odette Joyeux) gradually reveals herself to be more frivolous than the lovely and generous Anne (Jany Holt).The actors swirl in and out of character, and the romantic alignments shift subtly and often, until the circumstances surrounding the baron's mysterious death are explained. It seems he deliberately sealed himself inside a cellar (his death was "somewhat Egyptian," someone remarks), and left behind a will that untangles the plot's many questions of identity. His legacy should be one of clarity, but the film's concluding note is more one of wise and joyful acceptance, and of long-delayed understanding of the way things have always been.There is a thin, almost satirical wit to the stylized opening of the story, but it is not until later that a mood of maturity is established, and the more breathless segment of the story begins. The loveliest scene, an extravagantly romantic one, shows a dream shared by Anna and Herve, he carrying her across a misty "Wuthering Heights"-style landscape and she in a white gown with a long flowing veil. The ecstasy of the moment is unequaled by anything else here, but it is so extravagantly lovely that its radiance goes a long way.

title: White Rhodesians Way of Life And Political Views Show Strain
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Dec. 6The ads appear every few hours on television and every day in the newspapers. They show fashionably dressed, smiling people enjoying poolside barbecues, playing golf and tennis, dancing at nightclubs. The images change but the people are always white, never black. The tag line is always the same: Once you're a Rhodesian, no other land will do.

description: The Police Department's hockey team rounced the Fire Department, 111, yesterday afternoon Wore a crowd of 3,579 at Madison Square Garden. Greg Terhune scored three goals for the police.

description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 11  Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance said today that the United States would do all it could to mend the split in the Arab world and thereby improve the chances for achieving an overall ArabIsraeli peace agreement.

description: BOSTON, Dec. 11Peace requires choices. That practical truth has been imprinted on the consciousness of Israel in chese last weeks: aprincipal effect of President Sadat's visit.

title: Michigan Fire Kills 6 in Family
description: CENTRAL LAKE, Mich., Dec. 11 (UPI) A faulty oil heater in one of Antrim County's oldest homes was termed the cause of a fire that killed all six members. of the Howard Duncan family. Mr. Duncan, 32 years old, his wife, Ellen, 27, and their four young daughters all died in their beds yesterday in the fire, which destroyed the house in Central Lake Township they had occupied about a year. Most of the damage was around an oil space heater, said John Gaddis, Antrim County chief sheriff deputy. The first floor was burned through in that area. He said that the Duncans had been having trouble with the heater so we figure that's where it started.

title: The Life Of the Mind
description: Having spent five years in the lofty academic post of full professor at a prestigiops university, I can't puzzle out why my former colleagues in industry look with envy on my new affiliation. Most of them applaud my courage in walking away from a lucrative executive position, and wish that they. had the guts to abandon the rat race for the tranquil groves of academe. I assure them that their idea of a university bears little resemblance to the reality principle, and that their notion that they will find tranquility in academe is a gross canard.

Erie Mining Company that began Aug. 1, Joe Smilanich, president of the local, said yesterday. He added that the return to work would i start as soon as possible.

title: CYCLONE SURVIVORS STRUGGLING IN INDIA
description: PENUMUDI, India, Dec. 5The ferrymen of Penumudi, on the River Krishna, never dreaded a cyclone or flood before. They felt invulnerable. But the tropical cyclone that came upon them a few weeks ago, pushing a huge wave up the river, was the sort of thing they hope never to see again.

title: Testing Democracy in Portugal
description: The fall of Portugal's Socialist Government this week Is not the failure of its experiment in democracy, only demonstration of its difficulties. Nor is it a failure for the nation's impressive leader, Prime Minister Mario Soares. His choice of a parliamentary defeat over the available alternatives revealed again his deep commitment to moderation and to the ideal of broadly based government.

description: UNITED NATIONS, Dec. 11  As seen from here, the position of the Palestine Liberation Organization has been rendered precarious by the split between President Anwar elSadat of Egypt and the Arab countries that have atNews tacked his peace initiatives toward Israel. Analysis The P.L.O. possibly has the consolation that in the General Assembly there has been another round oil debates in which the Arab countries, with Communist and thirdworld support, once again have affirmed their backing for the P.L.O. in a raft of new resolutions.

All this implied in the proposed energy trust fund now being considered by Congress. Such a fund is intended funnel billions of dollars in crude oil tax revenues back to the energy industry to finance risky projects.

title: News Summary
description: The United States will do all it can to mend the split among the Arab nations over Egypt's peace overtures to Israel. Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance said at a joint news conference in Jerusalem with Prime Minister Menahem Begin. Mr. Vance's trip to the Middle East was made to obtain pledges from both Israel and Egypt that they would not seek a separate peace at next week's conference in Cairo and to persuade other Arab nations to attend the meeting. Mr. Begin said, as President Anwar elSadat said Saturday in Cairo, that he would not seek a separate treaty. Later. Mr. Vance said that the United States expected King Hussein of Jordan to join the conference. [Page 1, Column 6.]

description: PATERSON  Less than 10 minutes from the center of this Passaic County industrial community, horse lovers are happily at work rubbing down mounts, clearing stalls and, despite the brisk weather, taking advantage of the miles of riding trails on Garrett Mountain Reservation.

This combination attracted a nearcapacity audience to Carnegie Hall Saturday night where the popular French trumpeter Maurice Andre gave a joint recital with the organist Alfred Mitterhofer.

A bronze plaque and certificate was presented to church officials by Ira J. Hutchison, the deputy director of the National Park Service. The church, built in 1878, became the 16th historic landmark recognized in Alabama by the Park Service since the program began in 1960.

Not unless everyman wants to play tight end with a plastic vest protecting three broken ribs, one of which was still displaced. But when the New England Patriots completed their 1410 victory over the Miami Dolphins, Russ Francis had nlaved every down on offense.

A police spokesman said that the arrests were made last night along Sunset Boulevard by a special force of policewomen. He said that those arrested represented a wide cross section of American humanity.

title: Chess:

But the exhibition that recently filled Castelli was not only not a show of work by a wellknown artist, it also was not, strictly speaking, chow of works of art at all.

title: New York City Is Turning Down 48% of New Welfare Applicants
description: Nearly half of all new welfare applicants in New York City are being turned down  48 percent since July 1, compared with 25 to 35 percent before new, tighter controls in mid1976  and complaints of harassment and delays are being raised by client representatives.

description: Suzie Chen, a candidate for a doctoral degree in genetics at Albert Einstein College of Medicine, was married yesterday to Dr. Leigh Switzen Wise, who is doing biology research as a postdoctoral fellow at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

description: Governor Carey pressed yesterday for what he called a Federal credit compact to support borrowing by New York City.

title: NASA to Launch Japanese Satellite
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (UPI) The Space agency plans to launch Japan's first communications satellite Wednesday from Cape Canaveral, Fla., into a stationary orbit over the eastern Pacific. The spacecraft is designed to relay radio, data and color television signals between the Japanese islands for at least three years.

title: Reforming Welfare
description: WASHINGTONThe major issue In the debate over the President's proposal to reform the welfare system is beginning to emerge: Would it not be more prudent and efficient to approach welfare reform incrementally, stepbystep, rather than in one major leap forward as President Carter has proposed?

description: Negotiators for the striking United Mine Workers union and the coal industry met for several hours yesterday for contract talks and a top union official said afterward, We're making progress.

The ceremony was performed at the home of the bridegroom's son, Steven Schwimmer of Woodbury. L. I., by Acting Supreme Court Judge Nat H. Hentel of Queens County.
