description: THE SUBJECT of Monday evening's Alice Tully Hall program was the French Baroque, with music by Lully, Elizabeth Jacquet de La Guerre, JeadFerry Rebel and Rameau. The music was performed by the Concert Royal. Orchestra under James Riohman's di. rection, and in the first half two bits of Lully and something called Les Caracteres de la Danse by Rebel were danced as solos by three members of

title: SeattleSlew Best Horse; Forego 2d
description: Unable to confront each other on the race track, Seattle Slew and Forego finally met at the ballot box yesterday in the annual Eclipse Awards voting.

title: Korchnoi Wins Eighth Game,
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 13 (AP) Viktor Korchnoi, upsetting predictions, today won the eighth game of his 20game match against Boris Spassky in the finals of the tourney to determine a challenge for the world chess championship. The game had been adjourned yesterday in a position in which Spassky was largely favored to win. Korchnoi now leads 6 to 2 and needs 10.5 points to win the match and the right to challenge Anatoly Karpov, of the Soviet Union, the world oh moion.

title: Bonn Defense Aide Suspended After Spy Disclosures
description: WEST BERLIN, Dec. 13West Germany's Defense Minister, facing a storm of criticism over the disclosure of a major spy ring in his ministry, announced the suspension today of an official from whose safe both West German and NATO military secrets had been passed to East Germans.

title: SPEAR WITHDRAWS AS MARKET MAKER IN 18 OF 19 STOCKS
description: Spear, Leeds & Kellogg, the largest specialist firm at the New York Stock Exchange, yesterday abandoned its effort to compete with another specialist unit in 18 of the 19 issues in which they both have made markets since July.

title: Notes on People
description: THE. White House began its official observance of the holiday season yesterday when Rosalynn Carter shOwed off a very, N ery special 20foot fir tree with 1,500 decorations made by retarded persons. Later in the day the President and Mrs. Carter held a reception for members of Congress and their families. This afternoon, the Carters and their daughterAmy will entertain children of the diplomatic corps, at a Christmas party and a special performance of The Littlest Clown, starring the Pixie Judy Troupe withHelen. Hayes as guest narrator. The Pixie Judy Troupe, which performs the play weekendafternoons at the Copacabana Club in New York, is believed to be the first theater company for children to perform at the White House.

title: Three in Family Found Slain in Fire
description: ELIZABETH, Dec. 13A seclusive elderly couple and their daughter were ound slain in their flaming beds here this morning, and their son, discovered unconscious in his bedroom, died later at a local hospital.

title: Rock: Students Outshine The Master
description: THERE WERE two outwardly similar bands on hand Sunday and Monday at the Bottom Line. Both played a basically instrumental kind of rhythm-and-bluesflavored jazzish rock with extensive vocal overlays, and the members of the opening band count the leader of the headlining band as one of their principal influences. But in this case the students have outshone the master, in that the opener, Baby Grand. was appreciably more interesting than the headliner. Treasure.

title: SMALLPDX WIPED OUT IN ITS WORST FORM
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 13The worst form of smallpox, the kind that kills, blinds and maims, has been eradicated but a much milder form remains in Somalia on the horn of Africa, Dr. Halfdan Mahler, the head of the World Health Organization, said here today.

title: Gulf Oil Chemicals Unit Charges European Dumping of Cumene
description: PITTSBURGH, Dec. 13 (AP)The Gulf Oil Chemicals Company said today it had filed antidumping complaints against European producers of cumene, a chemical used to produce plastics, adhesives and synthetic fibers.

title: P.B.A. Opposes Codd Pension, CitingInterest Conflict
description: A lawyer for the New York City Patrolmen's Benevolent Association charged yesterday that Police Commissioner Michael J. Codd was involved in a conflict of interest in seeking a $46,600-a-year disability pension while still in office.

title: Jazz Beats Lakers, 11794, Before 31,119 in Superdome
description: NEW ORLEANS, Dec,13 (AP)The New Orleans Jazz gained a 11794 victory tonight over the Los Angeles Lakers, who had to fly in a sick player to muster the eightman squad required by National Basketball Association rules.

title: Market Place

title: Ormandy And Verdi Triumph Over Illness

But one by one, a week or so ago, they dropped away like . victims of anepidemic. Tatiana Tryoanos, in Paris, sent word she was ill. James McCracken and Martti Talvela came down with assorted ills. That left Martina Arroyo. She snapped her fingers at illness.

title: Mondale Says White House Overloaded Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13With Congress about to put off final passage of an energy program until next year, Vice President Mondale conceded today that the Carter Administration had overloaded Congress and that some of its initiative had suffered from fratricide.

title: Venezuela Denies OPEC Parley Delay
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 13A spokesman for the Venezuelan Government denied this afternoon that there were any plans for postponing the annual meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) that scheduled to begin here Dec. 20.

description: ATLANTA, Dec. 13 (AP)The National Bank of Georgia, once headed by Bert Lance, former Federal Budget Director, said today it had asked Federal bank regulators to allow trading of its stock to resume as scheduled this week when a 10day trading halt expires.

title: GULF OIL IS DROPPING PRICE WATERHOUSE
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation announced yesterday that its directors had recommended that Coopers & Lybrand replace Price Waterhouse & Company as the company's independent auditors.

But when he faltersas he did in taking only second prize in Manila last year, and more recently, ending in a tie for fourth in the Leningrad International Tournamentthat's another story. description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 13I spoke today to Cairo, Menahem Begin said. If anybody would have told his friend that three weeks agofour weeks ago that that is going to happen, that man would have tried to commit him.

title: F.B.I. Agents Describe Bizarre Years With Militants
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 12A curious tale a tale of feministleaning revolutionaries who, the authorities say, practiced for assassinations with BB guns, drilled for auto chases by driving gocarts and recruited an undercover Federal agent who taught them how not to shoot straightis emerging in court documents here.

title: BAN IN KENYA HAILED BY CONSERVATIONISTS

description: Robert F. Wagner Jr. is expected to be named chairman of the City Planning Commission, a job his father once held on his way to becoming a threeterm Mayor.

title: Queens School Board Told to Shift Racially Separated Gifted Students
description: The New York City Board of Education yesterday charged a community school board in Queens with assigning 140 gifted students to four special classes in a racially identifiable way. It ordered the local board to reassign some of the children to end racial separation.

title: The Carter Tax Program: New Complications Arise
description: As the Carter Administration continues to ponder the tax proposals It will make to Congress early next year, some new elements have entered.the picture that further complicate the situation. The dominant element is the Federal budget, in deep deficit now and not likely to make much progress or any toward the blance that the Administration had set as a goal by the end of its first term.

title: A Donor to Neediest Cases Recalls Young Boy's Death in Sending Gift
description: The death of a young boy was recalled by Roberta J. Maras of the graduate department of Clark University in Worcester, Mass., as she sent a check for $20 in his memory to the 66th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

Man and His Cougar Not Parted
description: WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 13It may have been the onset of the Christmas season and its attendant generosity of spirit, or it may have been the innocent, faraway look in her eyes but whatever the reason, the result was clear: Misty, a 4-year-old cougar, can stay with her owner. And as far as her owner, Arnold Weber, is concerned. all's well that ends well.

title: Europe Fears Holiday Terrorism
description: VIENNA, Dec. 13Security officials here and in other European countries fear that internationally linked terrorist groupsmainly Arab and West German extremistsmay be preparing a major attack in the Christmas period for the sake of maximum shock effect.

description: The appointments of Hugh F. Pr:ce anti Robert Curvin to the editorial board of The New York Times were ann.u.lced yesterday by Max Frankel, editor of the editorial page.

title: To BeThin, Beautiful and Cheek-to-Jowl
description: It's probably a good thing that skinny and fashionable are almost synonymous. A lot of people who took a deep breath at Sam LeTulle's party for Harriet de Rosiere last weekend, didn't have that easy a time exhaling. It was, as the saying goes, wall to wall people, and it wasa smash success.

title: West Side Board Creates Blueprint for Development
description: A New York City housing official yesterday credited the initiative of a Manhattan neignbornood planning board with the creation of a development blueprint that is expected to generate tens of millions of dollars worth of longdelayed construction on the Upper West Side.

description: ROME, Dec. 13 (UPI)  The police reported firebomb and arson attacks against political party offices, a church and West German commercial office today.

title: School Board in the Bronx Hires A Controversial Superintendent
description: Dr. Roland N. Patterson, who was dismissed in 1975 as superintendent of the Baltimore school system on charges of maladministration, has been hired as superintendent of Community School Board 9 in the Bronx. He takes over on Jan. 3.

title: 1 Iniured in Blasts at Millstone, Conn., Nuclear Plant
description: WATERFORD, Conn., Dec, 13 (AP)Two explosions at the Millstone nuclear power plant today blew a door off building at the plant, injuring one employee and releasing a small amount of radioactive material.

title: Harry Cohen, 73, Past President Of Bronx County Bar Association
description: Harry Cohen, president of the Bronx County Bar Association in 1953, died suddenly Monday while in Family Court, the Bronx. He was 73 years old and lived at 860 Grand Concourse, the Bronx.

title: Precious Metals Rise as Dollar Falls
description: With no remedy in sight for the weakening dollar overseas, the prices of pre.cious metals yesterday recovered some of their recent losses.

title: 3 NEAR COLLISIONS CITED AT KENNEDY
description: The Federal Aviation Administration Is looking into an unusual run of three incidents in the last two weeks in which, officials said, airliners over the New York area were given faulty instructions that brought them uncomfortably cloie to other planes.

title: WHITE CONCERNS GET A MINORITY CONTRACT
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13A S37.8 million Government contract to manufacture concrete railroad ties for the Northeast Corridor Project, originally earmarked for a company owned by members of a minority group, was awarded today to two whiteowned concrete companies.

title: 2 New Lawsuits Charge 9 Equipment Producers With Price Plot in Wiring
description: In the latest of a series of suits, nine manufacturers of electrical wiring equipment and 12 of their officers were charged yesterday with conspiring over a I4year period to raise the prices of wiring devices and control the conditions of their sale in violation of the Sherman Antitrust Act.

Advertising
description: AnheuserBusch, which has been looking for a new agency to replace Gardner Advertising as agency for its Busch Bavarian beer and Busch Gardens theme parks, yesterday announced it was splitting the assignment between two of the three finalist agencies. Needham, Harper & Steers, Chicago, is getting the beer and McDonald & Little, Atlanta, the parks.

title: ISRAELI INTERVIEWED
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 13Prime Minister Menahem Begin said today that Egypt and Israel would present drafts for proposed peace treaties when the Middle East peace negotiations open in Cairo tomorrow.

title: Battle Reported in West Sahara
description: NOUAKCHOTT, Mauritania. Dec. 13 (AP)Mauritanian troops battled in the western Sahara yesterday with guerrillas who infiltrated from Algeria in more than 120 vehicles, military sources here said. There was no immediate report of casualties. Algerianbacked guerrillas have waged a twoyear campaign against Morocco and Mauritania, which partitioned and annexed the former Spanish Sahara.

title: Star's Pride Dies at 30
description: HANOVER, Pa., Dec. 13 (AP)Star's Pride, the leading trotting stallion whose offsprings earned almost $25 million, died today at Hanover Shoe Farm. He was 30 years old. According to the United States Trotting Association, the earnings by the sons and daughters of Star's Pride established a standardbred stud record. Star's Pride sired eight Hambletonian winners and such standouts as Nevele Pride, Super Bowl, Savoir, Meadow Bright, and Armbro Flight.

title: Legislators Shaping Plan to Permit Vote On Social Security
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13A major Social Security financing bill could be passed by Congress Thursday under parliamentary compromise that appeared to be taking shape today in busy behindthescenes maneuvering on Capitol Hill.

Perhaps it is unfair, and also irrelevant, so long as readers are attracted to the poems and not their creator. But there can be little doubt that the appeal of Anne Sexton: A SelfPortrait in Letters is extraliterary. For if you take away the

title: Around the Nation
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 13 (UPI)The Missouri Legislature's refusal to ratify the proposed equal rights amendment has cost this city an estimated $1.1 million in lost convention business and the state should help make up the loss, according to city officials.

title: GOING OUT Guider
description: GREENWICH TIME Leave it to the Village Singers, one of the most enterprising vocal groups in the city, to help usher in the holidays with spirit and novelty. Tonight, at 7:30 the Singers are joining with the Sunday Brunch Company, a group of actors who stage poetry readings, for an evening of chamber and choral music, Christmas and Hanukkah stories, a presentation of Dylan Thomas's A Child's Christmas in Wales and the singing of traditional carols. The place is St. Joseph's Church, Avenue of the Americas at Washington Place. and the audience is invited to linger for a reception sponsored by the Caring Community, which is currently trying to buy the Village Nursing Home.

Rupp, whose 874 basketball victories at the University of Kentucky were the most in college history, was buried today in a private graveside ceremony following the public funeral service. The hearse bearing Mr. Rupp's body passed Memorial Coliseum, where two of his four national championship teams had played.

It has become obvious that the Canadian people need a new government before they can have any hope, said Joe Morris, president of the 2.3 millionmember Canadian Labor Congress.

Plans for Site 35 call for 16 threestory row houses on West 90th Street and 14 three- and fourstory town houses on West 89th. Site 40 has been re'er ed for two fivestory walkups and a sevenstory elevator building across the street from Site 41, where the Goddard Riverside Community Center plans housing for the elderly. title: Former Moon Disciple Sues Sect for $23,500
description: HACKENSACK, Dec. 13A 26-yearold former disciple of the Rev. Sun Myung Moon sued the Korean evangelist and his Unification Church today for return of $23,500 in cash and securities he said he gave the sect when he joined it December 1971.

title: TV Guide Is Raising Its Rate Base by 1.7%
description: TV Guide, the country's largestcirculation magazine, is raising its circulationrate base 1.7 percent to 18.3 million with the April I, 1978 issue. At the same time it will raise its ad rates about 8 percent. So a fourcolor page will go to $61,000 and black-and-white to $51,300.

title: The Consolations of Commissioner Codd
description: Much that is wrong in the laws and attitudes about pensions for public servants in New York can be illustrated by the case of the city's chief cop. We regret that an honest and diligent official like Police Commissioner Michael Codd should be caught up in the middle of all; he is hardly unique. But the very fact that he is only exercising his rights underscores our concern.

title: Thais Seize 49 Laotian Refugees
description: NONGKHAL Thailand, Dec. 13 (UPI)Hundreds of Thai police and rightwing activists swept into a United Nations refugee camp here today and arrested at least 49 Laotians they accused of being Communist spies.

title: World News Briefs
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 13 (Reuters)Prof. Veniamin G. Levich, the most distinguished Soviet scientist to apply to emigrate to Israel, said today that it was wishful thinking to attribute a rise in Jewish emigration to a change in Soviet policy.

title: 60Minute Gourmet
description: IT WILL. BE interesting to know the name of the cook or chef who first discovered that a splash of spirit would enhance the flavor of a dish. The name of the dish and the circumstances of that landmark decision will never be known, but posterity owes him a debt. .

title: Memories: II OldFashioned Wan
description: PARISIn a relative sense all wars prior .to Aug. 6 and after Aug. 9, 1945, when the first and second nuclear weapons were used, have been oldfashioned. Killing has been dreadful and on an especially large scale in conflicts like the Thirty Years War, World Wars I and II, Vietnam. But terrible as they have been, they were as nothing compared to what mankind now can do to mankind_

title: Music: Stuttgart Trio
description: THIS YEAR is the 150th anniversary of Beethoven's death, a milestone that has passed with little fanfare, compared to the numerous musical celebrations that marked the composer's 200th birthday in 1970.

title: Nevelsons Enhance Chapel
description: RELIGION, someone remarked the other day, is now just like art. It can be anything anyone wants it to be. This Is undoubtedly an exaggeration. Orthodox believers of every faith still somehow manage to preserve their traditional modes of doctrine, piety and worship. But the observation does go a long way toward describing the new Erol Beker Chapel of the Good Shepherd, which the sculptor Louise Nevelson has created for St. Peter's Church, at 54th Street and Lexington Avenue.

description: Tentative agreement was reached between the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York and a teachers union on R. new threeyear contract that, according to a state mediator, would bring the teachers salary into line with other Catholic school jurisdictions in the area.

title: TV: First Of Two Balanchine Programs
description: GEORGE BALANCH1NE does not especially like television, but several of his works can be seen tonight and next Wednesday, at 9 o'clock on Channel 13, on Public Television's superb Dance in America series. Now approaching the age of 74, the artistic director of the New York City Ballet is a compleat creature of the stage and live performance. Naturally enough, small screens with their two-dimensional electronic images tend to make him nervous and suspicious. But he is also shrewdly realistic.

description: WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 13The United States Department of Transportation today, in a controversial and long-awaited decision, approved the installation of an Instrument Landing System (ILS) at Westchester County Airport.

title: RICHARD KLAWITTER
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 13 (AP)Richard Klawitter, who played center for the Chicago Bears in 1956 and 1957, died in his sleep Sunday at his home in Waterloo, Iowa. He was 46 years old. Mr. Klawitter played at South Dakota State before joining the National Football League team.

title: Deaths
description: BAKERGeorge F Jr.December 11, 1977. Beloved husband of Kim, lather of Lavinia, Kane, George III, Anthony & Pauline.Funeral services Wednesday 11AM St Johns of Lattingtown, Lattingtown Road, Locust Valley NY.Surial will he private.

title: Future as a Player for Tomjanovich Still Uncertain
description: Because there is not yet a clear and unanimous medical opinion on what Rudy Tomjanovich's treatment and eventual recovery might be, the present condition and future prospects of the Houston Rockets captain remained uncertain yesterday.

title: American Can Plans To Buy Sam Goody
description: Sam Goody Inc.; New York's oldest record  tapes  audio equipment retail chain, has signed a preliminary agreement to merge with the Pickwick International subsidiary of the American Can Company, according to a joint announcement yesterday. The transaction involves an exchange of stock with a current value of $4.8 million.

title: Girl Dies of Injuries Suffered In Jersey City Car Crash Dec.
description: JERSEY CITY, Dec. 13 (UPI)A girt died last night of Injuries suffered Dec. 4 in a car crash caused by a youth who swung a pipe at the driver.

title: About Education
description: Back in the days before the knowledge explosion, when there was a consensus on what constituted a proper curriculum, almost all students studied pretty much the same subjects.

title: CARTER IS DISPUTED ON COUPLES
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13  President Carter, has said he wants to eliminate the tax advantage that unmarried couples enjoy over the married, but the word apparently has not reached the Department of Justice vet.

title: Loomis Retiring as Public Broadcasting Chief
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 Henry W. Loomis, who has been president of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting since 1972, announced today that he would retire at the end of his current term next September, or sooner, if successor were found.

title: Harlem School District Faces Audit in Spending of U.S. Funds
description: The new superintendent of Community School District 5 in Harlem, citing questionable practices in the spending of Federal funds, has asked for an audit of the district. Schools Chancellor Irving Anker has said in reply that a fullscale audit will be undertaken.

title: CORRECTION
description: In the People and Business item yesterday, the company in which James E. Preston was named to an executive post was identified incorrectly. Mr. Preston was elected executive vice president of Avon Products Inc.

title: Columbia Bows, 6756, To St. John's
description: What St. John's needed desperately last night in order to pull out its sixth victory in seven games was something like a new face, a bit of an anonymous threat. And the Redmen got both in the person of Rudy Wright, who came off the bench to help defeat Columbia, 6756, at Alumni Hall in Hillcrest, Queens.

title: Saudis Hint Favorable View on West Bank Proposal
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Dec. 13Saudi Arabian officials, speaking privately today, welcomed yesterday's rep6rts from Jerusalem that Israel might agree to partition the Vest Bank of the Jordan River, which it occupies. with Palestinians.

title: 9 Tons of Pecans for a Cause
description: I HAVE sixpacks stashed all over this apartment, Dorothy Guth was saying. That closet is full and every inch of the refrigerator is taken. It isn't exactly the sort of confession you'd expect to wring out of a stylish Smith College graduate who has just finished, among other things, editing The Letters of E. B. White.

title: ARTHUR H. HOLCOMBE, HARVARD LEADER,DIES
description: Arthur H. Holcombe, a retired professor of government and a major shaper of the curriculum in his department at Harvard University, died Friday in Gwynned, Pa. He was 93 years old.

title: Labor Meeting: Holding Operation Sans Fervor
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 13When rising to second the nomination of George Meany for still another term as president of the A.F.L.C.I.0., Raymond R. Corbett, head of New York State's Labor federation, confessed, I have wracked my mulct ror something to say that has not been said a thousand times before Mr. Corbett eventually produced a speech of praise for the 83-year-old Mr. Meany. But his problem reflected a condition that seemed to afflict this 12th annual convention of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations from its beginning last week: It is having difficulty saying things that have not been said a thousand times before.

title: Maniscalco Inquiry Of Alleged Beatings Dropped in Brooklyn
description: An investigation into charges that John Maniscalco had often beaten his wife, Rosemarywho died last week after 12 days in a comawas dropped yesterday by. District Attorney Eugene Gold of Brooklyn.

title: ABDUL MALEK
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, Dec. 13 (AP) Abdul Malek, the last governor of East Pakistan before it became Bangladesh, died today of a heart ailment. He was 74. Mr. Malek was jailed at the time of the IndianPakistani war that led to the independence of Bangladesh in 1971. He was released two years later under an amnesty.

title: Compromises in Coal Strike Hinted
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13Negotiations on a new coal labor contract that could .end the eight-day-old strike of 160,000 members of the United Mine Workers were officially in recess here today amid reports that each side was considering a softening of demands presented at the last bargaining session yesterday.

title: In the Sphinx's Shadow
description: As the Cairo conference convenes todayappropriately enough, in the shadow of the Sphinxthe Prime Minister of Israel and the President of Egypt, with the United States acting as uneasy middleman, are facing their moment of truth.

title: The Cardoon: A Stranger In the Kitchen
description: At first glance, cardoons look much like gigantic, overgrown celery. At first taste they suggeit exceptionally delicate artichoke hearts. By all odds these tail, wide, spiny stalks with their suedelike, silvery green covering are, to most Americans, a mystery. But the Italians who know them as cardi or cardoni, and the French who call this vegetable carde, both value them highly.

title: BOND MARKETS SHOW IMPRESSIVE STRENGTH
description: The credit markets showed impressive strength yesterday, handling an outpouring of new taxexempt bond issues with no trouble. In addition, Government securities prices rose modestly as the Federal Reserve bought notes and bonds and the Treasury disclosed plans to raise less money next week than expected.

title: CORRECTION
description: In the People and Business item yesterday, the company in which James E. Preston was named to an executive post was identified incorrectly. Mr. Preston was elected executive vice president of Avon Products Inc.

title: People and Business
description: Phil H. Richey has been named president of the Winchester Group of the Olin Corporation, one of the world's major producers of sporting arms and ammunition, James F. Towey, Olin's chairman and chief executive officer, announced yesterday. The appointment is effective Jan. 1.

title: COAST INQUIRIES PICK PANTHERS AS TARGET
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Dec. 11Elements of the Black Panthers are targets in investigations of murder, attempted murder, attempts to assassinate witnesses and possible misuse of public funds given for support of poverty programs dominated by Panthers.

title: National Strike of Farmers to Start Today
description: DENVER, Dec. 13Leaders of a nationwide farmer protest movement appealed to Congress today, on the eve of a strike deadline, to let them plead their case before a joint session.

title: JapanU.S. Trade Backlash
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13  There are dangers of a backlash in the present trade confrontation between the United States and Japan that could cause both sides to retreat for a little tranquil reflection after Nobuhiko Ushiba, the new Japanese Minister of External Economic Affairs, leaves Washington Thursday. His offers to reduce the size of his nation's huge trading surplus were immediately deemed insufficient by his American interlocutors, and yet if the United States presses too hard it may trigger In Japan a vehement nationalistic reaction against being pushed around.

title: We Do Not Pick No Jumpers
description: Back when Belmont and Aqueduct had a steeplechase or hurdle race every day, there was a gravelvoiced character who sold selection cards on the Long Island Rail Road's race track special. 'Here y'are, he would croak, padding through the coaches where players sat studying the past performance figures, here y'are, seven winners. We do not pick no jumpers.

title: News Summary
description: International

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Search for Fishing Boat Fails
description: BOSTON, Dec. 13 (UPI)The fourth day of an international air and sea search for a missing 85foot fishing boat with 13 Maine and Massachusetts men aboard ended in vain at dusk today. Much debris was found but none could be positively identified as belonging to the Navigator, scalloper that was reported missing on Saturday. .

title: New U.N. Agricultural Agency Chooses Saudi Arabian as Chief
description: ROME, Dec. 13 (UPI)A new United Nations organization, the International Fund for Agricultural Development, began operation today when its governing council elected Abdelmuhsin alSudeary of Saudia Arabia as its first president.

title: Did Japan Mislead Carter?
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13  Last spring, when Prime Minister Takeo Fukuda of Japan came to Washington, he told officials here that Japan would have an overall trade deficit this year of about $700 million. Instead his country will have a trade surplus of over $13 billion, about $8.5 billion with the United States alone.

title: 4 Killed in Haiti Accident
description: PORT AU PRINCE, Haiti, Dec. 13 (AP) A truck loaded with limestone went out of control, knocked down three telephone poles and careened into a group of pedestrians, killing four people and injuring 16, the police said today.

title: School Basketball
Leaders in Essex Take Districting Plan to Court
description: NEWARK, Dec. 13Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson and a dozen other Essex County residents and political figures sued in State Superior Court today to block, on racial grounds, the county districting plan approved last week by the Democraticcontrolled Board of Election Districting Commissioners.

title: Yokohama Mayor to Head Party But Some Say He Betrayed Them
description: TOKYO, Dec. 13 (AP)Mayor Ichio Asukata of Yokohama was unanimously elected today as chairman of Japan's opposition Socialist Party, but citizens of the port city denounced his election as a betrayal.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Feasting With Medieval Grandeur
description: The medieval feast was an occasion for great pomp and ceremony. At 10 A.M. on Christmas Day, the marshal ushered guests into the castle's great hall, to the sound of clarion trumpets, seating them at long tables according to the established order of precedence.

title: A. &
description: The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea CoMpany, which has undergone major surgery in an effort to regain its former top rank in the supermarket industry, disclosed yesterday that it would report a loss of about $5 million for its fiscal third. quarter.

title: About Real Estate
description: PASSAIC. N.J.The year 1972 is not recalled with affection by this venerable industrial city on the Passaic River. That was the year that Uniroyal Inc. and RaybestosManhattan Inc. pulled up stakes from their manufacturing facilities here, at a cost to Passaic of 3,000 jobs. Unemployment rose to 17 percent.

title: Vatican Aide at Cairo Talks
description: ROME, Dec. 13 (UPI)Pope Paul's special representative to the Cairo Middle East peace conference left for Egypt today to monitor any possible negotiations over the future of Jerusalem and Christian religious sites in the Holy Land. The Vatican confirmed the trip to Egypt by Msgr. Francesco Monterisi earlier in the day.

title: NATIONAL PARLEY ON JOBS URGED BY SENATOR BAKER
description: Senator Howard H. Baker Jr. called last night for President Carter and the leaders of both parties to convene a national employment conference of the nation's leading businesses to find work for the poor and unemployed.

title: V. M. Newton Jr., Former Editor Of The Tampa Tribune, Dies at 73
description: TAMPA, Fla., Dec. 13 (AP)Virgil Miller Newton Jr., retired managing editor of The Tampa Tribune and a leader In the fight against secrecy in government, died at his home today after an apparent heart attack. He was 73 years old.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: COLUMBIA, Mo., Dec. 13 (UPI)Warren Powers, who coached Washington State to its first winning football season since 1972, was hired today as coach at the University of Missouri. He succeeded Al Onofrio, who was dismissed Nov. 23.

title: CALLAGHAN REBUFFED ON EUROPEAN VOTING
description: LONDON, Dec. 13The House of Commons adopted tonight a voting system for the first election of a European Parliament, The action by Commons will almost certainly delay that election until 1979.

title: WASTE UNIT CLOSED AFTER EXPLOSIONS
description: BRIDGEPORT, Dec. 13A waste treatment plant ravaged by explosions and fire last Thursday remained closed to cleanup crews and everyone else today while state and Federal health and environmental agencies sought to determine if chemicals in air, ground and water pose a lingering threat to life.

title: Cancer Link to Hair Dye Feared
description: The General Accounting Office has concluded that some hair dyes may pose a significant cancer hazard because they contain coloring chemicals that are known or suspected causes of cancer in humans or laboratory animals.

title: Europeans Secure Textile Protection
description: GENEVA, Dec. 14A 50nation agree ment for maintaining orderly trade in textiles was renewed today for four years but with loopholes enabling the European Economic Community to take exceptional protective measures against lowcost producer countries.

title: No Doctor Hears Cries of the Ailing in South Bronx
description: When the sickly old woman in the next apartment had trouble breathing one night, Maxine Campbell called the police. She told them that someone had just been shot next door.

title: Disks. Virtuoso Chopin
description: FEW PIANISTS are viewed with such awed admiration by their colleagues as Martha Argerich. She is a born virtuoso, with a staggering yet effortless command of the keyboard, and an elemental, even animal, vitality that must be the envy of many a more civilized artist.

title: Evansville Mourns for Basketball Team That Died in Airplane Crash
description: EVANSVILLE,Ind.,Dec.14They came in a steady stream across ground sodden by the rains that had accompanied the night hours fire and blood. Dumbstruck or redeyed, depending on how they had been individually affected, blankfaced or somber, they made for an English Gothic chapel of Indiana marble that seemed to say. Here is comfort.

title: Fred Gladstone, Builder, Is Dead; Headed Charitable Organization
description: Fred Gladstone, a builder in New York City and Florida, died Tuesday at a hospital in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 79 years old and had lived in Palm Beach since 1950.

title: Calendar of Events
description: Country Art Gallery, 113 Forest Avenue, Locust Valley, N.Y.

title: New Bond Issues
description: Wednesday, D2C. 14. 1977

title: U.S. Will Press Vietnam to Free 3 Americans Held Since October
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 14The United States has decided to press Vietnamese authorities for the release of three Americans held since their sailboat was seized in October off southern Vietnam.

title: News Summary
description: THURSDAY, DECEMBER 15, 1977

title: Late Flood of Holiday Mail Feared
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP)  The Postal Service says people have not mailed as many Christmas cards and paitels as expected this month and that mtiy lead to a lastminute flood of mail that will arrive late. Postal Service officials today renewed their plea to the public to mail now to insure delivery by Dac. 25.

title: Leonard Silk
description: Why has capital spending revived so slowly in the current business recovery? One of the most common explanations asserted by many businessmen and business economistsis that corporate profits are too low by historical stand

title: MINORITIES PROGRESS IN ENGINEER SCHOOLS
description: One of the academic community's most successful affirmative action programs, aimed at producing more minority engineers, is quietly moving toward its goal and avoiding much of the controversy that has surrounded other special recruiting efforts.

title: CUBAN EXILE BANKER UNDER WIDE INQUIRY
description: MIAMIInvestigators from five Federal and local agencies are actively pursuing here one of the largest financial fraud inquiries in recent history.

title: A Guidebook for Those With Lofty Ideas
description: FIRST there was the brownstone movement, then alternative use of existing buildings began cropping up: the rundown factory into a chic collection of shops, the unused railroad station into restaurant.

title: Nat'l Hockey League
Woman Found in Los Angeles Lot, 1 ith Apparent Victim of Strangling
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 14 (AP)The police say the socalled Hillside Strangler who preys on girls and young women apparently claimed his 11th victim today, a woman whoe nude body was found by two newspaper boys in a vacant lot overlooking downtown Los Angeles.

title: Schweitzer Leads Poised L'Enfance
description: THOMAS SCHERMAN and his Little Orchestra Society rescued Berlioz's L'Enfance du Christ from history's discard pile and gave the first New York performance cf the cantata in 1951, when the work was nearly a century old. Periodically ever since, this narrative of Christ's childhood has been presented hereabouts as an. alternative to Handel's Messiah, the truly great but virtually inescapable holiday piece.

title: Allies Worried by Bonn Spy Case and Exaggeration
description: BRUSSELS, Dec. 14Western defense officials expressed concern today over the possible effect of the latest West German spy case on allied military cooperation but warned against elcaggerating the damage done to the security of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

title: Market Gains, Ignoring Bad News; Field Up 91/4, Coastal States Off
description: The stock market yesterday ignored the slump of the dollar abroad and news of lower domestic automobile aales as the Dow Jones industrial average showed late strength to post its first noteworthy gain of the week. Finishing at 822.68, the Dow ran ahead 7.45 points after displaying minimal changes on Monday and Tuesday.

title: Dutchman Is Guilty in Nazi Killings
description: AMSTERDAM, Dec. 14 (AP)A 78-yearold Dutch art collector was found guilty today of having participated in the Nazi killing of 20 to 30 Polish Jews during World War II and was sentenced to 15 years in prison.

title: United Press International
Books of TheTimes
description: THIS YEAR'S OUTPOURING of words and illustrated surveys covering the decorative arts and collectibles ranged from ridiculous to highly rewarding. While we can easily dismiss a book devoted to beer cans, it is hard to overlook the splendors of fraktur, those painted papers produced by craftsmen in the Pennsylvania German communities from about 1750 to 1850. Below are some of the more significant volumes published recently.

title: World News Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (Reuters)United States and Soviet negotiators opened a preliminary meeting here today on the question of the international arms trade, the State Department announced.

title: Dispute on Minorities'
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14--The principal contractor on the Northeast Corridor rail improvement project urged the Government as recently as last May to award a $37 million contract for concrete cross ties to any of four or five minority business qualified to handle it.

title: BUSINESS LEADERS EXPECT RECESSION
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP)Half of the nation's business leaders expect an economic recession in the United States within two years, and 15 percent think one will odour within a year, according to a poll released today.

title: Rangers
The U.N. Today
Jazzmania and the Hum-ha-horn
description: JAZZMANIA, the fourthfloor walkup jazz room at 14 East 23d Street, founded in 1974 by Mike Morgenstern, a bass clarinetist in search of a place to play, is celebrating its third birthday this week with sixday festival that began Tuesday evening and will continue through Sunday. Normally the room is open only on Friday and Saturday evenings.

title: Search Still On for Fishing Boat
description: BOSTON, Dec. 14 (AP)A Coast Guard cutter continued searching today for a missing fishing boat and its crew of 13, but bad weather kept eight search planes grounded. The search for the 86foot Navigator began Saturday, when the vessel was reported overdue at New Bedford. The Coast Guard said that it had found no sign of the vessel, its life raft or any debris.

title: Alabama Supreme Court Schedules March Execution Dates for Two
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 14 (AP)The Alabama Supreme Court has ordered two convicted slayers put to death In the electric chair next March 10. It was the first time the court had fixed an execution date under the state's new death penalty law, enacted by the Alabama Legislature.

title: BLACK LEADERS FIND CARTER READY TO AID
description: WASHINGON, Dec. 14A group of black leaders said today after a meeting with President Carter that they believed the President to be personally committed to helping the nation's urban poor but they expressed doubt that Mr. Carter would back up his commitment with enough money in next year's budget.

title: Port Authority Approves Lease For Alexander's in Trade Center
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey voted yesterday to lease four floors in the ninestory building at World Trade Center to Alexander's Inc. for a department store, the first in the World Trade Center.

title: Meadowlands
description: Horses listed In order of post poeitions

title: Dividends
description: WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 14. 1977

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Piano: Serkin Great
description: For those who can appreciate greatnessin music, in a person and in a pianistCarnegie Ha'l was the place to be last night. Rudolf Serkin. looking as ever like a benign and slightly befuddled chemistry professor, gave his annual Carnegie Hall recital for an audience that crammed the hall and overflowed into stage seats. Few of them could have gone away disappointed at what they heard.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Wednesday, Dec. 14, 1977 Petition Filed By: BARBARA FINN, 7 E. 14 St. Liabilities, $2,599; assets, $500. L1TA JOAN MENDELSON, 340 W. 55 St., N.Y. Liabilities, 55LILI;_littsilsetGIJVR, 330 W. 50 St., N.Y. Liabilities, $18,174; assets, 5301. HERBERT HIMMELSTEIN, 1990 Ellis Ave.. the Bronx. Liabilities, $12,081; assets, $3,950. CLAUDIA R. LOZIER, 61 Livingston St., Rhinebeck, N.Y. Liabilities, $100,566; assets, 5600. JOHN J. ZERELLO, Route 9, Cold Spring, N.Y. Liabilities, $6,703; assets, $720. CHARLES E. WRIGHT, 214 Riverside Drive, N.Y. Liabilities, 513,000; assets, none. MICHELANNE CASILLASFREHLEY, 2125 Cruger Ave., the Bronx. Liabilities, 54,047; assets, none. ETHEL BOND, 2303 7th Ave., N.Y. Liabilities $2,810; assets, none. ANNA BENNETT, 3449 Fish Ave., the Bronx. Liabilities, assets, none.

title: Catholics Appeal for Boat People
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14The Roman Catholic Church in the United States, through its social action agency, appealed to the Carter ,Administration today to offer unlimited asylum to refugees who have fled by boat from Vietnam, and promised to find them homes and jobs even without financial help from the Government.

title: Elvis Costello Makes Local Rock Debut
description: ELVIS COSTELLO's New York debut Tuesday night at the Bottom Line was another of those eagerly awaited rock-and-roll occa:lons that make following the rock world here so amusing. Mr. Costello is a leading member of London's new wave. at least in the looser sense of that term. although he really owes more to the pub rockers like Graham Parker and the rhythm-and-blues revival lists like Southside Johnny than to the true punks.

title: College Results
Stanford Tuition Rising 9.3%
description: PALO ALTO, Calif., Dec. 14 (AP)Tuition at Stanford University will increase 9.3 percent next year to $5,130, university trustees have announced. The board of trustees also increased room and board rates 10 percent, from $1,970 to $2,169.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a typographical error in the dividend table in the Business/ Finance section yesterday, a number of dividend increases were listed as irregular. A corrected table appears today on Page D12.

title: Sound
description: DEAR MR. FANTEL: I really need help with a large problem and turn to you for any suggestions you May have. Our family has subsisted all these years on a gramophone bought fur the first of our three children. Now that it has honorably died (the phonograph), we agree that it is time to move on to highfidelity equipment. Christmas wuuld be a very good time for that.

title: Lakers Win Quietly in Houston Under a Heavy Guard
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 14Jerry West, coach of the Los Angeles Lakers, had surveyed the events of violence and turbulence in the National Basketball Association during the last week, and he knew that now was a time to be magnanimous.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The Harnischfeger Corporation has filed a report with the Securities and change Commission indicating that voluntary company investigation disclosed payments aggregating about $350,000 to consultants and employees of foreign governmental and private customers by the company from 1972 to October 1977 to obtain sales.

title: Louis Stulberg, Former President Of Garment Union, Is Dead at 76
description: Louis Stulberg, a nationally known labor leader who was president of the 400,000member International Ladies Garment Workers Union from 1966 to 1975, died yesterday at his home at 25 Central Park West after a long illness. He was 76 years old.

title: Program to Aid Elderly, Sick Pobt Marked by Fraud, State Audit Says
description: A state audit has charged that New York City's program of home attendants for the elderly sick poor is pockmarked with nearly $8.4 million a yearmore than 10 percentin errors and fraud.

title: BEGINNING TO LOOK A LOT LIKE CHRISTMAS: At Bergen Mall in Paramus, above, youngsters lined up to view display of Children of All Nations.
description: The New York Times/Edward Hausner

title: Sewerage Panel Says Deadline On Dumping Sludge Can't Be Met
description: NEWARK, Dec. 14Officials of the Passaic Valley Sewerage Commission said here today that New Jersey would be unable to meet the Dec. 31, 1981, federally imposed deadline for an end to oceandumping of sludge. They said that a ruling by Eckardt C. Beck, regional administrator for the Environmental Protection Agency, which voided bidding procedures because of rule violations for an $80 million sewage treatment plant here, would result in a crucial delay in construction.

title: Razor and Oil Claims Get Minor Changes
description: All of the advertising claims for Gillette's Good News TwinBlade Disposable Razor and for Mobil 1 synthetic motor oil came under close scrutiny by the ad industry's selfregulatory body in November. And after all of the supportive research was studied the National Advertising Division of the Council of Better Business Bureaus, it rejected only one minor point for each. The advertisers agreed to change them.

title: O'Brien Places Stress on the Uncovering of Root Causes
description: The National Basketball Association said last night that it was considering decisive steps to try to bring an end to the incidents of serious violence that have plagued league play over the last few years. The most recent incident was the spectacular fight in Los Angeles last Friday that resulted in the hospitalization of a longtime N.B.A. player, Rudy Tomjanovich.

title: The Tale of a Dream House With an Outhouse
description: Northfield, Mass.

title: Dancing and Dining to Beautify Israel
description: IF NEW YORKERS are curious about whether their new Mayorelect dances, he does. K Fred Astaire he is nothis style is 1950ish, heads-to-temple and his partner's, right hand held rigidly vertical. But Edward I. Koch was very visible on the dance floor of the Plaza's grand ballroom Tuesday night.

title: Seoul Said to Seek Return of Park
description: Seoul, South Korea, Dec. 14The South Korean Government has asked the United States to agree to the unconditional return of Tongsun Park as part of a deal under which the indicted businessman would be returned to Washington to testify on an alleged Korean scheme to buy influence with members of Congress, informed Korean sources said today.

title: Schmidt Seeks Full Inquiry
description: BONN, Dec. 14Chancellor Helmut Schmidt told his Cabinet today that he ;vented a thorough invest:gation of Bonn's latest spy scandal, warning his poi.ical staff that on no account should it minimize the case or play it down.

title: Farmers
description: DENVER,Dec.14Farmers opened their national strike today with picketing of food stores, long caravans of flagdraped tractors and attempts in some areas of Texas to block deliveries of food and milk. The purpose was to cut off food supplies until they receive higher prices for their crops.

title: Toshiba Is 6th Japanese TV Maker to Plan U.S. Plant
description: The Tokyo Shibaura Electric Company of Japan announced plans yesterday to build a color television factory at Nashvine. It is the sixth Japanese electronics company to decide to assemble TV sets in the United States.

title: ISRAELI BRINGS IDEAS FOR PEACE PROCESS
description: JERUSALEM, Dee. 14Prime Minister Menahem Begin said today that his trip to the United States was for the purpose of meeting with President Carter on new ideas connected directly with the peacemaking process.

title: Legal Help for Elderly Sought
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 14 (AP)Art organization of state attorneys general has formed a subcommittee to develop means of helping the nation's elderly face theft legal problems. The panel was formed yesterday by a unanimous vote of the National Association of Attorneys General on a proposal by Francis B. Burch of Maryland.

title: People and Business
description: The election of Joseph P. Flannery as president, chief operating officer and director of Uniroyal Inc., one of the nation's largest tire and rubber companies, was announced yesterday by David Baretta, chairman and chief executive officer.

title: Knicks Beat Pacers, 10198
description: The Knicks, playing on the road, defeated the Indiana Pacers by 10198 in the National Basketball Association. The Nets also won. Page D1S.

title: FAKE DEATH ALLEGED IN DRUG CONSPIRACY
description: A New Jersey man, his wife and 10 others were charged in Manhattan yesterday with the operaion of a heroin distribution enterprise of national scope.

title: Moscow Will Slow Industry Expansion Following Setbacks
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 14The Soviet Union announced plans today for low growth rates in key sectors of its economy during 1978, including the smallest increase in heavy industrial production since World War II.

title: Q &
description: Q. We have moved into a house that has a cedar closet in the basement. We understand that it is important to make sure there is no dampness in this closet as this would be harmful to the clothes that are stored there. Is there any product we can use to absorb any dampness that might be present?B.R., Spring Valley, N. Y.

title: Anarchists And Terrorists
description: LONDONA little while ago the French Minister of Justice, Alain Peyrefitte, remarked, after the extradition of Klaus Croissant, the defense lawyer of some of the German terrorists: We find ourselves facing menace comparable to that of anarchism at the end of the 19th century. The Third Republic knew the answer to that menace. The Fifth knows it as well.

title: Notes on People
description: BACK in his days as a radical leader of the Black Panthers,Eldredge Cleaver wrote a fiery best seller called Soul on Ice. Now that he's become a bornagain Christian, Mr. Cleaver has written another book, called Soul on Fire, which will be put on the market by a religious publishing house, WOrd Books of Waco, Tex. Lois Ferguson, an official of Word, said that the volume got its inspiration not only from Mr. Cleaver's first book, but also from the Christian symbol of fire as renewal. The new book is autobiographical and begins with Mr. Cleaver's flight to Cuba and Algeria to avoid prosecution in connection with a shootout with the police in California and his subsequent decision to return to the United States as a Christian. Mr. Cleaver is writing another Word book, Letters to My Children.

title: Sperm Whale Quotas Cut
description: TOKYO, Dec. 14 (Reuters)Japan and the Soviet Union, the only countries that hunt the sperm whales of the North Pacific, have agreed to reduce their catches for next year in accord with decision by the International Whaling Commission, it has been announced here. Japan's quota will be 2,754, compared with this year's limit of 3,078, while the Soviet Union will have a quota of 3,690, a drop of 432, the fishing agency said.

title: New Zealand Passes Measure Tightening Abortion Restrictions
description: WELLINGTON,New Zealand,Dec: 14 (Reuters)A law passed yesterday will require women wanting an abortion to get approval from two doctors belonging to a committee appointed by Parliament.

title: EGYPT AND ISRAEL START MEETING, VOW TO SEEK STEPS TOWARD PEACE; BEGIN FLIES TO U.S. TO SEE CARTER
description: CAIRO. Dec. 14Egyptian and Israeli negotiators met today across a conference table in Cairo while Americans looked on, opening a new effort to work out a satisfactory framework for a peace settlement in the Middle East.

title: Gene Splicing
description: The national debate over the genetic research technique called gene splicing is entering a new phase that many scientists consider important .to the future of biological science and that some see as crucial to public safety.

title: C. S. Lewis Story Is Coming to TV
description: THE LION, the Witch and the Wardrobe, the first of a series of seven classic children's stories by C. S. Lewis, the British author, will be adapted by the Children's Television Workshop for broadcast on CBSTV during prime time.

title: Northeastern Ski Areas Expect Warming Trend
description: Just when ski area operators throughout the East were becoming convinced the ski season was shaping up as an outstanding one, along came a forecast yesterday for a warming trend for the next three or four days.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: $500,000 Mark in Contributions Passed by Neediest Cases Fund
description: The 66th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund yesterday passed the $500,000 mark with the receipt of $15,560 from 251 contributors. Now in its second week, the campaign has received $507,774 from 1,357 contributors.

title: Dollar at Low in Japan and Europe
description: TOKYO,(Thursday); Dec. 15 (Reuters) The dollar dropped sharply in early trading on the foreign exchange markets here, falling by more than two yen another.record low, 238 yen.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: SCHOOL GROOVES Down at New York University's Loeb Student Center, a thriving jazz sanctum in Greenwich Village, tribute will be paid tonight at 8 to the veteran tenor saxophonist Al Cohn. This is the annual evening of the Highlights in Jazz series that honors a living musician, and the special guest, whose contributions in the field go back to the bands of Artie Shaw, Woody Herman and Buddy Rich, is still very much with us.

title: About New York
description: There is an awful annual deadline approaching at high schools everywhere the application date for college admission, a process that seems as vital dad minutely complicated as the curl Of life's double helix. Who will catch which bit of the evolutionary code to become someone else, somewhere else, for better or worse?

title: KENNETH MAY, 62, TAUGHT MATHEMATICS AT TORONTO
description: Dr. Kenneth May, professor of mathematics and of the history of science at the University of Toronto, died Dec. of a heart attack at his home in Toronto. He was 62 years old.

title: 5,000 SOVIET REFUGEES WILL BE ADMITTED BY U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (UPI)Attorney General Griffin Bell gave approVal today for 5,000 Soviet refugees, most of them Jews, to enter the United States by May 1.

title: Telephone Company Puts Off Shortening 10Cent Coin Calls From 5 Minutes to
description: The New York Telephone Company will postpone its shortening of the time the drop of a dime will buy in a pay phone, a spokesman said yesterday, because the company is not sure the added revenue will exceed the cost of the changeover.

title: Hawks 108, 76ers 99
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 14 (UPI)John Brown's 11 pointt in the third quarter helped the Atlanta Hawks break from a halftime tie tonight and go on to 10899 victory over Philadelphia, the 76ers third loss ir, a row.

title: Dance: The Debut Of Montreal Group
description: LE GROUPE de la Place Royale, a feisty little moderndance troupe founded in 1966 in Montreal, made its New York debut last night by raising the sort of questions nobody bothers about much it, these carts.

title: News Summary
description: THURSDAY, DECEMBER 15, 1977

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Revue: Lampooners
description: THAT'S NOT FUNNY, That's Sick! a compilation of bits and pieces from two earlier National Lampoon Revues, National Lampoon Lemmings and The National Lampoon Show, which is at the Other End this week and next, is not really sick. And it's actually funny.

title: Companies List Earnings Reports
CORRECTION
description: Because of a typographical error in the dividend table in the Business/ Finance section yesterday, a number of dividend increases were listed as irregular. A corrected table appears today on Page D12.

title: Aqueduct Racing
description: RESULTS

title: GARDENING
description: HOLLY is as English as plum pudding and as Christmasy as the hard sauce that goes with it. Although the history of icily in man's folklore goes back far beyond the first Christmas to the science and superstition of ancient Greece, Rome, Egypt and China, it is r from England that we have taken this particular symbol. The English, in turn, usurped it from the ancient Druids of Gaul, who brought holly sprigs into their homes so that the woodland spirits might seek refuge there from the fierceness of winter.

title: Nat'l Basketball Ass'n
Sports News Briefs
description: ARLINGTON, Tex., Dec. 14 (UPI) The Texas Rangers added Ferguson Jenkins to their pitching staff today.

title: Bond Prices Fall Sharply as Fed Draws Some Banking System Reserves
description: Government bond prices dropped sharply yesterday as Treasury securities were pushed down after the Federal Reserve drained some reserves from the banking system temporarily. Corporate bond prices, meanwhile, were hit by news that the Bankers Trust Company sought to sell $150 million of highgrade longterm bonds.

title: The Standings
Legislative Oversight Panel Is Proposed to Monitor Executive Branch
description: TRENTON,Dec. 14A plan to create a legislative oversight committee that would monitor actions by the executive branch was unveiled today.

title: Metal Futures Prices Swing Sharply on Dollar Drop and Burns Rumor
description: The metals futures markets were scenes of sharp price swings yesterday, provoked by both rumors and fact. The fact was that the dollar fell to lows overseas, causing increased buying of precious metals.

title: Marshall Field Board Rejects Hawley's Bid
description: The directors of Marshall Field & Company in Chicago unanimously rejected a merger proposal by Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc. of Los Angeles, partly because they considered the terms inadequate, Marshall Field said yesterday. BLit Philip M. Hawley, president or Carter Hawley, said he disagreed that the terms were inadequate, adding, however, The terms are negotiable and Carter Hawley* Hale had advised Marshall Field that it was willing to entertain its ideas as to more appropriate terms.

title: Industrial Production Up by 0.5% Despite Auto and Coal Slowdowns
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (Reuters)Industry in the United States showed its biggest production gain in four months during November, despite slowdowns in auto and coal production, the Government reported today.

title: Tomjanovich Still Improving
description: The condition of Rudy Tomjanovich, the Houston Rockets star who was hospitalized Friday after having been struck by Kermit Washington of the Los Angeles Lakers, continued to improve yesterday. Surgery was tentatively scheduled for Saturday morning.

title: Market Place
description: Judging from the results of a redemption last spring, there must be a number of rueful former holders of National Starch and Chemical securities now that National Starch is about to become a part of Unilever, the giant international food and drug company.

title: Rangers, With a New Look, Play a 22 Tie With Hawks
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 14The ultra-conservative style of the Chicago Black Hawks le.d tonight to the team's 10th tie in 30 games this season, this one a 22 game with the reshuffled New York Rangers before a meager crowd of 8,988.

title: Leader in Farmers
description: DENVER, Dec.14The American Agriculture Movement, which has been organizing a national farm strike that started today, makes a point of having no officers and of having its leadership shared among, organizers. But

title: JAPAN DETAILS PLAN TO EXPAND IMPORTS; U.S. FINDS IT SCANTY
description: TOKYO, Dec. 14In the first detailed description of the proposed trade liberalization package delivered to Washington this week, the Japanese Government officially announced here tonight a number of tariff reductions and import quota expansions. Quantitative restrictions on imports of 27 categories of agricultural and manufactured goods were not abolished, according to the announcement.

title: Personal Beauty
description: WHICH WAY to the Christmas gifts? Just follow your nose to the perfume counters. There's hardly Womanor a manwho can resist sweetsmelling something wrapped in glitter. Remember that even the Magi chose scentsfrankincense and myrrh along with gold, as presents for the Christ Child.

title: Helen Hayes and Amy Carter Share Stage at the White House
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14A couple of troupers named Helen Hayes and Amy Carter shared center stage this evening as 430 tots from all over the world crowded into the White House for a performance of The Littlest Clown.

title: U.S. AEROSPACE GOALS QUESTIONED IN INDUSTRY
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14The president of the Aerospace Industries Association called today for a clear signal from the Carter Administration and Congress as to whether they are committed to keeping the United States the world leader in aerospace technology.

title: Dresser Profit Up 16% for Quarter
description: Dresser Industries reported yesterday a 16 percent rise in earnings in its fourth fiscal quarter to $61.6 million, or $1.58 share.

title: EGYPT AND ISRAEL START MEETING, VOW TO SEEK STEPS TOWARD PEACE; BEGIN FLIES TO U.S TO SEE CARTER
description: CAIRO, Dec. 14Egyptian and Israeli negotiators met today across a conference table in Cairo while Americans looked on, opening a new effort to work out a satisfactory framework, for a peace settlement in the Middle East.

title: Cauthen Is Named Sportsman of Year
description: Steve Cauthen, the sensational 17yearold jockey, was named Sportsman of the Year yesterday by Sports Illustrated. Cauthen picked up the Grecian vase trophy at a midmorning luncheon, then went to work at Aqueduct where he had one winner in four trips to the post.

title: U.S. Takes 80 Golf Lead
description: TOKYO, Dec. 14 (AP)The United States swept the four firstday doubles matches and took an 80 lead today in the third United StatesJapan collegiate golf meet. Masahiro Kuramoto, Japan's 1977 collegiate and amateur champion, shot the best individual round, a three-under-par 69. He was followed by John Stark of Houston and John Cook of Ohio State with 71's and Chin Beck of Georgia with 72.

title: Yale Faces Budget Cuts
description: The Yale Corporation said today that expenses must be cut or income increased over the next five years to bring Yale's budget back into balance and end a decade of deficit spending.

title: Hearne to Veto Bill on Pay Raises In Time for Council to Override It
description: Mayor Beame reaffirmed yesterday that he would veto the controversial pay raises for the city's incoming top 51 elected officials in time for the City Council to override the veto.

title: Design Notebook
description: ARCHITECTURE can sometimes be like a Broadway playa good concept that may need a bit of tinkering before it can attain commercial success. That was surely the case with the U.S. Steakhouse Company, a restaurant that opened in 1975 in the Time & Life Building in Rockefeller Center.

title: TURKISH GOVERNMENT LOSES ITS MAJORITY
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Dec, 14  Prime Minister Suleyman Demirel and his archrival, Bulent Ecevit, who heads the main opposition party, have become locked in another struggle for power, the second in five months.

title: Family Money: Reading the Fine Print on Theft Insurance
description: RISING burglary rates and the growing popularity of pleasure boating are , chipping away at the amount of protection many major insurance companies are willing to write into homeowner's coverage.

title: Count Your Mundane Blessings
description: NOT LONG AGO I met a man, an astronomically rich man, who had spun so much straw into gold that he was forced to reverse the process in order to have a good reason to get up in the morning. Having already assembled the wine, women and airconditioned houseboat on the Rhine (these were luxuries that had long ago converted to necessities appreciated with about the same fervor that other people feel for indoor plumbing), he found himself increasingly compelled to be more original about pleasure, if pleasure itself was not to elude him in the end.

title: Topics
description: These are auspicious days for the Federal program of legal assistance to the poor, that embattled but successful survivor of the late war on poverty. The Legal Services Corporation is on the verge of receiving more money and a fresh charter from Congress. And now President Carter has moved to desegregateby race, sex and professionthe corporation's 11member board of directors which, as currently constituted, it, allwhite, allmale and alllawyer.

title: High Food Prices and a Shortage of Goods Arouse Discontent in Ghana
description: ACCRA, Ghana. Dec. 10Soaring food prices and a shortage of goods have aroused widespread discontent and brought Ghana's military Government to the lowest level of popularity since took power in 1972.

title: Negotiating Committee Reportedly Nears Break In Coal Talks Impasse
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14A negotiating subcommittee of United Mine Workers union representatives and coal industry executives was reported tonight to have nearly broken the bargaining impasse that resulted in a strike by 160,000 Appalachian and Middle Western coal miners nine days ago.

title: New U.N. Aide to Meet. Waldheim
description: COPENHAGEN, Dec. 14 (Reuters)-Former Prime Minister Poul Hartling of Denmark left here today for New York to discuss his appointment as United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees with Secretary General Kurt Waldheim. Mr. Hartling's nomination to the post was approved last week by the General Assembly.

title: DEC. 110 AUTO SALES OFF 6,3%, WITH SHOWING 13.6% DROP
description: DETROIT, Dec. 14Another slump in newcar sales was recorded in the first 10 days of December by the nation's automobile industry, as deliveries fell 6.3 percent below the level of a year earlier, according to reports issued today by the four maior auto companies.

title: Deaths Recall Other Air Disasters Involving Athletes
description: The airplane crash that killed the 14 memberso f the University of Evansville basketball team and their coach Tuesday night was the second such air disaster in which all members of an American athletic team were killed and the sixth in 18 years in which many members of one team died.

title: Texts of Statements by Egypt, Israel and the U.S. at the Cairo Conference
description: CAIRO, Dec. 14 (AP)Following are the official texts of the opening statements delivered in English at the Cairo conference on the Middle East by the chief Egyptian delegate, Ahmed Lsmat Abdel Meguid; the chief Israeli delegate, Eliahu BenElissar, and the chief United States delegate, Assistant Secretary of State Alfred L. Atherton Jr.

title: Fd Towles
Carter to Stress Aid for Economy; Sees Tax Plans Ready in January
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14  President Carter said tonight that his State of the Union message next month and the major purpose of his Administration in 1978 would be devoted to plans to strengthen the nation's economy.

title: GEORGE RUSSELL, 62; CYANAMID DIRECTOR
description: George W. Russell, senior vice president and a director of the American Cyanamid Company, died Tuesday night at Valley Hospital, Ridgewood, N.J. after a short Illness. Mr. Russell, 62 years old, lived on Indian Trail Drive in Franklin Lakes, N.J.

title: Backgammon:
description: Strategy in backgammon has evolved considerably in the last few years  particularly with regard to the opening stages of the game. Experts today emphasize quick and efficient development, rather than the safety of individual men. Bold play like this often leads to complicated positions in which both sides have several men back early in the game.

title: Knicks, Cool in Stretch, Defeat Pacers by 10198.
description: INDIANAPOLIS. Dec. 14The New York Knicks made the big plays down the stretch tonight and captured their second National Basketball Association nailbiter in two nights with a 10198 conquest of the Indiana Pacers.

title: The Wrong Way to Subsidize Tuition
description: Christmas almost came early this year for the parents of a halfmillion college students. An attempt by the Senate to tack a $250 tuition tax credit onto the Social Security bill narrowly failed in a conference committee with the House. The idea is far from dead, however; tax relief for college costs is certain to be brought up again in Congress next spring. We hope the members will think hard about the implications of a tuition tax credit before undertaking so dubious an enterprise.

title: Hers
description: BETWEEN the ages of 7 and 10, I spent good deal of time dreaming of the day would follow in the footsteps of my hero. Jacob Nelson (Nellie) Fox, and play second base for the Chicago White Sox. The crowd would roar as I stepped up to the plate in the bottom of the ninth with two out, runners on second and third and the Sox trailing by one run. The road would turn to whoops of joy as I, like the everreliable Nellie, punched a gamewinning hit through the infield.

title: Pakistani Leader in Shanghai
description: PEKING, Dec. 14 (Reuters)The military ruler of Pakistan, Gen. Mohammad Zia ulHaq, on his first visit to China, arrived in Shanghai today after his plane was diverted from Peking because of bad weather. It was not immediately known when he would reach the capital.

title: DR. STEPHEN SVAJIAN, 71, HISTORIAN OF ARMENIA
description: Dr. Stephen G. Svajlan, a dentist and writer on Armenian history, died Saturday after a long illness at his home at 524 Third Street in the. Park Slope section of Brooklyn. He was 71 years old.

title: Skiing
description: WORLD CUP STANDING

title: Bridge:
description: One of the American stars Nyho won the world championship in Manila is a man of many talents. Eddie Kantar of Los Angeles is a fine athlete who used to rank high in tournament table tennis and can beat almost. any amateur tennis player.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Freezing rain and nearly a foot of snow hindered a search by the New york State police for an 18-year-old woman reported missing from the State University of New York at Oneonta in ihe foothills of the Catskills. The freshman student, Linda Velzy, the daughter Of the Rev. Dr. Howard Velzy of the United Methodist Church in Woodbury, was last seen around 6 P.M. Friday, a mile from campus, apparently attempting to hitchhike, the police said.

title: Gorey Stories
description: ALTHOUGH EDWARD GOREY is primarily thought of as an artist and illustrator, he is also a gifted writer; his prose is, as intricate and as elegant as his spidery pictures. Together, words and drawings form little Victorian melodramas, cliffhanging Gothictles of malfeasance. mischief and pranks of fate.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: Moscow Will Slow Industry Expansion Following Setbacks
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 14The Soviet Union announced plans today for low growth rates in key sectors of its economy during 1978, including the smallest increase in heavy industrial production since World War II.

title: Rules on Accounting Litigation Proposed by S.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14The Securities and Exchange Commission today proposed rules defining the circumstances in which an accountant involved in litigation will not be considered independent from the client he is auditing.

title: Blaze Drives Elderly Tenants From Rooming House
description: Fire swept the top floors of an upper West Side rooming house yesterday afternoon, driving elderly residents into the rain. One fireman atop a tower ladder was engulfed in flames when a ball of fire exploded from a fifthfloor window.

title: Jamaica, Shifting Leftward Under the Manley Regime, Is Battered by Economic Currents
description: KINGSTON, Jamaica, Dec. 12Every afternoon the men in tattered clothes push against each other in the betting shops of Kingston to hear the results of some distant horse race. They are part of the army of jobless men who have drifted into the capital, walking the streets past women hawking green bananas and citrus fruits spread on newspaper on the sidewalk.

title: BELL OBJECTS TO HAVING NEW BANKRUPTCY SYSTEM
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP)Attorney General Griffin Bell objected today to establishing a bankruptcy court system separate from the Federal district courts, saying the idea is unwise as well as unneeded.

title: ROSOVSKY DECLINES OFFER TO HEAD YALE
description: NEW HAVEN, Dec. 14  Dr. Henry Rosovsky, dean of the faculty of Arts and. Science at Harvard, has been offered and has turned down the presidency of Yale University, a senior Yale official said tonight

title: Best of Families: A Leap In Time
description: THE BEST of Families began its eightepisode ran on television in the setting of a heat wave in 1880. Last week, the three central familiesthe wealthy Wheelers, the middleclass Lathrops and the poor Raffertyscelebrated the birth of a new century on New Year's Eve 1899. Tonight at 9 on Channel 13, the final installment suddenly jumps to 1977 and the coldest day of the year. Jan. 17.

title: Cancer Link to Hair Dye Feared
description: The General Accounting Office has concluded that some hair dyes may pose a significant cancer hazard because they contain coloring chemicals that are known or suspected causes of cancer in man or laboratory animals.

title: Home Improvement
description: ALTHOUGH they have been around for many years, interior paints that create a threedimensional, textured finish on walls and ceilings have become popular again with many homeowners and apartment dwellers. Particularly suitable for do-it-yourself painters who have problem walls or ceilings, these paints have a much heavier body than ordinary flat paints, with a creamy consistency that makes them easy to apply without dripping or spattering.

title: COLLECTIONS OF ART SEIZED BY RUMANIA
description: BUCHAREST, Rumania, Dec. 14The Rumanian Government has seized the cream of Bucharest's private collections of Rumanian and Western art and has closed more than a dozen private museums throughout the city.

title: HOFFA FOSTER SON INDICTED FOR LYING ON BANK LOAN
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14Charles L. O'Brien, a key figure in the investigation into the disappearance of James R. Hoffa, was indicted today by a Federal grand jury in Detroit on charges of making false statements on a 1973 application for bank loan.

title: G.A.O. Assails $1 Billion Program For an Infantry Combat Vehicle
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14A $1 billion Army program to build an infantry combat vehicle has been sharply criticized by a Government agency that called the weapon slow, noisy, smoky, expensive and somewhat easy to destroy.

title: HOUSE PANEL REJECTS BID TO WEAKEN WELFARE PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP)A special House subcommittee on welfare today defeated attempts to weaken proposal that would require welfare parents of young children to take parttime jobs or lose their cash benefits.

title: Is McGuire Youngest? Not So, Record Shows
description: At 41 years of age, some thought, Robert J. McGuire was about to become the city's youngest Police Commissioner. Not so.

title: Morocco Reported Seeking Arab Talks Alter Cairo
description: RABAT, Morocco, Dec. 14 (AP)King Hassan II of Morocco reportedly began diplomatic moves today toward convening an emergency conference of Arab leaders to consider the outcome of the IsraeliEgyptian talks in Cairo.

title: Port Body Votes 1985 Noise Rule On Concorde Despite U.S. Vows
description: Despite White House assurances to the BritishFrench Concorde team that such action would be delayed, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey adopted a noise rule yesterday that would keep the supersonic airliner from using New York airports in 1985.

title: World Hockey Ass'n
Knicks
Blumenthal Sees Declining Basis For Federal Loans to New York
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14  Treasury Secretary W. Michael Blumenthal told the Senate Banking Committee today that while the Carter Administration remained firmly committed to maintaining New York City's solvency, the continuation of a Federal loan program beyond next July 1 would have to be on a declining basis.

title: Boy, 8, Is Killed When He Leans Out Bus Window and Head Hits Pole
description: COPIAGUE, L. I., Dec. 14 (UPI)An 8-year-old boy was killed today when he leaned out the window of a moving school bus and his head struck a telephone pole, the Suffolk County police reported.

title: Vienna Communists, Close to Soviet, Urge Mideast Moderation
