description: VIENNA, Dec. 14The small Austrian Communist Party, apparently reflecting Moscow's views, said in a statement this week, that Israel had a right to existence, but must withdraw from occupied Arab terrorities and agree to creation of a Palestinian state.

title: Tennis
description: AT SYDNEY, AUSTRALIA $175,000 NEW SOUTH WALES Second Round

title: Blumenthal Sees Declining Basis For Federal Loans to New. York
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14  Treasury Secretary W. Michael Blumenthal told the Senate Banking Committee today that while the Carter Administration remained firmly committed to maintaining New York City's solvency, the continuation of a Federal loan program beyond next July 1 would have to be on a declining basis.

title: Washington &
description: Clyde H. Farnsworth discusses the factors behind the United States trade deficit, including what may be a loss of American competitiveness in world markets. Even so, Congressional researchers have found that American products are still more competitive than they were in 1970. Page D5.

title: Dave Anderson
description: Sid Borgia had the same clenched face that he had when he was one of the National Basketball Association's most respected referees. But this time he was blowing his whistle on the system. All this violence, he was saying, an awful lot of it goes back to the officials. Some officials have become complacent. Some are not physically capable of keeping up with the game, some look like bartenders. Some people think the game has become too fast for the officials. But what's happened is that the referees have

title: A Secret New York Draft Predicts Increasing Budget Deficits for City
description: A secret document prepired by New York City for the United States Treasury Department predicts growing and substantially greater budget deficits for the city in the next four years than any earlier analysis; and implies that workers will have to be dismissed if those who remain are to get raises.

title: A $13 Million TruckService Center Is Proposed for Hunts Point Terminal
description: Plans for a $13 million truckservice facility on cityowned land adjacent to the Hunts Point Food Distribution Center in the South Bronx were announced yesterday at City Hall.

title: The Gift of the Mayor
description: O. Henry would have loved it. A young Vermont couple, just arrived in New York City on a honeymoon, are taken to the big heart of the Big Apple after their 1970 Buick is stolen at gunpoint and used on a rampage near Times Square that leaves one man dead, 15 injured and the car wrecked. A grim start to a holiday.

title: U.N. to Create Top Economic Post
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. Dec. 14The Economic and Social Council today adopted a report recommending sweeping changes within the United Nationsincluding the appointment of an official who would in effect be an economic czarto make the world organization more responsive to the demands of the developing countries.

title: The New York Times/Jack Mannino
League Must Approve Deal, Shift of Club for 78
description: DENVER, Dec. 14Marvin Davis, a wealthy, independent Colorado oilman, announced today that he had an agreement to buy the Oakland A's and hoped to bring the club to Denver next year, pending approval by the American League and the settlement of the A's current stadium contract in Oakland.

title: British Company, Charging Distortion, Wins a Rare Ban on TV Film
description: LONDON, Dec. 14In a rare challenge to the freedom of British broadcasters, Tate & Lyle Ltd. won an injunction today against the showmg of parts of a television documentary it said grossly distorted its operations in South Africa.

title: Carter News Parley OnTV,Radio Today
description: The three television networks and their local stationsChannels 2, 4 and 7will telecast live President Carter's news conference, which is scheduled to begin at 11 o'clock this morning.

title: Carter to Stress Aid for Economy; Sees Tax Plans Ready in January
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14  President Carter said tonight that his State of the Union message next month and the major purpose of his Administration in 1978 would be devoted to plans to strengthen the nation's economy.

title: As Trees Grow, So Does the Value of the Home
description: Wellkept trees and shrubs have an obvious visual value for a home. But many homeowners may not realize that these same landscape assets have dollar value as well.

title: Vance Ends Mideast Trip Convinced an Active U.S. Role Is Needed
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Dec. 14Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance flies back to Washington tomorrow convinced that his latest Middle East mission has underscored the need for the United States to b as active as ever in the region's complicated diplomacy.

title: F.B.I. FILES DISCLOSE LETTER ON KENNEDY
description: WASHINGTON,Dec.14J. Edgar Hoover told Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy in 1963 that the Federal Bureau of Investigation had information that Mr. Kennedy had paid $500,000 settlement and had had court records sealed in a lawsuit brought by a woman who said she had been enga,7ed to marry his brother, John F. Kennedy, in 1951.

title: NEW &
description: Thomas K. Woodard and Blanche Greenstein traveled thousands of miles in the last two years in search of authentic American blankets from the 19th century, and a substantial number are now in their shop on Lexington Avenue. Three colors dominatered, blue and cream whiteand the designs are simple stripes or tattersall checks. The blankets, all singleply, were woven in two panels and sewn together down the center with the ends hemmed or, on some pieces, fringed. The selection is in excellent condition (though sold as is) and fits double- and queensized beds. Prices range from $200 to $450; one show piece crewel blanket carries a price tag of $2,500. The Thos. Woodard shop is on the second floor of 1022 Lexington Avenue (74th Street).

title: What Mr. Begin Should Tell Mr. Carter
description: One sign of just how much things have changed in the Middle East since Menahem Begin last flew to Washington five months ago is that this time he got a warm sendoff from the President of Egypt. We are really heading in the right direction, Mr. Sadat remarked when asked about the meeting tomorrow between the Israeli Prime Minister and President Carter.

title: Advertising
description: For the incumbent agency, making a pitch is like going to a wake, said Donald E. Creamer, chairman of Creamer Lois FSR.

title: Islanders
4 JERSEY PHARMACIES SUE BLUE CROSS IN U.S. COURT
description: NEWARK, Dec.14 (UPI)Four independent pharmacies have sued New Jersey Blue Cross for allegedly fixing prices through a prepaid prescription drug insurance program.

title: Houston Workers Press Search For Possible Victims of Tornado
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 14 (AP)Workers searched today for more victims of a tornado that touched down near a crowded freeway yesterday, killing one person and injuring at least 40 others.

title: Top Pop Records
Conservation Group Ends Boycott Of Goods From Soviet and Japan
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (UPI)One of the nation's largest wildlife conservation groups has called off its fouryear boycott of Japanese and Russian consumer goods because the two nations are complying with international efforts to conserve whales.

title: Carter Urges Energy Conferees To Press for Natural Gas Accord
description: WASHINGTON,Dec. 14  President Carter told key Congressional energy conferees tonight that it would be devastating for them to leave town without making an allout effort to agree on natural gas.

title: The New York Times/Jack Manning and Gene Maggio
description: WHEN Yvette and Allen Grubman moved from Riverdale to Park Avenue two years ago, they knew their apartment had to serve two distinct functions. It would have to be place where Mr. Grubman, a lawyer specializing in the music business, could entertain his clients, a sophisticated lot including rock singers, record companies and theatrical agents. It would also have to be a place where their daughters, Jennifer, 4, and Elizabeth, going on 7, could live comfortably.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Jet Skids Off Runway, All Safe
description: BATON ROUGE, La., Dec. 14 (AP)A11 77 passengers and the crew escaped injury when their DC9 jet skidded off Ryan Airport runway and got stuck in the mud, officials say.

title: SAUDI OIL PRICE VIEW SAID TO CHEER VANCE
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Dec. 14A spokesman for Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance indicated that Mr. Vance felt encouraged after conferring with Saudi officials today about the prospects for continued oilprice freeze at a meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries that is scheduled to begin in Venezuela next Tuesday.

title: Transit Authority Policeman Shot
description: A plainclothes Transit Authority police, officer was shot yesterday evening after he approched two men said to have been harassing women on a subway train in the Willinmsburg section of Brooklyn.

title: Court Cancels RentFree Ruling
description: An elderly Brooklyn couple, who Converted the basement of their twofamily house into a third apartment and wound up with an albatross around their necks, have won relief in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn.

title: Segal Quits as Head Of City Arts Panel
description: WITH AN ASSERTION that the incoming administration of Mayorelect Edward I. Koch had not consulted the Commission on Cultural Affairs in its planning for the future of the arts and the city, Martin E. Segal, the unsalaried chairman of the commission, yesterday submitted his resignation.

title: ISRAELI BRINGS IDEAS FOR PEACE PROCESS
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 14Prime Minister Menahem Begin said today that his trip to the United States was for the purpose of meeting with President Carter on new ideas connected directly with the peacemaking process.

title: With All Deliberate Speed.
description: BOSTON, Dec. 14John Forster and his colleagues in the South African Government, in their bitterness at current American policy, console themselves with one thought. They believe, as they have made clear in numerous conversations, that Jimmy Carter does not really represent the American people in his critical attitude. They hope that before long another Administration will take a friendlier view of white supremacy in South Africa.

title: Solomon Dickstein, a Producer Of Dramas for Yiddish Theater
description: Solomon Dickstein, who produced plays in Yiddish both on Broadway and on Second Avenue, died Tuesday at the Vanderbilt Nursing Home on Staten Island. He was 87 years old and lived at 154 Avenue P, In the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn.

title: A $13 Million TruckService Center Is Proposed for Hunts Point Terminal
description: Plans for a $13 million truckservice facility on cityowned land adjacent to the Hunts Point Food Distribution Center in the South Bronx were announced yesterday at City Hall.

title: L.I. Job Loss Feared as Cutback in F14's Is Ordered
description: WASHINGTON,Dec. 14Defense Secretary Harold Brown, in placing a lid on the Navy's budget for next year, has ordered a sharp cutback in the production of F14 jet fighters that could mean the loss of thousands of jobs on Long Island.

title: HOUSESENATE PANEL CLEARS TAX INCREASE FOR SOCIAL SECURITY
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14House and Senate conferees cleared the way today for final Congressional approval tomorrow of a multibilliondollar Social Security tax increase.

title: Liberals Will Keep Laborite Pact
description: LONDON, Dec. 14The Liberal Party retreated tonight from a threat to break off its Parliament alliance with the Labor Party, giving yet another reprieve to the crisisridden Government of Prime Minister James Callaghan.

title: Meadowlands Results
Action on Codd Disability Pension Postponed Until at Least January
description: In a surprise move, the trustees of the Police Pension Board yesterday postponed a decision on granting the increasingly controversial request by outgoing Police Commissioner Michael J. Codd for a taxfree annual disability pension of $46,600.

title: Washington &
description: WASHINGTON  American exports have been growing since the second quarter of 1975, but not so rapidly or Isteadily as imports, especially imports of oil. The result has been a trade deficit approaching $30 billion this year, five times the previous record.

title: Beatha
description: Alrandar, Isabel Andrews. Helen Balcock Norman Barach, Alvan Bickel, Bertha Cassino. Mary . Cohen, Harry Cohen, Henry Dana, Selina David, Myrtle Dokouzlan, MIhran Eaton, Lester EbbItts Lilian Ellis, Harry Fluorath, Harry Forma, Ruth Freedman, Samuel Frischer, Helen Gailloan, Donna Gellman. Carrle Gewertz; B. Gladstone, Fred Greenstein, S. Grobsmtth, M.

title: Minister in Queens Is Promoted
description: The Rev. N. J. L'Heureux Jr. has been named executive director of the Queens Federation of Churches, an association of more than 350 Protestant churches in the borough. For the last four years, Mr. L'Heureux has served as pastor of the United Methodist Church in Maspeth. He will take over his new post Feb. 1.

title: Trading in Georgia Bank Resumes
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 14 (Reuters)Over the counter trading in stock of the National Bank of Georgia, suspended 10 days ago to allow investors to digest the news that Bert Lance, former United States Budget Director, had found a buyer for his holdings in the bank, will resume tomorrow, the Securities and Exchange Commission said today. When trading was halted 10 days ago, the stock was selling for $15 to $16 a share after a oneday rise of $5 a share.

title: Roosevelt
description: Horses listed In order of oost oositlons. Letter designates OTB listing.

title: HOUSESENATE PANEL CLEARS TAX INCREASE FOR SOCIAL SECURITY
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14House and Senate conferees cleared the way today for final Congressional approval tomorrow of a multibilliondollar Social Security tax increase.

title: Rent Rises Up to 7.5% Due in 78 For 27,000 New York. Buildings
description: While tenants under rent control in at least 19,000 New York City apartment buildings face rent rises of up to 7.5 percent next month, tenants under rent control in 8,000 more buildings may have to pay similar increases later in the year.

title: Letters
description: A Simpler Time

title: Egyptian Airline Office Bombed
description: SHARJA, United Arab Emirates, Dec. 14 (Reuters)A bomb exploded today in a travel agency that represents the Egyptian Governmentawned airline in this Persian Gulf emirate, officials said. The explosion caused some damage, but no one was injured as the offices were closed. The police are investigating the incident.

title: Nets 108, Warriors 104
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J., Dec. 14The New Jersey Nets, who had their longest victory streak of the seasontwo gamesbroken by the Boston Celtics last night, bounced back tonight and defeated the Golden State Warriors, 108104, before a crowd of 3,363 in Rutgers gymnasium.

title: Frst Successful Use of Total Artificial Heart Reported
description: ZURICH, Dec. 14 (AP)An international:team of surgeons announced today the successful use of a newly developed total artificial heart.

title: CUBAN EXILE BANKER UNDER WIDE INQUIRY
description: MIAMIInvestigators from five Federal and local agencies are actively pursuing here one of the largest financial fraud inquiries in recent history.

title: Criticized Cleaning Pact Extended At Trade Center by Port Agency
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey yesterday approved a $1.5 million extension of a World Trade Center cleaning contract that has been criticized for alleged irregularityies in an unreleased New York State Comptroller's report.

title: Stage: Green Pond is Full of Music
description: GREEN POND IS described in a note accompanying the program as a musical play about relationships. That stretches things. This flimsy contraption about four young people taking an extended vacation on the South Carolina coast is, at most, about feelings.

title: Hearings on Arts Begin In New York Tomorrow
description: Congressional hearings into the state of the arts and humanities will be held in New York tomorrow and Saturday. People prominent in the arts and humanities will testify at both heating.;. The public is invited to attend.

title: No Doctor Hears Cries of the Ailing in South Bronx
description: When the sickly old woman in the next apartment had trouble breathing one night, Maxine Campbell called the police. She told them that someone had just been shot next door.

title: Home Beat
description: The Seraph, a shop in East Haddam, Conn., is all wrapped up for Christmas

title: Classy Last Holdout On the Block
description: NOT MANY passersby notice it. And it's quite likely that even most persons who live in the neighborhood are unaware of its unique status. But there it is, No. 417, on the southeast corner of 55th Street, the only apartment house left on Park Avenue between Grand Central Terminal and 57th Street.

title: Canada Is to Resume Shipments Of Uranium to Common Market
description: STRASBOURG, France, Dec. 14 (Reuters)  Canada will resume shipments of uranium to the European Economic Community on Jan. 1, Guido Brunner, the Common Market's Commissioner of Energy, told the European Parliament here today.

title: United Press International
description: TORONTO, Dec. 14The Islanders should teach Barje Salming some more bad words. The Toronto Maple Leafs star defenseman, a native of Sweden, spouted off to the referee in the first period of tonight's game at Maple Leaf Gardens and was sent off for a twominute penalty, during which the Islanders scored a goal.

title: Savings Deposits Fall At Banks in Nation
description: Mutual savings banks experienced net deposit inflow of $90 million in time and savings accounts last month, the smallest November gain since 1959, the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks reported yesterday.

title: M.A.C. Will Refund $250 Million of Bonds
description: The Municipal Assistance Corporation announced yesterday that it plans to refund $250 million of its outstanding bonds in order to get lower interest rates and longer maturity.

title: Atom Plant Repairs In Connecticut Blast Will Take 3 Weeks
description: WATERFORD, Conn., Dec. 14(AP)-Northeast Utilities officials estimate it will take three weeks to repair the damage at the Millstone I nuclear power plant tihat was caused yesterdayby two explooions in which one worker was injured and a small amount of radioactivity was released.

title: J. Edgar's Private Files
description: WASHINGTON  F.B.I. Director J. Edgar Hoover kept official and confidential files, separate from other bureau records, on celebrated Americans. Through the Freedom of Information Act, I have obtained contents of half a drawer: a 700page portion of. the sanitized file, spanning 18 years, on John F. Kennedy.

title: Santa Brings 1.0.U.'s for Star Wars
description: One of the hottestselling toys this Christmas may not be a toy at all, but the promise of one.

title: APARTHEID ASSAILED BY U.N.'S ASSEMBLY
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 14The General Assembly today adopted 14 resolutionsa recordcondemning apartheid in South Africa, including one censuring Israel for its economic relations with South Africa.

title: Woman in New York Is Charged With Welfare Fraud in Two Counties
description: A 39-year-old woman who owned cooperative apartment in New York City and an expensively furnished $50,000 house in Suffolk County simultaneously received welfare payments in both places, the State Acting Welfare Inspector General charged yesterday.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Golden Gaining Leaders
description: The New York City Comptroller, Harrison J. Goldin, is gaining the cautious support of a number of Democratic leaders for his intended challenge to State Comptroller Arthur Levitt next year. Most of the Democratic leaders Mr. Goldin has approached say they do not object to his running against Mr. Levitt, although they say they may nominally support the incumbent, who has been in office 23 years and who won landslide victories in six previous elections,

title: Judicial Panel Will Hear Charges That 38 Justices Fixed Tickets
description: In the largest judicial disciplinary action in the history of the state, seven judges were appointed yesterday by New York's chief judge to look into accusations that 38 local judges throughout the state had fixed traffic tickets.

title: A Judge Suppresses Disputed Confession In Georgia Slaying
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 14A Georgia Superior Court Judge has for the second time suppressed a disputed confession by the key defendant in the firstdegree murder case of the socalled Dawson Five, five young black men accused of killing a white man in a grocery store holdup nearly two years ago.

title: Around the Nation
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I.,Dec.14(AP)Increased manpower and newer equipment might have provided better chances for rescuing the four coeds who died in Providence College dormitory fire, an officer for a firefighters union said today.

title: Westchester Arts Unit to Honor Rockefeller
description: The Council for the Arts in Westchester will present to Nelson A. Rockefeller its 1977 Arts Award in recognition of his lifelong commitment and leadership in the arts and in special recognition of the invaluable role he has played in the growth of the arts in Westchester. The award will be presented tomorrow evening in Center of the State University of New York at Purchase, N.Y.

title: Joy, Anger and, by Finley, a Parting Shot at Kuhn
description: Extreme reactions and even emotions were touched off last night by the sale of the controversial Oakland A's, the only team in baseball with a traveling mule, green-and-yellow uniforms and Charles O. Finley at the hehm.

title: Cleveland Swears in Police Chief, A Former San Francisco Sheriff
description: CLEVELAND,Dec. 14Richard D. Hongisto, the former sheriff of San Francisco County, was sworn in today as Cleveland's chief of police. the third one this year.

title: Disks: Maggie Teyte's Gems
description: IT WAS JEAN DE RESZKE, Maggie Teyte's teacher, who applied the adjective l'exquise to her, and there Is probably no better word to describe the singing of this English soprano who had such a strange career. She started out in the opera houses of France: was the second person to sing Melisande (after Mary Garden) in Debussy's opera, following extensive coaching by the composer; appeared intermittently in

title: Legality of Retaining McIntyre as Acting Director of the Office of Management and Budget Is Questioned
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14James T. McIntyre Jr., the acting director of the Office of Management and Budget, may be violating the law by continuing to fill the vacancy created by Bert Lance's resignation.

title: Indiana Tops Notre Dame On Foul Shot by Radford
description: BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Dec. 14 (AP)Wayne Radford, who entered the game for the first time with two minutes remaining, hit a free throw with four seconds to go tonight to give Indiana a 6766 college basketball upset victoi'yy over Notre Dame.

title: In Memoriam
description: AUGERRachel. Today Is your birth. day. In spite of death we ere still together. Lovingly and sorrowfully yours forever.

title: P.B.A. HEAD PLEDGES TO SUPPORT M'GUIRE
description: The head of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association pledged yesterday that his union would cooperate fully with Robert J. McGuire, a 41-year-old lawyer who is scheduled to be named Police Commissioner today by Mayorelect Edward Koch.

title: Barnes Mortgage Trust Gets $55 Million Credit Agreement
description: Barnes Mortgage Investment Trust said yesterday that it had arranged for $55 million in credit from four banks. Terms of the agreemnt prohibit the payment of dividends until the agreement matures, which is likely to be mid1979.

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Funeral Service Held For Churchill'sWidow
description: LONDON, Dec. 15 (Reuters) The funeral of Baroness SpencerChurchill of Ohartwell, widow of Sir Winston Churchill, took place after a quiet church service here today.

title: Publishing: 5 Tales By James T. Farrell
description: YOUNG LONIGAN first appeared in 1932. Olive and Mary Anne has just been publisheda Christmas gift of five tales from one of the country's old literary pros, James T. Farrell. He'll be .74 on Feb. 27 and, between calls of congratulations, will probably be typing steadily. The new book is his 51st.

title: People in Sports . .
Market Place
description: Last Monday's decision by the Texas Railroad Commission ordering the Coastal States Gas Corporation to refund more than $1.2 billion to its customers in effect makes Coastal States OPEC's latest victim.

title: Notes on People
description: Saying she was without funds to support herself with even the basic necessities of life, lawyers for Cornelia Wallace asked the Circuit Court in Montgomery for detailed information on the personal finances of Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama. Court sources said that Mrs. Wallace, involved in divorce proceedings with her husband, wanted the information so that she will know now mucn money to ask in alimony. Judge Joseph Phelps gave the Governor a week to answer 43 questions on his finances, some of which referred to surpluses from his 1972 and 1976 Presidential campaigns. Mrs. Wallace's lawyers also sought 45day postponement of a pretrial conference on the divorce, but Judge Phelps agreed only to delay it from Dec. 19 until Jan. 4.

title: Auto Industry Raising Output To Make Up for Snow Losses
description: DETROIT, Dec. 15 (AP)United States auto makers are stepping up production thisweek to make up for cars and trucks that could not be built because of last week's snowstorms, Ward's Automotive Reports, the trade publication, estimated today.

title: Dozens of Congressmen Told to Give Documents On Korea to Investigators
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (UPI)A few dozen Congressmen, including the head of an Asian affairs subcommittee, have been told to give House investigators extensive office records and other material for the inquiry into alleged South Korean :influence buying, sources said today.

title: Carter Says P.L.O.'s Intransigence Bars It Frorn a Role in Peace Talks
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15  President Carter said today that the Palestine Liberation Organization had forfeited the right to speak for Palestinian Arabs at any forthcoming Middle East peace talks, but the President added that a solution to the Palestinian problem was still vital to achieve an enduring peace in the region.

title: Stage Is Set To Contest Move by A's
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Dec.15Attempts to keep the Oakland A's from being transferred to Denver began today with legal action intended to hold Charlie Finley and the A's to their Oakland Coliseum lease, which has 10 years to run.

title: Congress Votes Clean Water Rules
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15  Congress gave final approval today to controversial legislation to amend the Clean Water Act, including $2S.7 billion to clean up the nation's water supply, the extension of deadlines for reducing pollution and a crackdown on toxic chemicals.

title: ALBANY IS ASSAILED ON FISCALCRISIS ROLE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15Senator William Proxmire, the chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, criticized New York State today for making only a weak, feeble effort to help New York City with its fiscal problems and for going ahead with plans for a tax cut. On the second day of hearings dealing with the city's request for an extension of Federal loan assistance beyond the expiration date of July 1, 1978, the Wisconsin Democrat also expressed dismay over the city's widening budget gap.

title: HOFFA FOSTER SON. FREED ON BOND AFTER INDICTMENT
description: MIAMI, Dec. 15 (UPI)  Charles L. O'Brien, a teamsters union organizer who describes himself as the foster son. of James R. Hoffa, appeared before Federal magistrate today after his indictment by a grand- jury in Detroit on charges of lying in a bank loan application.

title: Result of the Election for First Selectman In Greenwich Changed for a Third Time
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Dec. 15For a third. time, the apparent whiner of the November. election for . First.. Selectman in Greenwich has changedtemporarily.

title: Gen. Wilfred Kitching, 84, Head Of the Salvation Army for 9 Years
description: LONDON, Dec. 15 (Reuters)Gen. Wilfred Kitching, 84 years old, international leader of the Salvation Army from 1954 to 1963, died today at his home at Bexhill-on-Sea, south of London.

title: DAYTON, OHIO, JUDGE VOIDS A BUSING PLAN
description: DAYTON, Ohio. Dec. 15 (AP)A Federal judge who ruled nearly five years ago that the city's schools were deliberately segregated voided a busing program involving about 13,000 students today, saying evidence of intent to segregate had not been provided by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.

title: Councilman Quits After Conviction
description: LINWOOD, N. J., Dec. 15 (AP)A town councilman here resigned yesterday after pleading guilty to possession of marijuana. The councilman, Kenneth Weaver, 36 years old, was placed under court supervision for six months by Atlantic County Judge Manuel Greenberg, authorities said. The local police said Mr. Weaver, who was on the Town Council's Police Committee, turned himself in Nov. 2 after it was discovered he used the drug.

title: MONEY SUPPLY GAINS $18 BILLION IN WEEK
description: The nation's basic money supply increased $1.8 billion in the week ended Dec. 7, the Federal Reserve reported yesterday, but the rise put the $334.9 billion total not much higher than it was two months ago.

title: WEEKEND MOVIE CLOCK
description: MANHATTAN

title: State Blue Law
description: NEWARK, Dec. 15New Jerseyans have either eight shopping days until Christmas or nine, depending on where they live and, in some instances, what they want to buy.

title: Bahrain Opens Drydock At Cost of $342 Million: As Arab Oil Talks End
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 15 (UPI)The ruler of  Bahrain today opened a giant $342 million drydock for supertankers Op the Persian Gulf island state, marking the conclusion of a conference of Ara)a oil ministers.

title: Highest Filipino Court Intervenes In Case of Doomed Marcos Rival
description: MANILA, Dec. 15The Philippines Supreme Court today asked a Government military commission that has condemned former Senator Benigno S. Acquino Jr. to death to postpone any further action on his case until the court decides whether the military tribunal had the right to try him.

title: GRUMMAN IS SETTLING CLAIMS MADE BY IRAN ON F44 COMMISSIONS
description: The Grumman Corporation announced yesterday a compromise settlement of Iran's claims for the commissions the comany had agreed to pqr to agents in the sale of 80 FI4 interceptor planes to the Iranian Government.

title: 8 PROVISIONS ARE URGED IN BOTTLE DEPOSIT PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15The Resource Conservation Committee, an interagency study group, announced today that it would recommend to President Carter and Congress eight provisions to be included in any Federal legislation on mandatory beverage container deposits.

title: Music: A Songfest
description: There has been much talk about musical eclecticism recently, and Leonard Bernstein has done his bit by describing his new work, Songfest, as unabashedly eclectic. But others would skip all the fancy terminology and merely describe it as oldfashioned. -

title: S.E.C.'s Hearings on Rules Set
description: WASHINGTON. Dec. 15The Securities and Exchange Commission today announced it would hold public hearings on the impact of the agency's cults, regulations, and disclosure requirements on the ability of small businesses to raise capital. Following the hearings, tenta-

title: Ali, for $12 Million, to Fight Norton
description: Muhammad All has agreed to defend the heavyweight championship of the world against Ken Norton for $12 rnilinn, Bob Arum, the promoter, annminced yesterday.

title: JERSEY INCOME TAX IS MADE PERMANENT BY ONEVOTE MARGIN
description: TRENTON, Dec. 15New Jersey's long, emotional fight over a state income tax ended dramatically tonight when the State Senate voted to make the tax permanent, and Governor Byrne jubilantly signed the bill minutes later.

title: Carter Says P.L.O.'s Intransigence Bars It From a Rote in Peace Talks
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15  President Carter said today that the Palestine Liberation Organization had forfeited the right to speak for Palestinian Arabs at any forthcoming Middle East peace talks, but the President added that a solution to the Palestinian problem was still vital to achieve an enduring peace in the region.

title: U.S.Canada
description: In the folinwing record at observations yesterday at weather stat.ons In the United States. high and low temperatures given are for the 20.hour period ended at 8 P.M.; precipitation totals given are for the 24.hour period ended at 8 P.M. Weather descriptions are forecasled conditions for today. (All times sre In Eastern Standard Time.)

title: CARTER TO GET PLAN
description: JERUSALEM. Dec. 15Prime Minister Menahem Begin will submit to President Carter tomorrow ideas affecting the Israelioccupied territories of the West Bank of the Jordan. the Gaza Strip and Sinai, an informed Israeli source said today.

title: Reserve Report
Local Congressmen Angry
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15Several key members of New York State's Congressional delegation strongly criticized the Defense Department today for its decision to reauce proauction or F14 jet fighters, charging that that the cutback would leave thousands of workers unemployed on Long Island.

title: Pentagon Told to Review Strategy For a Nuclear War Against Soviet
description: WASHINGTON. Dec. 15The White House has ordered the Defense Department to conduct a major review of contingency plansofor waging nuclear war against the Soviet Union.

title: STATE YIELDS TO U.S ON MEDICA1DREVIEWS
description: Citing a new restrictive Federal law, New York State has tentatively agreed to abandon much of what it considers its most successful Medicaid costcontrol program and allow the expansion of Federal plan that state officials believe is ineffective.

title: Opera: A Butterfly Fresh From the Cocoon
description: FOR better or worse, there has been no shortage of Madame. Butterfly productions this season. Puccini's JapaneseItalian melodrama currently figures prominently at both of New York's major professional opera houses. And on Wednesday night the Juilliard American Opera Center got into the act with the first of four Butterfly performances by a cast of students and young professionals.

title: Berkowitz Case Delay
description: A United States District Court judge in Brooklyn has deferred until Tuesday arguments on a motion by lawyers for David R. Berkowitz for an injunction to block prosecution of the alleged .44caliher killer anywhere in New York State. In the meantime, Judge Henry Bramwell said, the opposing sides should try to reach agreement on as many facts in the case as possible.

title: Yanks Reward Guidry With Richer, Longer Contract
description: Ron Guidry, a lowpriced star on New York Yankees pitching staff dotted with highpriced disappointments, uecame a junior member of baseball's nouveau riche, signing a threeyear extension of his contract for about $600,000.

title: Art: Requiem For a Heavyweight
description: Champion Victory Wreath No. III, a watercolor by Richard Yarde in which he applies his inventiveness to the prizefighter Jack Johnson.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Stage: Lynn Redgrave in Saint Joan
description: The, new Circle-in-theSquare production of Shaw's Saint Joan starts weakly, almost purposelessly, and proceeds uncertainly for quite a while. And then it begins to gain strength, and to acquire such movement, variety and exhiliration that by the time it finishes it has become a decided achievement, though just short of a triumph.

title: How Not to Secede in NassauSuffolk
description: Some folks in Nassau and Suffolk Counties .would like to secede from the New York Metropolitan region, or at least that regional entity that is recognized by the Federal Government as the official TriState Regional Planning Commission. It was established by New York, Connecticut and New Jersey as a clearing house for almost all applications from metropolitan local governments for Federal aid to housing, transportation, sanitation and other activities of regional significance. The commission must comment on the regional impact of every proposal.

title: School Results
description: BOYS BASKETBALL

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES UP; GRAINS ALSO CLIMB
description: A strong domestic demand for soybean meal yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade reversed the recent downward trend in the futures prices of soybeans and their end products as well as grains.

title: E.P.A. URGES REFUSAL OF WESTWAY PERMIT
description: The Federal Environmental Protection Agency recommended yesterday that the Army Corps of Engineers deny a permit for construction of Westway, the controversial proposed replacement for the crumbling West Side Highway, asserting that the project's proponents had not proved that building the highway would not damage the Hudson River.

title: Dow Off Despite Gains for Dollar; Worry on Money Supply a Factor
description: Stock prices settled lower in nervous trading yesterday as enthusiasm over Wednesday's brisk rally quickly faded on Wall Street.

description: Dr. Brown in Westchester

description: (OTB payoffs subject To 5% municipal surtax.)

description: THURSDAY. DECEMBER 15. 1977

title: Aqueduct Racing
description: RESULTS

title: Flous an les With the Problems of Success
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 12From the airport 16 miles to the north, ,downtown Houston looks like the Emerald City in the Land of Oz. Its skyscrapers appear to thrust heavenward out- of a forested swamp and sparkle in the afternoon sun.

title: Telephone Company Seeks to Cut Rate In New York Area
description: The New York Telephone Company yesterday filed proposed rate changes that would reduce basic monthly charges for residents from the temporary rates instituted last Oct. 27 but sharply increase charges for new connections. It asked that the rates take effect on Jan. 1.

title: Gerulaitis, Tanner Win, Reach Quarterfinals
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 15 (AP)Vitas Gerulaitis of Kings Point, L.I., and Roscoe Tanner of Kiawah Island, S.C., scored hardearned victories over American opponents today and advanced to the quarterfinals of the $210,000 New South Wales grass tennis tournament.

title: New A's Owner May Be as Flamboyant as Finley
description: DENVER, Dec. 15The new owner of the Oakland Athletics, who are about to become the Denver somethings, may yet accomplish the stupendous feat of making Charles O. Finley look colorless.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: TORONTO, Dec 15 (AP)Carling O'Keefe of Toronto says it is negotiating to sell its financially troubled United States subsidiary, Carling National Breweries Inc. The company would not give any details, but said that it might make another announcement before the year's end. The lack of adequate price increases, together with continued high marketing support for Tuborg, a Carling beer, resulted in an operating loss in the latest six months, Carling said. Carling National's brewing capacity is about 6.9 million barrels a year.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: People and Business
description: The resignation of David W. Wallace, chairman and president of the Bangor Punta Corporation, as a member of the board of the United Brands Company was announced yesterday by Max M. Fisher, chairman of United Brands.

title: Murder Suspect Paroled
description: A justice in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn paroled a 22-year-old Panamanian paraplegic who had been held in police custody for six months on a murder charge. The justice, Leonard Scholnick, acted after an assistant district attorney, Steven Samuel, said two witnesses who had originally identified the Panamanian, Octavio McFarland, as the murderer of a drug dealer last Christmas Day had changed their minds. Mr. Samuel asked that the murder charge be allowed to stand for a week while he looked for, new evidence that might link Mr. McFarland to the shooting of the drug dealer, Russell Ballanger, 30. Justice Scholnick said that if the evidence was not forthcoming by Monday he would dismiss the charges.

title: ALBANY AIDE OBJECTS 70 FOOD STAMP RULE
description: New York State's new ACting Commisgoner of Social Services, Barbara B. Blum, has protested that new Federal Agriculture Department regulations on food stamps will irresponsibly heighten the expectations of tens of thousands of clients when a relative few will actually benefit.

title: For a detailed calendar of Christmas music, see Page C20.
Metropolitan Baedeker
description: WEST 72d Street spans only four long blocks between Central Park West and the Hudson River. But it captures the essence of Manhattan's West Side, an area that cannot possibly be confused with any other section of the city. It is lined with stores that reflect the interests of West Siders, which are often different from those of East Siders and other New Yorkers. It is a cosmopolitan street that expresses the marvelously,:diverse West Side experience in contrast to the splendid uniformity that characterizes much of the city on the other side of the park. West. 72d Street is not a street that staggers you on first glance; it takes a bit oflooking to savor it.

title: This Sunday, go out to meet Christmas with a song. In Herald Square.
description: Starting at 8 pm, you and your whole family can join opera and TV star Robert Merrill, along with Elly Stone and thousands of other New Yorkers in a gigantic Broadway singalong. One immense block in front of Macy's, wrapped in the spirit of Christmas. Sweeping spotlights lighting up Herald Square. And joining our stars on 3 giant stages, some of the city's finest vocal groups: St. Patrick's Cathedral Choir. The Voices of St. Matthew's Bap tist Church, The Boys Choir of . Harlem, the VIP Chorale, The Interfaith NeighborsSingers of Yorkville and The New Amsterdam Singers. Don't miss this evening of love, senand music.

title: Auctions
description: THERE are at least three preChristmas auctions scheduled for today through Thursday, sales at which shoppers will find a selection of 20thcentury art works, toys or Victorian curios. The action begins this morning at 10:15 at Sotheby Parke Bernet, Madison Avenue at 76th Street, when more than 150 modern paintings, drawings and sculptures go under the hammer in what is Sotheby's final sale of the year before the house closes down for a threeweek recess.

title: Lost Impetus on Energy Bills
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15In the beginning, the goal was to pass energy legislation this fall, Then, to pass it by Christmas. Then, to agree on the measure in conference by Christmas and pass it in January,

title: Diary of a Discerning Macy Shopper

title: Rail Freight Traffic Is Down 9%
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 14.1 billion tonmiles, off 9 percent from the yearearlier level. Carloadings in the same period totaled 399,201 cars, down 11.6 percent from last year. The American Trucking Association Inc., reported intercity truck tonnage was off 3 percent from a year ago.

title: Fire at Putney School

title: THE NEW YORK TIMES
A Public Health Miracle
description: The end of smallpox has been advertised so often recent years, newspaper readers should be forgiven for regarding its demise as greatly exaggerated. Typically, a public health official will announce that the last case of smallpox has been eliminated from some remote corner of the world only to have a new outbreak detected three weeks later. Thus, the announcement by the World Health Organization that the most brutal form of the diseasethe Asian version known as variola majorhas not been found anywhere in two years is welcome news indeed. An international commission has now declared the Asian version officially dead in Bangladesh, its last known hideout. The accomplishment, as W.H.O. boasts, is nothing short of a public health miracle.

description: PARIS, Dec. 15 (Reuters)Alexander Galich, a dissident Soviet poet and balladeer who emigrated three years ago, died here today, friends of his family said. He was 59 years old.

description: WASHINGTON Dec. 15 (UPI)The nation's reported crime rate for the first nine months of 1977 was 6 percent lower than in the same period of 1976, the Federal Bureau of Investigation reported today. It was the fourth quarterly decline in a row.

description: TIS the season of, among other things, The Nutcracker. It may not be easy to get ticket for George Balanchine's version of the ballet chestnut at Lincoln Center's New York State Theater, but commercial television is offering no less than two major Nutcracker productions this weekend. One, representing the first choreographic effort of Mikhail Baryshnikov, the dancer, can be seen on CBS tonight at 8 o'clock. The other, recorded at Moscow's Bolshoi Theater, is on NBC Sunday at 7 P.M.

title: Yale Resgmes Presidency Search After Rejection by Harvard Dean
description: NEW HAVEN, Dec. 15Members of the Yale Corporation. who still hope trio decide on a new president for Yale University this weekend, have backtracked a bit now that Dean ,Hency Rosovsky of Harvard has declined to take the post. William P. Bundy, who heads the search effort, said today that the corporation will go back to the drawing board at meetings starting tomorrow on Yale's campus. He said the corporation would be interviewing more of the candidates on their final list of .nine or 10 people because the previous interviews had provedvery enlightening.

Houston Tangles With the Problems of Success

title: Restaurants
description: FOR the last several years one of our very best Chinese restaurants has- been Hunam, featuring the hot, spicy and gingery cuisine of the province for which it is named. Although recent visits indicated there has been some decline in the quality of the cooking here, Hunam still offers a number of outstandingly good selections, primarily among its more unusual offerings. As in so many Chinese restaurants, far less care is taken with standard fare, a failing that is inexcusable no matter how common.

title: Where to Hear The Season's Best
description: HE Christmas season brings an outpouring of music unequaled in volume at any other time of year. Even the rustiest amateur is inspired to join in the carols, sacred and secu- lar, that make up so much of the Christmas repertory. This repertory has been accumulating in the Western world for well over 1,000 yearssince the Middle Ages at the very least. But carolslovely and evocative though so many of them are are not all there is to Christmas music. From the early Renaissance to the presenta span of, say, 700 years composers have been turning out motets, cantatas, oratorios, organ works, music for instrumental ensembles of myriad combinations, songs and even operas that touch in some way or another on the Christmas theme. In addition, there are works that, though not specifically intended for Christmas use, adapt very well.

title: O'Hagan Cleared by Ethics Board On Financing of Graduate Studies

His hope, he said, was that the negotiators would define a genuine peace, a predictable peace, and a relationship among human beings that might tran acend the incumbency of any particular leader.

title: Scientists in Hawaii to Resume Proiect Halted by Dolphins
description: HONOLULU, Dec. 15The big saltwater tanks at the Marine Research Facility at Kewalo Basin are still empty, but plans are afoot to resume the dolphin testing program that was stopped last May 29 when two employees released the test animals into the sea.

title: A Promising Remedy for Drug Controls
description: For years, the Food and Drug Administration has been bombarded with complaints about its regulation of prescription drugs. Critics on one side contend that the agency, in its zeal to keep unsafe drugs off the market, has stifled innovation and deprived the public of beneficial drugs, some of which are readily available abroad. Critics on the other side charge that the agency yields too readily to industry pressure and releases drugs whose effectiveness or safety is in doubt. Now the Carter Administration is preparing a sweeping revision,of the drug laws to meet both sets of complaints: It would make it easier to introduce new drugs, and easier to ban them if they prove dangerous. The proposal, still in draft form, represents a major step toward reform.

title: Screen: The Prince of Bay Ridge
description: TONY IS A HANDSOME, bighearted guy with a lot more style than he knows what to do with. His job in a paint store call for much lan, but Tony supplies that anyway, charming the customers and strutting gamely down the street as he makes his deliveries. His room at home if dreary and his family even more so, but Tony has done what he can with Farrah and Rocky and Pacino posters to give the place a little class. Even so, things can get him downbut just when they do, another week is over and it's time to hit the local disco. On the weekend, and on the dance floor. Tony is king.Tony's whole life, as somebody else in "Saturday Night Fever" manages to point out, is "a clich." But John Travolta is so earnestly in tune with the character that Tony becomes even more touching than he is familiar and a source of fierce, desperate excitement. The movie, which spends mercifully little time trying to explain Tony, has a violent energy very like his own.This is best demonstrated during the dancing sequences, which lake up much of the film's time. Tony is depicted as being better than most, but also one of many; everyone in the 2001 Odyssey disco in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, seems possessed of a similar short-term vitality and pride. Their dancing is fluid, but it's also strictly, almost militaristically choreographed; people who stake everything on style can't afford to be sloppy, or even genuinely boisterous. Though the dancing is set to a blaring, contemporary score and often photographed in a red glow, the movie owes a lot more to "West Side Story" than it does to "Mean Streets."Mr. Travolta dances with a fine arrogance that follows naturally from the rest of his performance, and he has one solo number that stops the show. But John Badham, who previously directed another stylish, street-smart movie, "The Bingo Long Travelling All-Stars and Motor Kings," isn't always content to let the simple energy of the music or the performances suffice. Too often, he cuts distractingly in the middle of a routine, and his efforts to aggrandize characters by shooting them at angles or from below are superfluous. If these kids weren't flamboyant enough on their own, no amount of camera tricks could cover for them."Saturday Night Fever," which opens today at several theaters, begins to flag when, after an initial hour filled with high spirits and jubilant music, it settles down to tell its story; the effect is so deflating that it's almost as though another Monday has rolled around and it's time to get back to work.It seems that Tony's friends, who are a lively but uninteresting lot are so dead-ended that they're beginning to make him worry about his own future. And Stephanie (Karen Lynn Gorney), who has a job in Manhattan, is such a braggart that she has begun to give him notions of upward mobility.Ten minutes into the movie, you can be sure that its ending will be at least partly upbeat and that whatever happens will be blunt. But that is still no preparation for all the gruesome tricks Norman Wexler's screenplay uses to get Tony out of Brooklyn.Surely there are some people who make decisions without needing to be spurred on by a serious family trauma, an exceedingly ugly sexual episode and a friend's leap off the Verrazano Bridge. Tony, from what we've seen of him, is too proud and sensitive to need this much disillusionment to get him moving, but the screenplay has a way of indirectly, insulting the character by coddling him far more than he would ever coddle himself.Mr. Travolta is deft and vibrant, and he never condescends to the character, not even in a scene that has Tony and Stephanie arguing about whose "Romeo and Juliet" it is, Zeffirelli's or Shakespeare's. (They also try to identify Sir Laurence Olivier, and then remember that he's the guy who sells cameras on television.) Miss Gorney uses a much thicker accent and many more mispronunciations, and too often she is transparent in playing dumb. Donna Pescow, as one of the many local girls whom Tony could have but doesn't want, stays much more comfortably within the boundaries of her role.Among the movie's most influential principalsalthough they never appear on screenare the Bee Gees, who provided the most important parts or its score. It could be argued that the Bee Gees have been turning out the kinds of jaunty, formulaic disco hits that punctuate the movie for so long that they've lost any trace of originality. But it could also be argued that the group now has this kind of music down to a science, and that originality is not exactly a key ingredient in the disco mystique. In any case, at its best, the music moves with a real spring in its step, and the movie does too.

It is released in the same sense that one turns on the ignition of a car, pushes a button at Mission Control, or opens a Pandora's Box of magic. An initial action sets off chain reaction. Holism could be defined as an extraexistence; when the event is released, something else is created besides the sum of the parts of the experiment.

title: Books of The Times
description: yES, this is about a fishing book. But before you nonfisherpeople stop reading, let me try to explain why a book such as Nick Lyons's Bright Rivers is really not a specialized piece of writing. It isn't so much that Mr. Lyons, aside from being a passionate flycaster, is also an English teacher (at Hunter College), an editor, a ghostwriter, and the author of books and articles on subjects other than fishing. Although it certainly helps. What is unusual about Bright Rivers is that it goes a long way toward explaining why so many grown and intelligent people are inclined to stand in cold water up to their hams and wave a stick back and forth until their shoulders ache.

title: Art: The Legacy Of Hans Hofmann
description: AFIGURATIVE expressionist when he first arrived from Munich, at the beginning of the 1930's, Hans Hofmann (1880 - 1966) was then quite a conservative teacher. According to the late Carl Holty, Work from nature in all her glory was a phrase his students heard more  than once. One might infer from this and other evidence, including the ink drawings at Emmerich (41 East 57th Street), that moving to the United States has as profound an effect on the master as he had On his pupils. coincidentally, one of these, Ludwig Sander (190675), is also represented by an exhibition of drawingsat Rosa Esmon (29 West 57th Street). The two exhibitions complement each other in a very instructive way and both are worth seeing.

title: Maine. Snow is failing in the woods as a man, saw in hand, thinks back.
description: IT IS SNOWING and I wonder if I am too late. Here in these woods of pine, spruce and balsam fir, the snow is gentled by the salt sea that lies just beyond the ridgea fluid, heaving presence of such vastness that it holds something of August's warmth even to this late December. The wind off the water is southeast, nudging the tops of the tallest firs, clotting the snow with its briny fragrance; the flakes swell, become pale feathers so saturated with the nearby sea that they caress my cheeks with the gentle wetness of a summer rain.

title: Supertankers Collide Off South Africa and Catch Fire

title: 'Telefon': Spies With Ants in Pants
description: There are a lot of things working against Don Siegel's "Telefon," including its title, which as easily suggests one of Jerry Lewis's marathon television specials as it does the material with which skillets are lined so that eggs won't stick. "Telefon," of course, has to do with neither.It's the Russian code name for a sabotage plan so unbelievable that the actors, when they must explain it to us in the course of the film, actually seem to be embarrassed. They know that we know that they know that it's tall-tale-time in the Kremlinshared knowledge that has the effect of disarming solemn criticism and inviting us to succumb to the breathless nonsense as co-conspirators.The Peter Hyams-Sterling Silliphant screenplay, based on the novel by Walter Wager, is a sort of post-Cold War update of one of John Frankenheimer's best films, "The Manchurian Candidate," though it's nowhere near as stylish. As people in such movies are inclined to say at key moments, the situation, briefly, is this:During the height of the Cold War, the Soviets hypnotized and programmed about 50 agents who then were sent to the United States to lead lives as ordinary Americans, though they were, in fact, ticking time bombs. Should someone come along and whisper in their ears a few lines from Robert Frost's "Stopping by a Woods on a Snowy Evening," they'd be triggered into action to carry out a series of suicidal sabotage missions. The agents, we are told, were programmed to believe they were true-blue Americans of the sort, one assumes, who wouldn't be caught dead at poetry readings.This plan, we are told further (and not so briefly), was junked with dtente, though the agents remained in place. Thus, today, when a nutty, unreconstructed Stalinist, played by Donald Pleasence as if on leave from Charendon, decides to wreck dtente by setting off these time bombs, something must be done.In some ways, I suppose, "Telefon" is almost heart-warming. The film, which opened yesterday at the Rivoli and other theaters, is the story of how the peace-loving members of the Soviet Secret Police and the Central Intelligence Agency work together (without always knowing it) to capture the mad Stalinist and defuse the agents.The man who does this is a dour, dedicated Soviet operative with a photographic memory, a fellow named Grigori Borzov, a role that Charles Bronson plays not much differently from the way he plays anything else, but which I now find I can respond to. Mr. Bronson is a movie actor of the old school. He doesn't seem to act (though that is what he's doing) as much as he inhabits a film with his particular, massive presence, giving the film much-needed ballast. Without him, "Telefon" would fly up to the ceiling and just hang there.As his resident contact in America, Lee Remick is as likely a Soviet spy as Janet Leigh was once a Soviet pilot (Von Sternberg's "Jet Pilot"), but she's pretty and game and very cheery company, even with the screenplay's failed attempts at breezy dialogue."Telefon" is one of those movies that can't sit still. It moves from Moscow to Denver to Washington to Moscow to Los Angeles like a spy with the fidgets. While it's rather fun anticipating what disguise Mr. Pleasence is next going to turn up in (I think I favor his blond toupee and sneakers), some of the other supporting actors are more difficult to take. Patrick Magee plays a Soviet intelligence chief as if he were in a revue sketch, and the people who play C.I.A. types look so bland and empty you may suspect that they, too, have been hypnotized by the KGB.Mr. Siegel ("Dirty Harry") is not a director whose light touch is always sure, though "Two Mules for Sister Sara" and "Charley Varrick" were very entertaining. He needs good screenplays and room in which to build action sequences. Though there are action sequences in "Telefon," they are never sustained, and the screenplay only occasionally comes up with witty substitutes for the missing plausibility. However, to describe "Telefon" as synthetic is to take it more seriously than it's taken by anyone connected with it."Telefon" has been rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"). It has isolated moments of explosive action and some blood, but nothing that would shock a child or a Soviet censor.

What Was lacking in the company's second program, presented Thursday, was the element of dance.

title: Life Signs Found Under Ice Shelf
description: LINCOLN, Neb., Dec. 16 (AP)Scienfists conducting the first experiments beneath a 1,375foot ice shelf in Antarctica saw two fish swimming near the seabed, proof that life exists in the frigid, sunless waters, according to scientists.

title: Sadat Implies He May Meet Soon With Begin in Egypt
description: CAIRO, Dec. 16President Anwar el Sadat, eager to maintain the momentum of his peace offensive, held out today the possibility of a new meeting with Prime Minister Menahem Begin, this time in Egypt, if the Israeli leader's present visit to Washington proved fruitful.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A 25-year-old South Carolina man was sentenced yesterday to a mandatory life prison term for participating in the kidnapping of two sisters last February at the Bergen Mall Shopping Center in Paramus. The defendant, David Brunson, got an additional 10to-20-year term for raping the older sister later in a motel in Paterson while another alleged abductor telephoned a $5,000 ransom demand to the woman's father.

Hyland.

title: Trenton Greets the New Income Tax With Sigh of Relief
description: TRENTON, Dec. 16When Governor Byrne signed the legislation last night making the state income tax permanent, the general reaction outside, as well as inside, the State Capitol was one of overwhelming relief. Lawmakers will no longer have to engage in the acrimonious debates over

title: Food Price Rise Seen
description: Food prices will rise about 7 percent in 1978, but no serious shortages or extreme price fluctuations are anticipated, the New Jersey Food Council said. The council said food prices increased about 5 percent this year.

title: Britain's T axLaws Unfair to Women, Rights Report Says
description: LONDON, Dec. 16British married women are victims of a humiliating tax system that treats them as invisible, deprives them of financial privacy and sometimes unfairly costs them money, the Equal Opportunities Commission charged today.

title: ExPoverty Aide Guilty of Perjury
description: A former official of an agency affiliated with B'nai Torah, a controversial operator of poverty programs, was convicted yesterday of having lied to a grand jury about spoiled food in the 1975 summer lunch program in New York City.

title: MEXICO WILL RELAX AUSTERITY PROGRAM
description: MEXICO CITY, Dec. 16The Mexican Government plans a cautious relaxation of its austerity program next year, allowing the economy to grow by about 5 percent but still maintaining its fight against inflation.

title: Italy Shaken by Banking Scandals
description: ROME, Dec. 16A series of banking scandals has shaken the Italian banking and business community.

title: Evansville Cancels Season
description: EVANSVILLE, Ind., Dec. 16 (AP)The University of Evansville formally canceled the rest of its 197778 basketball season today because of the deaths of the 14 team members and their coach, Bobby Watson, in a plane crash Tuesday. James By ers, the school's athletic director, said the Holiday Invitational Tournament would go on as scheduled Dec. 2930. He said Southern Illinois University had volunteered to play in place of Evansville for expense money only.

title: Trying to Beard a Drinker
description: AVENCHES, Switzerland, Dec. 16 (Reuters)A man who set fire to a drunken friend's heard to awaken him was given a suspended threemonth sen. tence and a fine of nearly $1,000 by al court here today.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: FOR ALL SEASONS Carols will ring out this weekend in three of the more picturesque locales in the metropolitan area. At 1 o'clock this afternoon, the 19th century Park Slope traditiion of an oldfashioned Christmas songfest and I bellringing ceremony will be revived at the Litchfield Mansion, Prospect Park West at Fifth Street, in Brooklyn. Carolers will be provided with song sheets and they are urged to bring along bells of all sizes. Children are asked to bring along stale bread, shelled nuts, popcorn and berries to decorate a tree for the park's birds aud animals.

title: Stocks Down in Moderate Trading; Fall Tied to Money Data and Dollar
description: The stock market, despite some encouraging economic news, ended slightly lower yesterday in moderate trading.

Falvey, the general counsel of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, on the extension of cleaning contract for the World Trade Center. Mr. Falvey said that he had questioned the United States Attorney's office about a criminal case involving the cleaning company and that he was told it was. not relevant to the Port Authority's interests.

title: Fate of Cypriot Remains in Doubt
description: NICOSIA. Cyprus, Dec. 16 (AP)The fate of Achilleas Kyprianou, the kidnapped son of President Spyros Kyprianou, remained in doubt today after reports that he would be released failed to materialize.

title: Ghana's Capital Still Bustles Amid Signs of Hard Times
description: ACCRA, GhanaIn Ghana, where travel by land is at best adventurous and at worst hazardous, the most appropriate metaphor for life is a road. So it is fitting that among the most trenchant comments about life are tne. names painted lovingly on the bulging passenger trucks that ply the The Talk byways. They are snippets of poetry, philosophy and personal affirmation.

title: Family Doctors Lose Move to Bar Specialists From Private Practices
description: TRENTON, Dec. 16A move by family practice physicians in Hunterdon County to prevent specialists from opening private practices there was rejected today in State Superior Court. Family Doctors Lose Move to Bar Specialists From Private Practices

description: CHICAGO, Dec. 16 (AP)Eight members of a neoNazi group were indicted today on charges of attempted murder, aggravated battery and armed violence in the beating of a member of the Jewish Defense League.

description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16Prime Minister Menahem Begin told President Carter today that Israel, in response to President Anwar elSadat's peace initiatives, was ready to restore to Egypt complete sovereignty over the Sinai Peninsula and to give Palestinians control over internal affairs in the West Bank of the Jordan River and the Gaza Strip.

title: U.S. Says Economy Gains Bit Faster Than Expected
description: The United States economy is growing a little faster than expected, according to statistics released yesterday in Washington by the Commerce Department.

description: RICHMOND, Dec 16 (AP)The Westinghouse Electric Company said today it had reached agreement with Texas Utilities Services Inc. in the uranium suit brought against the giant company by in ntiliciAs.

title: The Planner's Constituency
description: No position is more intimately Involved with the destiny of New York than the job of Chairman of the City Planning Commission. The man who made the city most aware of that, in everything from financial survival to the quality of urban life, was John Zuccotti. After he became Deputy Mayor, the man who has quietly carried on a series of longrange but critical programs is Victor Marrero.

title: Personal Investing
description: Utility stocks are at some of their lowest prices in 40 years, and yiehts have become substantial. Yields on many are so high that they are pushing against and even topping returns on longterm utility bonds. Page 37.

description: NASHVILLE, Dec. 14In 1641, the British Parliament banned clergymen from public office on the ground that bishops and other Persons in Hoiie Orders ought not to be intangled with secular Jurisdiccon (the Office of the Ministery being of such greate Importance that it will take upp the whole Man).

title: Three for the City
description: Three major boxes on the selection checklist for a new Police Commissioner are his capacity to win internal support from the force; to win the confider se of the public, especially minority groups, and the ability to manage an immense bureaucracy. The Mayorelect deserves high marks in at least two of those boxes for choosing Robert McGuire.

title: Congressman Reports a Reign of Terror
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Dec. 16An American Congressman, who arrived here today from Addis Ababa, said that there is no doubt that a reign of terror exists in the Ethiopian capital.

title: New York Banks T old to Increase Their Commitments to Assist City
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16  The top executives of New York City's biggest banks were told today by Senator William Proxmire, the chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, that they were not making enough of an effort to aid the city in its fiscal problems, and he called on them to come up with a much bigger commitment.

title: High Hopes And Sad Payoff
description: Great disappointments must begin with great expectations. Thus, those New Yorkers who campaigned to prevent the Concorde from landing at Kennedy Airport have suffered one of the greater disappointments of 1977.

title: Giants
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Dec. 16The Giants were breaking up today. In the spirit of that final pillow fight on the last day of children's summer camp, horseplay narked the team's last rigorous practice session of the National Football League season.

title: Soviet Rails Reach Coal for Japan
description: Soviet raillaying crews, keeping 14 months ahead of schedule in their northward advance through Siberian virgin forest, have reached a coal basin that is expected to suppiy a significant part of the fuel needs of the Japanese steel industry in the 1980's.

title: SURPLUS INCREASED $1 BILLION BY JAPAN IN NOVEMBER TRADE
description: TOKYO, Dec.  16One day after American and Japanese negotiators ended a new round of talks to curb Japan's mounting trade surplus, official figures were released here today showing another billiondollar monthly trade surplus for Japan.

title: Fire in Suburb of Manila Kills 32 Mental Patients At Overcrowded Hospital
description: MANILA., Dec. 16 (Reuters)At least 32 mental patients died early today in a fire that broke out in an overcrowded wing of a mental hospital here. S'me patients fought off firemen and guards who were trying to rescue them, and others died in isr.17tion cells.

title: She's Making Her Fashion Debut With Airy, FlowerStrewn Robes

description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP)Prime Minister Michael N. Manley of Jamaica met with President Carter today after defending Cuba's right to station forces in Africa.

description: An airquality permit vital to the Westway was denied yesterday by New York State's Environmental Commissioner, who said he believed the project's supporters had underestimated the traffic .and pollution that the Manhattan highway would produce. But the Commissioner, Peter A. A, Berle, said that he might reconsider.

description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16William Proxmire wore a Senator Scrooge name tag at his staff Christmas party today, and his two top aides were identified as Bah and Humbug.

title: G. M. Agrees to Pay Buyers $40 Million In Engine Switch
description: The General Motors Corporation reportedly has agreed to pay up to $40 million to thousands of customers who unknowingly purchased Buicks, Oldsmobiles and Pontiacs powered by Chevrolet engines, the California Attorney General's office said yesterday.

description: Thomas Schippers, conductor laureate of the Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra end one of the foremost of young Americn conductors, died in New York City last night of lung cancer.

description: The maritime traffic off the Cape of Good Hope, where two supertankers collided yesterday, is among the densest in the world. Most of the oil going to Europe and the United States from Saudi Arabia, Iran, Iraq, Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates passes around the southern tip of Africa.

title: Show Biz Sonny's Ammunition
description: One career is enough for most people and one too many for some. But yesterday 67-year-old David Abraham (Sonny) Werblin, as the new president and chief executive officer of the Madison Square Garden Corporation, began what amounts to his fourth career. His other three, in inverse order, were creating the New Jersey Sports Complex, reorganizing the New York Jets from bankruptcy to the Super Bowl, and lifting the Music Corporation of America's, income from packaged TV shows to $100 million annually.

title: State and Federal Officials Urge Blocking of New York Pay Raises
description: State and Federal officials urged the Emergency Financial Control Board yesterday to block raises for City Council members and other elected city officials, arguing that the increases would undermine the city's efforts to secure firrncial aid from Albany and Washington.

title: Citibank's Bid to Get $250 Million For Zaire Is Still Unsuccessful
description: A yearlong effort by Citibank to put together a $250 million loan for Zaire is still unsuccessful, Irving S. Friedman, a senior vice president of the bank, said yesterday. The loan was being arranged, in effect, to enable Zaire to repay its old loans from private banks, totaling some $400 million, on their original terms.

title: ERITREAN GUERRILLAS SAY RED SEA PORT IS CUT OFF
description: ROME, Dec. 16 (Reuters)Eritrean rebels fighting Ethiopian forces for control of the Red Sea port of Massawa have attacked the Ethiopian naval base there, the Eritrean People's Liberation Front said here today.

title: Nets, Facing Garden Suit, Wary of Move
description: If David A. (Sonny) Werblin's move from New Jersey to New York will have its maximum effect on the easern side of the river, it is at least causing an aftershock on the western side. The New Jersey Netsrecently the New York Netsare slightly staggered over the announcement.

title: American Price for Mexican Gas in Doubt
description: MEXICO CITY, Dec. 16The Mexican Government is becoming increasingly irritated by the Carter Administration's refusal to approve the price for Mexican natural gas exports that was previously negotiated with American distribution companies and that now will apparently have to be renegotiated.

title: LONDON AND SINGAPORE HALT CONCORDE SERVICE
description: LONDON, Dec. 16The three times weekly supersonic Concorde service between London and Singapore was terminated today because of Malaysia's refusal to permit the use of its territorial air space on environmental grounds.

title: Lasix Curbs Ordered For Tracks in Jersey
description: TRENTON, Dec. 16 (AP)New Jersey will require that racehorses receiving the drug Lasix be kept in a guarded barn for five hours before a race, the State Racing Commission said today.

title: DOLLAR ENDS RALLY IN EUROPE TRADING BUT GAINS IN TOKYO
description: The dollar recovered against the yen in Tokyo and New York yesterday, but it slipped again against most other major currencies in both New York and European foreign exchange trading, according to The Associated Press.

title: Lester D. Stickles, 83, Lawyer; Was Specialist in Corporate Work
description: Lester D. Stickles, a special deputy attorney general for New York State from 1931 to 1933 and the Corporation Counsel of Mount Vernon, N.Y., from 1936 to 1940, died Thursday at St. Charles Hospital in Port Jefferson, L.I. He was 83 years old and lived in Setauket, L.I.

title: P.L.O. ACCUSES CARTER OF MIDEAST DUPLICITY
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 16The Palestine Liberation Organization denounced President Carter tonight for calling it intransigent and ineligible for a peace conference rcle. title: Art and the Business of Art
description: In appointing Henry Geldzahler as New York City's Commissioner of Cultural Affairs, Mr. Koch has selected a man in the city's creative mainstream for a job that is central to both its economic and cultural life. As curator of 20thcentury art at the Metropolitan Museum, Mr. Geldzahler's credentials as a professional in the visual arts are incontestable. He further assures us that he is not a monoculture person; his interests are wideranging. Comparing his job as manager of culture here to being commissioner of wheat in Kansas, he promises a sophisticated, lively approach. If nothing else, he is going to be quotable, but the city can expect a great deal more.

title: Dancers Fuse Ballet and Modern Idiom
description: A grab bag of a disconcerting company that calls itself the Theater Dance Collection opened Thursday night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music with Donna McKechnie as guest artist.

description: Governor Carey and leaders of the State Legislature denied yesterday that as charged by United States Senator Wil Liam Proxmire. the state had been lax in coming to the aid of New York City in its fiscal crisis.

description: VIENNA, Saturday, Dec. 17 (Reuters)The kidnapped wife of an Austrian textile milircnaire was released unharmed after being held hostage for more than 100 hours, the police said early today. Lotte Boehm, 42 years old, returned home early this morning, a spokesman said, but there was no immediate confirmation that any ransom was handed over.

title: Nations Renegotiate Debts After a Default
description: Nations do not permanently default on foreign debt, an International Monetary Fund spokesman said in Washington. Instead, countries reschedule their debts in negotiations with foreign bankers, often assisted by the World Bank, while the I.M.F. may be called on to provide loans as well, in order to shore up a country's finances.

description: CHICAGO, Dec. 16For Peggy Mosely, a black elementary school teacher, the transfer from a good, welldisciplined school in a middleclass black community to an overcrowded school with limited resources and problems with discipline was like going from heaven to hell.

title: ELDRIDGE PETERSON, 72, PUBLISHED PRINTERS INK
description: Eldridge Peterson, who retired in 1958 as editor and publisher of Printers Ink, the now defunct magazine of advertising and marketing, died Thursday in Staten Island Hospital after a short illness. He was 72 years old and lived at 128 Brookside Avenue, Staten Island.

title: More Women Moving into Public Accounting, But Few to the Top
description: Thousands of accountants converged on Cincinnati this fall for the annual meeting of the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants, and scores among the thousands gathered at cocktail parties given by big national firms in the field.

title: The Changing Face of Public TV
description: The Corporation for Public Broadcasting has never quite managed to rescue its reputation from the tarnishing it took during the Nixon years. Created in 1967, the corporation was assigned the role of distributing Federal funds to public broadcasters. It was meant to be a buffer between those who appropriate the money and those who spend it, a shield against political control of what appears on the tube. The Nixon Administration, however, attempted to use the shield as weapon, to discourage funding for programs that the White House found unfriendly.

title: Notes on People
