Archbishop Marion Capucci, a Greek Catholic of the Melkite rite, was imprisoned for nearly three years, and his release took four months of negotiations between the Vatican and Israel. He had been  sentenced. to re years Tor sniu66,,..E, guns to Palestinian guerrillas. His release carried the stipulation that he not be reassigned anywhere in the Middle East.

Galligan, an 18-year-old freshman killed in Tuesday's dormitory fire at Providence College, was memorialized today for her deep loving heart. her bright smile, and for the joy she imparted.

title: GARDENING
description: THE trimming of the tree is probably the most exciting part of the Christmas decorating traditions. Families save their favorite trinkets, balls and bells for dangling on the ends of the evergreen branches. description: My wife, Beatrice, and I were almost alone in the motel under the 200foot redwood trees in Sequoia National Park last January, and there were signs warning of bears foraging among the cabins. Yosemite Valley was bustling with sightseers the following week, but even there a fiveminute stroll from the lodge took us into a silent cathedral of huge pines and sheer granite walls. Winter is the best time to see Yosemite and SequoiaKings Canyon National Parks in California.

title: Cleveland Police Protest Ends

Kucinich proclaimed victory and said he would keep close tabs on police operations, His administration resumed talks with the Cleveland Patrolmen's Association a few hours after the policemen started returning to work. They began calling in sick on Thursday in a contract dispute with the city leaving a skeleton staff of mostly supervisory officers on duty.

title: The Value Of New York
description: I was born in a poor section of the Bronx and grew up as one of the New York Irish, or more precisely the Bronx Irish, during the Great Depression of the 1930's. We never had any money. My grandmother had emigrated from Liverpool at the turn of the century. She managed to support her eight children by working as a midwife for the Henry Street Settlement, but there was nothing left to be passed on to her family. My father was a New York mu- sician, a trombone player. He lost his job in the Biltmore Hotel when the dining room closed as a consequence of the Depression, putting the house orchestra out of work. He ended up working for the W.P.A. We lived in Throgs Neck and later near Fordham Road in the Bronx. These neighborhoods were populated by tough, competitive Jewish, Italian and Irish families. Somehow those diverse strains learned to live together, to respect one another, and in many cases even to love one another,

title: Tow Truck to Rescue Is Swamped by Tide
description: CORONADO, Calif., Dec. 17 (UPI)A car became stuck in a tidal mud flat in San Diego Bay Wednesday and Larry Kavner came to its aid. He managed to free the car, but the winch on his tow truck broke and the car got stuck. Another tow truck was called. It too got stuck.The Marines came to the rescue with amphibious vehicles, but they could extricate only the second truck. Mr. Kavner's $16,000 truck was already under water at high tide.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: CONTRARY to what some people may think, a knife, chisel, wood plane or similar cutting tool is actually safer to use when its blade is very sharp, rather than being dull or nicked. A dull or incorrectly sharpened blade is not only harder to use and slower to work with, it also requires much more pressure on the tool's handle, and this means there is a much greater chance of slipping and an accident occurring.

title: THE UNLONELINESS OF THE LONGDISTANCE SKIER
description: KILLINGTON. Vt. Mull Delso, a retired Army mountaineering instructor, was seated behind a halfgallon jug of rose at a table in a rough-and-ready lounge at the Mountain Meadows Ski Touring Center. When 1 first came up here in 1964, I had the woods to myself, he said. Now, there's a skier behind every tree. His lament reflects warning issued by Rudi Mat tesich, president of the Ski Touring Council and the unofficial dean of crosscountry skiing in America. In an introduction to one of the many hooks that had begun appearing on the subject in the early 70's, he wrote: Ski touring would he spoiled if too much emphasis is placed on the merchandising of fancy equipment, changing fashions, or organized area skiing, and on the promotion of the name resort. The words are a blueprint for the present state of the sport.

title: Yarborough Eclipsed by Foyt in 77
description: Cale'Yairborough had the kind of season in 1977 that many other racecar drivers can only dream about. He won nine major stockcar races, finished all 30 he started, captured his second straight Winston Cup national driving title, pocketed more than $500,000 in earnings and had his year capped by being named Olsonite Driver of the Year. one of motor sports top awards. He, or anyone else, will be hard pressed to equal or surpass that record in 1978 or any other season. Mario Andretti, Tom Sneva, Al Holbert, Patrick Tambay, Niki Lauda, Hurley Haywood and Shirley Muldowney were among drivers who added to their outstanding credentials during 1977. The season produced other stars, but from these names it is easy to see that being in the upper echelon in motor sports in 1977 would be like climbing Mount Everestnot impossible but difficult.

title: Inside Rhodesia, `Muz Is the Leading Black
description: SALISBURY, RhodesiaThe man who at the moment commands the overwhelming support of Rhodesia's black majority is a Methodist bishop named Abel Tendekayi Muzorewa. Unlike his rivals for the leadership of Zimbabwe, as blacks call Rhodesia, he has never spent a day in prison, He is an uninspiring speaker and a man who, even some ardent backers concede, lacks political instinct and shrewdness. He has been disavowed by leaders of neighboring black states and has no real following among guerrillas fighting the forces of Rhodesia's white Government.

title: Headliners
description: Two volumes of J. Edgar Hoover's personal files came to light last. week and n them was the name of Alicia Darr Purdom. now Alicia Corning Clark, widow of Alfred Corning Clark the sewing machine heir. In a 1963 letter to Robert F. Kennedy, the then Attorney General, Mr. Hoover said his bureau had information alleging that. Robert Kennedy had paid a woman $500,000 to drop a suit arising from John F. Kennedy's failure to marry her in 1951. Mr. Hoover's letter went on to say that 'in this connection an Italian magazine had alleged that Mrs. Purdom had claimed that several years previously she was engaged to he married to John F. description: ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 17Political terrorism has become a fact of daily life in Turkey. Every day people are killed or wounded for political reasons. title: BEHIND AMERICA'S MARIJUANA HIGH
description: On Wednesday, Aug. 31, 1977, 27 Mexicans and six Americans boarded the Mexicana Airlines 8:30 A.M. flight to Oaxaca at Mexico City International Airport. The tall, smooth gringo in a tan leisure suit and shades who got on right before the doors closed went inure or less unnoticed. He wore a deep blue polyester shirt patterned with red and orange blossoms. His tourist permit listed him as one Henry Amazon, vacationing insurance agent from Denver. Amazon had paid for his ticket with two crisp American $20 bills and had lied about being vacat ion. The journey he was starting over the Sierra Madre del Sur and into the highland Oaxaca Valley was a business trip, and Amazon's real business had nothing to do with insurance.

title: A Different Kind of Art

title: But Regionally, Costs Are Soaring

Fuel oil, natural gas, electricity and other forms of energy are all more costly than they were last year, and while the world currently is awash in oil, experts say prices will continue upward next year.

As a director and worker at the Elmsford Animal Shelter, I've learned this from extensive experience in helping people adopt pets. A cat or dog coming into the home should get as much sensible attention as possible both for its own sake and for its adoptive family.

title: Up the River, but Why?
description: Criminology is in a transition phase, and transitions are notoriously unsettling. When the experts themselves are unsure, the public will be confused. The past year or so has witnessed the introduction of measures that seem to represent a hardening of attitudes toward the prison population. Talk of punishment now seems to be replacing the preVious dominance of the concept of rehabilitation. There is movement to do away with parole, eliminate the discretionary sentence and tighten the rules on juvenile justice. All of these, traditionally championed by the liberal community, are under attack by that same group. Yet the reversal of intention and motive is not so great as the methodological shift might imply.

description: PERU. Ind., Dec. 17 (UPI)The Federal authorities have arrested five persons on. charges that they extorted $300,000 from an elderly couple over a twoyear period. Arrested by the Federal Bureau of Investigation yesterday were Larry Joe Lucy, 24 years old, and his wife, Victoria Annette Lucy, 23, and Danny Lawrence Lopez. 31, all former Peru residents living in Norfolk, Va.; Terry Levier, 25, of Peru, and Arthur Nulf, 30, Logansport. The F.B.I. and the Peru police declined to identify the victims, but they said the scheme left them with only $600.

title: Vikings Down Lions for Division Title
description: PONTIAC, Mich., Dec. 17 (AP)Chuck Foreman ran for 156 yards and two touchdowns and Bob Lee threw two scoring passes tonight as the Minnesota Vikings wrapped up their fifth straight division title with a 3021 victory over the Detroit Lions.

title: Of Special Interest
description: A Shower of Shange

title: An Evening of Tonal Splendor By New York Choral Society
description: Not all choruses feel hehoiden to Christmas music this time of the year, fortunately. On Friday night in Carnegie Hall, the New York Choral Society presented a program of three works that find a more timeless place in the annual chronology. True, they were all sacred in nature, two of them paeans to the glory of God and the third a vigorous, not to say jubilant, setting of the mass. They provided an evening of tonal splendor and emotional vigor that suited the season in spirit not specifically in subject.

title: Wounds Fatal to State Trooper
description: BALTIMORE, Dec. 17 (AP)A state trooper wounded in a shootout Monday night died today at University Hospital here. A spokesman for the hospital said the trooper, Gregg Presbury, died this morning without regaining consciousness. The 27yearold police officer had been shot four times after stopping a car for a routine traffic check in Anne Arundel County. A suspect in the shooting is being held without bail.

title: Choice Destroyed After Stakes Spill
description: In an accidentmarred contest in which four of the nine starters went down as the field was entering the stretch for the last time, Jack R. Hogan's Gallivantor captured the 554,150 Display Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday.

description: Not 100% Computerized

title: FISHING
description: PROBABLY the most surprising aspect of the Island's fishing scene this year was the return of giant bluefin tuna off Montauk, viewed by experts as the best showing in 20 years. But sportfishing catches of the smaller school tuna on the Island also improved considerably, nearly doubling over the preceding year.

title: LETTER FROM WASHINGTON
description: ECONOMICALLY hardhit New Jersey cities are in the middle of a developing scuffle over how to divide up a supplemental $1.2 billion Federal pie for community development over the next three years.

title: Sports in 1977: Scandal and Surprises
description: In 1977 the American Broadcasting Companies ventured into fight promotion and came out with a black eye. CBS falsely advertised a series of tennis matches as winner  take  all events and was caught in the lie. New York racing's first ringer scandal in 30 years brought about the indictment of a veterinarian with a thriving prac- tice among thoroughbreds and raised suspicions that fast horses may have been substituted for slow horses in as many as two dozen races.

title: Students Get a Big Break and Take Off
description: From the halls of Middlebury to the shores of Monterey students are taking off in record numbers this month for semester break. Liberated by longer vacations, they are fanning out across the country and abroad, some for credit but most for fun, and spending more than ever before on winter trips.

title: B.Y.U. Tops Japan Team In Football Exhibition
description: TOKYO, Dec. 17 (AP)Brigham Young University, ranked No. 17 among United States colleges, got four touchdown passes from Marc Wilson and wore down the East Japan allstars, 61.13, today in an exhibition football game.

description: The fear of crime, a dominant emotion in American life for at least a decade, appears to be leveling off across the country, according to a survey released yesterday by the Gallup Poll.

title: The Mystique of the Balanced Budget
description: President Carter appears to be among the last in his Administration who believes that balancing the Federal budget in 1981 is still a good idea. Most of his officials are now avoiding mention of this goal or have taken to insisting that the balance will be desirable only in a fullemployment economy-which surely will not be attained by 1981. The Congressional Budget Office testified last week to the impossibility of accomplishing such a fiscal feat.

title: If You Go ...
description: . . . to Yosemite, you can stay for $9 a day in a cabin for two with oil heat but no water, or you can spend $15.50 to $28 a day for a double room or cabin with bath and electric heat at Yosemite Lodge and Curry Village. A double room with bath is $42 at the deluxe Awahnee Hotel.

description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (UPI)A Federal appeals court has ruled that a bona fide Washington correspondent has constitutionally protected interest in obtaining a White House press pass and must be told the full reason if one is denied.

title: Help for the Problems of Old Age
description: IT HAS been said that old age can become an expression of human experience.. ..it can be rich, varied, colorful and, in turn enriching; or it can be impoverished, empty and only serve to emphasize the futility of life. For the elderly, reality is best described by the latter possibility.

title: Millstone Blast: A Matter of Degree
description: WHILE episodes like the two explosions that occurred last week at the Millstone I nuclear power station near New London are fairly common at conventional industrial plants they are paid little heed because no radioactivity is involved.

title: Whither the National Arts and Humanities Endowments?
description: Made a journey to Washington some weeks ago, armed only with a notebook and an overnight bag, to learn more about the Federal Government's relationship to the arts and humanities in America. Created under the National Foundation on the Arts and Humanities Act of 1965, and amended and extended under the Arts, Humanities, and Cultural Affairs Act of 1975, the twin Endowments are now in their 12th year of operation, with a total appropriation of $225 million (including $36 million in challenge grants). Both have recently received new leadershipappointments that are attracting considerable criticism. And so I was eager to discover, through interviews with various movers and shakers on Capitol Hill, in what directions the Endowments were preparing to move under the Carter Administration.

title: FIRES EXTINGUISHED IN OILTANKER CRASH
description: PORT ELIZABETH, South Africa, Dec. 17 (AP)Safety inspectors boarded two stricken Americanowned supertankers today after fires on both had been extinguished and the vessels were taken in tow by rescue tugs, port authorities reported here.

description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP)A new mail service called Express Mail is the hest hope for getting Christmas packages to their destinations by Dec. 25, the Postal Service said today.

Dec. 17 (AP)New York's state and local percapita tax burden was higher in 107576 than in every other state but Alaska, according to an Albany lobbying group, the Citizen's Public Expenditure Survey. It quoted figures released last August by the Federal Department of Commerce, and it was the first time in years that New York's percapita tax bill was not the highest in the country.

title: DINING GJIT

On any night, the starving multitudes will be stuffed into the inadequate waiting area of this popular spot. People will attempt to enter or leave the restaurant, but like the Long Island Expressway, at rush hour, traffic is at a standstill. Even with a reservation, you cm expect to wait about fifteen minutes or more.

title: The New Tannhausee: An Old Story with Fresh Passion

Anything goes, it seems, as directors devise ever more farout reinterpretations of the composer's mythic plots and characters.

description: WASHINGTON  A Congressional committee is currently preparing to study the relations between the Central Intelligence Agency and the news media, and this in my estimation is an exercise that could invite all kinds of misunderstanding.

Peter Watterson of West Palm Beach has been elected Southeastern Bishop for the Anglican Church of North America, the breakaway faction of the Fpiscopal Church. Mr. Watterson, of the Church of the Holy Spirit in West Palm Beach, is to he consecrated Decr 28 in Denver, according to the Rev. Stirling Rayburn. who headed a conference yesterday and today that ended with the selection. He said that the conference drew about 100 persons.

title: DrawInaby Paul Flora

The hand of a tough editor might have made the differencecutting, reorganizing, forcing the author to clarify, prove assertions, check facts and enlarge his vision.

The latter was given by a chorus of 33 men and boys with an orchestra of roughly the same size, before an audience of 700 Randolph's forces include a chorus of 150 mixed voices and a chamber ensemble playing modern instruments for audiences of several thousand. He conducts two perforthhnces today in Avery Fisher Hall, at 2 P.M. and 6:30 P.M.. and third

description: HARTFORD ROBERT KELLY is a man with a missionan educational mission. Soft of voice, he is traveling the state selling an ida. And since ideas need samples just as tangible products do, his briefcase is ovorflowing.

description: In an office on the 82d floor of the World Trade Center, 150 planners pass judgment on requests for Federal money made by towns and cities as far away as New Haven, Poughkeepsie, N.Y., and Asbury Park, N. J. Before anyone in a 27county area, which includes Nassau and. Suffolk, can get a penny in special revenuesharing or community development grants from Washington, the office on the 82d floor must approve.

title: INVESTING
description: It has been a banner year for automo bile makers, those mighty engines of the American economy. Record profits are in store for the General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company. But support for the auto industry appears to be running out of gas on Wall Street.

title: Jude Bartlett's Rocky Road To Getting What He Wanted
description: Jude Bartlett is dancing this afternoon at the American Theater Laboratory. The news is scarcely enough to wean the Nutcracker devotee away from the New York State Theater or appreciably diminish the crowds cheering Alvin Ailey's Revelations at City Center. But Mr. Bartlett is the kind of anomaly that makes New York dancegoing an adventure: a small, literate and quietly independent voice from what one dance educator wearily calls the grant generation and some critics have come to think of as a blindered fraternity of loft performers.

title: Bestiality Found of Little Anpeal, Jury Acquits Movie Wholesaler
description: A jury in State Supreme Court in Manhattan last week acquitted a defendant of charges that he was a wholesaler of obscene films because it said it had found the films in question too disgusting and repulsive to appeal to the prurient interests'of average mole.

title: PEOPLE
description: In the depths of the Great Depression a retailer needed an edge to get by, and Sam Goody had one. He bought up discarded old records forwella song and sold them at a good markup to aficionados eager to fill in their collections of jazz vocals of the early 1920's and the like.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTONEver since it was disclosed in 1975 that the Government had unwittingly hired a part owner of a coal pipeline company to study the comparative costs of railway and pipeline transportation of coal, officials have been trying to prepare conflict-of-interest regulations for Federal contractors.

description: Margaret Danita Hair and Morgan C. Brown 3d. 1970 graduates of Syracuse University, were married yesterday in St. Baylon Roman Catholic Church in Hollis, Queens, by the Rev. Ernest Rudloff.

description: Spirit and determination were the dominant characteristics of top show dogs in 1977a great year for terriers. Last Ftbruary Ch. Dersade Bobby's Girl became the fourth sealyham in Westminster history to bask in the limelight of America's bestNews known dog show. Now, the English and American Ch. of Harwire Hetman of WhinDogs latter ,a wire fox, is leading among all breeds with record of 33 bests in show and 87 group trophies to date.

title: Tough Guardians Oversee Greenwich Design
description: Although it has been five years since Peter Brant tangled with the architectural review board in Greenwich, he is still smarting from the extra quarter of a million dollars he was obliged to spend as a result of that encounter.

title: The Eloquent Diplomat
description: STATESMEN rarely write memoirs that are memorable. Abba Eban, the former Israeli Foreign Minister and United Nations Ambassador, proves the exception to this cautionary rule. He has written an autobiography that makes compelling reading. Moreover, his story dramatizes the debate within the Zionist movement that has characterized the modern history of Israel. A struggleat times bitterhas raged between those who have favored the partition of Palestine that would leave a state almost exclusively made up of Jews, and others who believe that the ancient land of Palestine could be remade into the state of Israel while incorporating within its borders the Arab Palestinians. Eban's words and deeds derive from his commitment to the principle of partition; the current Israeli Prime Minister, Menachem Begin, has upheld the opposite view equally rigorously. It is within the context of those two ideas of Israel's destiny that the recent visit of Egypt's President Anwar Sadat must be seen. As a consequence, Eban's testament is not but timely.

title: Nassau Residents Over 60 Audit College Courses Free of Tuition
description: Over the last three years. a new breed of student has been attending Nassau Community College in Garden City. Unlike most of the student population, the new enrollees rarely cut class, are not interested in acquiring degrees, or pursuing careers. They do not matriculate or take exams. And they may take as many courses as they can schedule without paying any tuition.

Raskin, who is retiring this month from the New York Times after 43 years as a labor reporter, columnist and member of the editorial beard, has been awarded the first Distingui:hed.3ournalism Award of the Labor Press Council of Metropolitan New York. description: PARIS. Dec. 17After oniy three months of existence the proGovernment afternoon daily J'Informe ceased publication with today's issue.

title: This Time, Natural Gas Preparations Are Better

Schools, factories and offices across the Middle West and parts of the Northeast were closed and in some instances, gas supplies to homes were threatened. Another winter officially begins this week, but the prognosis among energy experts for gas supplies generally is optimistic. What happened in the last year reflects decisions that have had to be made as part of the developing national energy policy.

title: The Director's Story
description: TWO years hence the Museum of Modern Art in New York will observe the 50th anniversary of its founding. On November 8,1929, less than two weeks after the Wall Street crash, its first exhibition101 works by Cezanne, Gauguin, Seurat and van Gogh--opened in a rented space on the 12th floor of the Heckscher Building at 730 Fifth Avenue. At the same time. the new trustees accepted the first important v...,rk to enter the permanent collection--Iviaillol's bronze sculpture entitled Ile de France. So began one of the mighty enterprises of our culture and the greatest museum of its kind in the world.

title: Around the Nation

title: What's Doing in the DOMINICAN REPUBLIC

(The other third of the island is Haiti.) The city is one of the cleanest, greenest and most beautiful in the Caribbean.

title: FEUD IS SAID TO HURT HAWAIIAN CANDIDATES

Fast's bribery trial will elect the next Governor of Hawaii, either by convicting the Mayor and wrecking his campaign for the Democratic nomination, or by acquitting him and giving credibility to his contention that Gov. George R. Ariyoshi, also a Democrat, used his position to bring about the indictment for political reasons.

title: Wisdom Poetry
description: W HEN Stevens wrote about his Collected Poems as The Planet on the Table, he meant that a life's poetry, like a terrestrial globe, reproduces (though in a reduced scale) the whole world. The world as Nemerov knows it is revealed, prophetically, in the title of his first (1947) volume, The Image and the Law. The world comes us in images; the mind seeks a law in the heterogeneous information infiltrating the senses. A late poem shows Nemerov as a boy confronting The Book Knowledge, a luxury liner on [a] sea unfathomable of ignorance, with poetry as steady., still, and rare/ As the lighthouses now unmanneT and obsolete. These three thingsour already immeasurable knowledge of the world, our nonetheless profound ignorance of its ways. and our landmarks and beacons in th productions of consciousnessare Nemerov's constant subjects:

title: A CORRECTION
description: In an article by David Silverstone on the effect of the Freedom of Information Act on the Northeast Utilities rate hearings, a sentence describing the effect of the law should have read: The irony, therefore, is obvious: The very law that was meant to assist and protect citizens and the public Interest was used most advantageously by the private interest, for private gain at the expense of the public.

title: Rome Marchers Criticize Police
description: ROME. Dec. 17 (Reuters)Several thousand women marched through Rome tonight to protest the way demonstrators have been treated by the police. The marchers carried a large banner that said, We women say no to violence. Traffic in the center of Rome was brought to a standstill. Riot policemen stood guard put did not interve9e.

title: Anniversaries
description: Lorberhatim

title: Supporter of Nuclear Power Plant, Madeline Thompson, Dies at 53
description: MANCHESTER, N. H., Dec. 17 (UPI)Madeline Thompson, who organized New Hampshire citizens group to support the Seabrook nuclear power plant and the need for higher electric rates, died Thursday at her home after a brief illsuss She was 53 years old.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: THE CHRISTMAS TREE BOOK, by Phillip V. Snyder. (Penguin, $4.95.) How the custom of imaginatively ornamenting the evergreen as an expression of the Yuletide spirit was brought from Germany to Pennsylvania in the 18th century, took root, spread and has been flourishing across America in countless ways ever since. The story is told with good humor and several hundred old prints and photographs, maily of them in color.

title: YALE NEARS DECISION ON A NEW PRESIDENT
description: NEW HAVEN, Dec. 17Members of the Yale Corporation today began what they hoped would be the final round of deliberations to choose a new president for the university by interviewing A. Bartlett Giamatti, the director of. Yale's humanities division and a professor of English, and Thomas Ehrlich, the former dean of the Stanford University Law School and now the president of the Legal Services Corporation.

title: RULES ON DNA STUDIES VIEWED AS TOO STRICT
description: BETHESDA, Md., Dec. 17Society would have to pay a price in missed opportunity and delayed discovery for failing to do genesplicing research, scientists said at a meeting here.

title: One Woman's Educational Odyssey
description: Idon't like to be late, Dr. Leona Seldow said. In fact, in the 18 years since shefirst came to Hofstra University as an assistant professor in the School of Business, she had been late only once, because of a snowstorm.

description: Saturday, December 17. 87th night. Weather cloudy, track fast.

description: Nancy Elisabeth Fernald and Kenyon Bagby Hodge will be married in February.

title: Many Public Pension Plans Need Help Badly
description: WASHINGTONA simple fact about the Social Security bill passed by Congress last week highlights a characteristic of public pension plans in the United States that is becoming increasingly, and uncomfortably, evident.

title: J. DESMOND SULLIVAN
description: MYRTLE BEACH, S. C., Dec. 17 (AP)J. Desmond ( Des) Sullivan, 64 years old, a sixtime winner of the National Golf Writers Association championship, died today at his home here after a long illness, Mr. Sullivan was a sportswriter for the nowdefunct Newark (N.J.) Evening News for 25 years before retiring nine years ago and moving to Myrtle Beach.

title: Food
description: Christmas is celebrated in almost every country of the world. But while the spirit and meaning of the occasion are the same everywhere, the ways of celebrating it vary tremendously from culture to culture. Nowhere is this more obvious than in the food served at Christmas dinner. Every country. it seems, develops its holiday specialties by using favorite, and easily available. ingredients a festive manner, with symbolic touches of the past.

title: SHOP TALK
description: HOLIDAYS bring out the flamboyant in foods, as in other areas of giftgiving. For example, to have a gourmet eating out of your hand, so to speak, Bloomingdale's, whose New Jersey outlets are in Hackensack and Short Hills, suggests a whole side of Irish smoked salmon.

title: S. L. A. Marshal,77,Dies in Texas
description: Associated Press

title: Sometimes Stardom Runs in the Family
description: Just imagine if Judy Garland had soured on showbiz and decided to concentrate her formidable energy on shorthand and typing. Is it conceivable that her equally dynamic daughter Liza Minnelli would have won an Oscar for Cabaret without the inspiration of the Garland legend? And what if Henry Fonda had prospered as a professor of English Lit. instead of spending his days inside the shells of Tom Joad, Mister Roberts and Clarence Darrow? Would Jane have done her father proud, anyway, by walking off with an Academy Award fnr Klute?)

title: Miss Angermueller Wed to Edwin Knetzger 3d
description: In St. Teresa's Roman Catholic Church in Summit, N. J., yesterday afternoon, Katherine Louise Angermueller, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hans Angermueller of Summit, became the bride of Edwin Leonard Knetzger 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Knetzger Jr. of Bryn Mawr, Pa. The Rev. John P. McGovern performed the ceremony.

title: Capt. Hawley MacDermid, at 75, Served As Grace Line's Shipmaster
description: Capt. Hawley MacDermid, who retired in 1968 after 38 years as a shipmaster for the Grace Line, died Wednesday at St. Joseph's Hospital in Elmira, N. Y. He was 75 years old and lived in Glenora, near Dundee, N. Y.

title: The Importance of Being Arthur
description: Never before in human history has so much printer's ink been spilled over the future of an economist as has been devoted to the discussion of the reappointment of Arthur F. Burns. I add to this flood only in the belief that the discussion so far has been deficient in important respects.

title: Robert GuillaumeThe Wise- Cracking Butler of Soap
description: LOS ANGELES When Robert Guillaume was a young man driving a streetcar in St. Louis along the same track where Judy Garland sang The Trolley Song in Meet me in St. Louis, he sang, toobut with different results.

title: Fashion
description: In New York, the butler at a private dinner party tried to turn away designer Calvin Klein because he was not wearing proper black tie he was wearing a velvet jacket, silk shirt and gray flannel trousers. In London, Bianca Jagger is making the scene dressed like Scarlett O'Hara in white tulle, chiffon and lace and chic young people while away the night at the Club Zanzibar dressed sophisticated punk  skintight pants, stilettoheeled pumps and black eye makeup. In Paris, everyone is out of their Saint Laurent uniforms (luxurious peasant costume) and into looking individual  mixing old and new. In Palm Beach, a lot of real jewelry is still seen  because we know we're protected and won't be photographed, says Palm Beach regular, Jean Tailor. In Beverly Hills, the land of valet parking and private tennis courts, women are, dressing to the teeth (or private parties and restaurants, according to socialite Betsy Bloomingdale. And in Washington, they're wearing last year's clothes, comments Nancy Dickerson, the sharpeyed journalist. Evening pants are in in Palm Beach and on the way out in New York. Jeans are definitely out in Beverly Hills and Paris, still in in London, and 0.K  though less and less  in Rome. Boots are seldom seen at night  instead, highheeled sandals with sexy, sheer stockings. The pretty, little swinging shoulder hag is de rigueur. Costume jewelry waning, the real thing, discreetly worn, is coming back into favor. (In New York, women say they don't wear much of the real stuff, but, in fact they are beginning

title: Linna Barnes Bride Of Christian Mixter
description: Linna May Barnes and Christian John Mixter, lawyers who live in Brooklyn, were married there yesterday. The Rev. Franklin E. Vitas Jr. performed Ole ceremony in St. Ann and the Holy Trinity Episcopal Church.

title: President Expected to Focus on Economy
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17  President Carter is preparing a master agenda for action in 1978 that is meant to allocate his time and political attention carefully and is considering a major shift in ,economic policy that would use tax incentives as a weapon against inflation, according to senior White House advistrs. Stuart E. Eizenstat, who is Mr. Carter's principal domestic policy adviser, said that the Administration was looking with interest at a proposal by Arthur M. Okun, the economist, that would give tax advantages to companies and unions that voluntarily agree to restrain price and wage increases.

title: Soviet Proposal Snags Indian Ocean Talks With U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17Negotiations on regulating naval forces in the Indian Ocean have hit a snag over a Soviet proposal to reduce the size of fleets there, according to officials here.

title: McGuire a Big Winner With Tears in His Eyes
description: Al McGuire, the ultimate showman, part hustler and part philosopher, ended a 20year headcoaching career winning the National Collegiate Athletic Association championship at Marquette. But the man of many moods and con LrauxCollege tions was not on the Omni floor in Atlanta at the Basketball end as Marquette upset North Caro lina, 6759. Instead, McGuire paced the dressing  room with a towel to his eyes. He was crying,

title: Prosperous Kansas Town Takes The Farmers
description: HAYS, Kan.. Dec. 17In a shopping mall in this town of 16,000 people in the heart of the Kansas wheat and cattle country toe other thy, tarmers clustered in their pickup trucks, with the antennas of their C.B. radios whipping about in a fierce wind.

title: Music in Review
description: Good reports about Maria Chiara have come from European opera houses over the last several years, and now America is having an opportunity to see the soprano in person. Last month she made her United States debut in Chicago as Manon Lescaut. and on Friday night she appeared at the Metropolitan for the first time in La Traviata.

title: Kibbee Plans to Tighten the City University's Control of SEEK Program and to Raise Its Standards
description: Chancellor Robert J. Kibbee is preparing sweeping changes in the structure of the City University's SEEK program that would impose more stringent academic requirements and tighter fiscal controls.

title: Lucy Aldrich Hornans Married To Hugh F. Bangasser, Lawyer
description: Lucy Aldrich }romans, who is studying for a doctorate in education at Columbia University, was married yesterday in San Mateo, Calif., to Hugh Frederick Bangasser, a lawyer with the Federal Trade Commission in Washington. The Rev. Lesley Wilder performed the ceremony in the Episcopal Church of St. Matthew. A reception was held at the Burlingame Country Club.

title: Princess Grace Makes a Movie but It's No Comeback
description: Princess Grace of Monaco, who for years has vowed she would never make another movie, has made another movie. Sort of.

title: Births
description: Rakofshy

title: W. H. Lammers Jr., N.Y.U. Aide, Weds Mrs. Frothingham
description: Elizabeth Mason Frothingham, daughter of Mrs. Howard McConnell Donald son of Chicago and Sanibel Island, Fla., and the late Theodore Frothingham of Yarmouthport, Mass., was married last night to William Henry Lammers Jr., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Lammers of Katonah. N. Y.

title: SOARING URBAN CRIME TROUBLING SPANIARDS
description: MADRID, Dec. 17Cathedrals in Oviedo and Murcia are robbed of precious treasures. Muggers and thieves multiply their depredations. Illegal gamblers operate openly on Barcelona's gracious Rambles. Convicts riot and burn their prisons, and a leftwing senator, himself a priest, says they should all get a.nnesty. Pornography floods the newsstands. -

title: New Candidates for the Traveler's Bookshelf
description: How to define a travel book? The Travel Section chooses to dodge the issue. Travel books, for our money, can be anything from Fodor's South, 19771978 to Diary of My Travels in America, by LouisPhilippe, King of France from 1830 to 1848both after all cover some of the same ground, albeit with rather different intent and from considerably different points of view. In short, anything from guidebooks to coffeetable books will be fair aame.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: MYis Marian, and I'm a basketballaholic. Silence from an audience of faceless people seated in endless rows of folding chairs as I stand before them at a lectern, suffering unmercifully.

title: Lindsay Moves Viewed as Bids For Comeback
description: Time heals all wounds. and John V. Lindsay. who left City Hall as one of the most unpopular politicians in recent memory and still, three years later, registers badly in polls, appears to be testing the truth of that bit of folk wisdom. Many politicians are convinced that, the former Mayor, who is 56 years old, is trying to start a political comebackpossibly pointing to the United States Senate in 1980 when Senator Jacob K. Javits's term expires. At the very least, some Lindsay friends said, the former Mayor wants to rehabilitate his record and reputation.

title: KOCH URGED TO PRESS CHANGE IN WELFARE
description: A major change in the system of welfare grants that could increase costs for! the city, state and Federal Governments or wind up reducing help for some clients has been put to Mayorelect Edward I. 1 Koch by the outgoing Beanie administration as a pending issue for early decision.

title: Panel Told of Problems on Insanity Pleas in Courts
description: Problems concerning the custody and treatment of defendants judged mentally incompetent to stand trial and those committed to state hospitals after being acquitted of serious crimes by reason of insanity were aired last week at a public hearing held by the State Senate Committee on Mental Hygiene and Addiction Control.

title: Mideast Gains Could Affect Israel's Requests for Arms
description: Defense Department officials are speculating on whether the prospects for an IsraeliEgyptian settlement will lead to a reduction in Israel's latest request for American arms amounting to $1.5 billion annually over the next 10 years.

title: Whither Waste, If Not in Landfill?
description: IS the demise of landfill imminent, or has it merely been postponed? That question is on the minds of the Island's planners and local officials following the state's recent decision to cancel Oyster Bay Town's proposed landfill because of its environmental unsoundness.

title: Hopes Rise for East Orange
description: EAST ORANGE

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: The executive ladder with the weakest rungs has traditionally been found in the commodity departments of Wall Street brokerage houses. For one thing, the houses prefer to emphasize their investment image and play down the very speculative commodity trade. For another, poorly managed commodity departments have led many a brokerage house to go belly up over the years.

title: Yale Hospital Aide Gets Maine Post
description: BRUNSWICK, Me., Dec. 16 (AP)Herbort Paris, 43 years old, the associate director of the YaleNew Haven Hospital, has been named administrator of the Regional Memorial Hospital here. The appointment was announced today by the hospital's board of trustees. Mr. Paris, a graduate of Brandeis University, has a master of hospital administration degree from the Medical College of Virginia. He will assume his new duties in Februa ry.

title: The Government Puts a Damper on the Scanner Bonanza
description: CHICAGOHailed by medical authorities as a revolutionary advance in diagnostic science, the CT scanner was greeted with somewhat less disinterested joy by the medicalequipment industry when the computerized Xray device first made its appearance five years ago.

title: FollowUp on the News
description: With shock, the Public Library in Rudd, Iowa, learned last September that its small building, erected for S16,000 in 1967, did not comply with the law. There was no ramp for people in wheelchairs, as called for by Federal regulations. Under a state code, the library's two lavatories were not properly proportioned.

title: Koch Faces Limits on Economic Push
description: Mayorelect Koch has a couple of things going for him as he begins to address New York's most pressing troublethe continuing shrinkage of an economy that is already too weak to support city government in the fashion to which it had become accustomed.

title: LABOR UNIT TO DELAY TAYLOR LAW ACTION
description: The New York State Public Employment Relations Board has decided to delay a move to set aside New York City's Collective Bargaining Law, pending possible action by the Legislature to eliminate differences in the application of penalties for illegal strikes under the state's Taylor Law.

title: I Hope to Be Going On With Sam Beckett And He With Me
description: On my 50th birthday, as I vaguely remember, I had three Broadway plays running at the same time, two by Robert Anderson and one by Harold Pinter. At 60, just to make things more bearable, I've got three by Samuel Beckett opening Off Broadway at the Manhattan Theater Club, where Play and Other Plays starts performances on Wednesday.

title: Leona Mitchell Puts Fire Into La Boheme
description: The performance of Puccini's La Boheme. given by the Metropolitan Opera on Thursday night went smoothly and affectingly, and one of the reasons did was that Leona Mitchell, taking the part of Musetta for the first time with the company, sang and acted convincingly.

title: The Crowded World Of Urban Supermarkets
description: Supermarket shopping in the city can be much like riding bumper cars at an amusement park. A shopper drives a cart into your back; bulky columns, stray carts and slowmoving shoppers tie up traffic; while rounding the bend for the next aisle, you collide headon with a person wheeling a cart in the opposite direction. Urban supermarkets, leave little room for comfortor much else besides stacks of merchandise.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: The Nutcracker celebrates its 85th birthday this weekend with some 150 different productions in the United States alone: Not bad for a ballet they said wouldn't last. Actually, it didn't last. Despite its phenomenal popularity in the past 20 years, The Nutcracker on view today is not the same work that had its premiere at the Maryinsky Theater in St. Petersburg. Unlike Tchaikovsky's two

title: Jessica Tuchman Colin Mathews Planning to Be Wed on Feb. 25
description: Jessica Tuchman, section chief for Global Affairs in the National Security Council, and Colin Mathews, a lawyer in the General Counsel's office of the Department of Energy, plan to be married at the Cosmopolitan Club in New York on Feb. 25.

description: Toning Prints Serves More Than One Purpose

title: Clean Dirty Tricks
description: THE halo that J. Edgar Hoover hung like an ax over the crewcut choirboys of his F.B.I. now sits at a jauntier angle. Indeed, in the harsh light of postWatergate Washington it is sometimes hard to see at all, which may well prove a blessing the Feebies are free at last to peel off their Dacron jackets and mix it in the gutter with organized crime.

title: Wiring Apparently Caused Fire
description: BAY CITY, Mich., Dec. 17 (AP)A shortcircuit in a light fixture, not arson, apparently caused an apartmenthouse fire a week ago that killed nine persons land injured more than 60. Sgt. Richard i Hofmann, a state police detective, said yesterday that a preliminary investiga tion showed that copper wires in a corridor fixture at the Wenanah Park Building, an apartmenthotel, had melted, apparently starting the blaze.

title: Net Result: The Youth Was Served
description: A new generation of American tennis stars burst onto center court this year tin the persons of 14-year-old Tracy Austin and 18-year-old John McEnroe. While old favorites claimed the year's major titlesVirginia Wade of England and Bjorn Borg of Sweden succeeding at WimTennis bledon and Chris Evert and Guilliermo Vitas of Argentira, clay court specialists, at the United States Open---Miss Austin and McEnrne made their marks.

title: Debating the Force: Carter and Congress
description: The 95th Congress concluded it first session last week after almost a year of wrangling. At best, its relationship with the new man in the White House was uneasy. To assess the performance of President Carter and Congress, The Week in Review invited two Congressional leaders for a discussion  Alan Cranston, the Senate Democratic whip from California, and Representative John B. Anderson of Illinois, chairman of the House Republican Conference. They were interviewed by Adam Clymer, who writes on Congress for ThE: New York Times, and Clyde Haberman, an editor on The Review. description: MINLOLA, L.I., Dec. 17The Nassau County Planning Commission recommended last week the building =f multifamily lousing units in the 900acre Roosevelt Field shopping area as one of the major alternates for the future development of the field.

description: NEWARK, Dec. 16 (AP)  Newark International Airport announced yesterday that charter flights to Italy would he departing from Newark starting next spring. The Trans World Airline flights to Rome and Sicily will start at $369, airport officials said.

description: HARTFORD

title: Islanders Are Aggressive In Beating Bruins, 4 to
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Dec. 17The Boston Bruins don't get no respect from Patrick Division clubs. After running up a 17game unbeaten streak, the Adams Division leaders lost to the Philadelphia Flyers. 64, last night and 41 to the New York Islanders tonight.

title: GARDENING
description: EVEN before New Jerseyans get their Christmas trees set up, winter will be upon us. According to the Farmer's Almanac, it will arrive officially in time for dinner on Wednesday. At 6:24 P.M., to be exact.

title: Canadiens Dominate Like No Others
description: Surprise! Neither the. Soviet Union nor Canada won the world amateur championship. which was held in Vienna. Czechoslovakia did, with Sweden second. In what was no surprise, how.. ever, the Montreal Canadiens ran away with the National Hockey Hocke League champion.. Hockey ship, while the nearly consummated merger between the N.H.L. and the World Hockey Association fell through at the last moment.

title: CHESS
description: How do you beat an extraordinarily gifted, ultrasolid positional player who never takes risks and who has the slipperiest defensive technique going? Of course, I mean the current world champion, 26yearold Anatoly Karpov of the Soviet Union.

title: HIGHLIGHTS
description: The Japanese came to Washington bearing gifts of trade concessions last week. But, when the package was unwrapped, American officials promptly termed it unsatisfactory.

title: Drought and Graft Causing Hunger in Ghana;
description: ACCRA, GhanaAfter three consecutive years of drought, food supplies are at a critically low level in northern Ghana and international relief programs are being hampered by inefficiency and corruption.

title: Bayside Easily Takes P.S.A.L. Swim Crown
description: Bayside High School swimmers won six of the 10 events as the Commodores easily captured their sixth straight Public Schools Athletic League individualmeet title yesterday at Brooklyn College. Bayside totaled 122 points to outdistante Bronx Science.

title: DINING OUT
description: THE Essex County suburbs came into their own in the second decade of the century, when the suburban lines of the defunct Delaware, Lackawanna & Western Railroad, now part of Conrail, made comfortable commuting a reality. In the years between World War I and the Depression, Montclair and the Oranges were among the most desirable communities in the nation in which to live.

title: The Nation
description: In Texas, striking farmers set up blockades to delay food shipments. In Georgia, one group cut the air hoses of a feed truck and another stopped a train. From the Deep South to the High Plains, stores and schools last week were closed in sympathy as tractordriving farmers held parades and rallies.

description: FICTION

title: Clark Bullock, Miss de Roulet Are Betrothed
description: Announcement has been made by Mrs. Vincent de Roulet of Manhasset, LI., of the engagement of her daughter, Whitney de Roulet, to Clark Lewis Bullock of New York and Los Angeles, son of Mrs. Jack Whitfield of Marcellus, N.Y., and Clarence Bullock of Beaver. Pa.

title: Women Athletes Help to Educate A Male Coach
description: In a recent article on this page, Patsy Neal discussed the problems facing women coaches. What about the unsuspecting male coach who enters the realm of women's sports?

title: Nutrition a Goal
description: Montclair CHILDREN in daycare centers in northern New Jersey may soon be getting better meals as well as a head start in good nutrition habits, thanks to a new program initiated this fall by Montclair State College's Life Skills Center.

title: Libbe Lipkin Is Betrothed
description: Dr. and Mrs. Lewis E. Lipkin of Bethesda, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Libbe Lipkin, to Steven Englander, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Englander of Montreal. The wedding will take place on Jan. 1 in Orange, Conn.

title: Pity the Sneaker: Its Era Is Ended
description: Last week, while walking past a specialty sporting goods store in Manhattanappropriately named The Athlete's FootI noticed several types of footwear. The window display included shoes for jogging, tennis, running, soccer, track, walking, bowling, hiking, basketball, handball, baseball, skateboarding and Astroturf.

title: Eyeing Red Giants and White Dwarfs From Brookville
description: BROOKVILLE, L.I.When he walked Into the meeting of the Astronomical Society of Long Island here, the visitor thought he already knew something about stars. And as he listened to Dr. Judy Cohen. an astronomer who had flown in from Arizona to address the meeting in a borrowed C. W. Post lecture amphitheater, he heard some familiar terms and names.

title: 2,071 New Gremlins Recalled
description: DETROIT, Dec. 17 (AP)The American Motors Corporation has said that it is voluntarily recalling 2,071 new Gremlins for inspection of a possible defect that could cause a short circuit. The potential problem on 1978 models with four-cylinder engines and fourspeed manual transmissions exists between the clutch linkage and the instrument panel wiring, A.M.C. said yesterday.

title: U.S. Joins Preservationists
description: WASHINGTON; Dec, 17  In a decision that could lead In more effective preservation of historic sites elsewhere, Interior Secftetary Cecil D. Andrus has moved to makp the Federal Government a legal partner of landowners who are fighting stripmining interests in the Green Springs area of Virginia,

title: North Korea Names a New Cabinet
description: TOKYO, Dec. 17 (AP)North Korea has accelerated efforts to bolster its economy, announcing far  reaching changes in the Cabinet.

title: Modern Mastery on View in Nassau
description: ROSLYN

title: All in the Family
description: NINETEEN SEVENTYSEVEN may well go down as the Year of the Family. It began with the inauguration of a new President who had campaigned strenuously on behalf of domestic values, and who promptly directed his own staff to spend less time on the job and more at home with spouses and children. Commissions, task forces and advisory groups on family life sprouted across the land. Readers of this newspaper, among many others, were treated to lengthy feature articles on the current crisis and future perils of the family. As the year ends, the signs of concern are everywhere, and they do not seem about to go away.

title: Redskins Win, Keeping Playoff Hope Alive
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17Pro football produced another wild scene today at Robert F. Kennedy Stadium when the Washington Redskins persevered in the final seconds and defeated the Los Angeles Rams, 1714, thus preserving their chances to qualify for the National Football League's postseason playoffs.

title: DIRECTOR'S RESIGNING ACCEPTED BY A.S.P.CA
description: Duncan Wright's resignation as executive director of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals was accepted last Thursday night with regret by its board of managers, fold lowing a wrangle over his criticism of the society's operating procedures and lack of leadership.

title: A Sentimental Salute to Al Cohn
description: Jack Xlcinsinger's Salute to Al Cohn on Thursday evening at New York University's Loeb Student Center auditorium was, as these tributes are apt to be. a sentimental affair. Colltagucs of Mr Cohn's in the Woody Herman Band of 1948 Played for himMarky Markowitz, the trumpeter: Jimmy Raney. the guitarist, who flew in from Kentucky for the occasion. and Zoot Sims, the saxophonist. His wife, Flo, sang I'm in Love With You, Honey. and Elliot Lawrence, in whose band Mr. Cohn once played presented him with a Highlights in Jazz plaque.

title: Aged Talk Up the Past
description: NEW ROCHELLE

title: Lively Yanks Are No. 1 in Lively Season
description: In the year of the lively ball, the free agent, the nocut contract, the resurrected Yankees and the traded Tom Seaver, more baseball players hit more home runs, jumped more teams and made more money than ever be- fore. There were more players because Toronto and Baseball Seattle joined the American League, making the total 650 men on 26 teams in the two bigger big leagues. There were more home runs because the new cowhide balls were juiced up to provide more carry, and they did: 2,013 homers were hit in the American League and 1,631 in the National for a record total of 3,644.

title: Linda Frank Fiancee of Lawrence B. Rodman
description: Linda L. Frank, a manpower-development associate with the Exxon International Company in New York, plans to be married in June to Lawrence B. Rodman, an associate with the New York law firm of Cleary, Gottlieb, Steen & Hamilton

title: Jane Schwartz Is Engaged To Jeffrey Hofman Kramer
description: Dr. and Mrs. Abraham Schwartz of Providence, R. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jane Paula Schwartz, to Jeffrey Hofman Kramer, son or Dr. and Mrs. Albert S. Kramer of Huntington, L. I. The weding it nlanned fur July.

title: 3 Named to Elections Board
description: Governor Carey last week appointed Remo J. Acito of Chappaqua to a 16month term as head of the State Board of Elections. Mr. Acito. 50 years old, was appointed to the board in July. The Governor also appointed Stephen May of Rochester and Donald Rettaliata of Bayport to the bipartisan board. The posts carry salaries of $25,000. The appointments are based on the recommendations of state chairman and legislative leaders of the two major political parties.

title: Blind Are Trained
description: NEWARK

title: Dave Anderson
description: The headlines fade into history. But behind the headlines are the subtle scenes. And in 1977, as in every year, those are the memories that remain.

title: CRIME
description: Brad Solomon's THE GONE MAN (Random House, $7.95) is a first novel. It is about a private eye in Los Angeles, and there are things one can say about the obvious derivations. Solomon has patterned his man, Charlie Quinlan, very much after Ross Macdonald's Lew Archer, and the writing is very much in the Macdonald vein. Virtually every privateeye clich is present. Quinlan is independent, honest, a bit mixed up emotionally, uses the wisecrack and the smartaleck remark as a defense mechanism. He also. represents Truth in a murky world, and there too he is Archeresque. There's a lot of L-- in this world. I don't want to add to it. And, I want to be able to look back at things and say to myself I did the best I

title: FACES PASSED
description: The stout man walked toward me along Sixth Avenue. his big face as red on that cold December day as if he'd fallen asleep on a beach in July. Blood pressure, I thought, wondering where my own was. Booze, I thought, too, calculating the number of drinks he might have had with lunch. Three or four. figured, quite possibly martinis, my own mourned favorite. He looked, in his tweed jacket with his neck flaming out of the blue buttondown collar, like men I remembered drinking and laughing with my father on smoky Saturday afternoons at Princeton in the 1930's. They would all joke and playfully crunch great camel's hair shoulders into each other as we shuffled downhill along leafstrewn sidewalks toward football game.

title: Mitchell Korn Fuses the East And Western Idiom on Guitar

On the other hand, the integration of nonWestern instruments and musical ideas into Western idioms poses daunting challenges.

title: Dave Anderson
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N. J., Dec. 18In snow and sleet, it was a day for a polar bear, not a dancing bear. And with only 42 seconds remaining in a suddendeath overtime period, the polar bear, Larry Csonka, apparently had provided the Giants with a 99 tie that would eliminate the Chicago Bears from the National Football League playoffs. But then the dancing bear, Walter Payton, his opportunity to break O. J. Simpson's season rushing record of 2,003 yards having slipped away on the slushslick Astro- turf of Giants Stadium, did his act. With the Bears in a first-and-10 situation the Giants 25yard line, Walter Payton took a short pass from Bob Avellini and stutterstepped past Larry Mallory, the Giants free safety, for a 14yard gain to the Giants 11yard line. Moments later Bob Thomas, unable to make the most of the previous opportunities in the overtime, kicked a 28yard field goal for the 129 triumph that qualified the Bears for the playoffs as the N.F.C.s wildcard team. But the Bears will oppose the Cowboys in Dallas next Monday because their dancing bear, Walter Payton, finally danced.

title: Why Are Farmers Striking?

title: De Gustibus: Healthy Serving of Culinary Word Soup
description: Although we made a solemn vow not to pursue the subject of tandoor (the Indian word for oven), one feels obliged to give forum to Solomon Feffer, chairman of the department of Hebraic studies at Rutgers University in Newark. If De Gustibus goes in for etymology, Jet's give credit where credit is due. Tandoor (or tandour or tendour) is originally an Akkadian word, tinuru. In the form of tannur it makes its appearance in the Bible, where it is used 15 times. In a form similar to the Hebrew, it is also found in Aramaic, Persian and Turkish. In all cases it means a portable stove or fire pot.

title: 'Greatest Lover,' Great Comedy
description: There's a scene in "A Boy Named Charlie Brown," the 1969 feature film based on the Peanuts characters, in which Lucy Linus and Charlie Brown are lying on their backs, freely associating as they watch the clouds roll by, Charlie Brown sees horsies and duckies in the clouds. Linus can make out the stoning of St. Stephen "and, down in one corner, the profile of Thomas Eakins, the 19th-century American portrait painter." Lucy, though she's as much at ease as she ever manages to be, is reminded only of wads of cotton. One feels sorry for poor Lucy, her appreciation of fantasy severely limited by an awareness that she is life's umpire.A comedy like Gene Wilder's "The World's Greatest Lover" is not for the Lucies of this world. Rather it's for people whose spirits more or less match those of Mr. Wilder, an imaginative fellow who tries to control his madness and, when he fails, comes forth with a movie. First there was "Sherlock Holmes's Smarter Brother" and now "The World's Greatest Lover"movies in what may be described as the "melbrooks" manner in honor of Mr. Wilder's occasional collaborator and the director of his funniest performance (in "Young Frankenstein").Watching "The World's Greatest Lover" is about as cheerful and satisfying a substitute for cloud-watching as I can imagine. It's also frequently side-splitting and, when it's not causing physical damage, so full of intelligent associations that it would hold the attention of someone with interests as varied as those of Linus."The World's Greatest Lover" was produced, written and directed by Mr. Wilder, who also plays the title role, that of an ambitious but desperately neurotic Milwaukee baker who, in 1926, sets out to become the new Rudolph Valentino.Rudy Valentine is not at first glanceor second or even thirda likely prospect. His face looks like a coconut on which someone has drawn a pair of blue eyes and pasted a Harpo wig. Then, too, in moments of stress he's inclined to invert the words of a sentence or, worse, to stick out his tongue, a gesture that's misunderstood in public places.Though Rudy is maniacally ambitious, he's very insecure a failing that is not helped by his sweet but equally nutty wife Annie (Carol Kane), who writes mash notes to the real Rudolph Valentino, or by the sort of people he meets on the road to the top. These include a classically crazy hotel manager (Fritz Feld), a hyperventilating Hollywood studio chief (Dom De Luise), and assorted, mostly anonymous lunatics who would give fatal pause to anyone less self-absorbed than Rudy.In an end credit card, Mr. Wilder thanks Federico Fellini for his encouragement in making "The World's Greatest Lover," thus acknowledging the inspiration he received from Fellini's 1950 comedy, "The White Sheik," which is also about naifs and the magic world of moviemaking, though an entirely different kind of film from the one that Mr. Wilder has made. Fellini's characters are rooted in a recognizable place and time. Mr. Wilder's live in the marvelous cloud-cuckooland of movie comedy where characters are defined by the routines and gags they survive."The World's Greatest Lover" has a story line, meaning that it makes narrative sense, but it moves forward through more or less accidental set-pieces, such as a hilarious sequence on the train carrying Rudy and Annie to Hollywood when Rudy, through no real fault of his own finds himself feigning passion for an old man in a blanket.Do Rudy and Annie love each other? Their private lives are completely spelled out in another sequence in which Rudy attempts to teach Annie how to make love with the help of a manual called "Sex by the Numbers": "Are we doing 3?" asks Annie. "You're doing 3," says Rudy, "I'm doing 8."For a comedy of this kind, "The World's Greatest Lover" is uncommonly handsome, the period sets and costumes having a lot of the fantasy quality of a stylish Broadway musical. There are also moments when the film's action seems to have been choreographed, which suggests the flow of a musical as well as the movements of old-time slapstick farce. Thus even when one isn't laughing, one is beguiled.Like Mel Brooks, Mr. Wilder always surrounds himself with fine actors. Dom De Luise and certainly the venerable Fritz Feld are known quantities, as is Ronny Graham, who is splendidly funny as a harried movie director. Miss Kane, though, is something of a revelation as a comedianwhether she is being stubborn, dim, sexy, plain or, sometimes, very, very beautiful."The World's Greatest Lover," which has been rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"), contains some suggestive material that is less offensive than the copy on most perfume ads.

title: Harvey Carter, 80, Government Aide In Petroleum Administration in War
description: Harvey D. Carter, a retired petroleum consultant who was the director of the supply division of the Petroleum Administration for War, during World War II, died Saturday at his home in Williamstown, Mass. He was 80 years old and a former resident of Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Kelly, Nason Plans Univas Partnership
description: Kelly, Nason, a United States agency with about $70 million in billings, and Univas, an international agency with about $230 million, have agreed in principle to enter into a partnership. A spokesman for the American company said that there would be a sharing of equity.

title: STUDY OF BORROWING IN TAXFREE SECTOR CITES SERIOUS GAPS
description: A study of recent bond offerings by 55 municipalities around the country has described their accounting and disclosure practices as woefully deficient, falling far short of voluntary guidelines suggested by an association of local government financial offices:

title: Around the Nation
description: DETROIT, Dec. IS (AP)When an unguarded, S9 million securities shipment was reported missing today, the Federal Bureau of Investigation mobilized in New York, Detroit and Chicago to investigate what sounded like a spectacular airport robbery but turned out to he a case of misplaced baggage.

title: African Empire Asks Inquiry
description: PARIS, Dec 18 (AP)The Central African Empire has invited the United states Congress to send a delegation to Bangui, the empire's capital, to learn the real state of affairs there, the Bangui radio said. The United States has suspended aid to the empire because of alleged human rights violations.

title: Yale Pact Ratified By Service Workers
description: NEW HAVEN, Dec. 18  Service workers at Yale University overwhelmingly ratified a threer year contract here today and prepared to return to their jobs on Wednesday, ending a two-anda-half-month strike that had closed most university dining halls and forced students to clean their own halls and bathrooms.

title: Rangers Win, 62
description: If ever someone needed a hat it was Ron Duguay, the 20-year-old Ranger rookie center with the buckprivate haircut, courtesy of his teammates. And last night, thanks to the rainy Weather. there %%TIT hats galore in Madison Square Garden to be tossed to the ire when Duguay scored three goals in New York's thumping ti2 victory Over the Detroit Red Wings.

title: E. G. Hawkins, Presbyterian Leader
description: The Rev. Dr. Elder G. Hawkins, the pastor of the St. Augustine Presbyterian Church in the Bronx from 1938 to 1970 and a former moderator of the General Assembly of the United Presbyterian Church, died yesterday in Princeton (N.J.) Medical Center. Since his retirement he lived in Princeton, at 226 Ross Stevenson Circle, and taught practical theology and black history at Princeton Theological Seminary. He was 69 years old.

title: Youth, 14, Shot on Hunting Trip
description: BULLHEAD CITY, Ariz., Dec. 18 (UPI) A Needles, Calif., youth who was accidentally shot in the head while hiding under a camouflage tarp on a duck hunting trip died yesterday, the authorities said. They said that Jimmy Wilson, 14 years old, was shot by Edward Puryer, 48, a farm worker, who, thinking that the victim's duck decoys were real ducks, fired several shots, one of which hit the youth. Mr. Puryer was arrested on a charge of involuntary manslaughter.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Gaming Chips Flow From Wine Area
description: BEAUNE FranceWhen visitors come to this little city, the capital of the Burgundy wine region, to see Daniel Senard, it is usually not to see his vineyards. This is a pity, because he has some beautiful vineyards. They stretch down the hill from his home in the picturebook village of Aloxe-Corton. a mile or so north of here.

title: CarDamage Inspection Program For Insurance Claims Is Assailed
description: A new program in New York State reqUiring visual inspection and photographs of automobiles for which propertydamage insurance is sought is causing controversy within the insurance industry and among car owners.

title: Son of Cypriot President Is Given a Hero's Welcome
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Dec. IR (Reuters)The kidnapped son of President Spyros Kyprianou was released unharmed early today and returned home to a hero's welcome after more than three days as the hostage of guerrillas seeking the release of failed comrades.

title: MANY CRUISE SHIPS FAIL HEALTH TESTS
description: Three days after she failed a Federal public health inspection for the sixth t:me in the past year, the Dutch cruise ship Statendam sailed out of Miami Dec. 2 for a 10day Caribbean cruise. Aboard were 671 passengers and a crew of 372.

title: The Editorial Notebook
description: The esthetic controversy of the Christmas season seems to be the red, white and green lighting of the Empire State Building. Because every New Yorker believes that he or she personally owns or is responsible for that enduring symbol of the city, feelings are running high. An informal and perfectly useless poll finds opinion divided between people who love the lighting and people who hate it, with a surprising absence of don't knows.

title: MRS. CARTER DISCUSSES ERRORS IN WHITE HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP)Rosalynn Carter said today that she and the President had each made an important mistake this year, he by not consulting in the very beginning with Congress as much as he could have, and she by not campaigning harder for the equal rights amendment.

title: WheelingPittsburgh Plans to Lift Prices of Sheet Steel by 7% on Jan.
description: The WheelingPittsburgh Steel Corporation, the ninthlargest steelmaker in the nation, announced yesterday that would raise its prices for basic sheet Products by 7 percent on Jan. 3.

title: Curbs on Medicaid Abortions Posing Perils and Problems for the Poor
description: ENGLEWOOD, N.J.Laura Green is a large woman, tall and bigboned. At 18 weeks into her pregnancy, she was downright bulky. She shifted in the narrow chair, searching for a comfortable spot. Then she leaned back, settled in and began to tell about being pregnant and on welfare and wanting an abortion in New Jersey, a state where almost all Medicaid funds for abortion have been cut off.

title: Queens Road Project to Begin
description: Work is scheduled to begin this week on rebuilding 20th Avenue, a major artery in the College Point Industrial Park, Donald R. Manes, the Queens Borough President said yesterday. The work will be done by the Mascali Construction Company of Flushing, under a $2,261,000 contract. The new construction will expand the width of the roadway from 20 feet to 74 feet.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: BACK IN THE GROOVE Jazz buffs will be happy to know that the downtown Village Gate (9245026), with its continuously expanding entertainments, again will be harboring cool sounds on Mondays, starting tonight. Concerts by the Billy Harper Sextet will be given at 8 and 10:30. Tickets are $3.50.

title: All Those Cans of Beer on the Wall-- Empty
description: Youngsters, who now outnumber oldsters in the ranks of beer can collectors, want nothing more in the world these days than an empty can of Billy Beer, the new brew endorsed by First Brother Billy Carter.

title: Bangladesh Leader Visits Nepal
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, Dec. 18 (Reuters) President Ziaur Rahman of Bangladesh flew to Nepal today for the first stop of a sixday trip that includes visits to India and Pakistan. The President said the tour had been organized despite pressing engagements at home, adding: This shows that we are sincerely trying to establish good brotherly relations with our neighboring countries.

title: James E. Diamond, a Designer, at 91
description: James E. Diamond, the designer and manufacturer of the gravity fuel pump that enabled seaplanes to fly greatly increased distances, died Saturday after a long illness at the West Haven (Conn.) Veterans Hospital. He was 91 years old The fivepOund pump was  used by Wiley Post and Harold Gaily in their famed 1931 flight around the world in 8 days 15 hours 51 minutes and later by Charles A. Lindbergh and his wife in their flight to the Orient.

title: Mrs. Gandhi Quits Executive Council Of Congress Party
description: NEW DELHI, Dec. 18Former Prime Minister Indira Gandhi resigned today from the executive committee of the Congress Party, protesting that it was not properly addressing itself to the formidable tasks of helping the Indian people.

title: Senate Unit Urges Consolidation Of 3 Main Regulators of Banking
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18A Senate committee report issued today describes the current system of Federal bank regulation as duplicative, confusing and inconsistent and recommends a major consolidation of the supervisory functions of the three principal bank regulatory agencies.

title: The Met Gets Finances in Tune
description: After eight years of operating losses, the Metropolitan Opera Company has mace a dramatic turnaround and is meeting its expenses and perhaps moving into a period of more stable financial fortunes, Anthony A. Bliss, the company's executive director, said yesterday.

title: Soviet Officers Said to Admire American Army
description: Soviet military officers admire the United States Army's professionalism, the experience ancr stability of its noncommissioned officers and the freedom given junior officers to use their own initiative in combat, according to Defense Department specialists who have studied Soviet assessments of the American military establishment.

title: Navarro Named Coach Of Princeton Football
description: Frank Navarro, who coached Columbia to its last winning football season in 1971, returned to the Ivy League yesterday after a fouryear absence when he accepted the head football coaching job at Princeton.

title: JAMES N. ANDREWS
description: James N. Andrews, president of the Fiber Box Association, the national trade association of the corrugated box industry, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home in Wilmette, Ill. He was 63 years old.

title: A Man of Many Talents
description: A minor poet and a major anthologizer, whose collections of extracts from other people's poetry were widely used in schools and colleges, Louis Untermeyer was once described by a student as an entire semester of required reading.

title: Begin and Sadat Expected to Confer Saturday at Earliest
description: CAIRO, Dec. 18In a switch in plans today, Prime Minister Menahem Begin of Israel is now expected to confer with Egypt's President, Anwar elSadat, at Ismailia, Egypt on Christmas Eve at the earliest and possibly a few days later, according to a wellplaced diplomatic source.

title: The Met Gets Finances in Tune
description: After eight years of operating losses, the Metropolitan Opera Company has made a dramatic turnaround and is meeting its expenses and perhaps moving into a period of more stable financial fortunes, Anthony A. Bliss, the company's executive director, said yesterday.

description: Robert J. Milano began his business career $10 behind (he had lost at pool the night before he opened his- office) and he ended it about $16 million to the good, so he hardly needed the wrinkled dollar bill that Mayorelect Edward I. Koch handed to him yesterday. But Mr. Koch insisted. Mr. Milano will be his $1-ayear deputy mayor for economic development and, the Mayorelect said whimsically, This administration will keep its commitments.

description: Morris O. Alprin's holiday greeting card is specially designed to express his appreciation of the annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

description: CARABALLEDA, Venezuela, Dec. 18The decision to freeze oil prices that has already been announced by the major Middle Eastern producers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries has made the ministerial meeting scheduled to open here Tuesday largely a formality.

description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18Prime Minister Menahem Begin said today that President Carter regarded Israel's latest proposal for movement toward a Middle East peace settlement as a fair basis for negotiation.

description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18Prime Minis ter Menahem Begin said today that President Carter regarded israel's latest. proposal for movement toward a Middle East. Peace settlement as a fair for negotiation.

title: A Museum Benefit (and Bear) Provide Unusual Occasion for Detente
description: LARGO, Md., Dec. 1SA crush of people crammed into a room today at Capital Center, the gigantic entertainment arena 15 miles from Washington, for an unusual party after a benefit performance of 1 the Moscow Circus. Mingling with needy children, Washington socialites and Administration officials were Russian Embassy aides, Russian children and a Russian baby hear.

title: Plank Captures Downhill Race; Klammer Third
description: VAI. GARDENA, Italy. Dec. IR (AP) Herbert Plank of Italy defeated Franz Klammer, the Austrian downhill expert, by two seconds today and won the men's World Cup downhill race on Klammer's favorite course.

description: ENTRIES

title: Nude Bar on L.I. Circumventing a Legal Ban
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L.I.  The Salem Inn. It sounds like a rustic tavern that Nathaniel Hawthorne might have written about. But the Salem Inn on Port Washington Boulevard here has been immortalized in writing of another sortcourt decisions.

title: Rochester Lawyer Sentenced
description: ROCHESTER, Dec. 18 (AP)A Rochester lawyer has been sentenced to a year in jail for his part in an alleged misuse of union funds. Justice Wilmer J. Patlow of State Supreme Court pronounced sentence on Lawrence D. Chesler, 40 years old. Mr. Chesler was convicted of seconddegree grand larceny and criminal facilitation Oct. 22. The alleged crimes took place in 1971 and 1972 while Mr. Chesler was a lawyer for a corporation set up by Barbers Union Local 246 to build a housing project. Mr. Chesler was a trustee for some of the union's money.
