description: MONTEREY, Calif.We've created an adventure, said Bruce Weaver. and if adventure has to do with the untried and uncertain, then he and his small group of astronomers are indeed adventurers.

title: 78 Seen as Challenge For U.S. Credit Market
description: The American credit markets in 1978 will face their toughest challenge since the current economic expansion began nearly three years ago, Henry Kaufman, a partner and economist at Salomon Brothers, asserted yesterday as the firm issued its annual projection of supply and demand for borrowed funds for the year ahead.

title: About New York Eggbag the Cat's Card Trick
description: Eggbag the cat is asleep in the back of the magic shop, and Eighth Avenue looks almost greasy with the afternoon rain. There isn't much magic on the avenue and the hookers stand out under their golf umbrellas.

title: Sales in Most Areas Up by 10% to 15%
description: At Marshall Field & Company, Chicago's largest department store, a customer called the State Street store's personal shopper and ordered all his Christmas gift needs on the telephone $1,500 worth.

title: Users of Food Stamps Down by One Million
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP)One million fewer people were enrolled in the Federal Government's food stamp program in October than in the same month in 1976, the Agriculture Department reported today.

title: Entire Town Being Evicted in Utah by Copper Company
description: LARK, Utah, Dec. 17The 591 people who live in this tiny town have got word that it is being closed down by the Kennecott Copper Corporation.

title: The Economic Scene
description: Leonard Silk asseses the situation involving the reappointment or replacement of Arthur F. Burns as chairman of the Fed. He reports that the President could defer the appointment of the next chairman beyond Jan, 31, when Dr. Burns's term as chairman expires, and could have Dr, Burns continue to serve until his successor is appointed and confirmed by the Senate. Page 59.

title: Bodies of 3 Found in Crashed Jet
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Dec. 19 (AP)The bodies of the three crew members of cargo jet that crashed yesterday in rugged mountains 26 miles north of here in a snowstorm were found in the wreckage today. Investigators are still searching for two recording devices. The United Airlines DCSF jet crashed on the north side of Ed's Peak in Baer Canyon.

title: Russian Warns of Letup on Rights
description: Vladimir K. Bukovsky. a dissident deported by the Soviet Union, expressed concern in Manhattan yesterday at what he perceived as an apparent weakening of President Carter's stand on human rights and warned that it might result in further oppression in the Soviet Union and even in the loss of lives there.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: ANNETTE ROSLYN COHEN
description: Annette Roslyn Cohen, past president and treasurer of the Sisterhood of Congregation Sharey Israel of Brooklyn and former president of the Helada Sunshine Group of Brooklyn, died yesterday in her home, 220 Prospect Street, East Orange, N.J. Mrs. Cohen was 83 years old.

title: Where Mr. Begin Is Headed
description: A quarteryear agoit now seems a quartercentury agowe remarked that in Middle East diplomacy, the glass is either half empty or half full and that we prefer to view it as half full. That is certainly how we prefer to see Prime Minister Begin's explication of the proposals he will put to President Sadat when they meet on Christmas Day. The ideas he outlined to President Carter last weekend appear to confirm that peace and the return of virtually all of Sinai are now possible on the Egyptian front. The crucial question is whether Jordan and the Palestinians of the West Bank and Gaza can be enticed into the negotiations for a much broader and more promising process of peacemaking.

title: Opposition Thwarts Efforts to Rewrite Communications Act
description: Representative Lionel Van Deerlin, Democrat of California, who heads the House Communications Subcommittee and who for two years has sought to rewrite the Communications Act of 1934, yesterday conceded that there was too much opposition to the proposal for the revision to occur in 1978.

title: Victim of Rape Freed In Attacker's Death
description: ALBANY, Dec. 19 (UPI)Christina Pratt, charged with manslaughter for killing the man she said had raped her. has been granted executive clemency by Governor Carey.

title: BEGINSADAT PARLEY ON PEACE PLAN IS SET FOR CHRISTMAS DAY
description: Prime Minister Menahem Begin said here yesterday that he would meet Sunday in Egypt with President Anwar elSadat and was confident that the Egyptian leader would not reject Israel's peace plan out of hand.

title: Wet Willie Is a Hot, Bopping Band
description: Wet Willie, an Atlantabased band with roots in Mobile, Ala., was part of the new wave of Southern rock marketed by Capricorn Records during the early 1970's. Although the group made seven albums for Capricorn, and had a hit single, Keep On Smilin', it always seemed doomed to stand in the shadow of the Allman Brothers, the Marshall Tucker Band and Lynyrd Skynyrd, at least in the public eye. This was too bad, because Wet Willie was not up to the same thing.

title: Around the Nation
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 19As many as 40 percent of the women held in Cook County Jail last year on charges of killing their male partners had been physically attacked on several occasions by the same men, a corrections official reported today.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: News Summary
description: TUESDAY, DECEMBER 20, 1977

title: Koch Plans to Ask State to Allow City Direct Control Over Its Hospitals
description: Mayorelect Edward I. Koch plans to ask the Legislature early next year to restructure or perhaps even abolish the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation so that a mayoral agency can assume direct control over the management of the city's 17 municipal hospitals.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Provenzano Is Reindicted in a Kickback Conspiracy
description: Anthony Provenzano, the leader of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters in New Jersey, was indicted in Manhattan v?? e?? for the thi?? time on the same Federal charge involving an alleged conspiracy to arrange a kickback on a $2.3 million loan from union funds.

title: King Khalid to Get A $12 Million Yacht
description: AMSTERDAM, Dec. 19 (AP)A 212foot yacht being built in the Netherlands for King Khalid of Saudi Arabia has three decks, a helicopter platform, an operating room, a swimming pool, a sauna, a barber shop and a gymnasium. It will cost. $12 million.

title: NEW TRIAL ORDERED FOR FILIPINO NURSES
description: DETROIT, Dec. 19A Federal judge, in an order accusing Government prosecutors of persistent misconduct, today ordered a new trial for two Filipino nurses convicted lest July of poisoning patients at the Ann Arbor Veterans Administration Hospital.

title: JACK REIGOT, 53, EXPERT IN THE DIAMOND MARKET
description: Jack Reigot, a diamond expert, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital of cancer. He was 53 years old and lived at 115 Central Park West.

title: Construction Plan for State Prisons Wins Final Approval by Legislature
description: TRENTON, Dec. 19The State Assembly today gave final legislative approval to a $19.5 million construction program for state prisons that would include the building of a new mediumsecurity prison near Hopewell, north of hcre, and a partial remodeling of the maximumsecurity prison in downtown Trenton.

title: Notes on People
description: Queen Elizabeth II's first grandchild is to be baptized Thursday, it was announced yesterday, and the christening has already stirred a controversy in Church of England circles. A number of clergymen have complained that the baptism will not set a good example, as it is not being held by the rules. Those rules state that unless an ifan health in is danger or there other grave circumstances, he should be baptised on a Sunday in the family's parish church. But Peter Mark Andrew Phillips, son of Princess Anne and Capt. Mark Phillips, is to be baptized on a weekday, not in church, but in the Music Room of Buckingham Palace. The tongues are clucking about that mostly because Queen Elizabeth, Defender of the Faith, and the Most Rev. Donald Coggan, the Archbishop of Canterbury and spiritual head of the Anglican Church, personally approved the baptismal arrangements.

title: Loeb and Wife Remain in Hospital After Car Crash on Ice in Nevada
description: RENO, Dec. 19 (UPI)William Loeb, the newspaper publisher, and his wife, Nackey Scripps Loeb, remained hospitalized today for injuries suffered when their fourwheeldrive vehicle skidded on an icy highway and overturned.

title: NO INCREASES FOUND IN COLLEGE DRINKING
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Dec. 19College students are not drinking any more these days and are not getting into any more trouble than they were five or 25 years ago, according to a report published today by the Rutgers Center of Alcohol Studies. The conclusions are based on a nationwide survey of 13 colleges and universities by Dr. Ruth C. Engs, of Indiana University.

title: Dow Off by 7.37 to 807.95 Close; G.M. Drop of 1 to '77 Low a Factor
description: Stock prices moved steadily lower in late trading yesterday as General Motors one of the market's bellwether issuesfinished at a 1977 low.

title: Evelyn Gendel, 61, Senior Editor With BobbsMerrill Since 1952
description: Evelyn Gendel, a senior editor at the BobbsMerrill Company since 1952 who supervised books on crafts, cooking, gardening and decorative arts, died Sunday in Beth Israel Hospital in New York following surgery. She was 61 years old.

title: Chicago Jewelry Store Is Looted of $1 Million
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 19 (UPI)Burglars using sophisticated tools took an estimated $1 million in furs and jewelry and $30,000 in cash today from a North Side jewelry store, police and store officials said.

title: Aqueduct Racing
description: ENTRIES

title: Advertising
description: Outdoor advertising is having its best year ever and because its 1978 rates will not be up as much as other media it expects to do even better next year.

title: World News Briefs
description: THE HAGUE, Dec. 19 (AP)Queen Juliana swore in the 16 members of a new centerright coalition cabinet headed by Andreas A. M. van Agt of the Christian Democratic Party today, ending the longest cabinet crisis in Dutch history.

title: Going out Guide
description: LAST CALL Art from Inside is the annual exhibition and sale of prisoners art works. They come from city, state and federal corrctional facilities and also include some contributions by former offenders. There is still time to catch the sixth display, on view through tomorrow, admission free, at the New York Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West 64th Street, just off Central Park West. Viewing hours are 11 A.M. to 8 P.M. just off Central Park West.

title: Market Place
description: Given the stock market's precipitous drop this year, it is not surprising that Wall Street opinion is divided on the prospects for many stocks. The computer makers are a case in point.

title: Pennsylvania Squonks and Other Jewels
description: It's easy enough to visualize a dragon or a unicorn, but most of us would be hard put to describe a Youwarkee. Yet this creature, half woman and half bird, shows up in as many versions as do the more familiar beasts, in an exhibition of jewelry by about 40 artists at the Aaron Faber Gallery through Jan. 7.

title: United Airlines Offers Fare Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP)United Airlines said today that it would ask the Civil Aeronautics Board to approve new group air fares that would save passengers 33 percent on flights to Nevada from several Eastern and Middle Western cities. The Group Inclusive Tour fare would be available to groups of 40 passengers or more flying to Les Vegas and ?? passengers or more flying to Reno.

title: The U.N. Today
East German Writer, Blacklisted at Home, Gets a Visa to West
description: WEST BERLIN, Dec. 19Jurek Becker, the East German dissident who wrote the screenplay for the movie Jacob the Liar, has come to the West on a twoyear visitor's permit, he said today.

title: Phantorn Fumble: And the Fans React
description: The questionable call by Fred Silva, the referee, in the BaltimoreNew England game on Sunday drew the sharpest protests yesterday in the Miami area, where Dolphin fans voiced their anger by telephoning television stations and newspapers.

title: $90 Million GarbageFueled Plant Proposed for Brooklyn Navy Yard
description: A plan to build a $90 million plant in the Brooklyn Navy Yard to extract ferrous metals and produce lowcost electricity from the city's garbage was unveiled yesterday at City Hall. Mayor Beame said the plan, which was presented by Ashmont Metals of New York, would create 2,000 permanent jobs and absorb 2,400 tons of the city's daily output of 21.000 tons of garbage.

title: Dancers Humor Their Audience
description: Humor is undervalued among most serious concert dancers, but not by Susan Creitz, who presented two witty works on a program shared with Anne Marie Ridgway Sunday evening at the Theater of The Open Eye. Miss Ridgway's funny bone had a zany twist, too, and she ended the concert with an improbable collection of dizzy characters in a series of blackout sketches.

title: Policeman Is Accused of Plotting 2 Murders and Narcotic Traffic
description: A New York City police officer who allegedly used telephones at Police Headquarters to arrange murders and to carry on a narcoticssmuggling business was indicted yesterday with two other persons by a Kings County grand jury.

title: 150Member Peking Ballet To Tour U.S. in Summer
description: The 150member Ballet Troupe of the People's Republic of China, based in Peking and considered the country's representative national company, will tour the United States next summer under the auspices of the Metropolitan Opera and the National Committee on United StatesChina Relations.

title: NEGOTIATORS ON ENERGY DIFFER ON THE RESULTS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (UPI)House and Senate energy negotiators, increasingly edgy as Christmas crept closer, held repeated private sessions today on natural gas regulation and differed widely on what they accomplished.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In an article on the seven winners of Rockefeller public service awards, published in The Times Dec. 11, one recipient's name was misspelled. He is Harold Rowley of Rochester.

title: Mrs. Abzug Announces Candidacy For Koch's East Side House Seat
description: Rejected twice by voters in one year, Bella S. Abzug formally began an attempt at apolitical comeback yesterday by announcing her candidacy for Mayorelect Edward I. Koch's seat in the House of Representatives from the East Side's 18th Congressional District.

title: Purcell Will Reject The Limousine Style Of Top Nassau Job
description: MINEOLA, LI., Dec. 19  Francis T. Purcel, the Nassau County Executiveelect, said today that the first priority of his administration would be to form a sensible economic policy. Toward that end, he said, he will begin reducing the staff of the County Executive's Office, refuse the use of a new Limousine and prohibit firstclass travel by county executives, thereby saving at least $400,000 a year.

title: Jet Rebuilding Plans: One Down, More to Go
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Dec. 19Like campers going home after a long summer, the babyfaced Jets trooped into Coach Walt Michaels's office today to say goodbye.

title: Liberty Bowl Scoring
description: N. Cara Wilhams, 12, cars from Kupec (Bindle, kick). Neh Donnell, 15, run (Todd, kick), N. Car. Loomis, 11, pass from Kupec (Biddle, kick). N CarFG, Bindle, 47. Neb, Craig, 10, pass from Garcia (Todd, kick). Neb, Smith, 33. pass from Garcia (Todd, kick), Attendance49,456.

title: College Results
description: MEN'S BASKETBALL

title: Marriner S. Eccles Is Dead at 87; Headed Reserve Board 12 Years
description: Marriner Stoddard Eccles, former chairman of the Federal Reserve Board and an influential figure in national economic policymaking during one of the nation's most turbulent periods, died Sunday at his residence in Salt Lake City at the age of 87.

title: Carter Studying Excise Tax Cuts In '78 Package
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19  President Carter is considering a reduction of certain Federal excise taxes as a part of his taxcut proposals to Congress next year. White House officials said today

title: Court Bars Press in Most Cases At Pretrial Hearings on Evidence
description: The New York State Court of Appeals ruled yesterday that the press should be excluded from pretrial hearings on admissibility of evidence, unless the press could prove that the public had an overwhelming interest in keeping the proceedings open.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: JORDAN'S KING CONTINUES TOUR OF ARAB CAPITALS
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Dec. 19King Hussein of Jordan, after holding talks with Saudi Arabian leaders here, left today on a tour of Kuwait and other Persian Gulf capitals.

title: In Mentoriam
description: LEAHYEsther. First anniversaryMom, we cared for you. Will always love and have you In our hearts. Kaye, Jack, John, Patricia Ann and Tom

title: German and Italian Radicals Linked
description: VIENNA, Dec. 19Austrian police investigators say they have evidence that a terrorist alliance has been formed by West German and Italian underground organizations. The alliance, the investigators say, may have Arab backing.

title: Tennis
description: AT ADELAIDE, AUSTRALIA

title: Bombs Wreck Fauchon, a Famed Paris Food Store
description: PARIS, Dec. 19Two bombs wrecked Fauchon, the most renowned food delicacy store in France, before dawn today.

title: Election Unit Says A.F.I.C.I.O. Violated Campaign Spending Law
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP) The Federrl Election Commission has accused the A.F.I..C.I.O of viointing Federal campaign spending laws and recommended that a judge fine the labor organiintion $10.000.

title: Welfare Agency Cited for Bumbling In Its Promotion of Alleged Cheat
description: The state's Acting Welfare Inspector General accused the city's Human Resources Administration yesterday of bumbling the case of a 36yearold Brooklyn woman who allegedly collected welfare for years at excessive rates while working for the administration itself.

title: BUILDER'S RECORD IS CITED IN APPLICATION PULLBACK
description: An application to the New York City Planning Commission to renovate two apartment houses in the Bronx with Federal assistance was withdrawn yesterday because of the controversial background of the developer.

title: Companies Issue Earnings Reports
description: For periods ended Oct. 31 unless, otherwise indicated. (N) Indicates stock is traded on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) American Stock Exchange and (0) over thecounter.

title: Economic Setup In Japan Blocks Sale of Imports
description: TOKYO, Dec. 19The Japanese custonms inspector opens every crate of metal baseball bats from a foreign manufacturer. He selects one bat, saws it open and rules that the inside is not machined sufficiently. The whole shipment is rejected.

title: U.S SAYS IT WILL ABSTAIN ON UNITED NATIONS BUDGET
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 19 (AP) The United States said today that it would abstain from .voting for the 19781979 United Nations budget and may oppose future budgets unless extravagant programs are restricted and outmoded and obsolete ones are canceled.

title: Issue and Debate
description: Must the National Football League playoff system be changed? The question, like Caesar's Gaul, can be divided into three parts: Should there by playoffs at all, beyond a single championship game? Should they include wildcard teams? And what formula should be used to choose the qualifiers?

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Blasts Over Atlantic Remain Unexplained
description: A series of midair explosions some 50 miles out over the Atlantic Ocean during the last two weeks has baffled research scientists and military aqthorities. Columbia University's Lamont Laboratory at Palisades, N.Y., just north of New York City, has detected seven explosions since Dec. 2. each equal in force to the detonation of 100 tons of dynamite.

title: Prosecution Drops Murder Case Against 5 Defendants in Georgia
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 19The prosecution announced today that it had moved to dismiss the firstdegree murder charges against the socalled Dawson Five, bringing the case to an end nearly two years after the charges were filed. The first of the. defendants, Roosevelt Watson, was scheduled to go on trial Dec. 27.

title: Gertrude Cooper, at 88, Supervised Vanderbilt Estate in Hyde Park
description: Gertrude Sturgis Cooper, who was superintendent of the Vanderbilt estate in Hyde Park, N.Y., for the National Park Service in 194045 and then assistant director and director until 1948 of Greenwich House, the settlement house at 27 Barrow Street in New York, died yesterday in a convalescent hospital in Chester, Conn. She was SS years old and lived in Killingworth. Conn.

title: PROCESSOR OF WHITEFISH WINS IN A HEATED BATTLE
description: A major processor of smoked whitefish in Brooklyn has won a court battle against enforcement of a Federal regulation that required extremely high temperatures for processing the fish.

title: A SOVIET ASTRONAUT MAKES SPACE WALK
description: MOSCOW, Tuesday, Dec. 20 (AP)Astronaut Georgi Grechko, the flight engineer of the twoman Soviet team that has been in orbit for 10 days, spent nearly an hour and a half outside the Salyut6 space station today, Tass announced.

title: Bank Practices and Regulation Found to Vary Sharply
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19When Bert Lance's financial manipulations hit the front pages last summer, they posed unpleasant questions for the banking business.

title: A Sample of Untermeyer's Verse
description: Louis Untermeyer was an unflagging creator of verse, some of which included in his own anthologies. Following are two of his poems taken from Modern American Poetry, published in 1962.

title: Australian Aborigines Have Fiery Champion in Mum Shirl
description: SYDNEY, AustraliaThe shabby parish hall of a rundown Roman Catholic church in a Sydney slum is governed by the spirit and presence of an aboriginal woman in her mid50's who wears a big cross around her neck and curses with ringing conviction.

title: MILWAUKEE ROAD SEEKS PROTECTION IN BANKRUPTCY ACT
description: The Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul and Pacific Railroad voluntarily asked the Federal district court in Chicago yesterday to grant it protection under Section 77 of the Bankruptcy Act, making it the first major railroad to seek bankruptcy action since the Chicago and Pacific collapsed in March 1975.

title: No Increase Found In College Drinking By Student Survey
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, Dec. 19College students are not drinking env more these days and are not getting into any more trouble than they were five or 25 years ago, according to a report published today by the Rutgers Center cf Alcohol Studies. The conclusions are based on a pationwide survey of 13 colleges and universities by Dr. Ruth C. Engs of Indiana University

title: Carter Studying Excise Tax Cuts In '78 Package
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19  President Carter is considering a reduction of certain Federal excise taxes as a part of his taxcut proposals to Congress next year. White House officials said today.

title: British Judge Approves Showing Of TV Program About South Africa
description: LONDON, Dec. 19 (Reuters)A judge lifted a ban today on references to the Tate and Lyle sugar company in a planned television documentary about blacks who work for British companies in South Africa.

title: Canada Announces Economic Sanctions On South Africans
description: OTTAWA, Dec. 19 (Reuters)Canada cut off all official commercial aid to South Africa today but stopped short of severing diplomatic ties with the whiteruled nation.

title: Court Bars Press in Most Cases At Pretrial Hearings on Evidence
description: The New York State Court of Appeals ruled yesterday that the press should be excluded from pretrial hearings on admissibility of evidence, unless the press could prove that the public had an overwhelming interest in keeping the proceedings open.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Gold and Silver Futures Fall; Copper Firm as Platinum Gains
description: Persistent rumors that Washington will make its next periodic attack on gold by selling some of the metal next month caused some selling of bullion futures yesterday in the precious metals markets.

title: Polar Gas Plans Bid to Construct Arctic Pipeline
description: A longawaited application to build a $6.1 billion natural gas pipeline from the Canadian Arctic will be filed tomorrow before the National Energy Board of Canada, according to a spokesman for the Polar Gas Pipeline Consortium, which plans to build the line.

title: Dollar Slides in Trading Abroad
description: LONDON, Dec. 19 (AP)The dollar, while strengthening in Tokyo, fell dramatically in light, nervous trading on European foreign exchange markets today, setting record lows against a number of currencies.

title: Two Women Found Shot to Death In 93d St. Basement Apartment
description: Two women were found shot to death yesterday morning in a basement apartment on 93d Street between Broadway and West End Avenue.

title: CITY COUNCIL LEADERS AGREE TO WITHDRAW BILL TO INCREASE PAY
description: Facing a groundswell of adverse public opinion and opposition from Mayor Beame and Mayorelect Edward I. Koch, the City Council leadership surrendered yesterday and agreed to withdraw the bill that would have increased the salaries of Council members and other elected city officials.

title: Books of The Times
description: It happens that I was in Asia while reading this almost interminable book. It helps to become acquainted at first hand with the fact that Asians are human beings with more than their fair share of intelligence and grace, while contemplating what we did to so many of them in the last days of that miserable war.

title: Nat'l Hockey League
description: SUNDAY NIGHT AT BOSTON

title: Giamatti, Scholar of Renaissance, To Become Yale's 18th President
description: NEW HAVEN, Dec. 19A. Bartlett Giamatti, a 39yearold Yale professor of English, has accepted an offer to become the 18th president of Yale University, reliable sources reported tonight.

title: News Summary
description: TUESDAY, DECEMBER 20, 1977

title: Final N.F.L. Standings
description: (Reprinted from yesterday's late editions.)

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In an article on the seven winners of Rockefeller public service awards, published in The Times Dec. 11, one recipient's name was misspelled. He is Harold Rowley, of Rochester.

title: NEW TRIAL ORDERED FOR FILIPINO NURSES
description: DETROIT, Dec. 19A Federal judge, in an order accusing Government prosecutors of persistent misconduct, today ordered a new trial for two Filipino nurses convicted last July of poisoning patients at the Ann Arbor Veterans Administration Hospital.

title: Leonard Silk
description: With the dollar being battered in international financial markets, President Carter is under growing pressure to announce whether he will reappoint Arthur F. Burns as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board when his fouryear term as chairman expires The Jan. 31. But, contrary to widespread belief, President Economic Carter could defer the apScene pointment of the next chairman beyond that date and could have Dr. Burns continue to serve as chairman until his successor is appointed and qualified with the advice and consent of the Senate.

title: Louis Untermeyer, a Poet, Critic and the Producer of 90 Anthologies, Is Dead at 92
description: A minor poet and a major anthoIogizer, whose collections of extracts from other people's poetry were widely used in schools and colleges, Louis Untermeyer was once described by a student as an entire semester of required reading.

title: Communists Are A sked To Govern San Marino
description: SAN MARINO, Dec. 19 (Reuter)The Communist Party was today asked to form a government in the tiny republic of San Marino, which would make it the only Communistruled state in Western Europe.

title: Unanimous Discord Over New York
description: Singular unanimity was revealed among the New York City witnesses who have been testifying before the Senate Banking Committee. All agree that Federal longterm help is the key to a solution of New York's financial problems. The Senators presentWilliam Proxmire and Edward Brookewere similarly unanimous. They agreed that longterm aid was unlikely, and suggested that even a renewal of the seasonal loans would be difficult. They warned that the city, the state, the banks and the pension funds cannot count on Federal help to avoid the city's bankruptcy.

title: Promoter Cancels Arms Bazaar As Miami Beach Citizens Protest
description: MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 19Plans to hold an international arms bazaar in this convention city next year have misfired.

title: Spirited Show From Caribbean
description: The Republic of Trinidad and Tobago Cultural Association presented a long and extravagant show, From Whence We Came, at Town Hall on Sunday night. The weather outside was inclement and the wait between numbers sometimes seemed interminable, but for those who braved the slush and overcame their impatience, there was much to look at and listen to.

title: Guerrillas Attack Base in Rhodesia, Killing One Soldier
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Dec. 19 (AP)Black nationalist guerrillas have attacked Rhodesia's main forward air base near the Mozambican border, killing one soldier and wounding six others, according to a Rhodesian military announcement.

title: Patricia Murrill Gary Bride Of Marquette de Bary, Banker
description: The marriage of Patricia Murrill Gary to Marquette de Bary, president of the Marquette de Bary Company, stockbrokers and investment bankers, took place yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Epiphany. The Rev. Ernest E. Hunt 3d performed the ceremony.

title: Habib's Condition Improves
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP)The condition of Philip C. Habib, the Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs, has improved from critical to serious, officials at Walter Reed Army Hospital reported today.

title: Israeli Rightists, West Bank Arabs Denounce Begin's Peace Proposals
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 19Prime Minister Menahem Begin's proposals regarding the Israeli held Arab territories are beginning to be denounced by militant West Bank Palestinians as granting too little in the way of concessions and to be criticized by rightwing Israelis as possibly granting too much.

title: BEGINSADAT PARLEY ON PEACE PLAN IS SET FOR CHRISTMAS DAY
description: Prime Minister Menahem Begin said here yesterday that he would meet Sunday in Egypt with President Anwar elSadat and was confident that the Egyptian leader would not reject Israel's peace plan out of hand.

title: 3YEAR DEBT MORATORIUM ASKED BY JAPAN LINE CO.
description: TOKYO. De. 1?? (UPI)  The Japan Line Company Ltd., one of the largest ship fleet operators in Japan, with capital of $142.5 million, formerly asked today for a threeyear moratorium on bank loan repayments of $156 million, a company spokesman said.

title: Giants Find 1978 Outlook Encouraging
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Dec. 19Coach John McVay was studying the roster of Senior Bowl players this morning. The 1977 season ended yesterday for the Giants; 1978 is already beginning with what some doubters may call delusions of grandeur.

title: G.M. CONFIRMS REPORTS OF ENGINESWITCHING PACT
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 19 (AP)The General Motors Corporation confirmed today that it had agreed to pay a total of up to $40 million to more than 100,000 owners of 1977 Oldsmobiles, Pontiacs and Buicks in which it substituted Chevrolet enaines.

title: Zuccotti Reportedly Asked by Koch to Become School Chancellor, Showing Extended City Hall Influence
description: Seeking to extend City Hairs influence into the schools, the Koch administrationtobe has won a Board of Education pledge of input in picking a school chancellor and has approached former First Deputy Mayor John E. Zuccotti to take the job.

title: Downtown Athletic Club Admits Women
description: Another preserve of male exclusivity the Downtown Athletic Clubhas dropped its harriers against female members. The first women are expected to join the 51yearold club, at 19 West Street, after the New Year.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: KANSAS CITY. Dec. 19 (UPI)The Kansas City Chiefs, who had their worst season with a 212 wonlost mark, today.dismissed Tom Bettis their interim coach.

title: Pro Transactions
description: FOOTBALL

title: Release Expected For 3 Americans Seized by Vietnam
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19State Department officials said today that they have been informed by Vietnamese authorities that three young Americans seized aboard their boat off the Vietnamese coast in October would be released in time for Christmas.

title: Around the Nation
description: More than a thousand members of the United Mine Workers formed two long caravans yesterday and roamed the coal fields in parts of Alabama and Kentucky, looking for nonunion mines operating despite the threeweek strike.

title: CARTER TO PROPOSE $25 BILLON TAX CUT AND SOME REFORMS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20  President Carter has decided on a $25 billion tax reduction and revision package designed to stimulate the economy and check inflation, top Administration sources said. today.

title: 18th Leader of Yale
description: NEW HAVEN, Dec. 20A taxidermist's wonder looms over the dining hall at Ezra Stiles, one of Yale's undergraduate colleges. The ugly old moose head has been decorated for the holidays with lights and tinsel garlands

title: Dow Ends at 806.22 on Late Rally After Slipping Close to 800 Level
description: A late but somewhat feeble rally trimmed losses in the stock market yesterday as prices generally registered their fourth decline in a row.

title: Minor Explosion at Nuclear Plant Is Reported by Vermont Officials
description: MONTPELIER. Vt., Dec. 20 (AP)A spark touched off a minor explosion at the Vermont Yankee nuclear power plant more than a week ago, state officials confirmed today.

title: Senate Report Criticizes U.S. Intelligence on Oil Embargo
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20A Senate Intelligence subcommittee has concluded that some newspapers and magazines performed as well as or better than United States intelligence analysts did in predicting and evaluating Saudi Arabia's role in the oil embargo imposed in October 1973 by Arab nations.

title: L.I. Woman, 70, Killed As Pile of Books Falls
description: A 70yearold woman was pulled out from under a giant pile of books, newspapers and press clippings that had collapsed on her, but she died shortly after being rescued.

title: Carter Signs Social Security Tax Rise for 110 Million
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20  President Carter today signed into law a Social Security financing bill that mandates series of increases in Social Security payroll taxes starting in 1979 for more than 110 million working people.

title: SALT Beyond Minuteman
description: The storm now brewing over the next SovietAmerican strategic arms limitation treatySALT IIturns on something the technicians call Minuteman survivability. It means quite simply that toward the end of the proposed eightyear agreement, the Soviet Union is expected to acquire the theoretical ability, in a first strike, to destroy most of America's 1,000 landbased Minuteman missiles. That would wipe out the most important and reliable arm of America's triad of retaliatory forces (bombers and submarine missiles are the others). The vulnerability of the Minuteman missiles in their underground silos has been predicted repeatedly in the past without materializing. But, the experts now agree, the wolf is finally approaching the door.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: Auto PhotographInspection Law Will Be Reviewed, Carey Reports
description: POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Dec. 20The state's Insurance Department will review a regulation that requires the inspection and photographing of cars before they can be insured, Governor Carey said today.

title: Cliff Erosion Threatens to Topple Several Houses Into Long Island Sound
description: ROCKY POINT, L.I., Dec. 20Buffeted by strong winds and tides, portions of a 150foothigh cliff gave way last night and tonight, threatening to topple several houses into the Long Island Sound below.

title: WING F. ONG
description: PHOENIX. Ariz .Dec. Dec, 20 (AP)Wing F. Ong, the first ChineseAmerican elected as a state legislator in the United States, died yesterday. He was 73 years old. He screed two terms in the Arizona House before being elected to the State Senate.

title: U.S., Keeping Promise to Hopis, Is Forcing 3,500 Navajos to Move
description: BIG MOUNTAIN, Ariz.On a sere, barren stretch of land 100 miles from anywhere, over roads that belong in a radial tire ad, 3,500 Navajos are being forced to move by the Federal Government. Some believe this is the largest forced relocption of Indians since the end of the Indian 1,7Ars almost a century ago. It is being done in the name of justice.

title: Careers
description: In a labor market that is always reasonably tight, graduates of good music schools will find satisfying and often wellpaid jobs in 1978, just as they did this year, according to Dr. Robert Freeman, director of the Eastman School of Music at the University of Rochester.

title: U. S. SAID TO CAUTION BEGIN THAT HIS PLAN WON'T SATISFY SADAT
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20Prime Minister Menahem Begin of Israel was reportedly told by President Carter and other high officials last weekend that his plan for dealing with the Palestinians on the West Bank of the Jordan and in the Gaza Strip did not seem to offer enough to President Anwar elSadat. The Israeli leader was urged to repackage his proposals before he met with the Egyptian leader this coming Sunday.

title: Bond Market Retreat Continues as Government Issues Fall Sharply
description: The credit market's retreat continued yesterday as Government bond prices dropped sharply, half a dozen corporate issues were freed from syndicate price restrictions and posted large losses and yields on taxexempt bonds moved upward.

title: Linda Blair and 31 Held in Drug Case
description: WILTON. Conn.. Dec. 20 (AP)The ac tress Linda Blair, who starred in the movie The Exorcist, was one of 32 persons arrested today in a drug investigation, a Drug Enforcement Administration official said.

title: Genesco Sells Unit
description: Genesco Inc. announced in Nashvil le the sale for cash on Dec. 9 of certain assets of its Susan Thomas women's apparel division to Tan Jay international Ltd. of Winnipeg, Manitoba. The transaction includes the New York and Chicago showrooms, as well as fixtures and equipment. Susan Thomas's various brand names were not included. Terms of the sale were not disclosed.

title: $870 Million Plan to Revitalize South Bronx Unveiled
Carter Approves Bill On Corporate Bribes
description: WASHINGTON, Dec.20 (AP)President Carter signed legislation today providing for a $1 million fine against any corporation that bribes a foreign official, one of the stiffest monetary penalties on the books.

title: East Side, West Side, Tis the Season
description: Over on the East Side, Lee Menichetti, the designer, turned his bedroom into a dining room, with a brassand copper decorated Christmas tree, and brass and copper centerpieces on each of the small tables.

title: 853 More Characters Simplified by Peking
description: PEKING, Dec. 20 (Reuters)The Government today approved 853 more simplified Chinese characters for popular use and indicated that its ultimate aim remained the introduction of a Latin alphabet.

title: Belated Arrest in Theft of a Rockwell
description: MAMARONECK, N.Y., Dec. 20When Norman Rockwell donated his painting Goin Fishin to the Mamaroneck High School in 1965, his most serious concern, according to a letter to the school's principal then, was that the gay, carefree theme of the work might encourage truancy. He was, after all, the school's most famous dropout, said school officials, and presumably had firsthand knowledge of the many temptations of adolescence.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: It's party time, and in homes, offices, restaurants and bars throughout America, the drinks are flowing more freely than usual. Alcohol, the nation's favorite moodaltering drug, is supposed to make people feel good and friendlyto case social interactions, loosen tongues and spirits, and warm the body if not the soul. Many consider an idealperhaps even an essentialaccompaniment to holiday and other celebrations. Unfortunately, alcohol also has a dark side. Nearly half the nation's traffic fatalities and more than half of home accidents can be partly or entirety blamed on misuse of demon rum. Many people occasionally overindulge in alcoholic drinks and in the process embarrass themselves and their companions, perhaps endanger their lives and nearly always pay a painful price the next day.

title: Advertising
description: The ground floor office suite of Weiner Edrich Brownthat's three people not oneis bright and pleasant with a greenandwhite decor and house plants everywhere. A nice environment for thinking about the future, no matter how dismal it may appear.

title: About Education
description: John Dewey, the educational philosopher who founded the experimental elementary school operated by the University of Chicago, envisioned it as a place to test ideas, as well as an academy for preparing the children of University of Chicago faculty members for college.

title: Washington Reaction DOomed Council's Raise Bill
description: In the end, it was the reaction from Washington that doomed the City Council's bill to raise the salaries of its members and those of other elected city officials. A person close to the Council leadership said yesterday that when William Proxmire, the chairman of the Senate Banking CommitNews tee; assailed the raises at a committee hearing last Wednesday, senior Council members decided that the increases could not go through. Virtually by Thursday I knew that we had to withdraw, one key Council member said yesterday.

title: SPENDABLE PAY UP FOR SOME EMPLOYEES
description: Record purchasing power for an average New Yorknortheastern New Jersey factory production worker with three dependents was reported yesterday. The previous high was reached in December 1972, in data kept since 1950.

title: REGULATION LAGGING FOR U.S. BANKS ABROAD
description: American banks have gone international in a big way. Last year, as a group, the nation's 10 largest banks made more money abroad than at home. Thus far this year, Citicorp, the parent of Citibank, New York's largest hank and the nation's second largest, has looked abroad for more than 80 percent of its profits.

title: Reporter's Notebook: In France, Technology vs. Gastronoiiy
description: THE real food news from France can hardly be considered glad Christmas tidings for eaters the world over. For after an ac.ence of six years from that feaster's paradise, wt ieturned recently for lourweek eating tour, and the report of our findings puts us, we fear, in the same precarious class as any other messenger who carries bad news.

title: GROUP OF CONFEREES, REACHES AN ACCORD ON A GAS PRICING BILL
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20A small group of House and Senate energy conferees agreed just before midnight on a compromise natural gas proposal that would not end price controls but would permit a faster rate of price increases than the Carter Administration had sought.

title: Dividends
description: TUESDAY, DECEMBER 20, 1977

title: The New Yale President's Professors
description: NEW HAVENThe selection of A. Bartlett Giamatti as Yale's 18th president is good news, and not for Yale alone: to assign a firstrate scholar so prominent a position should encourage other universities to go and do likewise. But his job will be difficult, for he faces not only hard times, but also a restless faculty.

title: Madame Tussaud's Rejects Takeover Bid
description: LONDON, Dec. 20 (AP)The board of directors at Madame Tussaud's, London's famous waxworks museum, rejected a $20 million takeover bid today. The bid came from the Associated Television Corporation Ltd., Britain's biggest independent television company. It offered 55 pence a share. One penny is worth a little less than two American cents. News of the bid and its rejection sent shares in Madame Tussaud's Ltd. up from 52 pence to 59 pence on the London Stock Exchange.

title: MELVIN R. BANDLE
description: RESTON, Va., Dec. 20 (AP)Melvin R. Randle, 54 years old, a specialist in world food problems, died at his home here yesterday.

title: U.S., Keeping Promise to Hopis, Is Forcing 3,500 Navajos to Move
description: BIG MOUNTAIN. ArizOn a sere, barren stretch of land 100 miles from anywhere, over roads that belong in a radial tire ad, 3,500 Navajos are being forced to move by the Federal Government. Some believe this is the largest forced relocation of Indians since the end of the Indian wars almost a century ago. It is being done in the name of justice.

title: TV: CBS's LowerClass Bull
description: AS ABC CLINGS confidently to the top of the audiencepopularity ratings heap, some small measure of fascination, if not comic relief, can be found in watching the nervous counterprogramming antics of CBS. The selfdescribed Tiffany network coasted along for years as ratings leader on a substantial schedule of classy situation comedies, action series and occasional family products such as The Waltons.

title: Typical Annual Taxes
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20Following is a table of typical annual Social Security axes this year, next year and under the bill signed today by President Carter:

title: Meadowlands Board Rejects HighRise Housing Units
description: SECAUCUS, N.J., Dec. 20The concept of highrise residential development in the Hackensack Meadowlandsone of the basic precepts of development of the huge tractwas jeopardized today by the rejection of plans for the first highrise complex in the district.

title: Inland Steel, Following Bethlehem, to Lift Prices 5.4%
description: A pattern for steelprice rises began to emerge yesterday as the Inland Steel Company, the nation's sixth  largest producer, announced an increase of 5.4 percent for most of its products, effective early next year, closely following the Bethlehem Steel Corporation's increase of 5.5 percent announced the day before.

title: New Bond Issues
description: Tuesday, Dec. 20, 1977

title: About Real Estate
description: By next March J. mannetmer Inc. of Queens will he packing up its drums of patchouly oil from Indonesia and coriander oil from the Soviet Union, its clove oil from ladagascar and ilangilang from the Comoro Islands, its menthol cryFtals from Brazil and as petitgrain oil from Paraguay, and shoving off.

title: An Expert's View on Dollar And the Federal Reserve
description: WASHINGTON  Before it finally agreed to the first devaluation of the dollar in 1971, the United States was in effect accused by many of its Western partners of benign neglect because of its reluctance to initiate overt meastires to stem a substantial outflow of dollars from this country, an outflow that foreign central banks had to sop up. Now, as another. Administration tries to follow a similar handsoff policy in the foreignexchange markets in response to the dollar's latest decline, the same complaint is rising abroad.

title: First Visit to Santa
FRANCIS J. KIERNAN
description: Francis J. Kiernan, a controller for the Stanley Warner Corporation in New York until his retirement in 1968, died Dec. 15 in his home at 66 Willis Street, Northport, L.I., after a long illness. He was 75 years old. He is survived by his wife, Mabel, and a son, Gerard.

title: 2 Soviet Astronauts Take a Space Walk; Docking Device Said to Be Working Well
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 20 (UPI)Two Soviet astronauts took a walk in outer space today and reported that their troublesome docking device was working well. The venture was a possible prelude to the launching of a second spaceship.

title: JUDGE BACKS TAX PACT ON THE HUGHES ESTATE
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 20 (AP)A judge has approved a compromise agreement under which the maximum Federalstate tax bite from the Howard R. Hughes estate would be 79 percent, instead of possible 100 percent.

title: Quake Devastates 3 Villages in Iran
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 20 (AP)An earthquake struck southeastern Iran belore dawn today, devastating three villages near the town of Zarand in Kerman Province, officials said.

title: I.B.M. Lifts Dividend For Quarter to $2.88
description: The board of the International Business Machines Corporation yesterday declared a quarterly dividend of $2.88 a common share, up from $2.50 a share, payable March 10 on about 148 million shares to some 580,000 stockholders of record Feb. 9.

title: Czechoslovak Series Set

The N.H.L. had threatened to cancel the exhibition games because the Czechs had demanded that N.H.L. teams with Czech defectors remove them from the lineup or the Czechs would not play them.

title: Homeowners Trying New Ways to Beat Winter Cold
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 20Phyllis Johnson had called a dozen local companies, some repeatedly and with increasing insistence, before she found one that would sell her insulation for her home, and even that was not quite what she was looking for.

title: Robber Kills Brink's Guard
description: ABINGTON, Pa., Dec. 20 (UPI)A Brink's security guard was shot and killed in a department store crowded with Christmas shoppers yesterday by a masked robber who fled with two deposit bags containing about $103,000 in cash and checks. The guard, Carl Simonsen, 46 years old, of Philadelphia, a Brink's employee for 20 years, was shot once in the chest in a scuffle with the robber on an escalator at a Sears, Roebuck & Company store in this suburban Philadelphia community. The robber escaped.

title: Carter Signs Medical School Bill Ending Rule on Foreign Transfers
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (UPI)President Carter today signed a bill requiring medical schools to increase thirdyear enrollment by 5 percent but no longer forcing them to accept American students transferring from foreign medical schools.

title: 60Minute Gourmet
description: SOMEWHERE, years ago, I read an essay on pork that quoted Auguste Escoffier: However deservedly pork may be praised, it could never have been included among the preparations of firstclass cookery (except subsidiarily) had it not been for the culinary value of ham. I have never known the sources of that quote but it fascinates nee that he spoke of ham exclusively and not the entire range of charcuteric. I consider the sausages and salamis, the porkbased pates and terrines of my homeland to be among the great contributions to civilization.

title: LEON I. MIRELL, PRODUCER IN TELEVISION AND FILMS
description: Leon 1. Mirell, a film and television production executive, died Dec. 8 at his home in Los Angeles. He was 54 years old.

And the Dolphins' owner, Joe Robbie, has demanded a league review of the game's officiating.

title: Notes on People
description: WITH his agreement. Government cancer specialists have been treating Senator Hubert H. Humphrey with highly experimental drugs, an aide to the Minnesota Democrat confirmed yesterday. The situation was fully explained to him and he decided to let them proceed, the aide said in confirming the reports published by John Anderson, the columnist, and others. One of the drugs being administered to Mr. Humphrey, who has inoperable cancer, is an oral chemotherapy agent called hexamethylmelamine, Senator had recided to remain in his which causes side effects of nausea, fatigue and loss of appetite. Meanwhile, Mr. Humphrey has changed his mind about not going home to Waverly, Minn, for Christmas, possibly because Vice President Mondale made him an offer he couln't refuse. The Senator had decided to remain in his Washington apartment, but now he plans to take advantage of the free ride home Mr. Mondale offered the Humphrey family aboard the VicePresidential jet, Air Force II. They're leaving Washington tomorrow.

title: U.S. Agency Says any Adults Are Losing Battle to Slim Down

description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20Prime Minister Menahem Begin of Israel was reportedly told by President Carter and other high officials last weekend that his plan for dealing with the Palestinians on the West Bank of the Jordan and in the Gaza Strip did not seem to offer enough to President Anwar elSadat. The Israeli leader was urged to repackage his proposals before he met with the Egyptian leader this coming Sunday.

description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (Reuters)The Agriculture Department today barred most French liver pate products from entering the United States because of concern about possible food poisoning.

title: Bridge:

The Greater New York Bridge Association's regional Swiss teams at the New York Hilton Hotel Sunday, which concluded the last tournament of the year in the metropolitan area, was no exception.

title: Fill the Wassail Bowl With Jelly
description: The box had been delivered by hand, it wore a red ribbon but no other gift wrappings, which meant that under the house rules it could be opened before Christmas. It contained five sealed envelopes of plastic holding a colorless liquid. Portable Martini read the label on each. The gift nas not yet been sampled, but judging by its clarity the martini is powerdry, as it should be. The envelopes are in the refrigerator taking on the bitter chill that is as important as dryness. Their presence has set a long train of recollections in motion, a train that winds back quartercentury to the time when Joe H. Palmer was writing about racing for The New York Herald Tribune.

title: Tanner and Gerulaitis Sweep Aussie Rivals
description: ADELAIDE, Australia, Dec. 20 (AP) Roscoe Tanner and Vitas Gerulaitis gave the United States a sweep of four singles matches in a $50,000 tennis challenge against Australians today.

title: Technology
description: Unless Nigeria takes drastic steps to apply science and technology to its agriculture, it is headed for one of the world's most drastic food shortages within a decade, according to the Washingtonbased International Food Policy Research Institute.

title: Film: Children of the Kirov
description: ONE of the many ballet teachers interviewed in "The Children of Theater Street" is a man who, in his youth, once saw Nijinsky. The great dancer was a student at the time, and the man being interviewed recalls how different he seemed from the others; he could leap into the air and stay aloft much longer than seemed physically possible. The man remembers, though, that Nijinsky's own teacher saw things another way. The teacher was less impressed by talent and grandeur than he was by the fact that Nijinsky never landed in time to the music."The Children or Theater street," a documentary about the famed Kirov ballet school in Leningrad, is made in a spirit of which this teacher would doubtless approve. It is earnest, plodding and thoroughly earthbound, a fine illustration of how easy it is to demystify artistry by trying too hard to understand it.We watch young students auditioning for admission to the school, and we see older ones rehearsing for their all-important graduation performance. We are casually introduced to many of their teachers. And we are told endlessy, by a narrative script read in a genteel monotone by Princess Grace of Monaco, that these children must study long and hard to achieve a level of success that will always fall short of perfection. But we are never allowed much individual insight into anyone; the film shifts its attention too erratically and often to allow any of the dancers' struggles or triumphs much meaning. This is less a sustained study than it is a series of glimpses through keyholes.For a film about people who have dedicated their lives to the single-minded pursuit of one goal, "The Children of Theater Street" meanders to a surprising degree. Just when the director, Robert Dornhelm, seems about to single out a particular student or aspect of life at the school, the narration will make a point about dance in the 19th century and then change that subject, too. Details, when they are offered, are far from revealing: All we are cold about one stocky older woman who plays the piano at dance classes is that she has been wandering the halls of the school for ages, carrying her sheet music and her purse.The film pays particular attention to several of the students, and there is an 11-year-old girl named Angelina who takes one's breath away. With a long neck, sloe eyes and an expression of exquisite serenity, she already dances more beautifully than many of the older children we see; there's something magical about the way she always catches the eye, even in a crowd. The scenes that feature Angelina are both the loveliest here and the least successful; a spirit like hers is precisely what the film is so ill-equipped to capture.

description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 20 (AP)Mary Levy, fresh from coaching the top team in the Canadian Football League, signed a fiveyear contract today as head coach of the Kansas City Chiefs, one of the two worst squads in the National Football League this season.

Dec. 20During the last few months, the percentage of Jewish emigrants from the Soviet Union choosing to resettle in Israel rather than elsewhere in the West has grown in comparison with the percentage earlier this year and throughout last year, according to welfare workers here.

People are reluctant to believe that he can be an outstanding pro quarterback just because he's young (24 years old), goodlooking (blond in the allAmerica style), strong (a sturdy 5 feet 11 inches and 180 pounds), intelligent (a Rhodes scholar with a year to go at Oxford), a hometown hero in Los Angeles through high school and college and possessor of an unbroken record of displaying leadership on winning football teams wherever he has played.

title: REGULATION LAGGING FOR U.S.BANKS ABROAD
description: American banks have gone international in a big way. Last year, as a group, the nation's 10 largest banks made more money abroad than at home. Thus far this year. Citicorp, the parent of Citibank, New York's largest bank and the nation's second largest, has looked abroad for more than 80 percent of its profits.

title: INDONESIANS REPORT 10,000 CAPTiVES FREED

Mr. Gallo slumped to the sidewalk with a chest wound. He was rushed to Methodist Hospital, where he was pronounced dead.

title: Books of The Times
description: ALTHOUGH I can remember the grownups devouring it avidly when it came out in 1952 and I see that no less than Lionel Trilling pronounced it definitive, I have not read Edgar Johnson's original twovolume Charles Dickens: His Tragedy and Triumph. So I cannot say with authority whether Professor Johnson's singlevolume revision and abridgment constitutes an improvement or impairment of the original. But my guess is that the new work is better, at least from the standpoint of a general audience. Why? The most straightforward and expressive way to explain such a hunch would be to say that one simply can't imagine a more readable book about Dickens than the present one. And that is true enough, for whatever it may be worth. Whether or not he lived a more dramatic life than most writers, Dickens seems to have brought to whetever he did an unusually large sense of play. And Mr. Johnson, who is a Distinguished Professor Emeritus at the City Unievrsity, has somehow conveyed Dickens's outsized vitality with almost every line of his biography.

title: Some Artists' Ideas On Eating Well

And the Dolphins' owner, Joe Robbie, has demanded a league review of the game's officiating.

title: Terence Klingman And Cecily W. Cabot, Students, Are Wed

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: CHRISTMAS is ordinarily not thought of as time for romance, which is too bad because people who care deeply about their romances have always favored Christmas over all other times of the year. Autumn is for breaking off romances, and then walking around and feeling poignant about it Springtime has always been highly overrated for just about everything. and summer in New York is best spent somewhere else. Christmas, however, is different, Christmas is when you are supposed to walk hand in hand down Fifth Avenue and look in store windows. Then you find a small Italian restaurant and order mozzarella in carrozza. Then you go home and make love in front of a fireplace. There is almost nothing more romantic than this.

title: Private Lives

But until recently he has been doggedly determined to operate in a kind of country and western no man's land, and while there are plenty of cosmic cowboys in Texas who will listen to a Texas Jewboy, he has had some trouble connecting with the rest of the country.

Nowadays, it is de rigueur to give the oratorio complete; the tempos have become so brisk that the whole occupies considerably less than three hours. Part of the change followed the rethinking of Baroque performance style, and as such was admirable.

title: Front Page 1 -- No Title
Screen: Eastwood 'Gauntlet'
description: IN "THE GAUNTLET," his new film as both director and star, Clint Eastwood plays a detective in Phoenix who is described as a drunk and an incompetent. It is, you see, a character role. So, too, is that of Sondra Locke, the pretty, fresh-faced actress who made her debut in "The Heart Is a Lonely Hunter." Miss Locke plays a Las Vegas hooker who graduated from Finch College. "The schoolgirl look is very popular right now," someone says by way of explanation.Explanations aren't really necessary. "The Gauntlet" has nothing to do with reality and everything to do with Clint Eastwood fiction, which is always about a Force (Mr. Eastwood) that sets things straight in a crooked world."The Gauntlet," which opened yesterday at the Columbia I and National Theaters, is about the rigors faced by Mr. Eastwood's detective when he attempts to return the hooker from Las Vegas to Phoenix to testify at a mob trial. Along the way the detective and the girl establish a revivifying relationship (he will give up his Jack Daniel's if she gives up her johns), though the movie is more concerned with the mob's efforts to prevent them from completing their trip.There are escapes in ambulances, gunfights in speeding automobiles, a helicopter attack, a ride on a stolen motorcycle and, for the climax, a sequence in which a bus, armored like the Monitor, runs a police gantlet through downtown Phoenix to reach City Hall.It is a movie without a single thought in its head, but its action sequences are so ferociously staged that it's impossible not to pay attention most of the time. It's not simply that the film is noisy. It has a kind of violent grace, as when a house, which has been bombarded by the heavy artillery of the police, quietly gives up and collapses into fine rubble.Michael Butler and Dennis Shryack wrote the screenplay, which exists to accommodate the mayhem much in the way that the book for a Broadway musical supports the songs. Mr. Eastwood's talent is his style, unhurried and self-assured, that of a man who goes through life looking down onto the bald spots of others. Miss Locke is not only pretty, but also occasionally genuinely funny.In supporting roles, Pat Hingle has nothing much to do and as Mr. Eastwood's fussy, nannylike cop-friend, and William Prince models some very dapper haberdashery as the mob's highly placed contact within the Phoenix Police Department.

title: Bishop Timotheos, 60, in Chicago; Led Greek Orthodox Archdiocese
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 21 (UPI)  Bishop Timotheos, head of a Greek Orthodox archdiocese that includes six Middle Western states, died today at Northwestern Memorial Hospital here. He was 60 years old.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Canada's Waters Beckon Pursuers of Salmon
description: Any angler without connections who wishes to fish for Atlantic salmon in Canada must rely on public waters or outfitters. Connections mean membership in a club that leases a stretch of a salmon river or friendship with an individual or club that does the same.

title: Owner in Ringer Case Likely to Be Licensed
description: The State Racing and Wagering Board indicated yesterday that it would probably grant a temporary 1978 license to Jack Morgan, the listed ownertrainer of the mystery horse in Belmont Park's ringer case.

title: POLAR GAS IS APPLYING FOR PIPELINE TO CANADA
description: OTTAWA. Dec. 21 (UPI)Polar. Gas Ltd., as expected, applied today for permission to build a pipeline to carry natural gas from islands high in the eastern Arctic to markets in southern Canada.

title: Indiana Takes Final Again, Beating Alabama, 6657
description: BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Dec. 21 (UPI)  Wayne Radford, one of only two seniors on the team, pumped in a seasonhigh 24 points tonight and Mike Woodson added 17 to lead 16thranked Indiana to a 6657 victory over Alabama in the final of the Indiana Classic basketball tourney.

title: War Veteran, 101, Dies
description: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 21 (AP)  Anthony J. Denenea Sr., a 101yearold veteran of the SpanishAmerican War, died yesterday at the Veterans Administration Hospital here. Mr. Denenca was one of four remaining SpanishAmerican War veterans in Louisiana. In 1898 he served under Theodore Roosevelt in Company K, the Second Louisiana Volunteers.

title: Keely Smith With Butera

Miss Smith, who played a deadpan foil to Louis Prima in the 50's, and Mr. Butera, whose ensemble provided instrumental backing for Mr. Prima, are carrying on the boisterous Prima tradition as well as a lot of the Prima material, including Old Man Mose, You Rascal, You, Night and Day and Old Black Magic.

title: U. S. Inquiry Finds Neglect of Georgia Dam That Burst
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 21The darn that ruptured near Toccoa, Ga., on Nov. 6, resulting in 39 deaths, had not been properly inspected and maintained by its owners, a Federal investigative board said here today.

title: Market Place
description: Beginning in January, investors will have to hold securities for a full year to qualify for longterm capitalgains treatment. Wall Street, meanwhile, is looking for ways to protect shortterm gains from erosion until they mature.

title: Study Predicts Casinos Will Draw 2.45 Million To Atlantic City in 1982
description: ATLANTIC CITY. Dec, 21 (AP)Six casino hotels in 1982 would draw 2.45 million more visitors here and place higher demands on area housing and South Jersey highways, according to projections in two studies made public here today.

title: CONSUMER PRICE RISE HIGHEST IN 5 MONTHS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21A burst of inflation in some food prices and markups for Toyota cars imported from Japan helped propel the Consumer Price Index to an increase in November of onehalf of 1 percent, more than in any of the preceding four months, the Government reported today.

title: Panty Raiders Stocking Up
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Dec. 21 (UPI)The Oakland Raiders, thinking about the weather on the East Coast, have purchased 60 pairs of women's coffeecolored superqueensize pantyhose, meant to fit a person with 48 to 60inch hips who weighs between 200 and 260 pounds.

title: Global Christmas on Public TV
description: A PUBLICTELEVISION special, Christmas Around the World, will employ the largest and most complex international satellite hookup ever used to pick up and transmit signals from 7 countries for a live broadcast in 30 countries on Christmas Eve.

title: Rangers, Up By 30, Tie Capitals, 55
description: In their distinctive and increasingly ers lost an early 30 lead over the predictable way, the New York RangWashington Capitals last night and struggled to earn a 55 tie with two goals in the final period.

title: A New Mass Diplomacy, Using Television and the Press, Is Emerging in Middle East
description: PARIS, Dec. 21At their receptions, diplomats around the world are exchanging bitter complaints these days about the way the new diplomacy has turned the tables on them.

title: Canada Humphrey Is Henry's Daughter
description: SO LONG was the reign of Elizabeth I and so full of incident, and so mettlesome was she in person that it is easy to think of her as the centerpiece of all sorts of dramatic offeringsas the many plays and operas about her attest. Cavada Humphrey, known to theatergoers for her role as Mrs. Patrick Campbell in Dear Liar, the play made out of the CampbellBernard Shaw correspondence. evidently thinks so. too.

title: Neglect and Low Pay Thin the Ranks of Europe's Artists
description: ROMEAfter 18 years abroad, Paolo Carosone, a moderately successful sculptor and graphic artist, returned to his native Rome three years ago hoping to mount a few oneman exhibitions, publish a book on his best works and maintain a steady income.

title: New York, New York
description: BOSTON, Dec. 21Edward Koch becomes Mayor of New York on New Year's Day. Soon after that he will have to take a position on one of the biggest urban planning issues In the country: the proposal to build Westway, a $1.16 billion expressway along the West Side of Manhattan.

title: Design Notebook;
description: NEW YORK City has a new market. Not one that sells pomegranates and papayas, luke fish, octopus and gweduc, like the famous market in Seattle. a center of city life and holy place of all true urbanists. Yet a market neverthelessofficially so named, in the new Citicorp Building between Lexington and Third Avenues at 53d Street.

title: In the Air: Scented Homes
description: Only three more days till Christmas. Will your nose make it? Seventy percent of all yearly fragrance sales are made during the Christmas seasonand this year, many more of those sweet smells are headed behind the living room sofa instead of behind the ears.

title: Holding the Line on Steel
description: The latest steel price increases were no surprise to close observers of the industry. The first two companies to post increases, WheelingPittsburgh and Bethlehem, are in particularly poor financial shape. Both need a quick revenue boost to calm their creditors, and both understand that their financial frailty makes it more difficult for the Administration to be critical of an increase. Nor is anyone familiar with industry pricing surprised by the size of the announced increases. It has become a ritual for the steel producers to aim for more than they expect so as to leave room for retreat before Government criticism and lesser increases by competitors. WheelingPittsburgh's initial reach for 7 percent and subsequent announcements close to 5.5 percent by other companies suggest the game is progressing on schedule. Nonetheless, the decision to raise steel prices now makes plain how difficult it will be for the Carter Administration assist the industry in its time of troubles without significantly raising prices to consumers.

title: BARBARA KRAUS, EDITOR OF THE U.N. COOKBOOK, 48
description: Barbara Kraus, an international dietary specialist whose works included The Cookbook of the United Nations, died yesterday at her home at 325 East 41st Street. She was 48 years old and had been ill for some time.

title: NEW FILES RELEASED ON KENNEDY DEATH
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (UPI)The Secret Service investigation into the assassination of President Kennedy was heavily preoccupied with possible Cuban and even Chinese Communist involvement, according to documents released today.

title: CONFEREES REJECT COMPROMISE PLAN FOR NATURAL GAS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21Despite some quiet Administration support, a compromise on natural gas proposed by a group of HouseSenate conferees was opposed on all sides yesterday.

title: HOW TO AID THE FUND
description: Cheeks should be made payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and sent to P.O. Box 5193, Church Street Station, New York, N.Y. 10249 or to these agencies:

title: Top Pop Records
description: These are the most popular albums and singles nationwide, compiled by Record World, a trade publication. Albums are determined by sales figures from major retail outlets; singles are chosen by combined sales and radio airplay. An asterisk indicates an especially fastselling record.
