description: Checks should be made payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and sent to P.O. Box 5193, Church Street Station. New York, N.Y. 10249 or to these agencies:

title: 10 Killed, 17 Missing In New Orleans Blast
description: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 22 (AP)A chainreaction explosion ripped through 45 units of a 73silo grain elevator near here like a string of giant Roman candles early today, killing at least 15 persons. Another 9 were missing and were feared dead.

title: NEW YORKERS ASSAY JERSEY TAX CIIAN6E
description: TRENTON, Dec. 22Three New York state Assemblymen came here today to discuss New Jersey's schoolfinancing mechanism, including the state income tax and the laws that place limits on spending by state and local governments, and by school districts.

title: CAIRO EXPECTS ISRAEL TO RELAX ITS STAND ON PALESTINIAN ISSUE
description: CAIRO, Dec. 22Egyptian officials said today that Cairo had received assurances that Prime Minister Menahem Begin, at his meeting with President Anwar eiSadat on Sunday, would take a substantially more forthcoming position on the crucial Palestinian issue than he did publicly during his recent trip to Washington and New York.

title: The Glory That Was Abercrombie, the Grandeur That Was Fitch
description: THE CLEVELAND CLINIC FOUNDATION CLEVELAND, OHIO 44106

title: CONFERENCE BURIES COMPROMISE ON GAS AND QUITS FOR MONTH
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22The HouseSenate energy conference buried the latest proposed natural gas compromise today and quit for a month.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Brooks Puts a Spin on Vertigo
description: What's funnier than seeing a Mel Brooks movie? Seeing a Mel Brooks movie while sitting next to Mel Brooks.

title: U.S. Experts Meet on Flu Virus Widespread in Soviet
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 22Minute samples of an influenza virus that has caused widespread illness in the Soviet Union and Hong Kong were distributed here today to vaccine manufacturers to enable them to grow it and study it while other experts try to assess its threat to the American population.

title: Weight of Airplane Fatal to Team Noted as Within Prescribed Limit
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP)The DC3 plane that crashed last week at the Evansville, Ind., airport, killing all 29 aboard, was 148 pounds within its prescribed weight limit, a spokesman for the National Transportation Safety Board said today.

title: MAISLIN INDUSTRIES LTD.
description: Mr. Samuel Maislin, Chairman of The Board of Directors, is pleased to announce the appointments of Mr. Sydney Maislin as Vice Chairman of the Board of Directors, Mr. Paul Desrochers as President of Maislin Industries Ltd, and Mr. Alan W. Maislin as VIce President and General Manager of Maislin Transport of Delaware Inc.

title: Stores Are Having a Very Merry Christmas, Indeed
description: Christmas shoppers in the state are spending more freely than ever before, elated merchants and managers reported yesterday.

title: Bangladeshi Leader In Pakistan for Talks
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Dec. 22 (AP) President Ziaur Rahman of Bangladesh arrived today in the capital of the nation his country won its independence from six years ago for talks with the head of the military regime, Gen. Mohammad Zia ulHaq. It was the first official visit by a ranking Bangladeshi since the Indian Army helped win the independence of Pakistan's eastern province in 1971.

title: Queens Woman Is First in City To Get Master Plumber's License
description: When Josephine Striano was a little girl, she used to accompany her father on his business calls. Yesterday she joined her father and three brothers in their chosen calling. She became the first woman in New York City to become a licensed master plumber.

title: 2 in Row for Swiss Youth
description: VERBIER, Switzerland. Dec. 22 (Reuters)Silvano Meli, 17yearold Swiss skier, won a European Cup downhill ski race today for the second day in a row. He was clocked in 2:10.S1.

title: Broadway
description: IMMEDIA TELY the good news: Angela Lansbury is coming back in a musical. It will be Sweeney Todd, in which she will costar with Len Cariou, but which, unfortunately, will not get here until next season. This is the musical for which Stephen Sondheim is doing the music and lyrics and Hugh Wheeler the book, and for which Hal Prince will be the director. The producers are Richard Barr and Charles Woodward. You do not put a musical together overnight, and Mr. Barr and Mr. Woodward have been involved in this ever since they saw Christopher Bond's adaptation ofSweeney Todd, the Demon Barber of Fleet Street at the Stratford East Theater outside of Central London. Then they heard that Mr. Sondheim, who was then working on Pacific Overtures, was interested in doing it as a musical. Mr. Barr and Mr. Woodward then shook hands, in turn, with Mr. Sondheim, Mr. Prince and Mr. Wheeler. This meant the deal was on.

title: GTE Sylvania Accused of Bribing a Subway Engineer
description: GTE Sylvania Corporation was accused yesterday of paying nearly $12,000 in bribes to a New York City subway engineer who allegedly demanded the money for changing the specifications of $3.5 million in light bulb contracts.

title: 2 Departures End an Era for Mine Union
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22An era in American labor history came to an end today with the departure from office of two United Mine Workers union leaders whose Miners For Democracy uprising, by the power of the ballot, had thrust a corrupt regime literally into the street.

title: Art: Remember the 50's on 10th St.?
description: WITH a revival of the 1950's now in progress, it was probably inevitable that 10th Streetone of the more fondly remembered scenes of the art world of the periodwould sooner or later be given its due. And so it now has in a mammoth show called Tenth Street Days: The Coops of the 1950's spread out in five galleries in or adjacent to SoHo.

title: WEEKEND MOVIE CLOCK
DR. BABETTE MAY LEVY, 69, AN EDUCATOR AND AUTHOR
description: Dr. Babette May Levy, an educator and author, died Wednesday night in the Birchwood Nursing Home, Huntington, L.I. She was 69 years old and had lived in Amherst, Va.

title: Federal Reserve Statement
description: (millions of dollars)

title: How to Get There
description: To get to Tarrytown by car, take the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway to the last exit before the Tappan Zee Bridge, then head south on Route 9 for Irvington and Sunnyside or north for Tarrytown and the other restorations.

title: Geneen Leaving I.T.T. Helm, With Admirers and Critics
description: With the days running out, the master sat in his elegantly appointed office and talked about his abdication, The master is a small figure, dwarfed by the chair he sat in.

title: Guerrillas Tell of Battles
description: ALGIERS, Dec. 22 (Agence FrancePresse)The Polisario guerrillas said here today that two French air force Jaguar fighters had been brought down, killing the pilot of one of them, and three others hit by Saharan ground fire in operations in Mauritania and Western Sahara since Dec. 2.

title: Increasing the Pressure on Pretoria
description: The Canadian Government's announcement that it will no longer promote trade with South Africa is a useful reminder that there exists a range of steps short of boycott or embargo to bring pressure against the Pretoria regime. Ottawa's actions are ones which the United States and other nations that trade with South Africa should emulate.

title: Elisita S. Hill, 66, of California; Aided Bilingual Education of Deaf
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 22Elisita S. Hill, a pioneer in the bilingual education of deaf children, died at Northbridge Hospital last night of the effects of a stroke suffered on Oct. 28. She was 66 years old.

title: Keely Smith Is Back in Town
description: Keely Smith, who used to be a monument of deadpan, disinterested patience and musical riot that Louis Prima raised onstage with Sam Butera and the Witnesses, is back in town for the first time in 14 years. But this time, at the Rainbow Grill where she will be appearing for the next three weeks, Miss Smith is the center of the commotion.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Jean Arp's Paper Work At Modern
description: THE reputation of Jean Arp has not yet coagulated. When he died in 1966 at the age of 78, he was visible above all because of e large sculptures that he had produced toward the end of his life. These derived almost without exception from the biomorphic forms with which he had been working in two dimensions for many years previously. Those forms had something of the human body, something of the vegetable world, something of the sea bed.

title: Ski Conditions in Eastern Areas
description: (Reports swelled by resort owners Not all lifts operating).

title: Army Women to Get Combat Duty
description: WASHINGTON. Dec. 22 (AP)In a major policy change, the Arniv is opening missile units and other combat support assignments to women. The decision means that women may be exposed to hostile fire in a war.

title: Pennsylvanian Buys 50 Percent Interest In Papers on Coast
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Dec. 22 (UPI)A Pennsylvania publisher, Richard M. Scaife, has purchased a 50 percent interest in The Sacramento Union and 15 other California daily and weekly newspapers.

title: Galena, Ill., Wars on Cockroaches of Sky
description: GALENA, Ill.An 89yearold man shot at them with a BB gun and hung out bells to scare them away. The city tried to trap them in cages and even dusted their corn with a birth control drug.

title: Begin Plan Gets
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 22Prime Minister Menahem Begin received a unanimous endorsement today from Israel's Cabinet on the peace plan that he will formally present to President Anwar elSadat of Egypt when the two leaders meet in Ismailia, on the west bank of the Suez Canal, on Sunday.

title: Around the Nation
description: CINCINNATI, Dec. 22 (AP)A tentative agreement that could end the twoweekold Cincinnati bus strike has been reached, Queen City Metro officials announced today. Details on the agreement were not immediately available.

title: Midnight Organist Pulls Out All the Stops
description: For some five years now, Friday midnight has been a high point in Calvin Hampton's week. Mr, Hampton is the organist and director of music at Calvary Episcopal Church, Park Avenue South at 21st Street, and thereat an hour when not everybody is stirring he plays weekly organ recitals from October through May every season. And people go to hear them.

title: Islanders Overcome Blues, 63
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Dec. 22Bring on Montreal! That was the Islanders theme tonight as they beat the St. Louis Blues, 63, at Nassau Coliseum.

title: Waldheim to Assist in Release
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 22Secretary General Kurt Waldheim left tonight for Algeria where he will assist in the release tomorrow of eight French citizens held as hostages by the Polisario guerrillas. Mr. Waldheim will accompany them tomorrow to France for reunions with their families.

title: Mack America's Holiday Mood: Gloom, Suspicion and Pessimism
description: The mood in informed segments of black America is grim this Christmas season as the first year of the Carter Administration draws to a close. Collectively, the mood is perhaps even more pessimistic than many Individual observers interviewed over recent Urban weeks would have thought. Two events that occurred Affairs recently served to underscore that pessimism. The first was a debate sponsored by Encore American and Worldwide News between Dr. Faustine Childress Jones of Howard University, author of The Changing Mood in America: Eroding Commitment and Nathan Glazer, whose most recent book is Affirmative Discrimination.

title: Six, Including Woman. Named Finalists for Seat on Spacelab
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (UPI)The National Aeronautics and Space Administration today named six Americans, including a woman, as finalists for one of two scientist seats aboard the first Spacelab, a science laboratory to be orbited in the cargo bay of the space shuttle in March 1980.

title: French Jets Have Apparently Joined Sahara Fighting
description: PARIS, Dec. 22French warplanes have apparently engaged in bombing attacks several times this month in Mauritania against the Algerianbacked Polisario guerrilla forces.

title: Events and Openings
description: Friday

title: TV WEEKEND
description: CHRISTMAS brings the traditional programming package of holiday reruns, old movies, live pickups of caroling and religious ceremonies around the world and a sprinkling of fresh specials. As usual on Christmas Eve, WPIX will supply canned music to the filmed visual accompaniment of a burning Yule log. The ultimate exercise in makebelieve eets under way at 9 P.M. tomorrow.

title: South African Council of Churches To Pay Biko Family's Legal Fees
description: JOHANNESBURG, Dec. 22 (Reuters)The South African Council of Churches said today that it was paying the legal costs incurred by the family of Stephen Biko during the threeweek inquest into the black leader's death on Sept. 12 in police detention.

title: 15 Killed, 9 Missing In New Orleans Blast
description: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 22 (AP)A chainreaction explosion ripped through 45 units of a 73silo grain elevator near here like a string of giant Roman candles early today, killing at least 15 persons. Another 9 were missing and were feared dead.

title: PRESIDENT APPROVES $126 BILLION BUDGET FOR MILITARY IN 1979
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22  President Carter, in a decision that distresses the military, has approved a defense budget of $126 billion for the next fiscal year. The figure is about $4 billion lower than that sought by Defense Secretary Harold Brown.

title: An Ichabod Crane Christmas
description: CHRISTMAS in the country has always been special, and nowhere more so perhaps, than in the Hudson River environment of Washington Irving, America's first important author, and of the wealthier Frederick Philipse and Pierre Van Cortlandt, who owned much of what is now Westchester County.

title: H. U.D. Takes Over Plan That Provides Insurance in Floods
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22The Federal Government, in a move that officials have said could save taxpayers as much as $15 million next year and improve flood insurance coverage, announced today that it would take over the $36 billion program that protects homeowners and small businesses in floodprone parts of the country.

title: 74 Debutantes Bow At 42d Christmas Ball
description: Seventyfour young women were presented at the 42d annual Debutante Cotillion and Christmas Ball at the WaldorfAstoria last night.

title: Stage: The Dybbuk Returns to Haunt Us
description: FOR THE JEWS of the Eastern European diaspora, history was something to remember and wait for. The present was a few households, small rafts on a sea of irrational dangers nd hardships. Mingled with the orderly intimate life of the community there was an uncontrollable reality that had all the attributes of the supernatural; pogroms and the Czar's proclamations came like the decrees of a God who was asleep or away on other business.

title: Jersey Board Asked to Bar Dr. De Marco
description: NEWARK, Dec. 22A hearing officer found Dr. Peter T. De Marco guilty today of causing a hepatitis outbreak through gross malpractice and recommended that his license to practice medicine in New Jersey be revoked permanently.

title: Upstate Legislator Is Named by Carey As Operations Chief
description: Governor Carey yesterday named Thomas R. Frey, a Democratic Assemblyman from Rochester, to the post of Director of State Operations, one of the administration's most powerful jobs.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: HOLIDAY OUTINGS

title: Corporation Affairs
description: Time Inc., in its second major acquisition move this year, said yesterday that it had reached an agreement in principle to merge the American Television and Communictions Corporation, a cableTV company, into a Time Inc. subsidiary.

title: Art People
description: A CERTAIN tension is evident, both in and out of the Metropolitan Museum, over the length of time the Met is taking to find a new management team; a paid president and a director to replace Thomas Hoving, who on Dec. 31 retires officially from the directorial post.

title: Publishing: Mr. Murray's Dictionary
description: ONE of the transAtlantic sleepers of the year that has gained wide acceptance in academic circles and with the public as well is the biography Caught in the Web of Words: James A. H. Murray and the Oxford English Dictionary, by K. M. Elisabeth Murray, granddaughter of the dictionary's first editor. How the book came to be published by Yale University Press instead of Oxford University Press is one of the book adventure stories of 1977.

title: Tis the Season to Be Jolly
description: Now comes the time, the festive occasion

title: C.A.S. Head Opposes Carter's Braniff Choice
description: WASHINGTON. Dec. 22 (AP)The chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board said today that he strongly discr grecs with President Carter's selection of Braniff Airways instead of Pan American World Airways for nonslop service between DallasFort Worth and London.

title: ExG.I. Revisits World War II Town to Do Reprise of His 44 Role as St. Nicholas;
description: ROCHESTERIt might have been just another bleak day in a wartorn town in Europe. But as Christmas approached in December 1944, a group of American G.I.'s scraped up some supplies and put on a party for the children of Wiltz, in Luxembourg.

title: Boat People and Hill People
description: The Carter Administration's decision to seek the emergency admission of 7,000 more Vietnamese boat people is a welcome but overly cautious response to the mounting refugee tragedy in Southeast Asia. The State Department's original idea of admitting 10,000 would have been better, but still inadequate. Nearly three years after the fall of Saigon and three months after proposals from an interagency task force for a comprehensive, longterm program, surely the time has come to go beyond stopgap measures.

title: Immunity For Judges
description: The Dawson Fivea group of semiliierate young blackshave been at list cleared of murder charges in rural Georgia, and their freedom suddenly bears particular meaning for citizens of New York State.

title: OffDuty Capital Policeman Killed; Suspect in Earlier Murder Seized
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP)An offduty police detective was shot to death early today in a burglary and officers arrested a man free on bail for a murder that occurred in the same building earlier thi syear.

title: Progress Is Reported in Talks On Naval Forces in Indian Ocean
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (Reuters)The State Department said today that the United States and the Soviet Union had made progress in talks last week on regulating naval forces in the Indian Ocean.

title: Restaurants
description: ONE recommended formula for success in the restaurant business is to have a jampacked, noisy, elbowtoelbow setting with plenty bumping and pushing among waiters and clientele and an overall atmosphere suggestive of subway rush. The idea, supposedly, is that everyone wants to he where everyone else wants to be and that such a place is necessarily pat of the in scene. It is a theory that certainly gains credence at Le Veau d'Or, the 31yearold, very authentic French bistro on 60th Street, just west of Lexington Avenue.

title: 19 Hurt in Mississippi Blast
description: TUPELO. Miss., Dec. 22 (AP)An explosion that tore through steelreinforced concrete walls and ripped apart sheet metal partitions at a mill here today sent et least 19 people to hospitals, six of them critically burned, the authorities said.

title: A Holiday Guide for Children and Their Parents
description: With the children home from school, the whole city becomes a Christmas party. But it's a crowded party, as one would expect. Parents and their children must have the slithering ability of a snake to get through the crush as the Museum of Natural History's new reptile exhibition. And waiting on line at peak hours to view some of the Christmas windows at the department stores on Fifth Avenue can lead to a case of holiday depression. It all takes some advance planning and patience, but it's worth the effort.

title: Leo Perper, 83, Patron of the Arts And ExPresident of Roger Kent
description: Leo Perper, for many years president of the Roger Kent clothingstore chain and a devoted patron of the performing arts, died yesterday in New York. He was 83 years old.

title: Ruling Would Bar Mopeds And Bikes on Sidewalks And Look Ma, No Hands!
description: It started out as a simple effort to control the use of bicycles and mopeds on New York City sidewalks. But along the way, so that New York City would not be put in the position of impliedly approving of dangerous behavior, according to a city official, it turned into a proposal that would also make it illegal to ride a bicycle wih no hands

title: New York Bridge Association Gives $596 to Neediest
description: The Greater New York Bridge Associadon has presented a check for $596 to the 66th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Music: Musica Sacra's Messiah
description: MUSICA SACRA's performance and interpretatation of Handel's Messiah, as developed over the years by Richard Westenburg, probably comes about as close as possible to an ideal representation of the work in terms of current musicological information and presentday demands of musical performance in general.

title: Finley Bids Kuhn Detail Objections to Blue Deal
description: Neil Papiano, handling Charles O. Finley's legal battles on two fronts, expressed hope yesterday that Commissioner Bowie Kuhn would soon let him know what problems he might see in Finley's Vida Blue deal with the Cincinnati Reds.

title: Silent Salesman of Third Avenue
description: When someone says to Paul Thomas, as people often do, after staring at him for a while, I didn't think you were alive, he takes it as a compliment. The 19yearold Mr. Thomas is a mime who has found a new and rather lucrative profession as a live street mannequin.

title: Outbreaks of Flu Shut Schools In Parts of Jersey and in Suffolk
description: Outbreaks of influenza cases, some widespread enough to close schools early for the holidays, have been reported in 11 of New Jersey's 21 counties, and schools in two districts in Suffolk County were shut yesterday because of what authorities called flulike conditions.

title: Asia Society Acquires 70th St. Building Site
description: The Asia Society, ending a lengthy search, has purchased a site at the northeast corner of Park Avenue at 70th Street for a new cultural and educational building, the society confirmed yesterday.

title: Tatar Freed in Soviet After 4th Term in Jail
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 22 (AP)The Crimean Tatar nationalist Mustafa Dzhemilev has been released from prison after completing a twoandahalfyear term, dissident sources said today.

title: India Eagerly Awaits Carter Visit as Sign of the Affinity Between Largest Democracies
description: NEW DELHI, Dec. 22 When President Carter arrives in India on New Year's Day, he will find a Government eager to maintaining much friendlier relationship with the United States, and a people who seem delighted to welcome him here.

title: Army to Test a Computer System To Speed Reserve Mobilization
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP)The Army announced today that it would test a new computerized system that would speed mobilization of 160,000 reservists in a major crisis.

title: Final Football Statistics
description: AMERICAN CONFERENCE RUSHING

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Bank Hostages Kill Gunman, Ending Siege at U.S. Base Close to Manila
description: SUBIC BAY, the Philippines, Dec. 22 (Reuters)Hostages who had been held captive by a Filipino gunman for two and a half days beat him over the head and shot him to death today at a bank on the American naval base here.

title: Konica Camera Puts Stogel in the Picture
description: After more than 20 years with KSW&G and its predecessor agency, the Konica Camera Company, Woodside, Queens, is switching it account to Philip Stogel. The billings are around $1.5 million.

title: Money
description: P. Imp rate: 7.

title: Did N.F.L. Try Block Of Replay?
description: The National Football League acknowledged yesterday that Bob Cochran, its broadcast coordinator, was involved in a series of telephone conversations last Monday with representatives from three television news shows about the advisability of replaying the controversial fumble by Bert Jones in last Sunday's BaltimoreNew England game. Sports broadcasters for two of the stations receiving the calls interpreted Cochran's remarks as attempted censorship. The shows involved were the CBS Nightly News, News Center 4 on WNBCTV and Eyewitness News on WABCTV.

title: Carter TV Interview Is Set for Wednesday
description: Representatives of the three commercial networks and the Public Broadcasting Service will jointly interview President Carter from the White House in a live telecast next Wednesday evening, just before his trip abroad.

title: What's Right With Carter
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22At the end of his first calendar year in the White House, Jimmy Carter is getting what Damon Runyon used to call a medium hello, and it's not surprising. All of our last four Presidents have dropped points in the popularity polls during their first year, except Kennedy: hut Mr. Carter has slipped more in his first 12 months than any of then except President Ford.

title: Alyeska Pipeline Head Resigns
description: ANCHORAGE, Dec. 22 (AP)Dr. W. J. Darch is resigning as president of the j Alyeslta Pipeline Service Company, according to E. L. Patton, chairman and chief executive officer of the concern. Mr. Darch's resignation came at the re quest of the British Petroleum Company, Mr. Patton said today. That company had asked its 54-year-old executive to return to London now that startup of the $8 billion transAlaska oil pipeline is complete. Oil hegan flowing through the line on June 20 and reached the pipeline terminus; at Valdez in late July.

title: Recital: Peter Katin Makes a Belated Debut
description: PETER KATIN'S name is well known to record collectors, because some of his disks date back to the early LP days, but until his Wednesday night recital at Town Hall. the British pianist had not given a recital in America. In view of his professional history, he appeared surprisingly youthful, and in fact rather boyish, which made his belated debut seem not at all incongruous.

title: DR. BRUNO PUETZER, 79, RETIRED SCHENLEY OFFICER
description: Dr. Bruno Puetzer, retired vice president of Schenley Industries, died of heart attack at his home on Saturday. qe was 79 years old and lived at 1149 California Road, in Tuckahoe, N.Y.

title: Management The Prescreening Trend in Recruiting
description: There is a new and controversial trend in recruiting by corporations that may affect many college seniors in the peak JanuarythroughMarch recruiting period, It involves prescreening a tactic to cut the number of students the Corporate recruiter interviews when makes an annual visit to the campus.

title: Board of Estimate Votes a New Lease For Bridgemarket
description: The New York City Board of Estimate ended the year yesterday by approving a new lease for the Bridge:narket to be built under the Queensborough Bridge and by voting a huge rent reduction for the operator of the Brooklyn Navy Yard. A number of lucrative Federal jobtraining contracts were also approved, including one for nearly $2 million for a group with no prior experience in the field.

title: Bridge: Partners Don't Always Plan  Cards to Play on 2d Stage
description: Most partnerships take the troubl to discuss original opening leads with combinations that have no standard selections, such as three small and four small. But they do not always exert themselves to consider the second stage: What card should he led, or played, on the second round of the suit.

title: Maryland Eleven Wins, 177
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Dec. 22 (AP)Larry Dick passed for 211 yards and George Scott scored two touchdowns in a span of 2 minutes 11 seconds of the second quarter as Maryland downed Minnesota, 177, in the inaugural Hall of Fame football classic tonight.

title: Rail TonMileage Falls 10.7%
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 13,8 billion tonmiles, 10.7 percent below the corresponding week a year ago. Carloadings in the same period totaled 383.994 cars, 14.6 percent below last year.

title: The Pop Life
description: MANY 10best lists begin with cautious affirmations of the relativity of taste. Not this one. The following list of the 10 best albums of 1977 makes no such pretenses to subjectivity. This is it, folks, the 10 best disks, absolutely absolutely guaranteed.

title: In Memoriam
description: RUBINSTEINIda J., in memory of our beloved mother. Roy and Nina.

title: Roosevelt
description: ENTRIES

title: SCHOOL BOARD PRESIDENT IN WESTCHESTER RESIGN
description: WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 22The press dent of the Lakeland School Board resigned his post yesterday almost six weeks after district teachers went back to work, ending the longest school strike New York State's history.

title: No Price Riseand No Progresson Energy
description: Washington's lurching progress toward a national energy policy has been affected by two recent nonevents. One is clearly good news: the decision by OPEC, the foreign oil cartel, not to raise prices, at least for the time being. To developing countries, struggling to meet present oil prices, the decision, if it. sticks, is a blessing. Even to the United States, the potential benefit is substantial. The nation is importing some $45 billion in oil this year, so deferral of even a 5 percent price rise for a year would mean a saving of more than $2 billion.

title: DISTILLATE OIL SUPPLIES FELL SLIGHTLY IN WEEK
description: Supplies of distillate oil fell slightly to 253.1 million barrels for the week ended Dec. 16, according to the latest weekly supply figures reieased by the American Petroleum Institute.

title: FINANCING ARRANGED FOR THE COMMODORE
description: Two financial institutions have agreed to put up $100 million to reconstruct the Commodore Hotel. asd work will begin in February, Donald Trump, the developer, announced yesterday.

title: U.S. Praises Freeze On Crude Oil Prices
description: WASHINGTON Dec. 22 (UPI)The United States today hailed the decision by the world's major oil producers to freeze the price of crude oil, at least temporarily, and said it would help keep the United States economy growing and dampen inflation.

title: Aqueduct Racing
Schumacher Is Cited by Genesco
description: Continued From Page D1 Bonwit Teller's renovation to exceed its $3.2 million budget.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A 26yearold man tried to commit suicide by jumping from the 86thfloor observation deck of the Empire State Building at about 7 o'clock last night and fell on a ledge on the 85th floor, the police reported.

title: Article 2 -- No Title
People and Business
description: The resignation of Michael E. Tobin as president of the Midwest Stock Exchange to become president of the American National Bank and Trust. Company of Chicago was announced yesterday by the exchange's executive committee.

title: JOHN W. O'CONNOR, AT 68; HEADED PAPER COMPANY
description: John W. O'Connor, a former head of the Paper Corporation of the United States, died Tuesday at his home after a long illness. He was 6S years old and lived at 8 Bobbie Lane, Rye, N.Y.

title: S.I. Family Is Still Cleaning Up After Flood on Nov.
description: Fortunately for the Pulettis, the weather was cold enough in November so that they were able to store their perishable foods in their driveway. Their refrigerator, along with their furniture and books, had been ruined on Nov. 9.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The Appellate Division of the New Jersey Superior Court has upheld the power of companies to dismiss a husband or wife who work in the same concern. In a ruling involving a Carlstadt couple, the state's second highest court said the Legislature in passing a discrimination law did not mean to tell companies that they could not have a no relatives policy.

title: RAIDS FROM CAMBODIA ARE WORRYING THAIS
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 22Prime Minister Kriangsak Chamanand, accompanied by senior Thai military officers, left today for a twoday visit to the Cambodian frontier, amid mounting concern over intensified border skirmishes.

title: Metal Futures Surge in Price
description: Prices of precious metals bounded upward yesterday after Handy & Harmon, the big metals refiners, forecast &200 gold and $5 silver before the end of 1978.

title: People
description: Ward Archer named chairman and Ed White, president, of Ward Archer & Associates, Memphis.

title: Art: While Waiting For Tomorrow
description: THE history of modernism has been marked by strange marriages, not unlike those made by poor aristocrats striving to hold on to their estates. Fruitful alliances have been forged with the art of the socalled primitive peoples, children, the deranged and the peasantry.

title: Striking Miners Get Last 2 Weeks Pay
description: For many of the 188,000 striking members of the United Mine Workers, Christmas was brightened yesterday with payment of two welts wages, the last pay the miners will see until two weeks after their walkout is settled; United Press International reported.

title: Fed Voted to Keep Funds Rate Stable In Policy Meeting
description: In another move away from concentration on moneysupply growth, the Federal Reserve Open Market Committee, the 12man group that sets monetary policy. voted in midNovember to keep the money market stable for the month ahead.

title: ENERGY AGENCY SEES STABLE OIL PRICES
description: PARIS, Dec. 23Western energy experts now believe that the world oil price may remain stable for the next four or live years, following the decision of oilexporting countries in Caracas to keep prices unchanged.

title: Troubled Copper Industry Poised For Rebound After 5% Price Rise
description: The nation's copper industry beset by sluggish demand, sharply higher costs. labor unrest and heavy losses, is poised for a rebound.

title: PAN AM ASKS FOR DELAY IN BRANIFF LONDON ROUTE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (AP)Pan American World Airways asked the Civil Aeronautics Board today to delay the effective dates of new transAtlantic air routes.

title: Can Freshmen Lead Ivy Basketball To the Heights? The Coaches Doubt It
description: The Ivy League basketball teams are not expected to become eight major powers overnight just because the Ivy presidents decided recently to permit freshmen to play on the varsity teams starting next season.

title: Patents
description: WASHINGTONThe RCA Corporation believes that solar cells it is developing will be able to convert sunlight directly into electricity at costs competitive with conventional power sources by the mid1980's. This week the company received what it regards as a basic patent on amorphous silicon semiconductor devices to be used in the cells.

title: Too Much Water Over the Dams
description: There is nothing like a disaster to spur activity on dam safety. Back in 1972, after the collapse of dams at Buffalo Creek, W. Va., and Rapid City, S. D., and the loss of several hundred lives, Congress rushed through legislation directing the Army Corps of Engineers to inspect most large dams. Then the headlines subsided with the waters, and so did the inspection program. Congress was slow in appropriating money, and the Nixon and Ford Administrations preferred to leave the main responsibility for inspection to the states. By this fall the Corps of Engineers had compiled an inventory of 50,000 Federal, state, municipal and private damsthe first full list everbut not a single inspection had been conducted.

title: JACQUES TOURNEUR, FILM DIRECTOR, DIES
description: Jacques Tourneur, a Frenchborn Hollywood director known chiefly for his macabre horror films, died Monday in Bergerac, France. He was 73 years old.

title: Court Order on A's Dissolved
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 23 (AP)A temporary restraining order against Charles O. Finley and Marvin Davis was dissolved today and Oakland Coliseum officials agreed to meet next week with Finley, the owner of the Oakland A's.

title: Christmas Buying Crush: Unpredictable, Humorous
description: In the crush of Christmas shopping, the unpredictable, the humorous, even the bizarre sometimes occurs, relieving the tensions and tedium of the busiest time of the year for the nation's merchants and reminding everyone that Christmas is not strictly business for American retailing.

title: Commodity Price Index FeIL 0.3% to 212.8 for the Week
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials fell to 212.8 from 213.1 last week. The index, compiled by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, stood at 200.8 on Dec. 21, 1976.

title: The Smithsonian museum Decks the Hall in OldFashioned Trees of Christmas
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23At a time when Christmas can mean an exchange of hisandher windmills, halls decked with plastic holly, and carols bellowed by a 500voice choir augmented by electric harpsichords, the Smithsonian's Museum of History and Technology is getting back to basics with Trees of Christmas.

title: Venezuelan Freighter With 25 Tons Of Marijuana Is Confiscated by U.S.
description: MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 23 (UPI)The Coast Guard cutter Courageous escorted into port today a 100foot Venezuelan ship loaded with 25 tons of marijuana, worth an estimated 518 million.

title: Nets Win as Braves Miss Four Shots at End, 103102
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J., Dec. 23How often does one see a professional basketball team take four shots in the final 22 seconds of a National Basketball Association game and miss them all?

title: Lacrosse Coach Named
description: SALISBURY, Md., Dec. 23 (AP)Salisbury (Md.) State College officials named Joseph R. Ardolino today as the head lacrosse coach, following the resignation of Andy Jones. Ardolino, who was the offensive coordinator for Towson State's lacrosse team, assumes his duties immediately.

title: Laurie Kushel, Student, Is Wed to Charles Greene
description: Laurie P. Kushel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ely Kushel of Port Chester, N.Y., was married in New York yesterday in the Central Synagogue to Charles M. Greene, son of Mr. and Mrs. Myron H. Greene of New York. Rabbi Sheldon Zimmerman performed the ceremony, assisted by Cantor Jon Haddon.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: DIFFERENT PATH Experimental latitude is not new at the Theater for the New City, but fulllength opera is a departure for this Off Off Broadway showcase. The theater company has just moved to a more expansive heedquarters at 162 Second Avenue (at 10th Street) and is marking the occasion with performances or Atonements, a 90minute operatic work of village life in Poland, based on a story by Sholem Aleichem. Haim Elisha is the composer and Israel Eliraz is the lyricist. The latter collaborated on Joseph Tal's opera, Ashmedai, earlier this year at the New York City Opera Company.

title: A Winter's Tale
description: There are many kinds of ghosts. I dislike them all and fear some. There is one who comes to my bedroom in the darkest pit of night. Absolutely silent he is, but I am feel him moving through the room. Sometimes he stands directly beside the bed, making a cold spot in the darkness.

title: Blade Holder Protects Home Barbers
description: A.N. Spanel got a patent this week for a Barber King, a home hair cutter that is manufactured by Spanel International Ltd., a New York company of which he is president.

title: Eric Ashley SutcliffeSmith, 66; Was on London Stock Exchange
description: LONDON, Dec. 23Eric Ashley SutcliffeSmith, a former member of the London Stock Exchange, died on Tuesday at his home in Balcombe, in Sussex. He was 66 years old.

title: Bruins 6, Flyers 1
description: BOSTON, Dec. 23 (AP)  Bobby Schmautz scored three goals and the Boston Bruins extended their home unbeaten streak to 15 games tonight with a 61 victory over the Philadelphia Flyers.

title: Opera: A New, Paris Version of Tannhauser Introduced at Met
description: The story of the man who is seduced by the delights of the flesh and can be redeemed only by the love of a good woman, preferably a virgin, is told again and again in Western art. Goethe's Faust, Hogarth's Tom Rakewell and Wagner's Tannhuser all come in conflict with a society that views lust and spiritual love as opposite sides of the coin. The Metropolitan Opera's new production of Tannhuser introduced Thursday night, tells the ancient tale once more, and in magnificent fashion.

title: BIasts off East Coast Are Linked By Theory to Big Methane Bubbles
description: With sonic booms apparently eliminated, attention focused yesterday on the possibility that the rumbles and sharp blasts scard along the East Coast in recent weeks were explosions of huge methane gas bubbles erupting through one or more faults beneath the sea.

title: COMMON MARKET SEES MINIMUM STEEL PRICE
description: BRUSSELS, Dec. 23 (AP)A Common Market official predicted today that the organization would announce late next week a minimum import price for steel to protect jobs and business in the West European steel industry.

title: Six Die in North Carolina Fire
description: FALLSTON, N. C., Dec. 23 (UPI)Six person, five of them children, died today 1 in a fire that swept a small frame home where 14 persons, believed to be members of two separate families, were staying. Names of the victims were not immediately released. The children killed were five months, 4, 7, 8 and 10 years old. The adult victim was believed to be a 50yearold woman.

title: Dow Advances 8.06 to 829.87 in PreChristmas Rally
description: The stock market staged a rousing preChristmas rally yesterday to cap three days of steadily rising prices. Advances on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbered losers by a 104o4 ratio.

title: Rumor of Separation Of Rubinsteins Denied
description: PARIS, Dec. 23Aniela Rubinstein, the wife of the pianist Arthur Rubinstein, today denied newspaper reports that she and her husband were about to separate. Absolutely not, Mrs. Rubinstein said when asked about a rumor that her husband had become involved with another woman. This is not true. In America, there was some sort of gossip in a newspaper column, but it's not so. The Rubinsteins have been married for 45 years and plan to spend the holidays together in their Paris townhouse.

title: Judge Wins Right to Serve Past 70
description: In a decision that could have a broad effect on how the state courts are administered, a State Supreme Court justice in Manhattan ruled yesterday that a justice who reached the mandatory retirement age of 70 could stay on for at least two more years as long as he was physically and mentally fit.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: Liquor Ban Is Sought For Licenseless Club
description: The New York State Liquor Authority moved yesterday to stop Plato's Retreat from serving liquor because, it said, the club catered to swingers and encouraged sexual relations on its premises among its patrons.

title: EXPLODING PACKAGE KILLS MASSAGE PARLOR WOMAN
description: PITTSBURGH, Dec. 23 (UPI)A boobytrapped Christmas package sent to downtown massage parlor exploded today, killing the woman who opened and injuring three other persons.

title: Obituary 1 -- No Title
description: Drain;

title: Dollar Shows a Decline In Trading in Europe; Gold Rises to $162.12
description: LONDON, Dec 23 (AP)The dollar closed mostly down on European money markets today, and some dealers said President Carter's statements bolstering the dollar may not have the effect originally envisioned.

title: Another Skeleton Found in Florida
description: ZEPHYRHILLS, Fla., Dec. 23 (UP)The police said today that a skeleton found in an isolated rural area might be another victim of a killer suspected in the slaying of at least seven other women, most of them nude dancers or prostitutes with long blond or light brown hair.

title: Meadows Panel Urges Revision In Housing Plan
description: SECAUCUS, N.J., Dec. 23The agency that has already rejected plans for the first highrise residential construction in the Hackensack Meadowlands urged today that the entire concept of future housing development in the 1.9,730acre district be reevaluated and revised.

title: India Plans to Assist Small Business
description: NEW DELHI, Dec. 23The Indian Government announced today its longawaited industrial policy statement providing for a larger role in the economy for small scale and rural industries.

title: The WaterPollution Fight
description: With some grunting, groaning and argument, but with essentially unslackened impetus, the nation is moving into the second half of a decadelong effort to eradicate water pollution.

title: Fairfield 95, Montclair State 65
description: FAIRFIELD, Conn., Dec. 23 (AP)Toe DeSantis scored 32 points tonight to lead Fairfield to a 9565 victory over Montclair State.

title: WILLIAM H. BRISTOW, 68, A RETIRED EDUCATION AIDE
description: Dr. William Harvey Bristow, a retired director of curriculum research for the New York City Board of Education died Monday at the Christian Health Care Center in Wycoff, N.J. He was 68 years old.

title: Tourism Threatening a Malian Tribe's Splendid Isolation
description: SANGHA, MaliFrom the volcanic plain of the Niger River valley, the escarpment of Bandiagara rises 400 feet, an impenetrable curtain of rock. In the shimmering heat and dust the adobe dwellings of the Dogon people seem even smaller, almost an optical illusion, merging into the cliffside like miniature sand castles in a river bank.

title: Dual Purpose Funds.
description: Following Is a weekly listing of file unaudited net asset Onion applicable to the capital shares of dualpurpose Investment companies at close of business Friday. Also shown ore closing listed market prices or best overthecounter dealertodealer asked prices for the capital shares of each company with the percentage difference (discount or premium) between the net asset value and the asked.

title: Puerto Rican, in Jail for 23 Years, Refuses Freedom
description: MARION, Ill., Dec. 23 (AP)Raphael Cancel Miranda is an aging fighter a Puerto Rican war of independence who has spent half his life in Federal prison.

title: Letters
description: The bill to rescue Social Security accomplishes its goal of correcting the past fiscal irresponsibility of Congress by placing an inflationary and onerous burden on both business and worker alike. The present and future generations of workers will be especially burdened since they will in effect be paying for the overgenerous benefits provided in the past without hope of ever receiving an equitable return on the high contributions required by the present act.

title: HOW TO AID THE FUND
description: Checks should be made payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and sent to P.O. Box 5193, Church Street Sta. tion New York, N.Y. 10249 or to these agencies:

title: Nat'l Basketball Ass'n
description: AT MILWAUKEE

title: AUTO SALES DOWN 10.1% AT MIDMONTH IN FOURTH DECLINE
description: DETROIT, Dec. 23The nation's automobile industry, struggling to maintain the strong sales momentum built up earlier in the year, reported another decline today for the midDecember selling period.

title: Judge E. Talbot Callister, 52
description: SAN MARINO, Calif., Dec. 23 (UPI)Judge E. Talbot Callister of Superior Court, who put Patricia Hearst on five years probation last May for her part in a shooting at a sporting goods store, died at his home today of cancer. He was 52 years old.

title: In Bethlehem, W. Va., Coal in Stockings Holds No Awe
description: BETHLEHEM, W. Va., Dec. 21When Tim McDonald and his wife Andrea want to put the fear of Santa Claus in the minds of their three young children, they do not threaten that misbehavior will produce coal in stockings on Christmas morning.

title: Seven on Holiday Flight Are Killed By Crash into Oregon Mountains
description: EUGENE, Ore., Dec. 23 (UPI)A twinengine plane filled with young people on a holiday vacation trip crashed into the side of steep foothill of the Coast Range mountains last night killing all seven persons aboard, officials reported today.

title: A.F.C. Playoff Statistical Leaders
description: PASSING

title: Memories of an Original Bronco
description: The night before, a sudden snowstorm had swirled out of the Rockies and blanketed the Denver area with several inches. Until then warm weather had enabled the Broncos to practice in shorts. Now, in the freeze of the October snowfall, they needed sweatsuits. But the Broncos shivered in shorts that day because they had no sweatsuits.

title: MAN, 30, IS RULED OUT AS COAST STRANGLER
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec 23 (Reuters)The police today ruled out as a possible Hillside strangler suspect a 30yearold man who on Wednesday allegedly tried to pull a teenage girl into an auto looking like a black and white police car.

title: Biko's Family Demands Damages From 2 in South African Cabinet
description: JOHANNESBURG, Dec. 23 (AP)The family of Stephen Biko, the leading black activist who died in the custody of the security police Sept. 12, sent letters to two Government ministers today demanding monetary damages, according to the office of an attorney for the family.

title: RULE ON DIRECTORS IS ISSUED BY COURT
description: A Federal appeals court ruled in Manhattan yesterday that an antitrust law's regulation on interlocking directorates applies to corporations as well as to individual directors.

title: Around the Nation
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 23 (AP)A Federal judge ruled today that it was discriminatory and unlawful to segregate retarded persons in isolated institutions.

title: Coming to Town
description: In Washington, left, Santa Claus arrived at the White House on a skate board (to advertise a movie) ; In New Lebanon, N.Y. above, Santa drove the bus on last school day. And in West Chester, Pa., he was under a hair dryer getting ready.

description: International

title: Chromalloy Names Barta as Chairman
description: Wesley J. Barta was elected yesterday as chairman of the Chromalloy American Corporation, to succeed Joseph Friedman, who died on Tuesday. Mr. Barta had been administrative vice chairman and will continue to serve as chairman of the Chromalloy TransportMarine Company.

title: Colts Fans Are Cool to Crucial Contest Against Raiders
description: BALTIMORE, Dec. 23  It may not be winnertakeall when the Oakland Raiders play the Baltimore Colts here tomorrow in the opening round of the National Football League playoffs, but it certainly is losertakenone. The playoffs are a singleelimination tournament, and no team knows that better than the Raiders, the defending Super Bowl champions. They won it all last year, obviously because they didn't lose.

title: Sandra Fay Larson Married To John Randolph in Virginia
description: The marriage of Sandra Fay Larson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Merle E. Larson of Hampton, Va., to John Hamilton Randolph took place yesterday at the home of the bridegroom's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Edmund William Randolph 3d, in Yorktown, Va. The Rev. George Massay of the Grafton Christian Church performed the ceremony.

title: Notes on People
description: In Zurich, sources in the government said that Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn, the exiled dissident Soviet writer, owed Switzerland $250,000 in back taxes. He established Swiss residence when he was expelled from the Soviet Union in 1974 but since August 1976 has been living in seclusion in Vermont. The Swiss authorities consider the writer a taxable resident since he apparently failed to announce officially his change of residence. According to official figures, in 1974 Mr. Solzhenitsyn declared an income of $401,000 and capital of S2.3 million, most of the money coming from Western royalties for his books. Tax officials were said to be in touch with Mr. Solzhenitsyn's attorneys.

title: 5 Dominicans Die in Roof Collapse
description: SANTO DOMINGO Dominican Republic, Dec. 23 (UPI)Five workers were killed and eight injured today when the roof of a sports hall under construction collapsed in Santiago, the second largest city in the Dominican Republic, authorities here said. Several of the injured were said to be in serious condition.

title: Westway Report Estimates a Loss Of 10,000 New Jobs With TradeIn
description: Building the Westway could create up to 10,000 more jobs than would result from using the funds for that project to construct a more modest road and make major masstransit improvements, according to figures provided to Governor Carey and Mayorelect Edward L Koch by a special study panel.

title: Dr. David T. Zitner Weds Deborah Hart, A Medical Student
description: Deborah Montgomery Hart, a thirdyear student at Mount Sinai School of Medicine, and Dr. David Thomas Zitner, a resident in orthopedics at Mount Sinai, were married yesterday at the Harvard Club. Civil Court Judge Guy Gilbert Ribaudo performed the ceremony.

title: Tomjanovich Returning Home for Christmas
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., Dec. 23 (UPI)Rudy Tomjanovich of the Houston Rockets is doing very well after facial surgery and is to leave Centinela Hospital Medical Center tomorrow to fly home for Christmas.

title: Munson's Status Is Still Unclear
description: So what else is new? George Steinbrenner, alias the Eternal Optimist, says all is well with Thurman Munson, who, Steinbrenner says, will be hack with the Yankees as catcher and captain next season and for seasons to come. And what does Thurman Munson say?

title: News Summary
description: Prime Minister Menahem Begin's proposals for civil autonomy for Israelioccupied Arab terrorities of the West Bank and the Gaza Strip include a council composed of Israelis, Jordanians and Palestinian Arabs, according to sources in Mr. Begin's Likud bloc. This plan, which may be offered to President Anwar elSadat by Mr. Begin at their meeting in Ismailia, was discussed by Mr. Begin with the Foreign Affairs Committee of the Israeli Parliament, as well as with his party. [Page 1, Col. 6.]

title: NeimanMarcus Flies $1 Million to Customer
description: DALLAS, Dec. (23)(UPI)A chartered jet loaded with $1 million worth of Christmas gifts streaked across the blue Texas sky on the way to New Orleans yesterday, its cargo all bound for one very rich woman.

title: Memories: VILands of the Free
description: OVING, EnglandOne remarkable feature of the twogeneration period covered by my working years was the creation of new states, most of them backward and weak. There are, of course, exceptions to this rulelike reborn India, Israel, Pakistan. Vietnam. But the majority are helpless. Some, like the Seychelles or Maldives, have less claim to United Nations recognition than Monaco. Vatican City, Liechtenstein. San Marino and Andorra, none of which are represented at the world parliament.

title: CONFEREES DEADLOCK LEAVES ENERGY BILL HANGING IN BALANCE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23With the fate of the President's energy package hanging in the balance, a HouseSenate conference committee considering the legislation is stalemated as a result of failing to resolve the natural gas issue this week, according to Congressional sources.

title: G.I.'s Trapped Two Weeks in a Box
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 23(AP)Two AWOL soldiers who stowed away, on a WestGerman cargo ship were hospitalized in fair condition today after spending two weeks, apparently without food or water,in a cargo container carried by the ship from Europe.

title: Donations to Neediest Cases Fund  Push Total Past the $600,000 Mark
description: The 66th annual appeal of The New York tithes Neediest Cases Fund pissed the $600,000 mark yesterday with the receipt of $50,472.63 from 249 donors. The overall figure for the campaign, which is ending its third week and will continue through February, now stands at $630.837.14 from 3,156 contributors.

title: U.S. URGES FLEXIBILITY
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23The United States has urged President Anwar elSadat of Egypt and Prime Minister Menahem Begin of Israel to show the utmost sympathy for each other's political problems and to approach their meeting in Ismailia, Egypt, on Sunday with as openminded an attitude as possible to avoid setting back the prospects for an overall Middle East peace.

title: Unions Seeking Unity for Talks With New York
description: Paced with New York City's fiscal constraints and the prospect of difficult contract negotiations, city unions are talking about a jointbargaining and mutualassistance pact as they begin to press for what they call real wage increases next year.

title: Philippe Etter, 86, of Switzerland; Minister of Interior for 25 Years
description: GENEVA, Dec. 23Philippe Etter, who was Switzerland's Minister of the Interior for 25 years, died today in Bern. He was 86 years old.

title: Kennedy Going to China
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (UPI)Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts will leave tomorrow on a Christmas goodwill mission to China and Japan, accompanied by members of his family and an adviser on SinoAmerican affairs. The adviser is Prof. Jerome Cohen of the Harvard Law School. Others in the party will be his wife, Joan, and their children; Kara, Edward Jr. and Patrick; his sisters. Eunice Shriver, Patricia Lawford and Jean Smith. and a niece and a nephew, John F. Kennedy's daughter, Caroline, and Robert's son Michael.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In an art review In the Weekend section yesterday of the Kornblee Gallery exhibition at 20 West 57th Street, the name of the artist was incorrectly given. Polly Hope is showing her needleworked pictures at the gallery through Jan. 18.

Eric Orme. assistant director of the Office of Emergency Services, said about 6,000 residences were damaged in three counties, causing $S million damage, while 2,000 businesses were damaged at a cost of $2 million.

He planned to return to Washington in a week to 10 days.

The program included three works for this somewhat unusual but mellow combination: Beethoven's Trio in B flat (Op. 11), Bruch's Three Pieces (Op. 83) and Brahms's Trio in Aminor (Op. 114).

title: 'The Choirboys,' Film Version Of Novel About Police, Opens
description: "The Choirboys," which opened yesterday at the Cinerama Two and other theaters, is Robert Aldrich's screen adaptation of Joseph Wambaugh's best-selling novel about the private panics of a bunch of Los Angeles cops of assorted eccentricities. After dealing day and night with the city's flotsam, Mr. Wambaugh tells us, these policemen, neither brighter nor more sensitive than any other group of men, survive only with the help of booze and pills and a see-through cynicism that is worn as if it were plastic rain-gear.Mr. Wambaugh's episodic novel is tough and funny and comes alive with the unexpected details of a forlorn truth. The movie, which Mr. Aldrich directed from a screenplay by Christopher Knopf, is cheap and nasty without having any redeeming vulgarity and absolutely no conviction of truth. What went wrong?The material seems to be the sort that would perfectly suit Mr. Aldrich ("The Dirty Dozen," "The Grissom Gang," "Ulzana's Raid"), a man whose darker humors match those of the novelist, yet there's little evidence of that here. Further, the movie is such a stylistic and narrative mess one suspects it was originally shot to be one of those six-hour "television novels" and then cut down to its present two-hour running time for a theatrical play-off.Though it's the kind of film that's designed for people who don't read much, it can be followed only by someone who has some familiarity with the book. However, anyone who liked the book will probably be appalled by the movie. Which is about as close as "The Choirboys" ever gets to "Catch 22."The title, for those who came in late, is derived from the impromptu, late-night, booze-and-broads blow-outs that Mr. Wambaugh's cops hold in L.A.'s MacArthur Park after getting off duty. The sessions, which the cops call choir practice, are epic benders that have the effect of decompressing the men's psyches. They sing, fight, get sick, play cruel practical jokes on one another and, eventually, return to the surface of the earth.In Mr. Wambaugh's novel, the reader is able to understand the manic intensity of the choirboys at these parties, having been given some idea of the grubby violence of their working lives. The film attempts to treat their working lives mostly in comic terms, even though what happens is not especially comic, so that their off-duty behavior has no more meaning than would the off-duty behavior of a bunch of loutish television repairmen.Among the actors in the huge cast, some of the more prominent are Charles Durning, as the father-figure cop; Perry King, as an Ivy League sort, who turns out to be fatally effete; Tim McIntire, a red-neck, bigoted sadist; Randy Quaid, as "the kid," and Burt Young, who is funny and spirited as the vice-squad chief whom everyone mistakes for the station-house janitor.

title: Aqueduct Racing
Movie: Man's Inhumanity to Son
description: "Padre Padrone," which was shown at the New York Film Festival, was reviewed on Sept. 25 by Janet Maslin. Following are excerpts from the review. The picture opened yesterday at the Cinema 2 Theater, Third Avenue and 60th Street.Paolo and Vittorio Taviani, the two brothers who wrote and directed "Padre Padrone," say they first got the idea for their film from a newspaper clippingabout a shepherd who had lived in almost complete isolation in the hills of Sardinia until he turned 20, then went on to become a professor of linguistics and write a book about his experience.When the brothers learned more about the man's story, they began to perceive him not as an unsocialized innocent  la Truffaut's "The Wild Child" or Herzog's "The Mystery of Kasper Hauser," but rather as a more conventional figure whose character was shaped through his battle with a single huge impediment. The obstacle in "Padre Padrone" is not the shepherd's estrangement, or even his monumental loneliness, but rather his terrifying and tyrannical father.The film's beginning, and its most stirring segment, presents a 6-year-old boy being taken out of school and sent off to tend a flock on a desolate, ruggedly beautiful mountainside. His father, who beats young Gavino with objects as stridently symbolic as a stick and a dead snake, inducts the boy into his new way of life in the cruelest manner possible.There are isolated instances of the father's tenderness, when he shares his perceptions of nature with his son and when he realizes, after the boy bursts into tears and then faints from fright and exhaustion, that the torture has gone far enough. But most of the father's behavior borders on sadism, despite the economic necessity in which it is rooted. So the father remains as inconsistent and irrational to the viewer as he might seem to a small child.Years later, when Gavino begins bridling under his father's authority and angling for a chance to escape, his battle is fought along more familiar lines and his father seems a less formidable adversary. Gavino enlists in the army and travels to the Italian mainland, where he begins to educate himself and delight in the precise meaning of words. The title which means "My Father, My Master," also refers to Gavino's sheer exultation in the nuances of his new vocabulary.By the time Gavino returns to Sardinia, his father has begun to seem smaller, pettier, a bit more pathetic in his stubbornness. Gavino finally wins his freedom, but at a terrible cost: He is forced to witness the spectacle of his father's defeat and humiliation. "Padre Padrone" is stirringly affirmative. It's also a bit simple: The patriarchal behavior of Gavino's father is so readily accepted as an unfathomable given constant that the film never offers much insight into the man or the culture that fostered him. Intriguingly aberrant behavior is chalked up to tradition, and thus robbed of some of its ferocity. But the film is vivid and very moving, coarse but seldom blunt, and filled with raw landscapes that underscore the naturalness and inevitability of the father-son rituals it depicts.The Taviani brotheres have made other films, but this is the first of their efforts to receive wide international exposure and acclaim. "Padre Padrone," which was the grand prize winner at Cannes this year, should serve less as a debut than as an introduction.

Drawn by reindeer, you sit on straw, and as the sledge glides along, you feel every bump and hollow in the frozen ground. Your legs, hanging over the side, are the brakes, and you must be able to roll free of the wreckage if the sledge tips overas David, my husband, discovered on five occasions. Last April, David and I, eager to prolong our winter, called Finnair and booked a reindeer safari through the frozen wilderness of Finnish Lapland,

But she was looking at a palm tree and we were being brushed by a dnowflake, so there were no apologies. title: SCIENCE FICTION
description: Someday an enterprising editor is going to bring out an anthology entitled Great Beginnings of Science Fiction Novels. It is a sad but instructive fact that the first few chapters are often the best part of longer s.f. works. Imaginative writers seem to have no trouble introducing human beings with extra ordinary powers or problems, fascinating aliens, earthshaking technological advances, societies buil on thoughtprovoking premises, and so on. But after the introduction comes the hard work of unfolding a story, fleshing out characters, shading in the cultural detailsand all too often the promise of the first few chapters remains unfulfilled.

No other place in the world, with the possible exception of Chelm in Poland, had as many philosophers per square millimeter.

He has taken the latest in microcomputer technology and matched it with telephones, typewriters, facsimile machines and FM radio signals. After two years, his TDX Systems Inc. is doing a $10million-a-year business.

title: Family Romance, With Music
description: IN the course of tendering the customary bouquet of acknowledgements, Maynard Solomon thanks his preliminary readers fur, among other things, their extremely lively hostilities, which confirmed my feeling (and my hope) that I had written a book that might spark some small controversies. I don't doubt that there will be more hostilities and controversies (the latter not necessarily so small either), though I myself may not give Mr. Solomon much satisfaction in this regard: To me this is an admirable book, bold and exciting, revealing, moving, and one whose appearance we shall come to see as a landmark in Beethoven scholarship and interpretation.

In the second game at 9 Princeton plays Alabama. The championship game is at 9 P.M. Thursday after the thirdplace game at 7.

title: Starting With Paul Revere
description: Last year, to celebrate the 75th anniversary of its founding, the Society of Illustrators selected over 850 examples of work by the best American illustrators since the birth of the nation for an exhibition at the NewYork Historical Society. Now the works from the show have been collected in a book, 200 YEARS OF AMERICAN ILLUSTRATION (Random House, 939.95), which includes a history of illustration by Henry C. Pitz and an introduction by Norman Rockwell. The pictures350 them in full colororiginally appeared books, magazines, newspapers and advertising, and run a gamut of subjects from Early American (Paul Revere's 1776 engraving, Boston Massacre) to Countercultural (the Hildebrandt twins 1976 J.R.R. Tolkien Calendar). In between can be found the work of Howard Pyle, Thomas Nast, N.C. Wyeth, as well as the eclectic work of today's artists, as Immediate as yesterday's magazine or news-

title: Mime: Morse
description: Amid the torrent of seasonal programs the Richard Morse Mime Theater has put together a suitable selection of skits and songs that doesn't tax the attention span of any child or the intelligence of adult spectators. The theme or Gifts is Christmas observance from the medieval tale of The Juggler of Notre Dame to a slightly punchy chorus, rendering the Hallelujah Chorus with more physical verve than musical phrasing. The company presented the work Friday evening at its theater, 224 Waverly Place.

description: New York State has won an unenviableand jobdamagingtax distinction: It takes a greater proportion of its individual residents money in state and local taxes than any other state, according to a labor union analysis.

The victory in the first round of the National Football League playoffs sent Oakland into the American Conference title game against Denver Jan. 1.

title: Mill Neck Mansion Is Scene Of Hair
description: ON LOCATION IN MILL NECK NICE place, a visitor says. A prop man replies: When I'm king, this is where I'll live. They are referring to the Fordyce house, a mansion with more than 25 rooms, designed and built in 1936 by prominent architect, the late Henry Corse, who also built homes in Oyster Bay Cove and on Fifth Avenue in Man-

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW
description: In 1977 modern architecture was declared dead. I suppose that ranks as the event of the year. The publishers lists were heavy with requiems and manifestos. Conspicuously buried by, among others, Peter Blake and Brent Brolin, in volumes of mea culpa and j'accuse, the modern movement was also laid uneasily to rest in seminars and symposia and the better architectural schools. The vacuum is promptly being filled by something called, for lack of a better term, postmodernism.

title: Moscow Police Foil Vigil Honoring Jews In Hijacking Trial
description: MOSCOW. Dec. 24At least 16 Jewish dissidents were placed under house arrest today and five others were detained by the police as the authorities thwarted plans for a demonstration in downtown Moscow.

description: Dear North Carolina:

title: Christmas for Eddie
description: Bundled against the cold, he sat in a heated booth at Memorial Stadium in Baltimore yesterday, watching his Colts play football. And watching himself. I have to keep my cool in order not to increase my heart rate, says Eddie Block, the Colts 66-year-old trainer. I think I'm managing admirably. At least

title: Pop Music: Of Women, Country and The Punks
description: The year 1977 in popular music wasn't the most riveting within memory. Most of the trends that one could identify were developments of things that had gotten underway before, and a number of the field's biggest names laid low for one reason or another. In retrospect, 1977 may be seen as a year in which the excessive mellowness that has defined the decade began to shift back in a more exhilarating direction. But if the poles have been reversed, we may have to wait until 1978 or 1979 for the energy to flow full force.

title: Sadat Says He Wanted Peace Role For 5 Nations of Security Council
description: President Anwar elSadat of Egypt said that he had originally envisioned breaking the Middle East stalemate with a meeting involving not only Egypt and Israel but also the five permanent members of the United Nations Security Council, and Syria, Jordan, Lebanon and the Palestinians.

title: RUTH W. WHALEY, 76, LAWYER AND CITY AIDE
description: Ruth Whitehead Whaley, the secretary of New York City's Board of Estimate from 1951 until her retirement in 1973 and the first black woman to engage in active law practice in New York State, died Friday at Flower Fifth Avenue Hospital. She was 76 years old and lived at 2171 Madison Avenue.

description: HARTSDALE

title: A Student Views Press Freedom
description: THE age of overt public school censorship in Westchester County has, for the most part, come to an end. After a decade of court decisions in support of a free scholastic press and increased student nterest in journalism, most of Westchester's student newspapers have broken free of domination by school administrators and faculty advisers.

title: Jerilyn Rosenblatt Fiancee
description: Betty Rosenblatt of White Plains and Charles Rosenblatt of Montreal, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jerilyn Rosenblatt, to John De Rosa Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. De Rosa of White Plains. The couple are graduates of the Westchester Community College in Valhalla, N.Y. Mr. De Rom. is a student at Mercy College in White Plains.

title: Running Out Of Energy
description: When reasonable people sit down and reason together, they should be able to think up solutions even for unreasonable problems. That does not hold true, however, for the Congressional conference on energy, where the very definition of reasonableness is in dispute. As a result, the year will end not only without a national energy program, but with serious questions about when there will be one.

title: Abortion Cutoff Causing Hardship For Poor Women Around Country
description: HOUSTONThe war over public financing for abortions has reached a sort of holiday truce, but both sides will start firing aaain early next year.

title: Fusina Threatened With Death
description: TEMPE, Ariz., Dec. 24Chuck Fusing, Penn State's quarterback the last two seasons, has received threats against his life for the third time in the last 14 months. The most recent threat came less than two weeks ago and is on the minds of coaches and players as Penn State prepares to meet Arizona State in the Fiesta Bowl football game tomorrow.

title: Colgate Coach Struggles To Rebuild Hockey Team
description: The game had been over for 10 minutes or so, and the overworked voice of Terry Slater, the Colgate University hockey coach, was beginning to return. Anticipating the question, he asked it and answered it.

title: O'Neill's Poet
description: Had Eugene O'Neill been able to conquer the illness that so cruelly ended his playwriting career nearly 10 years before his death in 1953, A Touch of the Poet, which opens Wednesday on Broadway, might have been part of an epic cycle of plays embracing 200 years of American history. By 1934, with his great trilogy, Mourning Becomes Electra, behind him, O'Neill had begun to outline a series of four or five plays that would follow a single American family from 1857 to modern times. The cycle was to be called The Calms of Capricorn.

title: Art and Scholarship in a Democracy
description: Representative John Brademas played a twoday stand in New York City earlier this month, part of a national tour to churn up support for a White House conference on the arts and the humanities in 1979. The settings were appropriate: for the humanities, the New York Public Library; for the arts, the Jui!Hard School at Lincoln Center. Public officials, artists and scholars came forward to support the idea of a conference and to suggest the subjects that it might cover.

title: World News Briefs
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 24 (AP)Vietnam will release three repentant Americans, captured Oct. 12 aboard a yacht Vietnam said was in its territorial waters, the official news agency announced today. It was not known when the three would be freed.

title: C.I.A. Contacts With Reporters
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24The situation is a familiar one for American correspondents abroad: a fastbreaking newa story, possibly in the midst of a war; conflicting claims from both sides; no sure information on what is really, happening.

title: Probing the Brzezinski Factor
description: WASHINGTONAfter almost a year on the job, Zbigniew Brzezinski, the National Security Adviser to the President, remains a controversial and somewhat enigmatic figure. Although he has emerged as a key foreign policy strategist and, through day-to-day contact with Cabinet officials, is said to have had voice in every important policy decision to date, his impact less than many predicted before Inauguration Day.

title: Crossing Old Boundaries to New Frontiers
description: Continuing the momentum of Middle East negotiations, the leaders of Egypt and Israel were to meet today near the Egyptian town of Ismailia on the Suez Canal. Unlike their first encounter in Jerusalem, where the ceremony of the visit was the substance, the second meeting of Anwar elSadat and Menahem Begin was to be all substance and almost no ceremony.

title: Joanne Dorothy Balfour Fiancee of James Morgan

Sampson of Hamburg, N.Y. The future bride, whose father is senior associate judge of the New York State Court of Appeals, is a daughter also of the late Anastasia Gawinski Jasen.

Sure enough, in the morning the oats set out for his reindeer were gone and so were the cookies and cider set out for him. But the gifts were under the tree and the stockings hung full from the fireplace shelf.

title: A Call to Order
description: HARTFORD CANDIDATES often run for public office on a pledge to run the government on a more businesslike basis. It is a campaign slogan as good as any. Unfortunately, this campaign rhetoric is generally just that. Attacking waste and inefficiency has come to be a commonplace electiontime maneuver.
