title: PEACE CORPS: ALIVE BUT NOT SO WELL
description: It is 7:50 on a crisp, winter morning in Washington. Samuel Winfred Brown Jr., political organizer for Eugene McCarthy in New Hampshire in 1968, antiwar activist, former State Treasurer of Colorado and slayer of Establishment dragons, is at work in a large, corner office two blocks from the White House. Although his hair and mustache are still shaggy and full, his conversation mildly irreverent, the 34-year-old Brown has unmistakably Joined the ranks of the Establishment he battled in earlier years.

title: President Eanes Seeks Stability for a Wobbly Portugal
description: LISBONMany promiset.Eanes delivers. On the walls of Lisbon's cobbled streets, such posters from the June 1976 presidential election campaign have suddenly become a challenge to Antonio Ramalho Eanes, the arbiter and guarantor of Portugal's young democracy.

title: Who Cares If the Dollar Sinks?
description: The risks are enormous, the pace franticand the stakes beyond the ken of the average person. In the month of April alone, 44 American banks traded more than $106 billion in foreign exchange, and the action in London is estimated to be half again as big.

title: When Literary Lights Turn On the TV
description: In the early 1960's, William Faulkner refused to allow a radio or television set in his home; yet, he would arrive punctually at a neighbor's house every Sunday night to watch the NBC series Car 54, Where Are You? He made no social engagements for Sunday evenings that might keep him from his rendezvous with Tooty and Muldoon. When his daughter happened to mention to him Henry James's The Turn of the Screw, Faulkner smiled and said, That would make a great plot for Car 54, Where Are You?

title: DELBELLO PRESSES FOR PUBLIC UTILITY
description: Consultants Tell Him Westchester Has the Legal Right to Take Over Con Eu's Distribution System

title: The Command of Bethlehem
description: Deep down, in the Grotto, a silver star marks the spot from which the love and lore of Christianity radiate. At this era's street level, in Manger Square, the Moslem vendors hawk their souvenirs in olivewood and pearl, jostling for position among the crowds that sustain them. Atop the Church of the Nalivity, Jewish lads tug idly at their slung firearms and scan the ocher hills that command our history. What is sovereign there in Bethlehem? And who?

title: CHESS
description: It was Wilhelm Steinitz, the world champion from 1866 to 1899, who introduced the systematic pawnsnatching, hardbitten defensive style. The man just did not believe that an opponent's pawn sacrifice could be sound.

title: Biorhythms: Fiction Or Fact?
description: What is the difference between winners and losers? Human performance is what sports are all about, and often the margin of victory is slight. Athletes are so highly trained and tuned that they produce close to the limits of athletic ability. As a result, the key difference between winners and losers often is attributed to psychological factors.

title: A Correction
description: In The New York Times yearend sports review, it was erroneously reported that Jim McElreath, a 49-yearold racing car driver, had been killed in a car crash. Jim McElreath Jr., 23, the son was killed in a sprintcar race at Winchester, Ind., on Oct. 16 of this year. The New York Times regrets the error.

title: TV VIEW
description: Selecting the best (and worst) from a year of television inevitably means dealing with a jumble everything from major productions to brief images, plucked from a gargantuan mass of material. Rudimentary order demands the use broad categories to serve as catchall bins. And, needless to say, the choices are purely subjective.

title: PEOPLE
description: In July 1944 Marriner Stoddard Eccles, then chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, received a memo from President Roosevelt advising him to cease his 10-yearlong plea for a streamlining of governmental bank regulation. Thirtyodd yeats later, Mr. Eccles's cause was dusted off and taken up by a successor to the Fed chairmanship, Arthur F. Burns.

title: American Poets
description: DITORS and other persons in authority favor the sort of book that Five Temperaments announces itself to be in the introduction, a book with a thesis. But about the art of poetry there are many more good answers than there are good questions.

title: LETTERS TO THE WESTCHESTER EDITOR
Suzanne Williamson Married to Peter Pollak
description: Suzanne Williamson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles G. Williamson of New York, was married yesterday in Savannah, Ga., to Peter Anderson Pollak. operations manager of the Savannah office of Norton Lilley & Company, the shipping concern. He is the son of Ber- nard E. Pollak Jr. of Hilton Head Island. S. C., and the late Brenda Anderson Pollak. The Rev. William Ralston performed the ceremony in St. John's Episcopal Church.

title: Before Overtime, a Wild 15 Minutes

Of these 24 points, 21 were scored within 2 minutes 34 seconds of playing time. Why?

title: Suit Against Minority Contract Law Rejected by a Judge in Manhattan
description: A judge has dismissed a challenge by a construction group to a 1977 law requiring that at least 10 percent of each Federal grant for local public works projects in a $4 billion program be allocated to minority business enterprises.

He and his partner, Mike Passell of Dallas, arrived in ridiculous contract of five notrump instead of a normal contract of four hearts. Their contract came home thanks to a subtle defensive error and lucky lie of the cards, and they gained points because the normal contract failed in the replay.

description: The final days of 1977 have taken on Jolly look, for the nation in general and the world of business and finance in particular. Despite widespread uneasiness over high unemployment and inflation, over the huge trade deficit and the plight of the dollar, the American economy is winding up the year in a crescendo of rising production, employment, incomes and consumer spending. And last week brought a rash of positive developments.

title: Space Candidate's Daughter Pleased
description: HUNTSVILLE, Ala., Dec. 24 (UPI)Ann Whitaker, a 38-year-old physicist who may become the first American woman to fly in space, says her 7-yearold daughter thinks the prospects of Mrs. Whitaker blasting off 'is just great. Mrs. Whitaker was among six finalists named Thursday for one of two seats that, will be allotted to scientists aboard the first spacelab which will be carried into orbit in the belly of the space shuttle in 1980.

description: SOUTH SAN FRANCISCO, Calif.When Harold Nizamian talks about the monkey trial, he dosn't have evolution of the species in mind.

description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 24 (AP)Bernard King, a former University of Tennessee basketball star, has given the college a color television set to replace one that the campus police said King damaged earlier this year.

title: Can Regulators Keep Track of 1,000 New Substances a Year?; Chemicals in Search of a Solution
description: WASHINGTONAll this year the American public has been bombarded with cancer alarms from Federal agencies. Saccharin has been linked to bladder cancer, DES to breast cancer, carbon tetrachloride to liver cancer, Xrays to thyroid cancer, drugs to leukemia, fats to colon cancer, arsenic to skin cancer. This month alone cancer has been tied to hair dyes, lipstick colorings and pesticides.

title: For Retailers, One of the Best Christmas Seasons Ever
description: It isn't often that Christmas Eve comes on a Saturday night. Last week did, thus giving retailers around the nation the chance to cash in on the climatic day of the season on what is in any event the best day of the week.

title: Juan Velasco Alvarado, 67, Dies; Was Peru's President for 7 Years
description: Gen. Juan Velasco Alvarado, the former President of Permu whose military government carried out economic and social reforms unusual in a Latin American nation, died yesterday, the military hospital in Lima announced. He was 67 years old.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: While thousands of other Jews went up in smoke across the way, so close the stench always filled her nostrils, Fania Fenelon sang Madame Butterfly for the Auschwitz staff. She and a few other women who performed in the death camp's orchestra lived apart from the other prisoners in relative safety and comfort. Frotn January to November 1944, this pretty and tough halfJewish former Parisian chanteuse prostituted music and, some would say, herself in order escape the ovens and to continue receiving mediocre but minimally nourishing food. Eventually, she was sent on to BergenBelsen and drank her own urine. the SS had cut off all wateruntil the British Army

title: Tales, Cloth Spun As in Days of Old
description: FOR centuries, the art of making clothes and blankets has been passed on from parent to child as casually as family recipes. Now, after decades of machinemade sweaters and prepackaged foods, Westchester residents, like Sharon Moskow and Sylvia Thorne, are seeking out the familycrafts tradition once again.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: WASHING machines, clothes dryers, refrigerators and other household appliances come with tough, bakedon finishes that normally require no attention other than periodic washing. title: French Win, but Nile Regatta Founders
description: LUXOR, Egypt, Dec. 24The French national team, winner of the 1976 Nile rowing festival, picked up where it left off last year and won the first of this year's two races.

title: Many Roosevelt I. Shops Still Empty
description: The 18-month-old tramway to Roosevelt Island has an attentiongrabbing view of the Queensborough Bridge and the Manhattan skyline, but jaded residents of the island don't always bother to look. They spend the three and a half minutes over the East River juggling shopping bags and packages from Manhattan stores.

title: Jane Hickey Fiancee Of Mason S. Sexton
description: Jane Buckman Hickey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence F. Hickey of New York, plans to be married Feb. 4 to Mason Speed Sexton, son of May Speed Sexton of Plandome, L. I., and Michael James Sexton of Denver.

title: Begin's Flexibility Is Both Popular and Perplexing
description: JERUSALEMIn the last several weeks, events in the Middle East have moved at such a dizzying pace that words like unprecedented, historic, and epochal have become shopworn. But even those becoming accustomed the feast of firsts in this part of the world were taken a bit aback last week when Prime Minister Menahem Begin received the adulation of some doveslong his foesand the criticism of some hawkslong the bedrock of his support.

title: Christina Sedewick Welch Engaged
description: The engagemcnt of Christina Sedgwick Welch to John Peter Matthews has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Richard E. Welch Jr. of Easton. Pa., parents of the future bride. Her fiancd is the son of Mayor and Mrs. Byron J. Matthews of Newburyport, Mass.

title: Top of the Line In Magic Carpets
description: In the chill dawn this Thursday, President Carter is scheduled to board the ultimate magic carpet and, without so much as a whisper to the wind, be borne to Europe and the Middle East. Not even Solomon's legendary green silk carpet, which bore his throne and entourage aloft, could compare to the luxury of its modern counterpart: Air Force One.

title: . . .But Not at the Seminary
description: PRINCETON

title: Late Spree Tops Steelers, 3421, in Denver
description: DENVER, Dec. 24The unforeseen glory of the Denver Broncos will continue at least until New Year's Day. By beating the Pittsburgh Steelers, 3421, before 75,011 spectators in Mile High Stadium today, the Broncos earned the right to play the Oakland Raiders here nest Sunday for the American Conference championship.

title: Obtaining Cash Away From Home
description: Nearly everyone who travels extensively has had the harrowing experience of running low on cash. While more and more expenditures these days can be charged on credit cards, many cannot, such as small purchases, taxi fares, tips to porters and the like. A credit card may be accepted by Harrod's in London, but it is rarely useful in the bazaars of India or North Africa where not all bargains are inexpensive.

title: Ground Pines Capture the Yuletid e Spirit
description: Children may call them little Christmas trees, especially the tree clubmosses or ground pines. Where plentiful, adults use these small evergreens to wind into wreaths, ropes and swags for holiday decorations. Related to the ferns, the Lycopodiums or clubmosses are lowgrowing perennials with small pointed leaves arranged in rows or whorls, the leaves sometimes appearing almost like scales.

title: FollowUp on the News
description: It was a news item with many of the touches that editors look for in a bright little featurewellknown names, glitter, subdued humor and suspense. It went this way last Oct. 22:

title: Arrivals &
description: President Carter leaves on Thursday for his first extended trip abroad, to six countries in nine days. This is a scaleddown version of a journey that was to have taken place last month and carried him to nine countries in 11 days. What follows are some of the main points of interest in the President's journey as his national security advisers might see them.

title: Ski Business Is Booming After Reports of Snow
description: This ski season could well become one unlike most other ski seasons. On the eve of Christmas area operators, innkeepers and skishop owners across the United States were nearly all reporting toplevel business.

title: RobberySlaying Leader Gets Life
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 24 (UPI) Howard Willard's venture into multimilliondollar theft and murder brought him a life sentence yesterday. Mr. Wiilard, 3S years old, was convicted Dec. 6 in the S4 million robberyslaying in May of Marjorie Jackson, a grocery store heiress. He was accused of being the ringleader of the gang that pillaged and set fire to her home and took S4 million of S9 million in cash she kept at the horn and shot her to death.

title: Some Mail Recovered ln Jet Crash on Peak
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Dec. 24 (AP)Postal inspectors recovered 12 pounds of Christmas mad lost in the crash of a United Airlines cargo jet near here, but 100 times as much was left buried on a snowcovered mountain until the spring thaw.

title: 8 Seized at U.S. Embassy in Spain
description: MADRID, Dec. 24 (Reuters)Eight demonstrators were arrested today after they chained themselves to the gates of the United States Embassy here to demand freedom for Rudolf Hess, the jailed former Nazi leader. The protesters said they were part of a Christmas campaign throughout Europe on his behalf. A petition for the former Nazi's release will be delivered to the Soviet Embassy, which has rejected efforts to free him from Berlin's Spandau Prison.

title: Liberty, Equality But No...
description: STORRS MORE than seven years ago the fraternities and sororities here at the University of Connecticut were forced to move offcampus because of their selectivemembership practices. As a result of the administration's policy, more than 30 Greekletter groups disbanded.

title: Princeton: Activism Is Reborn
description: PRINCETON

title: The Traditional Music of Ireland
description: Up until a few years ago it would have been a rare American, or Irish-American, who wouldn't tell you that Irish music was MacNamara's Band or Danny Boy or, God forbid, When Irish Eyes are Smiling. The true Irish music had been long forgotten on these shores, stirred into the melting pot with other ingredients of Irish culture.

title: Design
description: Combining function and fantasy is never easy, and when it's to be done for the severest of critics one's own child  it requires both ingenuity and imagination. Michelle Gamm Clifton used both when she designed and made the barnyard bed /playroom for her son, Alexander. I think we should make what we live with fun, says Mrs. Clifton, an artist who has also created jungle, garden and circus rooms for adults as well as children. But everything is also practical. The cowcouch is made of hardwearing vinyl and the boardandbatting and tile roof of the barn is made of triwall cardboard that, says Mrs. Clifton, is virtually childproof.

title: The Nation

description: MELVI NDavid George.. Wife ES telle, brother Hyman and sister, Pauline Kovalsky and Gertrude Schechter and families sincerely thank their friends end relatives for their kind expressions of sympathy in their recent bereavement.

title: ART
description: PORT WASHINGTON THE current exhibition at the Port Washington Library powerfully demonstrates that photography is one of the most vital media in the arts today and that is being used as a means of forceful expression by some of the most gifted younger people for its experimental, esthetic and emotional possibilities.

title: San Franciscans Gird for Car Test
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 21 (AP)Thousands of San Franciscans will start the new year with a $10 chance in a sort of parking lottery that innovators hope will increase spaces for neighborhood residents and encourage out-of-towners to carpool.

title: Battered Beirut Tryirig to Revive Christmas Spirit
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 24The scene is a rooftop chimney, where a terrified Santa Claus is halted in his mission of joy by Arab peacekeeping troops with automatic rifles demanding his identity papers.

The wedding is planned for Feb. 26, Dr. Nearenherg is an anesthesiologist on the staff of Booth Menvirial Medical Center of Hushing Ouerms. The future bridegroom's father is president of Bendel Office Furniture Company of New York.

title: INTERVIEW

title: A New Climate Exists, but Enforcement Is a Question
description: One of the Government's toughest regulators, an official whose name is shuddered at by businessmen whose dealings skirt the law, was talking to a friend about the new law that calls for fines of up to SI million for American corporations that bribe foreign officials. I think it's going to be very, very difficult he said, for them to do the kinds of things they did before.

title: MuseumsChristmas Past and Present
description: MOST of the museums throughout the state are warmly aglow and bedecked with the spirit of Christmas. They have ladorned their walls with glittering art works celebrating the holiday season, turned their halls into festive Yuletide showcases with Christmas trees and creches and made their display areas into playlands for children and adults.

title: Bradley M. Taylor to Marry Lieut. Lynn Marie Jennings

title: Nassau Acts to Lure FilmMakers
description: MILL NECK IN an attempt to upgrade a declining economy and provide more permanent employment, Nassau County is embarked on a determined venture to lure the film industry here. In its courtship, Nassau is citing its natural resources: varied topography, the faces of real people and proximity to the mecca of creativity, Manhattan. The county recognizes that it must deal with the attitudes of a changing industry, wherein more and more actors, producers, writers and directors are electing to live in New York.

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY
description: NOW that we live in a house in the New Jersey suburbs, Christmas is an easier time. Windows and doors are more personal, with wreaths and fake spray snow and cards strung on thread. What I mean is: You know which window is yours because it's on your house.

title: The Main Duty of a LameDuck Mayor Is to Say Goodbye
description: There was a goingaway party one evening last week for Sidney J. Frigand, Mayor Beame's press secretary, and the Mayor and his wife, Mary, lingered at a table with reporters who were reminiscing and telling jokes. In the past four years, Mr. Beanie has seldom done that, preferring instead to drop in at social functions and leave as soon as possible, his tolerance for small talk being practically nil.

title: James Mackie Fleishman, at 79; A Player and Official in Baseball
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Dec. 24 (UPI)-Funeral services will be held Tuesday for James Mackie Fleishman, former baseball player and president of the Northwest League, who died Thursday at his home. He was 79 years old.

title: Nassau Paints Attractive Picture of Itself for Film Makers
description: MILL NECK, an attempt to upgrade a declining economy and provide more permanent employment, Nassau County is embarked on a determined venture to lure the film iiidustry here. In its courtship, Nassau is citing its natural resources: varied topography, the faces of real people and a proximity to the mecca of creativity, Manhattan. The county recognizes that it must deal with the attitudes of a changing industry, wherein more and more actors, producers, writers and directors are electing to live in New York.

title: Ismailia, Site of Talks, Was Rebuilt From Ruins
description: CAIRO, Dec. 24 (AP)  Ismailia, where President Anwar, elSadat of Egypt and Prime Minister Menahem Begin of Israel will meet tomorrow, was a ghost town a few years ago, devastated by Israeli bombs and shells.

title: Auto Racing Attendance Is Up, but the Average Drops
description: The annual report of auto racing attendance by the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company showed that the number of spectators had increased, but that because there were more events this year than in 1976, the average attendance per race was lower.

title: Does the System Work?
description: WASHINGTONThere is a yearend pause now in Washington. The President and the Congress have gone home for the holidays to rest and regroup for the battles of 1978. And, in the process, the guess here is that they will all he wondering whether they are caught in a political system that doesn't suite work either at home or abroad.

title: POINT OF VIEW; Companies as Heroes? Bah! Humbug!
description: A new conception of the social responsibilities of the corporation is abroad in the land. Nurtured by faculties of leading business schools and supported by an unusual coalition of business and labor leaders, consumer advocates and such traditional critics of market capitalism as the liberal clergy, the new view urges the corporation to identify needs for socioeconomic change, to formulate programs of action consistent wan these needs and voluntarily to implement these programs even at the expense of stockholder profits.

title: Long Island/This Week
description: DIX HILLSColor photographs by Col. Alvin J. Blake; regular banking hours through Jan. 14; National Bank of North America, 709 Old Country Rd.

title: Children's Fashion
description: It's finally arrived. Christmas morning, a happy day in the hearts of children and an ideal day for proud parents to show off their children, looking their best. And, for this one day', at least, even the most dedicated tomboy, male or female, enjoys dressing up. And those oldfashioned charmers  frothy lace collars, velveteen, shiny shoes and big bows  put Tshirts and jeans into total, if temporary, eclipse.

title: With His New Proposals, the President Is More SureFooted
description: Can President Carter, criticized at home and abroad for his uncertain, anxietyproducing management of the American economy during his first year, get his act together in 1978? He certainly means to try to demonstrate a new decisiveness, Last week, he proposed to send to Congress in January a $25 billion tax cut and revision package, aimed at simultaneously spurring economic growth and checking inflation.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: HE zoomed in at chimney level last night, too low to be spotted by radar. The sonic boom as he went through the sound barrier left a dizzying, echoing trail of hoho's that were far too cheerful to rouse the decibelcounters among the SSTwatchers on the South Shore.

title: Faith Donovan Plans To Be Wed on June 4
description: The Very Rev. Daniel Donovan, pastor of St. John the Baptist Russian Orthodox Church in Passaic, N. J., and Mrs. Donovan of Passaic, have announced the engagement of their daughter. Faith Donovan. to Kenneth George Johnson, son of Mr. and Mrs. George E. Johnson of Monessen, Pa.

title: Death of an American
description: WINCHESTER, Ind., Dec. 23E. Reed Abel was buried here today in the Indiana earth to which he had clung through all the rich years of his life, from his birth in the 19th century to his death this week at 89.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: Conference time. The shows go on every year, during the first and second weeks of December. Their settings are usually a sunshiny placePuerto Rico, the Bahamas, Miami Beach, Key Biscayne, Scottsdale. Center stage are large resort hotels with many conference rooms and restaurants that offer liberal quantities of allAmerican food. Just offstage are beaches, swimming pools, tennis courts, golf links, cocktail lounges, sometimes cabarets and casinos. The shows casts number 100 to 150, most of them sales representatives from every part of the United States, the rest editors and company executives from New York.

title: TURKS FEEL PRESSURE TO KEEP ROLE IN NATO
description: ANKARA, Turkey  Two diplomats, paying a visit to a respected Turkish editor recently, spent more than an hour urging him to use all his journalistic influence to help keep Turkey an ally of the United States and a member of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

title: ART VIEW
description: We have seen much this year to give us pleas ure, and there have been certain exhibitions of a quality and power never to be forgotten by those lucky enough to have seen them. A: the same time, the year 1977 is unlikely to h: regarded by posterity as one of outstanding creative accomplishment in the visual arts. The public fur serious art has never been larger, the interest ot the government never greater, and the art market too prospers in the midst of uncertainty in other areas of the economy. Yet the socalled lull, frequently alluded to in recent years whenever significant new creative develonment s bave come under discussion, continues without observable abatement.

title: Christmas Tree Costly in Venezuela
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 24 (AP)The Christmas tree of northern climes has become so popular in this tropical country that dealers can charge uppp to $80 for a tall, full specimen. Hun reds of thousands of trees are imported, rom the United States and Canada.

title: DINING OUT
description: THE beautiful restaurant, a sleekly fashionable statement in gleaming brass, lustrous wood and glass, has come to the Island. Winston's in Port Washington is :he newest example of this style that sets its dining scene with more than just paneling and paintings. ne new owners guttea tne cavernous rltd house once occupied by a Continental restaurant facing the water. Broad panes of fixed glass replaced the windows. An immense and handsome threesided bar, its railing gripped by polished brass elephants heads, occupies half the ground floor. Around it there is a twolevel dining room, restfully beige and lit by the glow opaline glass fixtures and candles. Upstairs, another dining room takes even better advantage of the view of Manhasset Bay.

title: Tower City, Pa., Returns to Routine of Mining Coal
description: TOWER CITY, Pa., Dec. 24 (AP)The hardy people who gouge their living from the coal fields have bounced back from the mine disaster that killed nine men and buried another alive last March.

title: Education
description: Last week, A. Bartlett Giamatti, a Yale professor of ? was offered and accepted the ? of Yale. Dr. Giartatti will take ? to fairly difficult times; for 10 years, the university has been spending more than it takes in, and many universities in similar situations have already been forced to make substantial cutbacks in academic programs.

description: THIS is not so much a critic's observations as collective communiqu (heavily illustrated) that informs the reader of the course of Soviet ballet during the past 10 years, as seen from the ministry of culture in Moscow. Its carefully couched judgments are political in the extreme, and genuine esthetic opinions play little part in its makeup. So little part that one wonders whether any at all are involved.

description: FOR centuries New Year's has symbolized a time of new beginnings, brave resolutions and elaborate celebrations. But this week, Westchester's women are turning their attention not only to New Year's party plans, but to the old year's taxes. At least that is the opinion of several local bankers who have witnessed an increase in the number of individuar-retirement accounts opened by women recently in area banks, and who expect flurry of lastminute activity later this week.

It sounds as though more and more insecure people are clinging to yet another social crutch in an attempt to cope with the complexities of interpersonal relationships.

title: CAMERA
description: To most people, there is hardly anything more boring than a slide show at a friend's house-yet it certainly doesn't have to be that way. With a bit of prepara tion, and an adequate supply of good slides about a single theme, a slide show can be not only entertaining, it can equal the best of documentary films in visual impact and informative value. Above all, a good slide show is an art form in itself.

title: A Christmas Carol

title: Robert Page Benson Fiance Of Lynn Burrows Michelson

title: STAGE VIEW
description: This was the year that the Vivian Beaumont went dark while every other house in town looked as though it had been turned into a brilliantly lighted, festively colored Christmas tree. In fact, as I drive my way crosstown these nights I am con- stantly dazzled by what I see: marquees ablaze everywhere, not just on playhousecrowded 45th Street but on streets where garage space used to be easy pickings because the theaters closest to them were all empty. There once was parking lot I could always get into on 52nd Street. No longer, not with Annie and Bubbling Brown Sugi.. alive on the block. The Uris used to be a snap. Now, with those hordes pouring in and out of The King and I, not to mention a recent jump in attendance at Circle in the Square, I wouldn't go near it. And so I whistle as I snake up and down all the side streets, past the Bijou and the Belasco and the Martin Beck and the Curt and all those houses that four years ago were on the verge of being written off altogether. I am content, in a way. 1 henestly didn't think I'd live to see what 1,4 called Broadway back in blockbusting business, making a gaudy toy of toe night sky. Perhaps I can dump the car on 41st Street, because the Billy Rose hasn't reopened yet. It's going to, soon, and I'll have to shove on again, I know. But sometimes it's nice that there's no room at the inn.

title: Woman Who Bought FeatherMosaic Album in Antique Shop for $20 Told by Appraiser: Lady, Name

description: Claudia Lindsey, a soprano whose considerable experience includes appearances with orchestras as well as the Metropolitan Opera National Company and the New York City Opera, gave her first New York recital last Sunday night at Alice Tully Hall. A strikingly handsome women with a flamboyant stage manner, Miss Lindsey flashed an intermittently exciting voice. She also displayed a penchant for dramatic expression, which was often exaggerated or misapplied in the lieder section of her program.

title: INVESTIGATIVE PROCEDURES ARE OUTDATED, G.A.O. SAYS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP)The Government's procedures for investigating its employees and job applicants have jbeen jumbled by changing attitudes and laws and nerd a thorough overhaul, the General Acccurting Office says.

title: Recalling the Night of the Blackout
description: EVERYONE remembers the blackoutthe sweltering night most Westchester residents had to do without lights, air-conditioners and television sets. But for some in Westchester that night, the night of July 13 was more terrifying than that.

title: MAILBAG
description: To the Editor: AII television viewers must be grateful to Walter Goodman for the rare insight into the thinking of TV executives he provided in his article How Should Public TV Handle inflammatory Material? [Dec. 111. He quotes Antony Mahn, coproducer of The Extremists, as saying that if it had been up to him, he would have rejected Black Perspective' on the merits or lack of them, but once the American Jewish Congress turned on the heat to keep it off the screen he would have run it. Astonishingly, Mr. Goodman describes this as a healthy professional view of the mat-

title: Santa Accused And Defended
description: AND so ends another season of Santa mania. Ever since Thanksgiving, the redrobed stranger has mesmerized us with his special kind of holiday magic. His portly presence dominated the media, caused crowds to collect at shopping centers and seasoned our slumber with sweet anticipation.

title: What's Doing in PARIS
description: TOPICS  Striking things in Paris recently have included: cold weather, terribly high prices, a cosmopolitan crowd looking badly dressed but living it up in restaurants. Of course, the French say, the weather isn't half so bad as in London, but what sort of a compliment is that? It will probably not apply either, come January, which most years is a month of cold and rain. As to the prices, it's simple: they have gone up once more, by an average of 10 percent, as they did the year before. Inflation here is a fact of life, and one of the mysteries of Paris has long been where all those people find the money to enjoy themselves in restaurants. The prices of meals have led most other prices in the rate of increase, so tourists find themselves among inflation's prime victims.

title: Why Do We Have to Read?
description: IGOT a Christmas gift early this year. It came unexpectedly, when a boy in my class remained after the bell. He just had to tell me something. Thank you, Mr. Gersten.

title: Iraq Christians Bar Christmas Fetes To Protest Sadat's Amity for Israel
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Dec. 24 (Reuters)Iraq's Christians have canceled Christmas festivities as a protest against President Anwar elSadat's peace gestures toward Israel, the Iraqi press agency reported today.

title: U.S. Experts Fear Saudi Troubles In the Oilfields May Limit Output
description: A number of leading energy experts in Washington now believe that the Saudi Arabian oilfields, the richest in the world, have been disrupted by a series of technical and managerial problems that may curtail the amount of oil that can he pumped.

title: Joy to The Word
description: CS. LEWIS'S autobiography is called Surprised by Joy ; his wife was named Joy;  the last words in this anthology of readings are Joy is the serious business of Heaven ; the publisher's promotional ejaculation is Joy to the word! ; the editor's title had to be what it is. The response of the unregenerate majority of us to the notion of joy, especially Christian joy, is bound to be pretty surly. Joy suggests the teetotalers of the Bible Belt

title: Airlines Face New Uncertainty
description: The world's commercial airlines, already navigating through clouds of uncertainty, last week found themselves confronted by two new imponderables, courtesy of the Carter Administration. The President approved direct air service to Europe from 11 new American cities. And the Civil Aeronautics Board,lessening restrictions on domestic and international charter flights, gave the charter companies a leg up on competing with bargain fares recently put into effect by scheduled airlines.

title: Computers at Department Stores Deny Credit to Gracie Mansion

title: ANTIQUES
description: posters have been collected ever since the 1890's when major artists became involved in this commercial art form. But with the notable exception of the always popular colorsplashed graphics of Henri de ToulouseLautrec, the current interest in vintage posters is less than decade old. And in that 10year period, designs from the turn of the century to World War II were rediscovered first by artist and by period, and more recently by such subject categories as travel, architecture, war, namebrand products, theater, circus and cinema, all of which command enthusiastic followings today.

title: These Days, ovies Light Up His Life
description: joe Brooks may be a relatively unknown director in motion pictures, but in the field of egotism he's the most promising heavyweight contender since Sylvester Stallone. Two years agowhen he was still totally unknown, except to the advertising crowd (he composed more famous jingles than Barry Manilow)he wrote, produced, scored, directed and hyped his first feature film. Nobody wanted to touch You Light Up My Life until Mr. Brooks himself paid for previews in Seattle and Houston to prove it would sell. So far, it has grossed $12 million and the catchiest thing about it, the title song, has had a firm grip on the Number One spot on pop music charts for four months.

description: heater Opening This Week

title: I Write About The Human Game
description: If there is such a thing as your average everyday garden variety playwright, Ronald Ribman just isn't him. A grim imp, boyish at 45, he gives the impression of the Fonz making his way through West Side intellectual streetsa troll whose bar mitzvah was celebrated in the darkest caverns of the mountains.

title: Chicago Store's Christmas Scenes Set Against Backdrop of Takeover
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 24Each day since Thanksgiving a crush of starryeyed children and their weary but obliging parenta have made a pilgrimage to State Street here to look in on the Enchanted Forest where Frederick Fieldmouse met, fell hopelessly in love with and finally, thanks to Santa and the Honorable Wise Old Owl, married Marshd Housemouse.

title: EXPLOSION SHAKES BETHLEHEM SQUARE
description: BETHLEHEM, IsraeliOccupied West Bank, Sunday, Dec. 25 (AP)An explosion erupted last night in a sidestreet off Manger Square, where thousands of Christian pilgrims celebrated Christmas Eve in the town of the birth of Jesus.

title: Procedural Changes Are Expected For City Council in the New Year
description: The New York City Council, when it convenes after New Year's Day with a 30 percent turnover in its membership, will undergo substantial change in the way it carries out its business.

She is a sales representative fur the industrial-abrasive division of the 3M Company in West Caldwell, N. J. Her fianc is an assistant treasurer with the Bank of New York.

description: There here were dark depths as well as sorne glowing being in the 1977 photography year, and we might as well drag ourselves through the real pits first.

description: PLAINS, Ga., Dec. 24President Carter met today with a delegation of striking farmers and expressed sympathy with their economic problems but urged them to plant crops next spring.

description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Dec. 24 (UPI)  The state Personnel Board is encouraging state training officers to play a game similar to Monopoly to prevent discrimination.

title: Julie Acuff, Student, Is Engaged to James Weitzel
description: Mr. and Mrs. C. Shelley Acuff of Trenton, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Julia Sean Acuff, to James F. Weitzel of Arlington, Va., son of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Weitzel of West Bloomfield Hills, Mich. The wedding is planned next October.

title: Headliners
description: Hamilton Jordan, Jimmy Carter's top political aide, was the subject last week of gossip surrounding allegedly racy remarks he made at a party given by Barbara Walters, the television reporter. According to the reports, unidentified guests at the partywhich honored Israeli Ambassador Simcha Dinitz and Egyptian Envoy Ashraf Ghorbalsaw Mr. Jordan glance at Mrs. Ghorbal's cleavage and say something about wanting to see the pyramids. Mr. Jordan promptly denied saying it. Mrs. Ghorbal denied hearing. And Mr. Ghorbal simply cited an Arab proverb that He who repeats an insult is the one insulting you.

title: Vietnamese Said to Use Warplanes in Battles Along Cambodia Border
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 24 (AP)Vietnam and Cambodia have intensified their border conflict into fullscale battles involving warplanes and artillery and resulting in heavy casualties, according to sources who monitor developments in the two Communistcontrolled nations.

title: JOHNNY WHITE
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Dec, 24 (AP)Johnny White, a former Indianapolis 500 race driver, suffered a fatal heart attack today. He was 45 years old.

title: A Time to Remember
description: Gunnar Myrdal once commented that the big majority of Americans, who are comparatively well off, have developed an ability to have enclaves of people living in the greatest misery without almost noticing them. And Samuel Beckett wrote of all humanity, You don't have to look for distress; it is screaming at you. To ignore suffering, to be blind to the needs of the poor, the old, the sick is surely one of man's chronic failings. Christmas is a powerful antidotea reminder to remember those so often forgotten. The joy of Christmas lies not in merrymaking. It lies in the glow of blessings shared.

title: East Europeans Are Better Off
description: WARSAWThe streets of Warsaw were overflowing with Christmas shoppers last week and they generally liked what they found. The stores were loaded with meat, and there were figs, dates and other treats of the season. Because if there were nothing in the shops the other 51 weeks of the year, the week before Christmas would still be the week that counts for the increasingly powerful East European consumer, whose demands, many governments are beginning to realize, can make or even break a Communist regime.

title: All in the Family
description: NINETEEN SEVENTYSEVEN may well go down as the Year of the Family. it began with the inauguration of a new President who had campaigned strenuously on behalf of domestic values, and who promptly directed his own staff to spend less time on the job and more at home with spouses and children. Commissions, task forces and advisory groups on family life sprouted across the land. Readers of this newspaper, among many others, were treated to lengthy feature articles on the current crisis and future perils of the family. As the year ends, the signs of concern are everywhere, and they do not seem about to go away.

title: Engagements
description: Man delblattDilbert

title: Unusual Powers
description: ROALD DAHL'S stories for adults and children are a bit on the bizarre side. I'm thinking of the adult story of the apiarist who began turning into a bee after putting himself on a diet supplement royal jelly and was so pleas( I by this metamorphosis that he started his infant da .ghte on the same food.

title: Not-So-Handy Homeowners Long for the Jack-of-All-Trades
description: A faucet drips. A door won't close over the new carpeting. There is no shelf in the front hall closet. The children want a basketball hoop over the driveway. The refrigerator tilts and makes a funny noise.

title: Christmas Tree Thefts Becoming Threat to Growers in Carolina
description: SPARTA, N. C., Dec. 24 (UPI)The theft of Christmas trees in the state is becoming such a problem that the North Carolina Christmas Tree Association will hold a meeting in February to discuss the situation.

title: Children in Iowa Breaking Law, But Punishment Will Fit the Crime

description: BETHLEHEM

title: DANCE VIEW
description: The dance season in 1977 was so riddled with so many canceled engagements that a list of 10 significant nonevents might be in order this year. Happily, there was still something to write home about. Despite this unusually high number of cancellations, which were rooted in labor disputes or financial and administrative difficulties, 1977 offered new testimony to dance's continuing growth in this country. Out- standing creativity, unfortunately, was at a lower ebb than usual: The tendency was to rely upon revivals and star vehicles. And yet it was a great year for dancers dancing, with performance standards in both modern dance and ballet the same strong level of recent times.

title: Freedom House Reports Gains for Liberty This Year
description: Solid gains for political and civil liberty were scored in 1977, according to the annual worldwide survey by Freedom }louse classifying countries and territories as tree, partly free or not free.

title: Posthumous Career
description: WHEN Byron expired at his wretched Greek lodgings on April 19, 1824, the heritage of storms that had pursued him since birth did not quickly die away. Even those who had championed the living poet began to dispute over the fallen hero; and some of the most sensible for example, his old friend John Cam Hobhouserevealed their worst and silliest side. In May 1824, only a few days after the news of Byron's death had reached England, Hobhouse was already urging that the poet's unpublished memoirs, which he had originally presented to Tom Moore, should be destroyed as soon as possible; and burned they were on May 17. Thus, a book that was surely a masterpiece Byron, an accomplished selfportraitist, also wrote superb prosedisappeared be-

title: GARDENING
description: THE misty drizzle rain that froze and coated road and sidewalks in the Westchester and Fairfield County region 10 days ago was a quick reminder of the weather tricks of winter. People as well as plants have to tough it out.

title: For Married Priests, the First Christmas in Their New Ministry
description: DANBURY, Conn., Dec. 23The Rev. Michael Coburn is giving the Rev. Ann Coburn a Genie Magic Garage Door Opener for Christmas because Ann hates to get out of the car in this weather. Her present to him will be brandy snifters because that's one of Mike's favorite activities, sniffing brandy with a nice cigar.

title: Debra J. Cowan Bride Of Arthur Fishman
description: Debra Jean Cowan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Cowan of Hollywood, Fla., was married there yesterday to Arthur Mark Fishman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Fishman of Rydal, Pa.

title: ONE CRITIC'S FICTION
description: I remember observing, in a panel discussion of Norman Mailer, that his novels suffered because he was not sufficiently interested in character, that what fascinated him was power, and this was why The Armies of the Night was superior to his novels, because it was about the character of power. Now, as consider these two sophisticated and diverting suspense novels, one by Abraham Rothberg, the other by Sherman Williamson, I wonder how Mailer has managed to resist writing one.

title: Though Not to Soar
description: THERE is nothing that can match the raw emotion and uncontrollable excitement that come seconds before the start of a marathon run. Packed elbow to elbow and shoulder to shoulder like a tin of Norwegian sardines, some 2,000plus runners set out a couple of Sundays ago on a 26mile, 385yard trek along the New Jersey coastline.

title: What They Are Saying
description: Robert Carlson, legal counsel for the New Jersey Nets, when informed that David A. (Sonny) Werblin had resigned as chairman of the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority to become president of Madison Square Garden: I think I liked Sonny more where he was.

title: A Gift of Outings For the Children
description: PROVIDING youngsters with interesting activities during the Christmas vacation can be challenging, even for the most ingenious parent. To he sure, there is the usual round of plays, ballets and shows during the holiday season. But why not introduce your child to something different this year, something he might not have had occasion to pursue during schoolti me?

title: Cape May, N. J., Listed Among Best Spots in U.S. To Watch Bird Migration
description: WASHINGTON, Dec 24 (UPI)Cape May, N.J. is among the 10 best spots in North America to find an abundance of migrating birds according to the National Wildlife Federation.

title: The World
description: There was nothing altruistic about the oilexporting nations decision last week not to raise prices. Nor was diplomatic pressureWashington's claims of victory not withstandingan important cause for the de facto freeze. At a time when demand for the cartel's oil is being undermined by slow economic growth and conservation in the West, among other factors, the 13 members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries had little choice but to obey the dictates of economic common sense.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: A writer in World Coin News, noting that the year has produced less than a numismatic rose garden, points to one area that is booming: the collecting of fiscal paper of all kindsbank notes, stock certificates and drafts.

title: Of Special Interest
description: Charles Ludlamplaywright, actor, founder and director of the Ridiculous Theatrical Company, and, it has now become apparent, an admirer of Edgar Bergenpicked up a dummy in a magic shop, dubbed him Walter Ego and fashioned a play around him. The Ventriloquist's Wife, as it is called, will inaugurate cabaret theater at Reno Sweeney's on Monday. The play deals with the backstage life of a ventriloquist (played by Ludlam, naturally) and his wife (BlackEyed Susan, a regular of the Ridiculous troupe) and includes a routine featuring Mr. Ludlam and his new friend. (See Theater)

title: A Bird Album Rarely Sighted
description: My first reaction, Elsie Newhouse Dietz recalled, was Wow! The time was more than 10 years ago. The place was a quaint, cluttered antiques shop in Bayport, where pullchain lights illuminated two small rooms while a steady rain dripped out of a gray sky.

title: Roger Austin Is the Fiance Of Miss Marvel
description: Chancellor William Marvel, Chief Judge of the Court of Chancery of Delaware, and Mrs. Marvel of Greenville, Del., have announced the engagement of Chancellor Marvel's daughter, Wilhemina Marvel, to Roger Graeme Jung Austin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Victor Austin of Bedford, N.Y. Plans have been made for an April wedding.

title: Patricia Hanrahan Fiancee of Thomas Chardavoyne
description: Patricia A. Hanrahan of Belle Harbor, Queens. an assistant to Queens Borough President Donald R. Manes, and Thcmas K. Chardavovne of Brooklyn, community coordinator in the division of economic opportunity of the New York Secretary of State's office, plan to be married next March.

title: Air, a Jazz Trio, at Axis in SoHo
description: Contemporary jazz musicians have a habit of performing new music almost every time they play, and as a result evaluating their progress has become somewhat difficult. One used to listen to Miles Davis play Bye Bye Blackbird or to John Coltrane's My Favorite Things and hear new worlds of technique and feeling that were all the more striking because the material was so familiar.

title: Kalanchoes for Color
description: These days even the neophyte indoor gardener recognizes the kalanchoe. With its longlasting clusters of red, orange, or yellow flowers and its indestructible waxy emerald foliage, K. blossfeldiana is near the top of the Rift nlant Hit Parade

title: Boating Increases
description: Each year increasing numbers of landlubbers discover the pleasures of boating. And according to an industry survey, the ranks of recreational boatmen swelled by 50,000 during 1977; In all, 52.6 million enthusiasts spent a record $5.9 billion on boats and gear, a figure that has increased nearly 20 percent in two years, largely because of inflation.

title: Mary. Lacey Bride Of John R. McCann
description: Mary Patricia Lacey and John R. McCann were married yesterday afternoon in the Roman Catholic Church of the Sacred Heart in Bloomfield, N.J., by Msgr. Walter G. Jarvais, who also celebrated the nuptial mass.

description: WHITE PLAINS

title: A Hunting Dispute: Steel vs. Lead
description: THE enactment of a Federal regulation requiring them to use shells loaded with steel rather than the traditional lead pellets has left the Island's duck hunters hopping mad. The regulation, known informally as the steel shot decision. was proposed in 1974 and announced by Secretary of the Interior Thomas S. Klepv in 1976.

title: Memories: VIIWomen's Work
description: AYLESBURY, EnglandIn any list of major developments during the last half centurytechnological advances, nuclear energy development, decolonization, the spread of racial equality, the rise and fall of Fascism, the diffusion of Communismone must give due place to women's total change of status in most societies.

title: Steel Increases Received Calmly
description: It all went so smoothly. As most of the major steel companies last week announced price increases of 5.5 percent, the reaction from Washington was that the level was in line with what the companies needed to recover production cost increases caused by inflation.

title: U.S. Urged to Avoid Pushing Israel
description: Rabbi Walter S. Wurzburger, president of the Rabbinical Council of akmeries, called upon the Carter Administration yesterday to refrain from pressuring Israel to yield what she regards as vital interests, indispensable to national surdival.

title: For a Peaceful Holiday in Poland, a Full Larder
description: WARSAW, Dec. 24The lines began forming before dawn today at Marymont Hall on the northern fringe of Warsawtwo lines for meat and one very long one for fish, particularly carp, the omnipresent Christmas fish in Poland. But the manager of the Marymont market, Stanislaw Szvderski, prepared. Unlike this time last month, or even last week, today there was meat, lots of it, in Marymont and in shops across Poland.

title: Mr. Dickens (As It Were)
description: It is arguable that The Inimitable, as Charles Dickens called himself, invented our sense of Christmas. Certainly, he wrote it so memorably that it is difficult, at times, to know whether we are in our own Christmases, or in one of Dickens's. In his life and art, he seized upon Christmas as an occasion for celebrating family love in the temple of the firelit home. But Christmas was also the time, for Dickens, of great painwhen memory flooded, and sad recollections of loss and wound were entertained like awful beloved relatives.

title: THAT WEEK IN HOUSTON
description: here had been talk, before last month's National Women's Conference in Houston, that the women's movement was suffering from

title: When the Boss Gets Sacked
description: One day next month John Schumacher, the former $200,000-a-year president and chief executive officer of the Bonwi! Teller chain, is scheduled to appear before a threemember arbitration panel and tell how he was ousted from his job on less than 24 hours notice and ordered to empty his desk immediately. Mr. Schumacher has filed a claim for unspecified damages for what he calls the demeaning and degrading treatment he received from Genesco Inc., Bonwit's corporate parent. And last week it was reported that Genesco has responded with its own charges, alleging that Mr. Schumacher had diverted funds, labor and materials from Bonwit's Fifth Avenue Store to the renovation of his own Park Avenue apartment.

title: Skeletons, Spiders and Mortality
description: You don't have to be 100 years old to have memories of the Museum of Natural History, although that distinguished institution is celebrating the centenary of its construction this month. For generations of New Yorkers, the images are indelible: the welcoming blue whale, the plaster Indians hurling immobile spears from silent canoes poised on motionless seas in dim, nocturnal rooms; the pleasurable shock of giant prehistoric skeletons looming over fragile fossils: the transparent woman displaying the secrets of life in technicolor plastic tubing; the regiments of spiders with long, Latin names; the skulls of Homo sapiens offering lessons in anthropology and mortality.

title: Best Sellers
description: FICTION

title: Elton John Reaches for Artistic Recognition
description: lton John's Greatest Hits Volume H caps the first phase of the most commerically successful solo recording career since Elvis Presley. While Mr. John's albums, especially those released in the past three years, have seemed fleshed out with filler, Greatest Hits Volume IIa collection of six hits taken from five previous albums, three additiohal

title: Innovations Are Stressed in SludgeDisposal Efforts
description: In a garage at the Newtown Creek sewagetreatment plant in Brooklyn there's a glass case, a fan at one end blowing air against black substances heard or 15 layers of Plexiglas, each eieht feet by one and a half feet.

title: Nancy Fox Fiancee Of Ronald A. Krauss
description: Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Fox of Elkins Park, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Ruth Fox, to Ronald Alan Krauss, son of Alisa Krauss Rosenberg of Great Neck, L.I., and the late Milton Krauss. The wedding is planned for the summer.

title: 52 Filipinos Become U.S. Citizens As a 36Year Promise Is Fulfilled
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 24 (AP)They fought for the United States in World War II and were told by Congress in 1941 that they would he rewarded with American citizenship. After 36 years of waiting, 52 Filipinos have seen the promise fulfilled.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: It has been a busy season up to now. It also has been a rather dull one. Great artists, of course, come into New York and make their audiences happy. Major orchestras are constantly on the scene. The opera houses keep busy. Yet the doldrums seem to have set in. Orchestra programs are not very imaginative. The Metropolitan Opera to date has had none of the stimulating new productions we enjoyed a few seasons back. The creative scene looks bleak. None of the new works dutifully presented by the Philharmonic or by smaller groups shows much personality chance of survival. Composers are looking for a new style, and they keep assuring everybody that they want to make contact with the public. But they are not doing so very well.

title: ISLAND IN CARIBBEAN WANTS THE NAVY OUT
description: VIEQUES, P. R., Dec. 24 (UPI)  It might almost have been called a love affair, the way the residents of this small Caribbean island felt about the United States Navy.

title: Gerulaitis Gains in Australia Tennis
description: Gerulaitis Gains in Australia Tennis

title: TREASURES FROM A GOLDEN TOMB
description: SALONIKA, Greece. The road leading southwest from Salonika toward the village of Vergina passes through fields of rice and cotton being harvested by bentbacked workers with kerchiefs wound around their heads. Occasionally, the monotony of the landscape is broken by the tents of a gypsy encampment or a shepherd with his flock, but generally the terrain is as flat and dull as the plains of Kansas.

title: New Plan Tried for Elm Disease
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24The Forest Service has begun a new campaign to check the spread of Dutch elm disease, which has already killed 56 percent of the elms in the United States.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: WASHING machines, clothes dryers, refrigerators and other household appliances come with tough, bakedon finishes that normally require no attention other than periodic washing. However, because of normal abuse and exposure to moisture and harsh detergents, there will inevitably be scratches, dents and chips in the finish that expose the bare metal underneath.

description: IVORYTON

title: LETTERS TO THE CONNECTICUT EDITOR
description: An Essay On Eloquence

title: A Plea for Some Untarnished Athletic Heroes
description: Despite all the violence, hunger and agony in the world, the most crushing event of the decade to millions of Americans was the sudden death of Elvis Presley. Just as crushing as his death was the publication of his life story by three former employees. They told us Elvis was violent, drugaddicted, moody and, above all, imperfect.

title: GARDENING
description: THE misty drizzle rain that froze and coated road and sidewalks in the Westchester and Fairfield County region 10 days ago was a quick reminder of the weather tricks of winter. People as well as plants have to tough it out.

title: Judges are lending an ear to pleas from executives seeking cash balm for humiliation.
Barbara Rose Is Married
description: Barbara E. Rose, daughter of George Langbart of Palm Beach, Fla., and the late Sylvia Blank Langbart, was married last evening to Morton G. Meyer. Rabbi Herman W. Saville performed the ceremony at the Stanhope Hotel. Mr. Meyer is a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Max Meyer of New York. The bride's four sons by a previous marriage, which ended in divorce, and Mr. Meyer's daughter attended the ceremony. Mr Meyer's wife died. The bridegroom, who was formerly president of the Metropolitan Tobacco Company, distributors in New York and New Jersey, is consultant to the Culbro Corporation, a New York manufacturer and distributor of snack foods, medicine and tobacco.

title: Two Women Slain in Los Angeles, One a Possible Strangler
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 24 (AP)A young woman whose partly nude body was found dumped on a hillside early today may be the 12th victim of the hillside strangler, the police said.

title: Upstate College Town Unsettled By a Disappearance and Deaths
description: ONEONTA, N.Y., Dec. 22A bizarre string of events has left this normally quiet Catskill college city struggling to regain its equilibrium. A woman student from the state college disappeared two weeks ago, quickly followed by the deaths of two other students, one of them a visitor from another campus.

title: U.S. ACADEMY ACTED TO AID SIICHARANSKY
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24The National Academy of Sciences, in an unusual move, announced today that it had Intervened on behalf of Anatoly Shcharansky a Soviet computer specialist, arrested nine months ago and accused in the Soviet press of having worked for the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: Yalta: Wedding Party Rapprochement
description: It was the last week of our Russian tour and members of the group, who had started out being very polite and agreeable to our Intourist guides were subtly beginning to revolt. At first we let obvious historical misinformation go unchallenged and shrugged off the not-sosubtle propaganda. But when they can- ceted a visit to the Zagorsk Monastery near Moscow and substituted yet another scientific exhibit for a longawaited visit to a gallery of Impressionist art, even the most docile of our party rebelled. No one showed up for the exhibit tour and from that time on, relations were a bit strained.

title: CRIME
description: Save us from private eyes who have read Hume, Kant and Hegel. Here's Jacob Asch, working out of Los Angeles, looking into the death of a heavyweight fighter. He is talking to a sheriff in Reno. Sometimes, says Asch, it's just a matter of cognition. Reality isn't necessarily as we perceive it. All that raw data out there is filtered and molded by us according to the way we're taught to see it.

title: Andre Eglevsky
description: It is difficult to believe that Andre Eglevsky is no longer with us. Both as a dancer and a teacher, he was simply and unqualifiably great. His legacy was uniquedrawn from Nicolas Legat to Fokine to Balanchine. In no one dancer were so many diverse strains of the Russian classical tradition united and it was a heritage that only he would have been able to pass down to succeeding generations. Now that legacy is lost. With it is gone the special inspi- ration to male classical dancing that Mr. Eglevsky symbolized for 25 years until his retirement from the stage in 1959 and later, as a teacher and director of the Eglevsky Ballet Company.

title: Chaplin's Little Tramp, an Everyman Trying to Gild Cage of Life, Enthralled World
description: No motion picture actor so captured and enthralled the world as did Charles Spencer Chaplin, a London ragamuffin who became an immortal artist for his deft and effective humanization of man's tragicomic conflicts with fate. In more than 80 movies from 1914 to 1967, he either portrayed or elaborated (he was a writer and director as well as an actor) the theme of the little fellow capriciously knocked about by life, but not so utterly battered that he did not pick himself up in the hope that the next encounter would turn out better.

title: Covering Up the Trial Before the Trial
description: A basic assumption about American justicethat it is public business and should be conducted in the open has been undermined by the State Court of Appeals. In a recent case the court upheld the closing of important criminal proceedings to the public, including the press. The court ruled that an upstate trial judge had acted within his power when he granted a secret hearing on the admissibility of murder confessions by two men awaiting trial. He rejected a plea for access from the Gannett news organization. The 4-to-2 appellate majority laid down a broad rule: Whenever news coverage of such hearings poses a risk of prejudicial publicity, the courtroom is presumptively closed to the public. We believe the rule is most unwise and its broad sweep is deplorable. We wish the Gannett organization well in its quest for Supreme Court review.

title: Mel Brooks in 'High Anxiety'
description: Dr. Richard H. Thorndyke, the Nobel Prize-winning psychiatrist, could be the quintessential Alfred Hitchcock hero. His is unmarried but available. He dresses immaculately in dark suits with vests. He wears his Phi Beta Kappa key on a fine gold chain and neatly spears his understated tie with a gold pin that also keeps his shirt collar tucked in. More importantly, he has an elegant flaw. Dr. Richard H. Thorndyke, newly appointed head of Los Angeles's posh ($12,000 a month for room and board) Psycho-Neurotic Institute for the Very, Very Nervous, suffers from high anxiety, which is like vertigo, only worse.One could easily mistake Dr. Richard H. Thorndyke for the hero of a film like "The Man Who Knew Too Much" or "Vertigo" except for one thing. He has the cowardly man's restless glance as he keeps track of the terrain and of all the ways to make a quick exit. The explanation is simple. The actor playing the role is Jimmy Stewart compacted to the volatile proportions of Mel Brooks in Mr. Brooks's funny, brainy, film-buff comedy, "High Anxiety," which opened yesterday at the Sutton Theater.In a way that seems sneaky only because he has been so successful at the box office (and popularity must always be suspect), Mr. Brooks is extending the boundaries of parody in contemporary films. In "Blazing Saddles" he brought anarchy to the Wild West and in "Silent Movie" he demonstrated his affection for slapstick comedy with approximately 258 variations on the pratfall and the pie-in-the-face. "Young Frankenstein," his best film to date, cheerfully recalled everything we remember most fondly about 1930's horror films in general and James Whale's "Frankenstein" in particular."High Anxiety," Mr. Brooks's homage to the extraordinary career of Alfred iHitchcock, is as witty and as disciplined as "Young Frankenstein," though it has one built-in problem: Hitchcock himself is a very funny man. His films, even at their most terrifying and most suspenseful, are full of jokes shared with the audience. Being so self-aware, Hitchcock's films deny an easy purchase to the parodist, especially one who admires his subject the way Mr. Brooks does. There's nothing to send up, really. There are only characters' scenes, manners and gestures to be remembered with affection.In "High Anxiety," the story of the flawed Dr. Richard H. Thorndyke's coming to terms with his neurosis, Mr. Brooks remembers all sorts of Hitchcock films, including "The Lodger," "Rebecca," "Psycho," "Vertigo" and "The Birds," and a lot of the film's fun is sharing his affection. That the enjoyment tends to be cerebral is confirmed. I think, by the fact that it's a movie that is almost as funny to hear about as to see.What will people feel about the film if they don't know Hitchcock from Hawks? After watching five- and 10-year-old children, who'd never heard of "Frankenstein," collapsing with laughter at "Young Frankenstein," I suspect it won't make any difference at all. There's an infectiously funny rhythm to a Brooks film to which even the unenlightened can respond.As the afflicted Dr. Thorndyke, Mr. Brooks plays it so very, very straight that just the memory of one of his famous leers is funny, as when he arrives at his post and meets Nurse Diesel (Cloris Leachman), a thin-lipped, sadistic Florence Nightingale who has the slightest hint of a mustache and breasts that seem borrowed from Brunnhilde. Among the other people with whom he must deal, there are the dapper but masochistically bent Dr. Montague (Harvey Korman), kindly old Professor Lillolman (Howard Morris) and especially the glamorous San Francisco socialite, Victoria Brisbane, played by Madeline Kahn, a woman who can be gloriously funny simply by attempting to control an upper lip. She's a cocktail waitress's loving concept of "the real Kim Novak."The screenplay, written by Mr. Brooks with Ron Clark, Rudy De Luca and Barry Levinson, all of whom make cameo appearances in the film with gusto, deals in Hitchcockesque skullduggery set at the Psycho-Neurotic Institute and at a doctors' convention in San Francisco where, one way and another, the doctor gets to the bottom of the mysterious incidents at his sanitarium.Miss Leachman and Mr. Korman have great fun as the villains, as does Ron Carey, who, early in the movie, dutifully introduces himself to Dr. Thorndyke as "your driver and sidekick." Mr. Brooks also has succeeded in making the movie look like a Hitchcock production, even to dolly shots of a kind one seldom sees in movies any more."High Anxiety," which has been rated PG ("parental guidance suggested") includes a few vulgar gestures and words of the sort that, to children, have Shavian impact.

title: Striking Portuguese Pilots Agree To Fly Workers to Jobs Abroad

President Antonio Ramalho Eanes had asked the pilots to interrupt their strike so that workers who returned to Portugal for Christmas could return to their jobs.

description: Banks, stock exchanges and commodity markets in the United States and Europe wore closed yesterday for the Christmas holiday. The banks and financial markets will reopen today, except in Britain, where the Christmas holiday lasts until tomorrow.

title: One Killed, 3 Hurt in Connecticut In Crashes of Two Small Planes
description: Two small planes crashed in Connecticut yesterday, killing one person and injuring four, officials said. One of the planes crashed in the town of Brooklyn, late in the afternoon in a wooded area, killing one man and injuring two persons seriously. The dead man was identified as Joseph Lanoue, 54 years old, of Norwich, and the injured were identified as Lewrence Lanoue. 29, and Suzanne Lanoue, 28, of Jewett City, both Connecticut. The relationships were not immediately known.

title: Begin Gets His Wish To See the Pyramids
description: TEL AVIV, Dec. 26Several times in recent days, Prime Minister Menahem Begin has said he wanted to see the Great Pyramids of Giza. Today, as he returned from his talks with President Anwar elSadat in the Suez Canal town of Ismailia, the Israeli leader got his wish.

title: Beame Reflects on His Service in City
description: Twelve years ago, the voters of New York rejected Abraham D. Beame as Mayor, accepting his opponent's notion of him as a dull, unimaginative bookkeeper. title: ALBERT E. TOLLEY
description: Albert E. Tolley, a former vice president of the Ward Baking Company, died Saturday at his home in Upper Montclair, N.J. He was 77 years old.

title: P.L.O. Says Sadat Has Forsaken the Palestinians
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 26The Palestine Liberation Organization charged today that President Anwar elSadat of Egypt had forsaken the cause of the Palestinian people in his meeting_ in Ismailia with Prime Minister Menahem Begin of Israel.

title: Extremists in Rome Fail in Attempt i To Set Fire to Classical Monument
description: ROME, Dec. 26 (Reuters)Unidentified extremists failed in an attempt early today to set fire to one of Rome's bestknown classical monuments, according to the police. The extremists broke into the glasswalled hall housing the ornate marble Altar of Peace, dating from the era of the Emperor Augustus, and set fire to a pile of rags soaked in an inflammable liquid.

title: TV: Illegal Immigrants Studied
description: For an hour this evening, beginning at 8, CBS Reports, looks at The Aliens, the illegal immigrants who have transformed Los Angeles into a major Latin American city. In fact, Los Angeles, which was in Mexico for about 200 years until it was occupied by United States troops in 1846, is the world's thirdlargest Mexican city. Rill Moyers, describing the massive flow of illegals across the border (about 37,000 were caught at one point in a single month), notes that the new immigrants come not in steerage, but on the freeway north.

title: Power to the People Maybe
description: A year that began with Jimmy Carter promising to restore confidence in government may be ending with the American people more cynical and mistrustful of their leaders than ever before. Mr. Carter's uneven personal performance, his frequent clashes with Congress, the Bert Lance affair, the persistence of inflation and unemployment, the highpowered beginning and sputtering continuance of the energy controversyin light of all that, it would not be surprising if many Americans had been confirmed in a view of government as incompetent and unresponsive.

title: St. Lawrence Seaway Closed
description: OGDENSBURG,,N.Y., Dec. 26 (UPD)St. Lawrence Seaway officials say that the navigation season in the channel that links the Atlantic Ocean and the Great Lakes is over. The seaway officially shut clown Dec. 15, but 200 ships were still in the system. A warm spell last week gave them a reprieve from the rapidly thickening ice, however, and Seaway officials reported yesterday that all the vessels had made it out of the system. The Sea1 way will now be shut down until spring.

title: Accident Kills 2 Relatives Of Texas Football Coach
description: ARMOREL, Ark. Dec. 26 (UPI)The brother and nephew of the University Texas football coach, Fred Akers, were killed along with another man today in a car accident near the tristate border of Arkansas, Tennessee and Missouri. The coach's nephew, Lonnie Akers jr., 22, the driver of the car, and brother, Carl Akers, 36, both of Blytheville, Tex., died when their car left Arkansas Highway 18, hit a dirt embankment and caught fire, the police reported.

title: Experts Debate the Amount of Microwave Radiation That Can Cause Danger to Health
description: Microwave radiation has become so familiar in the form of television and communications signals, radar, microwave ovens and other uses that most Americans take it for granted. But some scientists are raising insistent questions as to whether it poses a subtle bat serious health hazard. A heated- debate is gaining force among expertson just how much microwave radiation a person may absorb without injury, and whether the Federal Government should set a legal limit to such radiation, as it does for Xrays.

title: T00 MANY SHIPYARDS TROUBLING JAPANESE
description: TOKYO, Dec. 26Japan, which has led the world in shipbuilding for 23 years in a row, now has to decide what to do with twice as many shipyards and shipbuilders as it needs to fill dwindling orders.

title: Charges Against Gregory Dropped
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP)Charges against Dick Gregory, the comedian, his wife and three other persons arrested Christmas. Day for protesting in front of the South African Embassy were dropped today in the District of Columbia Superior Court. A court spokesman said Federal prosecutors decided against pressing the case in which the five were charged with violating a local law prohibiting demonstrations within 500 feet of a foreign embasey.

title: ALBERT POFFENBERGER, 92; PROFESSOR AT COLUMBIA

title: Getting Tough With Japan
description: Echoing some loud cries of distress from industry and labor, the Administration has lately been warning that Japan must rapidly eliminate its giant trade surplus with the United States lest the domestic pressures for protection against Japanese imports become unstoppable. The surplus is certainly largesome $8.5 billion this year part of Japan's global trade surplus of $15 billionand the pain to particular industries considerable. But Washington's reaction has perhaps been too blunt and too panicky. The brewing minicrisis between the two governments could do serious damage to the international trading system and to the relationship between the United States and Japan that has been crucial to stability in Asia since World War

title: RIFT ON PALESTINIANS

title: Notes on People
description: At the Vatican, Pope Paul VI resumed his regular schedule after a busy and tiring Christmas on which he celebrated three masses in 12 hours and praised the Middle East peace initiatives to 200,000 people gathered in St. Peter's Square. In his annual Christmas message, the 80-year-old Pontiff said that he hoped the summit meeting between President Anwar elSadat of Egypt and Prime Minister Menahem Begin of Israel would lead to peace shining on those dear people who have been so sorely tried by wars and bereavements. The Pope, who walks haltingly because of arthritis in the legs, began Christmas with a traditional midnight mass in St. Peter's Basilica, another in his private chapel and a third at midmorning. Although he delivered the noontime message in a forceful voice, two aides had to help him to his feet after several minutes of praying on his knees during

title: The Reporter and the Spy
description: As a series of New York Times articles concluding today demonstrates, the American press has a piece unfinished business with the Central Intelligence Agency that is also public business: the use of reporters as spies. With information that is more than 10 and 20 years old, but still hard to come by, the articles offer further evidence of what has been widely suspected and sketchily, sometimes wrongly, reported, The C.I.A. once used the credentials of American news organizations as cover for a dozen or more of its operatives around the world.

title: The Little Tramp
description: A year that has seen the passing of such entertainment phenomena as Elvis Presley, Groucho Marx, Bing Crosby and Guy Lombardo now comes to an end with the death of Charlie Chaplin. Entertainer is too weak, star too lightly used a word to do any of them justice, but Charlie was always in a class of his own. His was one of those precious talents that bridge the gap between popular and highbrow art. Three generations of audiences have joined in laughter at the Little Tramp and recognized that in laughing at that jaunty figure, we laugh at our common predicament, the commotion we cause and the indignities we suffer trying to come to terms with the vagaries of the world.

title: MAX SCHWARTZ
description: Max Schwartz, founder and president of the 50-year-old Elmhurst Milk and Cream Company in Jamaica, Queens, died suddenly Monday in his home, at 8235 Surrey Place, Jamaica Estates, Queens. The son of a dairy farmer, Mr. Schwartz started his delivery business driving a horse and wagon to customers.

Unless the Federal Government sets enforceable national standards for disclosure, investors will continue to be illinformed about the municipal bonds and notes they are asked to buy.
