title: Mortgage Rate Rises Expected; Inflation, Fast Buying Pace Cited
description: Interest rates on home mortgages, which range between 8 and 9 percent depending on where one lives, are expected to edge upward by spring. As high as those interest rates are, compared with levels of only a few years ago, many economists believe they are here to stay at least for the forseeable future.

title: Miller of Broncos and Madden of Raiders Agree It's Difficult to Forecast Teams
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Dec. 27Red Miller, who coaches the Denver Broncos, remains virtually unknown to the general public outside of Denver, although he's familiar enough to pro football people. This is his first year as a head coach, but he spent 17 years in the National Football League as an assistant.

title: Begin Briefs Cabinet As Criticism Rises; Dayan Not Present
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 27Prime Minister Menahem Begin reviewed his meeting with President Anwar elSadat for the Israeli Cabinet today, amid growing criticism and complaint that the meeting had not lived up to expectations.

title: Bishop in Montana Resigns
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP)Pope Paul VI has accepted the resignation of the Most Rev. Eldon B. Schuster as Bishop of Great Falls, Mont., the United :States Conference of Bishops announced ,today. The announcement said that he was retiring because of ill health. He is 66 years old and has been Bishop of Great Falls for 10 years.

title: Chile Plans Debt Payments
description: SANTIAGO, Dec. 27 (Reuters)Chile will pay all its foreign debts falling due in the new year, it was officially announced here today. Minister of Planning Roberto Kelly told a news conference it would be the third consecutive year in which Chile will meet all its foreign commitments. He said foreign debts due in 1978 were about $1 billion.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP)  The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said today that it would ask the Federal Communications Commission to reconsider its decision to block construction of a seventh transAtlantic cable until at least 1985.

title: New York Gets City Hall Lift
description: Mayor Beame yesterday dedicated the first elevator to be built in the 165-year-old New York City Hall. It has three buttonsup, down and a panic button for Mr. Koch, the Mayor said in a reference to Edward I. Koch, who will succeed him on Sunday.

title: Houston Opera's Porgy To Tour Europe
description: The Sherwin M. GoldmanHouston Grand Opera production of Porgy and Bess, which ran on Broadway from Sept. 25, 1976, to Jan. 9, 1977, will make a European tour starting Jan. 19. It will begin with a sixweek engagement at the Palais des Congres in Paris, sponsored by the Paris Opera.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: Lawrence Van Gelder

title: Thelma Given Verdi, 81, Violinist Who Was a Renowned Child Prodigy
description: Thelma Given Verdi, a violinist, who became renowned as a child prodigy, died Sunday in Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston after suffering a stroke. She was 81 years old and lived in Provincetown, Mass.

title: CHAPLIN IS INTERRED IN BRIEF, PRIVATE RITE
description: CORSIER  SUR  VEVEY, Switzerland, Dec. 27Charlie Chaplin, the silver screen's impecunious tramp with a heart of gold, was buried today in the small cemetery of this village overlooking the Lake of Geneva.

title: Chrysler Recalls 1.3 Million Cars Over Problems in Carburetors
description: DETROIT, Dec. 17 (UPI)The Chrysler Corporation announced the recall today of 1.3 million cars because of problems over stalling.

title: Brazilian Is Winner Of $3 Million Lottery
description: The winner, Paulo Gustavo Coutinno de Faria, who owns a publ:shing company, has no plans for the money yet.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: New Year's Feast on the Half Shell
description: DESPITE the elegance of oysters and the connoisseurs utter delight in dining on oysters on half shell, it is generally conceded that the man who swallowed the first oyster must have been of fearless spirit, redoubtable self.assurance or, conceivably, faint from hunger. Jonathan Swift put it succinctly: He was a bold man that first eat an oyster.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: States foreign policy that seeks to gain justice for African blacks; how, many nonJews support a U.S. foreign policy that insists on Israel's secure independence.

title: A Start at Ismailia
description: No one should be surprised that President Sadat and Prime Minister Begin did not reach agreement in their twoday meeting at Ismailia on a statement of principles to govern a Middle East settlement. Nor can it fairly be charged that Mr. Begin has somehow failed to meet his part of a bargain-Arab recognition in exchange for Israeli withdrawal-implicit in Mr. Sadat's dramatic journey to Jerusalem last month. The surprise would have been a facile agreement toward resolving a dispute that has divided Israel from the Arab world for three decades. That would have implied either that the disputed issues are trivial or that Mr. Sadat is interested only in an EgyptianIsraeli deal. Neither is true.

title: Harmful TaxChange Idea: Cutting Benefits on Export
description: Thomas E. Mullaney

title: Nat'l Basketball Ass'n
description: Associated Press TOGETHERNESS: Kings Tom Burleson, left, closely guarded by Rockets Moses Malone, after scoring 2 points in the first period of play Monday night at Houston. Rockets won, 11399.

title: 1977- 1978: Memory And Hope
description: WASHINGTON-The turn of the year for most people in this country is a brief and happy holiaay. For the old, it is a time of memory; for the young, a tine of hope. For most people in the rest of the world, however, it is just another day on the calendar -a hangover from ancient struggles or last night's celebrations.

title: Less BigPower Tension, Greater War Danger
description: WASHINGTON-The Nixon-Brezhnev detente, now six years old, is a fragile relationship because it rests on a paradox. There is less tension between the two superpowers than in the coldwar years, but the danger of nuclear war is greater than ever.

title: H.E.W. to Publish Three Booklets Describing Rights of Handicapped
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP)The rights of handicapped people will be described in three nw booklets being prepared by the Department of Health, Education and Welfare.

title: Psychotherapy: Finding a
description: FINDING a psychotherapist in New York is like looking for a needle in a sewing store. There are lots of them but they come in so many forms, each seemingly suited to different purpose, that it is difficult to know which one to choose.

title: Livestock Prices Mixed
description: Chicago livestock prices were mixed; cattle futures closed slightly lower, while hogs and pork bellies were strong. Most pork bellies contracts closed at or near the limit of 2 cents a pound.

title: Article 4 -- No Title
description: United Press International As President Carter listened, James T. McIntyre spoke in Washington after his nomination as budget director

title: Beame Finds Panic Button In First City Hall Elevator
description: Mayor Beame yesterday dedicated the first elevator to be built in the I65-year-old City Hall. It has three. buttonsup, down and a panic button for Mr. Koch, the Mayor said in a reference to Edward I. Koch. who will succeed him next Sunday.

title: The Opera: A Special Sutherland Anniversary
description: BY WAY of celebrating the 20th anniversary of her Royal Opera debut, and the 30th of her singing career. Joan Sutherland is appearing in London's Covent Garden as Maria Stuarda in the Donizetti opera of that name. The role is not new to her, and in America she has sung it at the San Francisco Opera and elsewhere. But never in New York or London, and adoring audiences are flocking to.the Royal Opera to cheer the great lady on.

title: Dollar Is Mixed In T rading Abroad; Gold Price Gains
description: The dollar was mixed in postholiday trading on foreign exchanges and in New York yesterday, while the price of gold bullion showed a sharp gain, the Associated Press reported.

title: Energy Agency Sees Exxon Overcharges
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 27In .the first of what may become a potential string of similar actions, the Department of Energy charged today that the Exxon Corporation overcharged buyers of crude oil from two small fields in Alabama and Florida by $70.8 million between March 1, 1974, and Dec. 31, 1976.

title: Italians Hunt New Terror Network
description: ROME, Dec, 27Italian antiterrorism units are hunting a new network of urban guerrillas that calls itself Communist Frontline, often uses police uniforms for disguises, enrolls teenagers and is infiltrated by West German terrorists.

title: Notes on People
description: A FORMER PARISH PRIEST in Uganda who is now Angli can Bishop of Kenya, .1. Henry Okullu, warned church leaders to be wary of other Idi Amins in other. African nations. Bishop Okullu, chairman of his country's National Christian Council, issued his warning while on a short visit to the headquarters of the World Council of Churches, 475 Riverside Drive. Idi Amin, President of Uganda, has been held responsible for the reported deaths of 100 Ugandans. Bishop Okullu said that such actions could be repeated elsewhere on the African continent except in Kenya, which has remained relatively serene thanks to the great leadership of its President, Jomo Kenyatta.

title: TV: Szysznyk Runs A Coiiimunity Center
description: In assorted interviews, everyone connected with the series Szysznyk indignantly insists that the basic plots sprang whole and virginal from the heads of the creators. But a minute's sampling of the new CBS situation comedy, which can normally be seen Wednesdays at 8:3G. P.M. tonight Conversation with President Carter will be on insteadclearly fixes the format in the currently popular bluecollar mold somewhere between Chico and the Man and Welcome Back, Kotter.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: Come to a Party

title: Tentative Approval Given to a Plan To Overhaul Civil Service in State
description: TRENTON, Dec. 27Top Civil Service officials announced their tenative approval today of a planned reorganization of the system, which covers 60,000 state and 140.000 local government employees in New Jersey.

title: Critic's Notebook: Search for New Ima ebs-
description: N0 DOUBT great whales are swimming around in the Broadway depths waiting to break water and astound us. So tar, this season has consisted pretty much of small fry, though there have been one or two larger specimensThe Gin Game, for instance. Some of the small fry have been gaudy and expensivean Act or a Dracula'but no matter how much you gild a minnow, it is not going to shift very much water.

title: An American Khalil Gibran
description: Seven years ago, Hugh Prather, unemployed and frustrated over the fact that nothing he had written had been published, submitted his personal diary to the Real People Press, a small husbandwife book publishing team in Moab. Utah.

title: World News Briefs
description: PORT ELIZABETH, South Africa, Dec. 27 (AP)Three persons were wounded when the police fired on a group of blacks attempting to set a beer hall on fire and the police used tear gas to disperse a crowd gathered for the funeral of a man who died in prison, officials said today.

title: Blue CrossBlue Shield Seeking 7.1% Rate Increase in New York
description: Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Greater New York asked the State Insurance Department yesterday for permission to raise the premiums for 3.3 million of its hospitalization subscribers by an average of 7.1 percent next March 1.

title: California Official Denies Racial Bias in I.Q. Tests
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 27Intelligence tests do not discriminate against blacks, a California official told a Federal judge today in a case that is expected to determine whether the state will be allowed to use such tests to place children in remedial classes.

title: Nancy Lee Buzzalini Is Married to Dale Carlson
description: Nancy Lee Buzzalini, daughter of Peggy Jensen and Arnold Buzzalini, both of Tulsa, Okla., was married yesterday to Dale Richard Carlson. son of Richard A. Carlson of Seoul, Korea, and June J. Carlson of Lawton, Okla.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: FUTURES OF WHEAT CLOSE 5CENTS HIGHER
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 27 (AP)Reports of poor Chinese grain harvest started stoploss'buying that sent wheat futures soaring at the opening today on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: ExState Official Of Delaware Banks Makes Guilty Pleas
description: WILMINGTON, Del.,Dec. 27(AP)John W. Green, Delaware's former banking commissioner, pleaded guilty today to three counts of accepting illegal bank loans and one count of conspiracyin case resulting from a Federal investigation of Formers Bank..

title: Administrator of SouthWest Africa Says Territory Will Be Freed in 78
description: JOHANNESBURG. Occ. 27 (AP)SouthWcst Africa will become independent:next year regardless of the outcome of talks between South Africa and five Western nations, according to the territory's chief administrator.

title: Agency Control of Lawsuits Urged
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 27A Senate committee report issued today has concluded that with the exception of cases before the Supreme Court, the Government's independent regulatory agencies should conduct and control their own lawsuits.

title: Japan's Trade Surplus 2d Highest; New Commercial Mission in U.S.
description: The battle between the United States and Japan on the trade front moved another step forward yesterday with the arrival oof an important Japanese trade mission in Washington and the announcement of a new batch of balance of payments and other economic statistics here.

title: Beame Appoints 13 to Judgeships
description: Five days before his term of office expires, Mayor Beanie yesterday filled the last salaried positions at his disposal, naming 13 persons to the Criminal and Family Courts.

description: Music

title: The Now York Times
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 27Bert Lance and the Saudi businessman who is buying 60 percent of his bank stock for the premium price of $20 a share both said today that the sale was strictly a business deal that had nothing to do with Mr. Lance's Washington connections or possible plans to have the former budget director take part in a bank holding company to help handle Arab Investments in the United States.

title: SADAT VOWS TO BACK A PALESTINIAN STATE AND ISRAELI PULLOUT
description: CAIRO, Dec. 27President Anwar elSadat said today that while Israel had offered to return to Egypt all the Sinai Peninsula territory still under Israeli occupation, he would not back down from demands for full Israeli withdrawal from other occupied Arab territories and for creation of a Palestinian state.

title: Begin Briefs Cabinet As Criticism Rises; Dayan Not Present
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 27Prime Minister Menahem Begin reviewed his meeting with President Anwar elSadat for the Israeli Cabinet today, amid growing criticism and complaint that the meeting had not lived up to expectations.

title: Rules of Roe For Lovers Of Caviar
description: ANYONE WHO REGARDS caviar as an essential element in a bona fide New Year's Eve celebration, will hardly welcome news of the current astronomical prices in that highly prized fish roe, most especially in the case of largegrain beluga. The junin in the last 12 months ranges from 75 to 100 percent. The range around town is from $144 for special sale merchandise at Macy's to $200 at William Poll, both for a pound, which in caviar language means 14 ounces.

title: A House and Historians Burn
description: PARAMUS, Dec. 27On a stormy night two weeks ago, a group of 50 volunteer firemen poured gasoline on a white clapboard house and burned it down for practice. The fire drill touched off a controversy involving borough officials and the firemen as well as history enthusiasts, who say that they learned too late that the house was 225 years old.

title: Study Finds Guns Less Deadly on TV
description: ALTHOUGH THE THREE television networks in general have made good on their vows to cut back on physical violence in prime time this year, a new study by the United States Conference of Mayors has found that deadly weapons mainly guns and knivescontinue to appear with great frequency in the principal actionadventure shows.

title: Charles Gilman, 84, Top Business Aide For City's Schools
description: Charles Gilman. who rose from *office boy to the top business administrator in the New York City school system, died Monday night at Montefiore Hospital in the Bronx after a long illness. He was 84 years old and lived at 3333 Henry Hudson Parkway in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

title: Ismailia Parley Disappoints Saudis
description: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia, Dec. 27The results of the Ismailia meeting have left the Saudi Government somewhat disappointed and with mixed feelings about the prospects for Egypt's Middle East diplomacy, sources close to the Saudi royal family reported today.

title: Dance: A Week ofMolina
description: THE CURIOUS fluctuations of public taste that raise and topple performing empires have made Spanish dance a sometime tiling on Broadway. The process is quite mysterious but quite dictatorial, which is why a crisp ensemble such as Jose Molina Bailes Espaholes as very welcome when it does make an appearance. The company is presenting week of performances at the Bijou Theater, and Tuesday evening showed its bright combination of regional and flamenco dances.

title: CARTER ENDS IMPORT FEES ON OIL FOR RESERVE
description: WASHINGTON. Dec. 27 (AP)President Carter, saying the United Stateil must set up a strategic petroleum reserve as quickly as possible, issued an order today exempting oil products destined for the reservs from import fees.

title: Colleges Are Found Accepting Drinking on Their Campuses
description: STONY BROOK, L.I.The campus of the State University of New York here is much like a city. It has a large population, a police department and a bus system. It also has nine bars, six of them run by students.

title: Landry Scoffs at 11Point Odds on His CowboysHope It Snows in Dallas,
description: The point line posted in Reno yesterday had the Dallas Cowboys 11point favorites over the Minnesota Vikings for the National Conference championship at Texas Stadium on Sunday. That is a lot of points for championship game, and in Dallas the Cowboy coach, Tom Landry, had strong dissent.

description: The Center for Disease Control has col. lected data on 15 deaths that appear to lave been linked to use of liquid protein i diets.

title: Rutigliano Succeeds Gregg as Coach of the Browns
description: CLEVELAND, Dec. 27 (AP)Sam Rutigliano, receiver coach of the New Orleans Saints, was named today as head coach of the Cleveland Browns of the National Football League.

title: 2 More Dead in Dorm Fire
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 27 (AP)Two 18-pear-old Connecticut women who were severely burned in a dormitory blaze at Providence College two weeks ago have died, bringing the fire's death toll to nine. Dorothy A. Widman of Cheshire died last night at Roger Williams Hospital. Sallyann Garvey of Enfield died this morning at Brooke Army Medical Center in San Antonio.

title: Mary S. Wilson Is Wed to Michael Bassis
description: Mary Suzanne Wilson, daughter of f.Mr. and Mrs. Clark Loudon Wilson of New Canaan, Conn., was married there I yesterday at her parents home to Michael Steven Bassis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Bassis of Harrison, N.Y. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Edward W. Mills of St. Mark's Episcopal Church in New Canaan.

title: Deputy Mayor Friedman's Party: A Water Supply and Then Some
description: It's your last chance . . . You won't have Stanley Friedman to kick around any more, read the invitations to a party that Mayor Beame's Deputy Mayor for politics sent to his friends.

title: U.S. Is Pleased
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 27The State Department said today that the United States was pleased by progress reported at the Ismailia meeting of Prime Minister Menahem Begin of Israel and President. Anwar elSadat of Egypt, and said that priority should be given to creating a negotiating framework in coming weeks for an overall ArabIsraeli peace accord.

title: No Increase in '77 For China's Grains
description: HONG KONG, Dec. 27 (UPI)China reported today that its grain production did not rise in 1977. The news came first a year after a grain shortage forced the world's most populous nation to go on one of the biggest grainbuying sprees in history.

title: East Germany Sets Fishing Zone In Baltic Sea Effective Sunday
description: EAST BERLIN, Dec. 27 (Reuters)East Germany today joined Sweden and Poland in claiming a fishing zone in the Baltic Sea and said it would go into effect on Sunday.

title: Public Service Delays for 3 Years A Floating Nuclear Power Plant
description: NEWARK, Dec. 27New Jersey's largi esk,utility announced today that it would delay for three years its $2.1 billion project to operate the world's first floating nuclear power plant.

title: 16 Women Are Presented At Annual Cornelia Cotillion
description: Sixteen young women, seniors at the Cathedral School of St. Mary in Garden City, Li., and/or communicants at the Episcopal Cathedral of the Incarnation there, were presented in the cathedral last evening to Bishop Robert Campbell Witcher of Long Island, The young women, who qualified by service to the church and community, each received a commemorative gold medallion.

title: Port Body Action to Bar Concorde for Noise Level In 1985 Vetoed by Byrne
description: Still apparently hoping to snare the Concorde supersonic jetliner for service at Newark International Airport, Governor Byrne yesterday vetoed an action by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey that would have barred the BritishFrench planes from the three metropolitan jetports after 1985.

title: Judge Nullifies Will on Garden State Park
description: MOUNT HOLLY, Dec. 27 (UP1)A Superior Court judge has ruled against Eugene Mod Jr. in his attempt to gain control oldie burnedout Garden Slate Park race track, paving the way for the state to buy the track.

title: Mexican Actors Adapting Drama to Political Scene
description: MEXICO CITY, Dec. 27Assuming the pose of a Mexican president but dressed like a tramp, the young actor took questions from the audience of workers. What's the Alliance for Production? someone shouted. That's very simple, the actor replied quickly. You work and we earn. There was a roar of cheers, whistles and boos and then another question.

description: A plan to build 72 attached houses on the former Delafield Estate in the Riverdale section of the Bronx was unanimously rejected yesterday by the New York City Planning Commission.

title: Banker Turns Down Koch Offer to Be Housing Aide
description: Mayorelect Edward L Koch, as part of an effort to get more blacks to join his administration, offered the post of Commissioner of Housing Preservation and Development to William H. Hayden, a 36-year-old investment banker. But Mr. Hayden, citing personal reasons, declined the offer yesterday.

title: FRENCH HOSTAGES SAY ALGERIANS HELD THEM
description: PARIS, Dec. 27Six French citizens taken prisoner by guerrillas fighting for the independence of the Western Sahara said today that they had been detained in Algerian military bases and on one occasion had been beaten.

title: MILD., in Major Policy Change, Increasing Aid to Central Cities
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 27The Department of Housing and Urban Development announced today that it would channel more Federal rent subsidy and public housing money to central cities, a move that seemed to contradict the department's oftenstated policy of providing more suburban housine for the Door.

title: Books: Accent Put on Negative In Short Stories by Gayl Jones
description: IN HER FIRST TWO BOOKSCorregidora and Eva's Many both novelsGayl Jones explored the ambiguous, grim and violent. Ieis of love and sexuality. Despite the grisly. often lurid, nature of her theme and the acerbic narrative tone, the author's tightly controlled prose and perceptive characterization pile those novels a IYrical, bittersweet quality. In this, her first collection of short stories, Miss- Jones returns to the same theme: but in these short tales something of the vigor and en, eloping passion of her earlier works is lost.

title: ExMarshal Testifies in Secret on 1974 Gross Trial
description: NEWARK, Dec. 27A former United SIntei. deputy marshal testified secretly in Federal Court today that he and other marsha romanced women jurors during the the fraud trial of Nelson G. Gross in 1974.

title: John H. Crichton Is Dead at 58; Led Advertising Agencies Group
description: John Henderson Crichton, president of the American Association of Advertising Agencies, the most powerful organization in the agency business, died yesterday morning at his desk, of a heart attack. He was 58 years old and lived in New Canaan, Conn.

title: Added Help for Gifted Students Is Provided Throughout State
description: TRENTONSpurred by the State Board of Education, state and local school officials are devoting more and more of their attention to special programs in New Jersey public schools for unusually Rifted students.

title: Nat'l Hockey League
After an Unkind Cut, the Kindest Cut of All
description: I got a haircut today. But then, people get haircuts all the time. Three things made my haircut special. One, it was the first real haircut I'd had since I got married, 10 years ago June. Two, it was against my will. And three, I had my haircut at Kenneth's.

title: Carter Is Reportedly Nominating Texan as Democratic National Chief
description: WASHINGTON, Dec, 27 (UPI)President Carter's choice for Democratic national chairman is Deputy Agriculture Secretary John White, who was a Carter campaign strategist in Texas last year and was one of the fcw Texans to back Senator George McGovern for President. in 1972, it was learned today.

title: Budget Includes Soldier Field
description: CHICAGO. Dec. 27 (UPI)  A record $78.8 million .budget approved today !,v the Chicago Park District includes an tz800,000 allocation for maintenance on decaying Soldier Field through Jan. 1, 1979. Soldier Field will not be in operation after that.date unless rehabilitation plans are made and work has begun, Spokesman Said.. The stadium is the home of the Chicago Bears.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE CHARACTERS of Evelyn Waugh are a lesson in,the other end of anthropology. Here are the natives of a highly articulated culture that has no myths, only rituals. Like a magician's, all their tricks are in their top hats. Dying of manners, they are determined to go on snubbing reality, as if it were crasher at the party. The most thoroughly weaned generation in the world, they are discovering that a little money is a dangerous thing.

description: MADRID Dec. 28The invitation to Mr. Soares followed protracted consultations and behind-the-scenes horsetrading and seemed to confirm that the 53-year old Socialist leader was the indispensable man of Portuguese politics.

title: Carter, in TV Interview, Affirms Opposition to a Palestinian State
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 28  President Carter said tonight that Prime Minister Menahem Begin of Israel had taken a long step forward in offering selfrule for Palestinians on the West Bank of the Jordan River and in the Gaza Strip. He affirmed that the United States did not agree with President Anwar elSadat of Egypt that the Palestinians should be given an independent state.

title: Hanna's Lawyer Is Seeking Delay Of Bribery and Conspiracy Trial
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2S (UPI)A lawyer for former Representative Richard Hanna. Democrat of California, a defendant in the Korean bribery investigation in Congress, has asked for a postponement of Mr. Hanna's bribery and conspiracy trial.

title: Ministers
description: Residents of an upstate Catskill town who became ministers to protest rising property taxes were improperly removed from the town's tax rolls, a New York State Supreme Court justice has ruled in Albany.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: SHE'S BACK That great lady of the jazz keyboard, Mary Lou Williams, has come up from her North Carolina home to perform briefly tonight through Saturday at Blue Hawaii, a new supper club specializing in sea food at 135 Third Avenue (at 15th Street). Miss Williams last played here in April, in a joint recital at Carnegie Hall. Her swinging style, with its Kansas City roots from the 1930's and bebop sounds of the 40's, made a colorful contrast to the avantgarde playing of Cecil Taylor, who shared the keyboard bill.

title: Arab Foes of Sadat Plan to Meet Again Before MidJanuary
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 28  Amid growing disappointment over the EgyptianIsraeli peace talks, Arab opponents of President Anwar elSadat's initiatives announced plans today to meet again.

title: Pope Paul Said to Back Return of Hungarian Crown
description: ROME, Dec. 28The United States reportedly cleared its intention to return the crown of St. Stephen to Hungary with the Vatican before an announcement was made.

title: Associated Press
description: EVASIVE ACTION: Garry Jordan of Niagara University trying to evade University of Connecticut players during action last night in Hartford in the opening round of Connecticut tournament. Niagara won, 9672.

title: Behind the Brush: A Painter's Story
description: ALOT Is said about the nightmare of repainting, and endless sympathy is offered those who face it. I think it's time some consideration Is given the painter. He has stories to tell too, for things aren't much better at the top of the ladder.

title: About Newyork
description: There really is a New York City agency that collects and stores every single press release from the Mayor's office into perpetuitya Victorian pervesion, surely, comparable to pressing each leaf from a windblown forest into one fat book of burnished days.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Governor Byrne signed a bill yesterday that will give 38,000 retired persons a $12 million increase in their cost-of-living pension benefits.

title: Victim of 34th St. Fire is Arrested
description: The owner of a 34th Street shoe store who complained bitterly that the building could not be saved from a fire Monday because the sprinkler system did not work has been arrested for failing to appear in court seven months ago on a charge that the sprinkler system was faulty.

title: Companies Issue Earnings Reports
State Moves to Curb Shore Projects Linked With Oil Drilling in Atlantic
description: TRENTON, Dec. 28New Jersey's general strategy for protecting its coastal area from overdevelopment during the rapidly approaching Atlantic oil-drilling era is nearly completed, David N. Kinsey said in an interview today.

title: Workers and Asbestos Makers Settle
description: Cleveland, Dec. 28 (AP)A V.8 million settlement was reached today on filed against 17 corporat'ons by 10 insulation installers who became ill and relatives of 16 workers who died after inhaling asbestos, according to lawvers for the workers and relatives.

title: Roosevelt
description: ENTRIES

title: One Dies, 2 Hurt in Mine Cave-In
description: LAUREL GROVE, Tenn., Dec. 28 (AP)A cavein today at a small coal mine killed one of the mine's owners and injured two miners, officials said. The men were reportedly alone in the mine just inside th mouth when the shaft collapsed and were trapped in the fall. The D.C. and S. Mining Company mine, about 30 miles north of Knoxville, was just beginning operations. The dead man was identified as James Singleton, 46 years old, a coowner.

title: Spanish Officer Convicted
description: MADRID, Dec. 28 (Reuters)A Spanish Air Force captain who belonged to a secret officers group opposed to the late Francisco Franco was sentenced to seven years in prison today on a charge of hay.: ing incited rebellion in the armed forces. The officer, Capt. Jose Ignacio Dominguez, will not serve the prison sentence because the offense was covered by a royal amnesty, but he will be dismissed from the air force, his lawyers said.

title: Home Improvement
description: AS EXPLAINED IN LAST week's discussion of how the heating efficiency of an open fireplace can be increased, the typical open fireplacewith no heating accessories often wastes more heat than it generates. This happens if it is used while the home's central heating system is working and when temperatures outside drop below a recently defined breakeven level, usually about 19 to 20 degrees Fahrenheit. Above this temperature, there is likely to be a heat gain from the fire.

title: GOVERNMENT BONDS SUP IN LIGHT TRADE LATE IN THE SESSION
description: Government bond prices fell moderate ly late yesterday afternoon in reaction to newswire reports, later confirmed, that G. William Miller, chairman of Textron, Inc., would be named to replace Arthur F. Burns as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board.

title: BEGIN INSISTS ISRAEL MUST KEEP TROOPS IN WEST BANK AREA
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 28Prime Minister Menahem Begin defended, his peace plan before Parliament today, insisting that Israeli forces must remain in the occupied Arab territories of the West Bank of the Jordan and the Gaza Strip and declaring that the next move in the IsraeliArab peace maneuvering was up to Egypt.

title: Public Held Split on Health Benefits
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 28The Department of Health, Education and Welfare concluded today that while Americans favored some type of national health insurance there was wide disagreement on the benefits that should be offered and how its costs should be met.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Dec. 28  The Exxon Corporation has purchased major copper mine in the largest private United States investment in Chile since the military overthrow of President Salvador Allende in 1973.

title: U.S. CORRESPONDENTS GIVE VIEWS ON C. I. A.
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 28Four longtime correspondents told a House intelligence subcommittee today that any relationship with the Central Intelligence Agency beyond ari exchange of information violated the ethics of their profession.

title: Text of Begin's Plan for West Bank and Gaza Strip
description: JERUSALEM. Dec. 27Following. in the official English version. is the text nj the plan for the West Bank of the Jordan River and Gaza Strip that Prime Minister Menahem Begin read to the tnreeli Parliament today.

title: The Allure of Teleprinter Leads To School Program Tied to News
description: A few years ago, Richard 0. Curtis was teaching children in Maryland who had difficulties in learning to read. Occasionally he would take his students to the local radio station, where he was moonlighting as a disk jockey.

title: Stores Looted in Blackout Get NoInterest Loans
description: When Clemente Rodriquez dared to look, he found he had been wiped out. Vandals had smashed his windows and stolen $55,000 worth of men's and boys clothing during the July 1314 blackout in New York City.

title: Con Ed Maps Antiblackout Steps In a FiveYear, $65 Million Plan
description: After five months of studying last July's systemwide power blackout, the Consolidated Edison Company yesterday announced a fiveyear, $65 million program of technical steps intended to prevent a recurrence.

title: Rockland's Services Are Disrupted As County Employees Start Strike
description: NEW CITY, N.Y., Dec. 28Many Rockland County offices were closed and many services were curtailed or reduced today as a large number of county employees walked off the job in support of their union's demands for a new contract with higher pay.

title: Spacious Frame for Art and Living
description: When Maryse and Robert Boxer gave a party for Elie and Jacqueline Jacobson, their friends from Paris who own the Dorothee Bis ready-to-wear business, a house tour was part of the entertainment.

title: Hers
description: IHAVE long blond hair hanging well below my shoulders. I always carry a handbag and have also been known to carry a briefcase when I am lugging around a stack of papers. My favorite colors are yellow, orange and red; I don't Own a sinele navy blue suit.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article published on Tuesday, quoting intelligence sources, identified a reporter who had a working relationship with the Central Intelligence Agency as the late Edward P. Kennedy of The Indianapolis Star. The correct identity is the late Edward It Kennedy, who worked for The Indianapolis Times, now defunct.

title: Bombing Near Market Kills 2 Men in Israel
description: TEL AVIV, Thursday. Dec. 29 (AP)A bomb exploded near the main market in Netanya this morning, killing two men and injuring two others, Israeli radio reported. One of the injured was said to be in critical condition.

title: SAUDI DECLARES U. S. MUST PRESS ISRAEL
description: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia, Dec. 28A senior official of the Foreign Ministry, commenting today on President Carter's visit next week, said today that the Saudi rulers wanted the United States to force Israel to make concessions on Middle East issues.

title: Bridge:
description: If you are thinking in terms of highcard points, tricks, trumps or any kind of match points, two can be assumed to be better than one, although there are some rare exceptions. But when it comes to guesses, one is better than two, except for those rare mortals who always guess right.

title: If It's Thursday, This Must Be Warsaw
description: Wise headsfrom Henry Kissinger's to George Ball's are spinning over what is said to be an absence of clearcut priorities in the Carter Administration's foreign policy. For evidence, critics point to the President's whirlwind dash halfway around the world, which begins today. When the trip was originally plannedback in October, when Bert Lance was on the griddle and Mr. Carter needed to look more Presidentialhis itinerary included nine countries on four continents in 11 days. Now, with Brazil, Venezuela and Nigeria postponed for a separate expedition in March, Mr. Carter will visit Poland, Iran, India, Saudi Arabia, France and Belgiumsix countries in nine days. The list of issues to be covered now and in March is as exhausting as the itinerary itself. The issues include:

title: Associated Press
description: TWO DIE IN ATLANTA SHOOTOUT: Police officers taking cover behind car yesterday as a Fulton County Marshal, left, lay dead after a gun battle with occupants of house who were being served an eviction notice. Officers who surrounded house and returned gunfire killed one of the two occupants. Soon after tear Las was fired into house, starting a fire, Mujahid Muhammad, also known as Nicky Gore, surrendered to the police.

title: Ski Conditions
Nat'l Hockey League
description: AT PITTSBURGH

title: Brig. Gen. Joseph W. Barron, 62, Retired Official of Singer Company
description: Joseph W. Barron, a retired brigadier general in the Air Force and vice president for government liaison for the Aerospace and Marine Systems Group for the Singer Company, died Monday at his home in Potomac, Md., at the age of 62.

title: Guyana Sells Alumina To Soviet First Time
description: GEORGETOWN, Guyana, Dec. 28 (UPI)Guyana has sold 25,000 tons of alumina to the Soviet Union for delivery during the first quarter of 1978, the first ever sale from Guyana's baux ite industry to the Russians.

title: GARDENING
description: THIS might be a good time to settle some points on the care of Christmas gift plants lest they suffer from neglect inthe New Year's celebrating.

title: Thai Premier, Playiniss. Down Border. Clashes, Voices Hope for Better Relations With Indochinese
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 28Prime Minister Kriangsak Chamanand took pains in an interview today to minimize the importance of the continuing skirmishes along the Cambodian border, which have taken the lives of 173 Thais this year.

title: Personal Beauty
description: JUST about the surest way to invite a ski accident is to set off on the slopes before your body is in shape for strenuous sport. Even if you are an experienced skier, if you haven't been on skis since last winter, all experts warn that you are asking for trouble if you plunge in before your muscles are ready.

title: F.D.I.C. Audits Asked
description: The General Accounting Office recommended yesterday that the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation require audits of bank supervisors and more thoi ough documentation on problem banks. Page D2.

title: The New York Times/Robert Walker
description: STILL NO CLUE: Divers search the Hook Creek in North Woodmere, where the clothes of Debra Cohen, 19, were found along the bank five days ago. Private divers were hired by the girl's family after police temporarily broke off the unsuccessful underwater search.

title: 15 JUDGES SWORN IN AMID A CONTROVERSY
description: Brushing aside criticism of his judicial appointments, Mayor Beame swore in 15 judges yesterday to the Criminal and Family Courts and then ran into new criticism from his Judicial Screening Committee, which had approved all of the names.

title: HOWARD SHOOKHOFF, EPIDEMIOLOGIST, DIES
description: Dr. Howard B. Shookhoff, an authority on tropical diseases and an epidemiologist, died Tuesday of a heart attack. He was 67 years old and lived at 550 Fieldstone Road in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

title: Ad Agency Wanted to Sell
description: The New York City Planning Commission wants to hire an advertising agency to develop plans and strategies to increase subway ridership in order to maintain the 50cent fart.

title: Assoclated Press IN LONDON, TOO: Security officers at Debenham's store in London's West End preparing to open the doors to start its postChristmas sale yesterday. Many of the shoppers waited for days to cash in on the sharply reduced prices.
Presented at Regina Cotillion
description: Seven young women from Long Island were presented last night to Bishop John R. McGann of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Rockville Centre at the 20th Regina Cotillion at the Plaza Hotel. The presentation is sponsored by the Regina Assemblies. an affiliate of Catholic Charities. Proceeds go to the Bishop's Fund for Children.

title: Study by CareyKoch Panel Calls Westway Best for City's Economy
description: A panel appointed to provide Covernor Carey and Mayorelect Edward I. Koch with definitivl arguments for and against the Westway reported yesterday that building the roadway would produce substantially more jobs and bring in more public money than would trading in the Project for masstransit improvements.

title: Two-Teen-Agers in Bronx Are Held In Attacks on Woman Neighbor, 72
description: Two teenage boys, one 13 years old, the other 14, were held in the Bronx yesterday in connection with a sixday siege of terror against a 72-year-old woman, a former concert pianist, who lived in the same apartment building.

title: Count Galeazzo Sforza, Served Council of Europe as Deputy Head
description: STRASBOURG, France, Dec. 28 (AP)Count Galeazzo Sforza, deputy secretary general of the Council of Europe for the last nine years, died here early today at the age of 61 following a long illness, the council secretariat announced.

title: Man Who Killed Wife Is Sentenced To Work for the Poor for 3 Years
description: DAVENPORT, Iowa, Dec. 28 (UPI)Richard Reddy will not go to prison for the slaving of his wife.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Our coffee table has a real marble top, and when our grandchild was visiting us recently she spilled orange juice on it in several places. Rings and spots remain that I have tried to remove with a liquid kitchen wax, to no avail. Can you tell me how to remove these unsightly spots and rings? Mrs. M.E.S., Philadelphia, Pd.

title: Oral Roberts Women Find Adventure Here
description: Because the scheduling of the Queens linliday Basketball Tournament had worked out in their favor, giving them yesterday afternoon free, and because most of them had come from small Midwestcrn towns with populations of 200 to 300, and this was their first trip to New York City, the members of the Oral Roberts University women's team decided to take on the town before last night's semifinal game against Old Dominion.

title: Letters
description: Terminal Defense

title: Associated Press Prime Minister Menahem Begin of Israel speaking with Deputy Prime Minister Yigael Yadin during Parliament session in Jerusalem at which Mr. Begin defended his peace proposal. At right is Foreign Minister Moshe Dayan.
description: CAIRO, Dec. 28President Anwar el Sadat urged today that Israel reconsider its Middle East policy to take proper account of the new climate created by his talks with Prime Minister Menahem Begin in Jerusalem last month and in Ismailia on Sunday and Monday.

title: Skiers Do AboutFace Down a Catskills Slope
description: WOODRIDGE, N. Y., Dec. 28Quite a stir was created at the Big Vanilla ski area this afternoon when a dozen youngsters were schussing down that southern Catskills main slopebackwards.

title: Tuna Industry Spokesmen Assert Foreign Fleets Lure U.S. Talent
description: SAN DIEGO, Dec. 28 (AP)Foreign tuna fleets are taking skilled workers from the American industry, with many captains taking tOs on foreign boats to make more money and to escape strict Federal regulations, industry spokesmen say.

title: News Summary
description: THURSDAY, DECEMBER 29, 1977

title: $2.08 BILLION DEFICIT IN NOVEMBER TRADE IS BELOW OCTOBER'S
description: WACHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP)The United States bought 52.08 billion more than it sold to other countries in November, but the monthly trade deficit fell short of the record S3.09 billion set in October, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Somali Arms Request Reported
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 28 (Reuters)President Mohammed Siad Barre of Somalia said today that he had asked the Shah to give President Carter a message that is believed to be a request for arms. President Carter is scheduled to come here Saturday.

title: Teachers in Bergen Fight Proposal To Limit Heating in Schools to 68
description: NEWARK, Dec. 28Teachers from 21 Bergen County school districts opposed today, for reasons of both comfort and education, the State Department of Energy's proposed fuel conservation regulation that would forbid a thermostat setting higher than 68 degrees Fahrenheit in public buildings.

title: Rites for Crichton
description: A memorial service for John Crichton, president of the American Association of Advertising Agencies who died Tuesday, will be held Friday at 11 A.M. at the New Canaan Presbyterian Church, 178 Oenoke Ridge Road, New Canaan, Conn.

title: Disks: Early Budapest Quartet
description: THESE RECORDINGS, which in the opinion of some connoisseurs of stringquartet playing represent the Budapest at its finest level, have been out of circulation for many years. Later versions of these works by later versions of the Budapest drove out the 78rpm performances, which date from the mid1930's when the violist was Istvan Ipolyi. He was one of the founders of the group, whose original members had been playing in the Budapest Opera Orchestra when they formed their quartet in 1918. The others, if you want to stump your musical friends, were Emil Hauser and Alfred Indig, violinist, and Harry Son, cellist. So these recordings form a bridge between the original Budapest and the group that most record listeners know.

title: Charles Payson Weds Miss Kraft
description: Virginia Kraft, an associate editor of Sports Illustrated magazine, was married at the Episcopal Church of St. Mary the Virgin in Falmouth Foreside, Me., yesterday to Charles Shipman Payson, retired chairman of the Vitro_ Corporation of America and majority sti:ckholder of the New York Mets baseball team.

title: Soviet Union Wins, 32, In Junior Hockey Event
description: QUEBEC, Dec. 28 (AP)The Soviet Union rallied after trailing by 20 and defeated Canada, 3.2, in the first game of the A Division final in the Junior World Cup hockey tournament.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Carter Picks John White, a T exan, As Chairman of Democratic Party
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP)President darter today named John C. White, a Texan, as his choice to run the debt-ridden Democratic Party and told him the coming Congressional election year would be a good challenge.

title: 4 U.S. PUBLISHERS ISSUE PLEA FOR IRANIAN WRITER
description: Four leading publishers have issued an appeal on behalf of Dr. Gholamhossein Saedi, an Iranian writer, who has been invited by American publishers to visit the United States but has been denied a passport by his country.

title: CARTER REAPPOINTS KAHN AS CHAIRMAN OF THE C.A.B.
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP)President Carter reappointed today Alfred E. Kahn, the New York economist, to another oneyear term as chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board.

title: Gerulaitis Wins, Rosewall Also In Quarterfinals
description: MELBOURNE. Australia, Dec. 2S (UPI) Topseeded Vitas Gerulaitis defeated a countryman. Dick Bohrnstedt, 64, 64, 64, today and became the only American in the men's quarterfinals of the rainplagued $200,000 Australian open tennis championships. Gerulaitis was quick and sharp on the grass court.

title: Against Boycotting for the E.R.A.
description: Recently a governing body of an organization to which I belong voted to hold no national meetings in any state that had not ratified the Equal Rights Amendment.

title: Carey Urges Control Board Role In City Negotiations With Unions
description: ALBANY, Dec. 28Governor Carey said today that the Emergency Financial Control Board should participate simultaneously in contract negotiations that the administration of Mayorelect Edward I. Koch will conduct early next year with New York City publicemployee unions.

title: Dispute on Heart Surgery Grows in Journal's Pages
description: A raging controversy over pubcation of results of a study of coronary bypass surgery in one of the world'' leading medical journals has led the magazine to print a special correspondence stetion in today's issue.

title: Refined Copper Stocks Rise
description: Refined copper stocks held in the United States rose 38,900 short tons in November, the American Bureau of Metan Statistics said yesterday in its latest monthly report. The increase followed rises of 8,600 tons in October and 38,800 tons in September. Refined stocks were 456,900 tons at the end of November. Crude copper production slipped to 114,300 tons in November from 114,6200 tons in October. Refined production rose to 137,300 tons from 120,600 tons in October. Refined deliveries were estimated at a preliminary level of 125,800 tons, down from 145,700 tons in October.

title: Rock: New Theater Opens With Punk
description: ICAN'T BELIEVE how unfinished this place is, a young woman said as she brushed a layer of plaster dust off her coat. She was squinting at the darkness inside the old Anderson Theater through a pair of sunglasses. You look cute, her friend said. Punk. I like it.

title: Study by CareyKoch Panel Calls Westway Best for City's Economy
description: A panel appointed to provide Governor Carey and Mayorelect Edward I. Koch with definitive economic arguments for and against the Westway reported yesterday that building the roadway would produce substantially more jobs and bring in more public money than would trading in the project for masstransit improvements.

title: Notes on People
description: FORMER Attorney General John N. Mitchell, who has been in Federal prison in Alabama for six months after his conviction complicity in the Watergate coverup, began a 10day medical furlough yesterday. He left the prison camp at Maxwell Air Force Base to visit orthopedic surgeons who will determine if the 64-year-old lawyer will need an operaticn to correct a degenerative condition of his right hip. The furlough, which. ends Jan. 15, was approved by Attorney General Griffin B. Bell after the prison authorities ruled that it might not be safe for Mr. Mitchell to go to Springfield, Mo., for diagnosis, the customary procedure. Mr. Mitchell entered the prison June 22 to serve 30 months to eight years. Federal District Judge John J. Sirica later reduced his sentence to one year, making him eligible for parole next June.

title: New York City Sidewalk Cafes May Ignore 9 Agencies at Once
description: If nine New York City agencies are asked to enforce one set of city regulations, half the businesses affected by them will ignore all of them.

title: Levitt Industries President
description: Lester Dembitzer has been appointed president and chief operating officer of Levitt Industries Inc. He has been active in the management of the company since 1971 and has served as its vice chairman since April 1975.

title: Carol Kahn. EditorWriter, Is Married to Peter Mathes
description: The marriage of Carol Kahn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Kahn of New York, to Peter Mathes took place yesterday at Congregation Habonim. The bridegroom is a son of Mrs. Abraham Ribicolf and the late A. Herbert Mathes of Miami, an architect. His stepfather is a United States Senator from Connecticut,

title: New Parents, in Gift to Neediest, Remember LessFortunate Children
description: A new mother with a 7-Week-old daughter found time to think of those who are deprived when she gave a gift of $50 to the 66th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Islanders

title: The New York Times/Jack Manning HOLIDAY TREAT: The Cottage Marionette Theater at Central Park West and 81st Street drew intent spectators to its performance of The Reluctant Dragon.
Music: P.D.Q. each
description: THE MUSIC of P.D.Q. Bach is untiringly disinterred by Prof. Peter Schickele, who sees fit to present his new finds to New York audiences as a kind of holiday gift each year. The latest program was presented in Avery Fisher Hall on Tuesday night. A second performance was given last night, and the final one is scheduled for tomorrow.

title: Backgammon:
description: Backgammon is a game of calculated risk. When your opponent has a 5point home board, it is especially important to reduce danger to a minimum.

title: Around the Nation
description: DETROIT, Dec. 28The Chrysler Corporation, which announced yesterday the recall of 1.3 million cars because of stalling problems, has notified the Government that it also plans to recall 1.2 million cars to correct malfunctioning secondary hood latches.

title: Associated Press Tower of grain elevator complex in Galveston, Tex., after blast ripped structure. It was the third grain facility blast in the past week.
description: GALVESTON, Tex., Dec. 28 (UPI)Agriculture Department officials said today that unusually dry conditions might have been a key factor in explosions at three Southern grain handling facilities that killed at least 49 persons and injured 47 others in less than a week.

title: DOLLAR DIPS LOWER ON WORLD MARKETS
description: The dollar fell on world foreign exchange markets yesterday amid news of another large United States trade deficit for November and, in later trading in New York. to President Carter's nomination of G. William Miller to replace Arthur F. Burns as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, The Associated Press reported.

title: Wheat Up
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 28 (AP)Commissionhouse buying lifted wheat futures almost 3 cents a bushel, but other grain futures declined today on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Record production at an RCA plant. Demand for new copies of old Crosby and Presley recordings has been so great that manufacturers cannot keep up.
description: The deaths of Elvis Presley and Bing Crosby, two of the most successful recording artists in history, have created a commercial bonanza for the nation's record industry. An unexpected surge in demand for new copies of their old records has strained capacity throughout the industry and forced delays in producing new releases.

title: The New York Times/Carl T. Gossett Richard Gieg looking through used books as Marie Tarczewski, an employee, looks on at the Bookworm in Cranbury
description: CRANBURY, Dec. 23 A recent proposal to build a church on South Main Street has inspired a typical conflict in this quaint, pastoral Middlesex County township.

title: Amtrak, Pushing Sales, Takes BoxTop Route
description: In an unusual promotion, Amtrak, the National Railroad Passenger Corporation, has joined with the Kellogg Company to offer freeride coupons on cereal boxes.

title: Economic Mix Can Revitalize Northeast, Study Says
description: A new federally financed study of the economic plight of the Northeastern States traces many of the region's problems to adversarial relationships between business, labor and government and to the dispersing effect that modern transportation and communications systems have had nationwide on manufacturing and people.

title: SHIP ENGINE WHOLESALER GOES BANKRUPT IN JAPAN
description: TOKYO, Dec. 28 (UPI)Sagami Shipbuilding Industries, a ship engine wholesaler based in Tokyo, went bankrupt today with $83 million in accumulated liabilities, the fourth largest such action this year.

title: Family Money: Tax Audits
description: IF THE Internal Revenue Service has audited your tax returns for the last several years and you feel that you're being picked on, there is one consolationyou've got plenty of company.

title: First Steps on Corrections
description: Mayor-elect Koch ate Christmas lunch on Rikers Island with inmates of the House of Detention for Men, defendants awaiting trial, sentence or transportation to state prisons where they will serve their terms. Mr. Koch's visit suggests that he will give high priority to the problems of the city's jails. They need it.

title: Nat'l Basketball Ass'n
Grant Paves Way for Converting Meadowlands Landfills Into Park
description: SECAUCUS, Dec. 28The Hackensack Meadowlands Development Commission today received a $75,000 grant for the initial engineering and architectural planning to transform four huge garbage dumps into the key segment of a 2,000acre state park.

title: Transit Motorman Suspended Twice Has IND Accident
description: A motorman the Transit Authority said had been suspended twice for several days this year for passing red lights was suspended again yesterday without pay following a crash in which about 30 people suffered minor Injuries.

title: Associated Press Prime Minister Menahem Begin of Israel speaking with Deputy Prime Minister Yigael Yadin during Parliament session in Jerusalem at which Mr. Begin defended his peace proposal. At right is Foreign Minister Moshe Dayan.
description: CAIRO, Dec. 28President Anwar elSadat urged today that Israel reconsider its Middle East policy to take proper account of the new climate created by his talks with Prime Minister Menahem Begin in Jerusalem last month and in Ismailia on Sunday and Monday.

title: Deliverers Walk Out At The Daily News
description: Deliveries of today's editions of The Daily News were halted last night by a wildcat strik by members of the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union. sources at the newspaper said. The News has a weekday circulation of two million.

title: Chilean Junta Split By Pinochet's Bid ForVote of Support
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Dec. 28President Augus'o Pinochet's decree asking Chileans to vote on whether they support him or a United Nations resolution condemning humanrights violations here has producrd a serious crisis in Chile's military junta.

title: Dave Anderson
description: DALLAS, Dec. 28As the tiny, son of the New York Giants light end of two decades ago, Ken MacAfee Jr. occasionally toddled about the Giants locker room.

title: Deaths
description: ANZELSophie, beloved wife of Dr. Jemes. Interment private.

description: Two Minneapolis policemen last night accused New York City police officials of interfering with their search here for teenage prostitutes from Minneapolis.

title: Decisive Corporate Humanist
description: Back in 1956, G. William Miller was approached by Royal Little, the founder of Textron Inc., one of the early conglomerates, with a job offer.

title: Waldheim Sees Independence For SouthWest Africa in 1978
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 28Secretary General Kurt Waldheim held out hope today that the independence of SouthWest Africa would be achieved in 1978.

title: Stocks Gain but Dow Is Unchanged; Amex Index Rises to Record Levels
description: The stock market, lifted by selected buying late in the session, finished slightly higher yesterday as trading volume expanded from Tuesday's slow pace.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: WETHERSFIELD, Conn., Dec. 28 (AP)The promoter of a Middletown ilhoroughbred racing track, facing a lice. 31 financing deadline, said today he had commitments from 11 of 14 investors to provide $9 million. But Ronald Mooney told the State Gaming Commission it was unlikely he could yet a commitment in writing from a baiik by Dec. 31 to provide the remaining $40 million he needs to build the rck.

title: Portugal Asks Caretaker Prime Minister to Form a New Government
description: LISBON, Dec. 28 (AP)Mario Soares, ousted earlier this month as head of Portugal's first freely elected government in half a century, said today that he had been asked to try to form a second one.

title: S.E.C. SCHEDULES HEARINGS. ON OIL ACCOUNTING RULES
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 28The Securities and Exchange Commission today announced it would hold hearings next March on controversial oil and gas accounting standards recently proposed by the Financial Accounting Standards. Board.

title: G.A O., Citing Errors in Carter Transition, Urges More Curbs
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP)A report by the General Accounting Office says that procedures for handling the funds available to incoming Presidents should be tightened to avoid irregularities such as those it attributed to President Carter's transition team.

title: Associated Press The Crimson Hall of the 17thcentury Wilanow Palace in Warsaw where President Carter and his wife, Rosalynn, will stay during their visit.
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 28On the eve of his departure, President Carter immersed himself today in preparations for his second trip abroada sixnation tour covering 18,500 miles.

title: Players'
description: Union College will not play tonight and tomorrow in its own hockey tournament at its home base in Schenectady, N.Y., nor against Clarkson next Tuesday. As it happens, Union has had to cancel all the eames.

title: 1971 MAKES CARTERS MILLIONDOLLAR CLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP)in the 11 months since Jimmy Carter became President, members of his family have enjoyed a windfall of nearly a million dollars from ventures ranging from wellpublic appearances and product endorsements to books by several family members.

title: Language Center Bombed in Iran
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 28 (UPI)An explosion rocked the IranAmerica Society's coaching center six blocks from the United States Embassy in downtown Tehran tonight, injuring at least three persons, authorities said. The center, an institution that organizes language classes for Iranians, is affiliated with the IranAmerica Society, which is sponsored by the United States Embassy.

title: Burton to Do Lear and Mercutio
description: Richard Burton will play the title role in King Lear on Broadway next season, performing it in repertory with Romeo and Juliet, in which he will act the role of Mercutio. Both plays will be directed by John Dexter an will be produced by Alexander H. Cohen.

title: Business Records
A Touch of the Poet
description: EUGENE O'NEILL'S A Touch of the Poet is not one of his greatest plays but it has greatness in it.

title: Third Man Being Sought In Murder of Policeman And Harlem Transvestite
description: A third man was being sought by the police yesterday for the murder of an offduty police officer and a transvestite in a Harlem tenement last week.

description: Tuesday, Dec. 28, 1977

description: Horses hsted is order of post positions

title: Doctor Says Reports Tying Deaths To Liquid Protein Are Premature
description: LOS ANGELES. Dec. 28Dr. Robert Linn, author of The Last Chance Diet. a bestseller that popularized the liquid protein diet, charged today that Government reports that the diet may be responsible for the deaths of some patients were full of ifs, maybes and perhapses.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: be used to help develop a D.E.C. urban wildlife program.

title: HOUSING PLAN OMITS AID FOR NEW YORK
description: New York City will not be affected by a change in Federal housing policy that could send additional subsidy funds for public housing to the central cities, a Federal housing official said yesterday.

title: Georgia Counties Sued on Voting
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 28The Atlanta office of the American Civil Liberties Union has added Jimmy Carter's home county of Sumpter to the growing list of jurisdictions against which it has filed suit, contending that the black vote is so diluted by atlarge elections that no black has a chance of election.

title: American Tobacco's New Head
description: Virginius B. Lougee 3d has been named president of the American Tobacco Company, it was announced yesterday by Robert K. Heimann, chairman of American Brands, Inc., the parent company. Mr. Lougee who joined the company in 1951, has been executive vice president of American Tobacco, of which he will also be chief operating officer. The 51yearold executive is also a director or the parent company.

title: The New York Times/D. Gorton Henry C. Wallich of the Federal Reserve System, before speaking at luncheon meeting in New York yesterday.
description: The basic soundness of the dollar, which has this year fallen by 5 percent against other maior currencies on a tradeweighted basis, was the theme of a major policy speech yesterday by Henry C. Wailich, a Federal Reserve System governor.

title: Bailey Stars As Rutgers Wins Easily
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J., Dec. 28 (AP)Rutgers led by an many as 29 points in the second half and swept past Seton Hall, 9378, to win the New Jersey classic basketball tournmanent tonight. St. Peter's topped Fairleigh Dickinson, 8262, in the thirdplace consolation same_

title: Burlington and Frisco Request Permission of I.C.C. to Merge
description: Burlington Northern Inc. and the St. LouisSan Francisco Railway Company applied formally yesterday to the Interstate Commerce commission for permission to nierge. The filing came after more than nine months of study by executives of the two roads and an agreement on financial terms was approved by directors of both companies early this month.

title: Edia: S. Kelly Wed To C. F. Reiman Jr.
description: Edith Sillcox Kelly of Montclair, N. J., widow of Frank A. Kelly, was married yesterday in the Unitarian Church of Montclair to Conrad Frederick Reiman Jr. of Orange, Conn. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Donald Kinloch Edmonds of Glagow and Norfolk. Va.

title: LUCILE HERZSELD HARRIS
description: Lucile Herzseld Harris died of cancer Monday night at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital. A resident of Dallas, Mrs. Harris, who was 78 years old, was the widow of Leon A. Harris, a pioneer Texas merchant whose department store was merged into the SangerHarris Company. Active in civic affairs, Mrs. Harris was a trustee of the Dallas Museum of Fine Arts.

title: U.S. Aides Frustrated Over Soviet Gains in Ethiopia
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 28Government officials are voicing frustration over American inability so far to persuade the Soviet Union and Cuba to reduce their military involvement in Ethiopia in the conflict with Somalia.

title: Metropolitan Briefs't
description: Two gunmen wearing ski masks entered the offices of the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority on Randalls Island early yesterday morning, ordered officials to lie on the floor and took $63,000 in payroll cash and escaped.

title: Playoff Injury Report
description: Following is the list of injured players for Sunday's National Football League conference championships, as provided by the teams yesterday. Ken Stabler, whose knees have given him problems through much of this season, was not included on Oakland's list.

title: Einsidler Junior Victor
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Dec. 28Mike Einsidler of Great Neck, Scott Nichol of Fort Lee, N.J., and Bob Crames of Searingtown won two matches apiece to lead the early advance in the boys 18 division of the Rolex International junior tennis tournament at the Port Washington Tennis Academy today.

title: Sound
description: THE WANING YEAR has seen the centennial of Edison's invention of the phonograph, and even the United States Postal Service issued a special commemorative stamp for the occasion. Indeed, 1877 marks a historic turning point, for surely the world has been altered in important ways by the fact that music and speech are no longer ephemeral, that voices can be recalled, and musical performances need not vanish forever with their own sound.

title: The New York Times/Tyrone Dukes Mayor Beame leading Senator William Proxmire through tour of station at 940 DeKalb Avenue in Brooklyn yesterday
description: Over ham-and-cheese hero sandwiches yesterday in the kitchen of a firehouse in the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn, Mayorelect Edward 1. Koch pleaded with Senator William Proxmire to take the lead as our advocate, our lawyer.

title: NEW &
description: On a recent foray along Second Avenue, soapstone inlay boxes, handcrafted in India, were spotted in the window of Jorice at Number 1057 (near 55th Street). These decorative boxes are made by artists in the city of Agra, home of the Taj Mahal. The production process is manual and timeconsuming. Rainbowhued semiprecious stones (coral, turquoise, tiger eye, mother of pearl, garnet and jade) are ground to shape on a handoperated grinding wheel. They are prepared for inlay into boxes chiseled from solid pieces of pyrophilite, a hard soapstone. Working with stone chisels, the artist chips out a floral pattern (jasmine, rose, sunflower, poppy or grape leaf) and the inlay is set in place with glue. In various sizes and shapes, the boxes range in price from $10 to $25.

title: Levich's Wite in Moscow Hospital After Having Suffered Heart Attack
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 28Veniamin G. Levich, the Jewish scientist who has been barred from emigrating, said today that his wife suffered a heart attack on Dec. 19 and was under intensive care in a Moscow hosnital.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article published on Tuesday, quoting intelligence sources, identified a reporter who had a working relationship with the Central Intelligence Agency as the late Edward P. Kennedy of The Indianapolis .Star. The correct Identity is the late Edward R. Kennedy, who worked for The Indianapolis Times, now defunct.

description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 28  President Carter announced today he would replace Arthur F. Burns as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board with G. William Miller, the chairman of Textron Inc., a diversified manufacturing company based in Providence, R.I.

title: Family of Slain Rights Worker Seeks $2 Million From F.B.I.
description: DETROIT, Dec. 28 (UPI)The family of Viola. Gregg Liuzzo, a Detroit civil rights worker who was shot and killed by Ku Klux Klansmen in Alabama in 1965, has filed a $2 million claim against the Federal Bureau Of Investigation.

title: Europeans Taking Soldier Unions in Stride
description: UTRECHT, the Netherlands  The unionization of military conscripts, which a few years ago sent shivers down the spines of conservative officers worried about a breakdown in discipline among recruits in NATO forces, has peaked and may be in decline throughout Western Europe.

title: 3 Policewomen Suspended Tuesday Are Reinstated Pending a Hearing
description: Three policewomen who were suspend?? without pay Tuesday night for alleged?? refusing to follow orders have been ?? to service pending a Pollee Department hearing.

title: 12 Arrested in Nuclear Protest
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP)Twelve demonstrators protesting against nuclear, weapons were arrested today after blood was thrown on entrances to the Pentagon. Fifty demonstrators from a group calling itself the Atlantic Life Community appeared at several Pentagon entrances and in its shopping concourse with signs protesting nuclear weapons and calling for disarmament now.

title: News Summary
description: THURSDAY, DECEMBER 29, 1977

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Judge Calls for Broad Sanctions Against J. P. Stevens
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 28An administrative law judge of the National Labor Relations Board has held that the J.P. Stevens Company failed to bargain in good faith with union employees at seven Stevens plants, in Roanoke Rapids, N.C., a major battlegound in labor's fight to organize Southern textiles.

title: Flyers Top Rangers On Clarke's Goal, 43
description: Bobby Clarke's second goal of the game with 2 minutes 43 seconds remaining gave the Philadelphia Flyers a 43 victory over the New York Rangers last night after the teams had played to ties in their last four meetings at Madison Square Garden.

title: Bridal Held for Leslie Lott And M. T. Moore, Lawyers
description: Leslie Jean Lott, an associate with the New York law firm of Pennie & Edmonds, was married yesterday in Memphis to Michael T. Moore, an associate With the New York law firm of Burlingham, Underwood & Lord. The Presbyterian ceremony was performed in the nondenominational Schaeffer Memorial Chapel by the Rev. Jim Latta.

title: Metals Futures Reverse Slide; Silver and Platinum Lead Rise
description: An observation by a Federal Reserve official yesterday afternoon that any intervention in the foreignexchange market to bolster the dollar would be useless caused a sharp turnaboL.t in the prices of precious metals.

title: Business Leaders Praise Prospective Head of Fed
description: The New York Times

title: Adrienne Kennedy Decides That the Classroom's the Thing
description: ADRIENNE KENNEDY will turn teacher in midJanuary when she begins a playwriting course at the Women's Interart Center. Ten weeks later, she hopes to have produced a crop of dreamers.

title: Legislators Seek Help For Amateur Sports
description: New York lost its bid for the 1984 Summer Olympics but is trying to win the struggle to salvage the future of amateur athletics throughout the city and state.

title: Office Pool, 1978
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 28In honor of the fifth anniversary of this Office Pool, an event few readers thought they would have to live to see, wewill avert our eyes from last year's results four right out of fourteen, an alltime lowand go directly to the contest between pundit and reader.

title: Volcker and Roosa Praise Nominee
description: Two men who had been widely mentioned as possible successors to Arthur F. Burns as Federal Reserve Board chairman said yesterday they were pleased with the selection of G. William Miller of Textron.

title: U.S. Dependence on OPEC Oil Rose for 1977, According to A.P.I.
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (UPI)The United States considerably increased its dependence on oil from the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries during 1977, the American Petroleum Institute renortted today.

title: Advertising
description: New York State will break a $1 million ad campaign next week that is aimed at keeping New York businesses in New York. In print and on radio, the advertising will respond to negative attitudes quantified in two studies by Yankelovich, Skelly & White, the research firm.

title: Junk
description: THE mother of a Minneapolis housewife had just collapsed of an apparent heart attack, and her daughter wanted to find help fastthe doctor, the ambulance squad. But what the daughter got when she grabbed the telephone in her mother's home was a recorded solicitation that wouldn't stop even when she hung up.

title: VETERAN PREFERENCE FACING MODIFICATION
description: TRENTON, Dec. 28About 78 of every 100 war veterans who get Civil Service jobs with the New Jersey State Government, are said to do so because they are veterans and not because they scored well on Civil Service tests. Under New Jersey law, veterans must be hired over. nonveterans.

title: The Best of the Worst for the Home
description: It seems like only a few weeks ago that The Home Section moved on Thursdays, but, in fact, we've been in residence now for more than nine months. And during that time, we've received our share of junk mail.

title: PRISCILLA B. HOEFER
description: Priscilla B. Hoefer, an editor with the ZiffDavis Publishing Company in New York City for 34 years, died last Saturday in her home, 175 East 74th Street, Manhattan, after a lingering illness. She was 62 years old.

title: Rochester Couple Ordered to Stop Competing With Postal Service
description: ROCHESTER, Dec. 28A Federal judge here, ruling against a wife-and-husband letterdelivery service, has upheld the legality of statutes giving the United States Postal Service the exclusive right to deliver firstclass mail.

title: Dance: Dumas Bill
description: RUSSELL DUMAS is interested in reducing dance to its elements. His Counterbalance IL presented at the 541 Broadway loft Tuesday in a joint concert with Ulla Koivisto, was a rewarding exploration of the problems of balance; sustained and broken movement and the free use of space.

title: 5 in OPEC to Meet On CrudeOil Price
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 28 (AP)The oil ministers of five nations of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries are to meet in Switzerland Feb. 1 to discuss crudeoil prices says Valentin Hernandez Acosta, the Venezuelan Minister of Energv and Mines.

title: Sales Tax Exemption
description: TRENTON, Dec. 28 (AP)Gold and silver sold in New Jersey by registered dealers was exempted from the state sales tax under legislation signed told by Governor Byrne. The legislation, sponsored by Senator Bernard Dwyer, Democrat of Middlesex, requires that the dealer he a member of a national securities association registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission. To be exempt. from the sales tax, the gold purchase from such a dealer must he held in storage and not subsequently used by the buyer.

title: Grand Jury to Investigate Death of Football Player
description: CHRISTIANBURG, Va., Dec. 28 (UPI)The Montgomery County prosecutor, J. Patrick Graybeal, called for a special grand jury investigation today into the death of a Virginia Tech football nlaver. Bob Vorhies.

title: Top Pop Records
description: These are the most popular albums and singles nationwide, compiled by Record World, a trade publication. Albums are determined by sales figures from major retail outlets; singles are chosen by combined sales and radio airplay. An asterisk indicates an especially fastselling record.

title: Longshoremen in Tentative Pact That May End Baton Rouge Strike
description: BATON ROUGE, La., Dec. 28 (AP)Longshoremen and carriers in Baton Rouge have tentatively agreed on a new contract that the union said might end its strike by tomorrow.
